reference: dr9.54, ms6D_210, msdiv137, pts-cs3.64, pts-vp-pli1.44, sc204

root-pli-ms: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā, uddhamāghātanaṁ asaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.

Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā uddhamāghātanaṁ nevasaññīnāsaññiṁ attānaṁ paññapenti aṭṭhahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā sato sattassa ucchedaṁ vināsaṁ vibhavaṁ paññapenti sattahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā sato sattassa paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ paññapenti pañcahi vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
reference: csp1ed6.41, csp2ed6.41, lv1.109, ms6D_214, msdiv141, pts-cs3.68, sc208, vri1.39

root-pli-ms: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā aparantānudiṭṭhino aparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti catucattārīsāya vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.

Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
translation-en-sujato: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the past and the future on these sixty-two grounds, it is not possible that they should experience these things without contact.

root-pli-ms: 4.4. Diṭṭhigatikādhiṭṭhānavaṭṭakathā
translation-en-sujato: 4.4. Dependent Origination

root-pli-ms: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā sassatavādā sassataṁ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi, yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā …pe…
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā saññīvādā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā asaññīvādā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā uddhamāghātanikā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ucchedavādā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādā …
yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparantakappikā …

yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṁvedenti tesaṁ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the past and the future on these sixty-two grounds, all of them experience this by repeated contact through the six fields of contact. Their feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

root-pli-ms: 5. Vivaṭṭakathādi
translation-en-sujato: 5. The End of the Round

root-pli-ms: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṁ phassāyatanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ imehi sabbeheva uttaritaraṁ pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, they understand what lies beyond all these things.
reference: csp1ed6.42, csp2ed6.42, ms6D_218, msdiv145, sc212, vri1.40

root-pli-ms: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā, ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
translation-en-sujato: All of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past or the future are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho kevaṭṭo vā kevaṭṭantevāsī vā sukhumacchikena jālena parittaṁ udakadahaṁ otthareyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ye kho keci imasmiṁ udakadahe oḷārikā pāṇā, sabbe te antojālīkatā. Ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti; ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjantī’ti;
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a deft fisherman or his apprentice were to cast a fine-meshed net over a small pond. They’d think: ‘Any sizable creatures in this pond will be trapped in the net. Wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.’

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, all of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past or the future are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.

root-pli-ms: Ucchinnabhavanettiko, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati.
translation-en-sujato: The Realized One’s body remains, but his attachment to rebirth has been cut off.

root-pli-ms: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā.
translation-en-sujato: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā na naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā.
translation-en-sujato: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ambapiṇḍiyā vaṇṭacchinnāya yāni kānici ambāni vaṇṭapaṭibandhāni, sabbāni tāni tadanvayāni bhavanti;
translation-en-sujato: When the stalk of a bunch of mangoes is cut, all the mangoes attached to the stalk will follow along.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ucchinnabhavanettiko tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati,
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, the Realized One’s body remains, but his attachment to rebirth has been cut off.

root-pli-ms: yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā,
translation-en-sujato: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: kāyassa bhedā uddhaṁ jīvitapariyādānā na naṁ dakkhanti devamanussā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
reference: csp1ed6.43, csp2ed6.43, km14.113, ms6D_223, msdiv148, pts-cs3.74, sc217, sya9.60, vri1.41

root-pli-ms: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, ko nāmo ayaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātiha tvaṁ, ānanda, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ atthajālantipi naṁ dhārehi, dhammajālantipi naṁ dhārehi, brahmajālantipi naṁ dhārehi, diṭṭhijālantipi naṁ dhārehi, anuttaro saṅgāmavijayotipi naṁ dhārehī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Net of Meaning’, or else ‘The Net of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Prime Net’, or else ‘The Net of Views’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne dasasahassī lokadhātu akampitthāti.
translation-en-sujato: And while this discourse was being spoken, the galaxy shook.

root-pli-ms: Brahmajālasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ paṭhamaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 2
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 2

root-pli-ms: Sāmaññaphalasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: 1. Rājāmaccakathā
translation-en-sujato: 1. A Discussion With the King’s Ministers

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe pannarase komudiyā cātumāsiniyā puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā rājāmaccaparivuto uparipāsādavaragato nisinno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the Komudi full moon on the fifteenth day of the fourth month—and King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha was sitting upstairs in the stilt longhouse surrounded by his ministers.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe udānaṁ udānesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Ajātasattu expressed this heartfelt sentiment,

root-pli-ms: “ramaṇīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, abhirūpā vata bho dosinā ratti, dassanīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, pāsādikā vata bho dosinā ratti, lakkhaññā vata bho dosinā ratti.
translation-en-sujato: “Oh, sirs, this moonlit night is so very delightful, so beautiful, so glorious, so lovely, so striking.
comment-en-sujato: While these terms may be translated differently according to context, BB’s pasadika = “tranquil” is incorrect; it is part of a stock list of terms meaning “beautiful, attractive”. AN 4.85, etc. Lakkhanna as “auspicious” is also questionable. It is apparently unique in the EBTs. Whereas it may have this sense, following the principle of least meaning I take as not introducing a new theme of “auspiciousness “but as reinforcing the previous terms, i.e.” possesses memorable and remarkable features, i.e. outstanding or striking”.

root-pli-ms: Kaṁ nu khvajja samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā payirupāseyyāma, yaṁ no payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Now, what ascetic or brahmin might I pay homage to today, paying homage to whom my mind might find peace?”
comment-en-sujato: For this setting, compare AN 5.50. BB has “Is there any recluse or brahmin that we could visit tonight who might be able to bring peace to my mind”. However this removes agency from the king to the ascetic. It is not that the ascetic has some special power, but that the King’s act allows him to find redemption.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When he had spoken, one of the king’s ministers said to him,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, pūraṇo kassapo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Pūraṇa Kassapa leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
reference: cck9.60, dr9.60, km14.116, mc9.48, ms6D_228, msdiv152, pts-cs3, pts-vp-pli1.48, sc3, sya9.62, vri1.43

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, makkhali gosālo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Makkhali Gosāla leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
reference: bj7.84, csp1ed6.45, csp2ed6.45, lv1.120, ms6D_229, msdiv153, ndp6.42, pts-cs4, sc4

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, ajito kesakambalo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Ajita Kesakambala leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
reference: km14.117, lv1.121, ms6D_230, msdiv154, pts-cs5, sc5

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, pakudho kaccāyano saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Pakudha Kaccāyana leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
variant-pli-ms: sañcayo → sañjayo (bj, sya-all, pts1ed) | belaṭṭhaputto → velaṭṭhaputto (sya-all); bellaṭṭhiputto (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo sañcayaṁ belaṭṭhaputtaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa sañcayaṁ belaṭṭhaputtaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,
reference: csp1ed6.46, csp2ed6.46, lv1.123, mc9.49, ms6D_232, msdiv156, pts-cs7, pts-vp-pli1.49, sc7

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, deva, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta leads an order and a community, and teaches a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, regarded as holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo nigaṇṭhaṁ nāṭaputtaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa nigaṇṭhaṁ nāṭaputtaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: But when he had spoken, the king remained silent.

root-pli-ms: 2. Komārabhaccajīvakakathā
translation-en-sujato: 2. A Discussion With Jīvaka Komārabhacca

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre tuṇhībhūto nisinno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting silently not far from the king.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the king said to him,

root-pli-ms: “tvaṁ pana, samma jīvaka, kiṁ tuṇhī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But my dear Jīvaka, why are you silent?”

root-pli-ms: “Ayaṁ, deva, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho amhākaṁ ambavane viharati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is staying in my mango grove together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana bhagavantaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
translation-en-sujato: He has this good reputation:

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

root-pli-ms: Taṁ devo bhagavantaṁ payirupāsatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

root-pli-ms: Appeva nāma devassa bhagavantaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, samma jīvaka, hatthiyānāni kappāpehī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, my dear Jīvaka, have the elephants readied.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭissuṇitvā pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā rañño ca ārohaṇīyaṁ nāgaṁ, rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭivedesi:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Jīvaka. He had around five hundred female elephants readied, in addition to the king’s bull elephant for riding. Then he informed the king,

root-pli-ms: “kappitāni kho te, deva, hatthiyānāni,
translation-en-sujato: “The elephants are ready, sire.

root-pli-ms: yassadāni kālaṁ maññasī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Please go at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcasu hatthinikāsatesu paccekā itthiyo āropetvā ārohaṇīyaṁ nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu rājagahamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena, yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanaṁ tena pāyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then King Ajātasattu had women mounted on each of the five hundred female elephants, while he mounted his bull elephant. With attendants carrying torches, he set out in full royal pomp from Rājagaha to Jīvaka’s mango grove.
comment-en-sujato: BB has “500 of his women”, which implies an extensive harem. But the text doesn’t imply that they were “his”, nor that they were selected from a larger group. They could have been palace women generally, not necessarily attached to Ajatasattu.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre ambavanassa ahudeva bhayaṁ, ahu chambhitattaṁ, ahu lomahaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: But as he drew near the mango grove, the king became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to Jīvaka,

root-pli-ms: “kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na vañcesi?
translation-en-sujato: “My dear Jīvaka, I hope you’re not deceiving me!

root-pli-ms: Kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na palambhesi?
translation-en-sujato: I hope you’re not betraying me!

root-pli-ms: Kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na paccatthikānaṁ desi?
translation-en-sujato: I hope you’re not turning me over to my enemies!

root-pli-ms: Kathañhi nāma tāva mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa aḍḍhateḷasānaṁ bhikkhusatānaṁ neva khipitasaddo bhavissati, na ukkāsitasaddo na nigghoso”ti.
translation-en-sujato: For how on earth can there be no sound of coughing or clearing throats or any noise in such a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants?”

root-pli-ms: “Mā bhāyi, mahārāja, mā bhāyi, mahārāja.
translation-en-sujato: “Do not fear, great king, do not fear!

root-pli-ms: Na taṁ, deva, vañcemi;
translation-en-sujato: I am not deceiving you,

root-pli-ms: na taṁ, deva, palambhāmi;
translation-en-sujato: or betraying you,

root-pli-ms: na taṁ, deva, paccatthikānaṁ demi.
translation-en-sujato: or turning you over to your enemies.

root-pli-ms: Abhikkama, mahārāja, abhikkama, mahārāja, ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā jhāyantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Go forward, great king, go forward! Those are lamps shining in the pavilion.”

root-pli-ms: 3. Sāmaññaphalapucchā
translation-en-sujato: 3. The Question About the Fruits of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā, nāgā paccorohitvā, pattikova yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Ajātasattu rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the pavilion door on foot, where he asked Jīvaka,
reference: bj7.88, cck9.63, lv1.127, ms6D_238, msdiv160, ndp6.44, pts-cs11, sc13

root-pli-ms: “kahaṁ pana, samma jīvaka, bhagavā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But my dear Jīvaka, where is the Buddha?”

root-pli-ms: “Eso, mahārāja, bhagavā;
translation-en-sujato: “That is the Buddha, great king, that is the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: eso, mahārāja, bhagavā majjhimaṁ thambhaṁ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisinno purakkhato bhikkhusaṅghassā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: He’s sitting against the central column facing east, in front of the Saṅgha of mendicants.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the king went up to the Buddha and stood to one side.

root-pli-ms: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhībhūtaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ anuviloketvā rahadamiva vippasannaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
translation-en-sujato: He looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very silent, like a still, clear lake, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment,

root-pli-ms: “iminā me upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu, yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “May my son, Prince Udāyibhadda, be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”

root-pli-ms: “Agamā kho tvaṁ, mahārāja, yathāpeman”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Has your mind gone to one you love, great king?”

root-pli-ms: “Piyo me, bhante, udayabhaddo kumāro.
translation-en-sujato: “I love my son, sir, Prince Udāyibhadda.

root-pli-ms: Iminā me, bhante, upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.
translation-en-sujato: May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā, bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā, ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the king bowed to the Buddha, raised his joined palms toward the Saṅgha, and sat down to one side.
reference: csp1ed6.48, csp2ed6.48, km14.123, lv1.129, ms6D_240, msdiv162, pts-cs13, pts-vp-pli1.51, sc15, sya9.66

root-pli-ms: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “puccheyyāmahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ kañcideva desaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
variant-pli-ms: kañcideva desaṁ → kiñcideva desaṁ lesamattaṁ (sya-all, km, mr)

root-pli-ms: sace me bhagavā okāsaṁ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
“Puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Ask what you wish, great king.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā nu kho imāni, bhante, puthusippāyatanāni,
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, there are many different professional fields.
comment-en-sujato: Most translators render sippa as “craft”. However, the basic meaning of craft is “an activity involving skill in making things by hand”. What is meant here is “a paid occupation, especially one that involves prolonged training and a formal qualification.” which is “profession”.

root-pli-ms: seyyathidaṁ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā
translation-en-sujato: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
comment-en-sujato: The first set of these is defined as branches of the military at AN 7.67.

root-pli-ms: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sippaphalaṁ upajīvanti;
translation-en-sujato: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, weavers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in the present life.

root-pli-ms: te tena attānaṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: With that they bring happiness and joy to themselves, their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

root-pli-ms: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in the present life?”

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, mahārāja, imaṁ pañhaṁ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Great king, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, imaṁ pañhaṁ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I do, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kathaṁ pana te, mahārāja, byākariṁsu, sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “If you wouldn’t mind, great king, tell me how they answered.”

root-pli-ms: “Na kho me, bhante, garu, yatthassa bhagavā nisinno, bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, mahārāja, bhāsassū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, speak then, great king.”

root-pli-ms: 3.1. Pūraṇakassapavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.1. The Doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa

root-pli-ms: “Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena pūraṇo kassapo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā pūraṇena kassapena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “One time, sir, I approached Pūraṇa Kassapa and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kassapa, puthusippāyatanāni,

seyyathidaṁ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sippaphalaṁ upajīvanti;

te tena attānaṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikaṁ.
Sakkā nu kho, bho kassapa, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to me:

root-pli-ms: ‘karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato socayato, socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātāpayato, adinnaṁ ādiyato, sandhiṁ chindato, nillopaṁ harato, ekāgārikaṁ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṁ gacchato, musā bhaṇato, karoto na karīyati pāpaṁ. Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṁ maṁsakhalaṁ ekaṁ maṁsapuñjaṁ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṁ pāpaṁ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Great king, the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

root-pli-ms: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṁ gaccheyya hananto ghātento chindanto chedāpento pacanto pācāpento, natthi tatonidānaṁ pāpaṁ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
translation-en-sujato: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

root-pli-ms: Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṁ gaccheyya dadanto dāpento yajanto yajāpento, natthi tatonidānaṁ puññaṁ, natthi puññassa āgamo.
translation-en-sujato: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.

root-pli-ms: Dānena damena saṁyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṁ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of inaction.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, pūraṇassa kassapassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Pūraṇa Kassapa.

root-pli-ms: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
comment-en-sujato: Comm explains Anuggaṇhantoti sārato aggaṇhanto. Anikkujjantoti sāravaseneva idaṁ nissaraṇaṁ, ayaṁ paramatthoti hadaye aṭṭhapento. Byañjanaṁ pana tena uggahitañceva nikkujjitañca. This apparently takes uggahita and nikkujjita as synonyms, which is followed by BB, but not by either Rhys Davids or Thanissaro. I can’t see how this can be right, elsewhere nikkujjati always means “overturns”.
variant-pli-ms: pakkamiṁ → pakkāmiṁ (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed) | anikkujjanto → anikkujjento (sya-all, km, mr)

root-pli-ms: 3.2. Makkhaligosālavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.2. The Doctrine of Makkhali Gosāla

root-pli-ms: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena makkhali gosālo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā makkhalinā gosālena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: One time, sir, I approached Makkhali Gosāla and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho gosāla, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
sakkā nu kho, bho gosāla, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, makkhali gosālo maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said:

root-pli-ms: ‘natthi, mahārāja, hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṁ saṅkilesāya, ahetū apaccayā sattā saṅkilissanti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Great king, there is no cause or condition for the corruption of sentient beings. Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or condition.

root-pli-ms: Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā,
translation-en-sujato: There’s no cause or condition for the purification of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: ahetū apaccayā sattā visujjhanti.
translation-en-sujato: Sentient beings are purified without cause or condition.

root-pli-ms: Natthi attakāre, natthi parakāre, natthi purisakāre, natthi balaṁ, natthi vīriyaṁ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo.
translation-en-sujato: One does not act of one’s own volition, one does not act of another’s volition, one does not act from a person’s volition. There is no power, no energy, no manly strength or vigor.
comment-en-sujato: The first three phrases, with the Magadhan nominative singular in -e, are unique to this passage. Cp AN 6.38: natthi attakāro, natthi parakāro.

root-pli-ms: Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti.
translation-en-sujato: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.

root-pli-ms: Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā dvaṭṭhantarakappā chaḷābhijātiyo aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate vīse indriyasate tiṁse nirayasate chattiṁsa rajodhātuyo satta saññīgabbhā satta asaññīgabbhā satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā satta devā satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā satta pavuṭasatāni satta papātā satta papātasatāni satta supinā satta supinasatāni cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
translation-en-sujato: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven embryos without attachments. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven winds, 700 winds, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
variant-pli-ms: mahākappino → mahākappuno (si, pts1ed) | pavuṭā → paṭuvā (pts1ed); sapuṭā (mr)

root-pli-ms: Tattha natthi “imināhaṁ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṁ vā kammaṁ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṁ vā kammaṁ phussa phussa byantiṁ karissāmī”ti hevaṁ natthi.
translation-en-sujato: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little,” for that cannot be.

root-pli-ms: Doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse.
translation-en-sujato: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti;
translation-en-sujato: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.

root-pli-ms: evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno saṁsārasuddhiṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Makkhali Gosāla about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of purification through transmigration.
reference: cck9.69, km14.134, lv1.140, mc9.55, ms6D_248, msdiv169, ndp6.48, pts-cs21, pts-vp-pli1.55, sc23

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno saṁsārasuddhiṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, makkhalissa gosālassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Makkhali Gosāla.

root-pli-ms: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

root-pli-ms: 3.3. Ajitakesakambalavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.3. The Doctrine of Ajita Kesakambala

root-pli-ms: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena ajito kesakambalo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā ajitena kesakambalena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: One time, sir, I approached Ajita Kesakambala and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho ajita, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
sakkā nu kho, bho ajita, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, ajito kesakambalo maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said:

root-pli-ms: ‘natthi, mahārāja, dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā, ye imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Great king, there is no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
variant-pli-ms: paro loko → paraloko (sya-all) | sammaggatā → samaggagatā (sya-all); samaggatā (mr)

root-pli-ms: Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṁ puriso, yadā kālaṁ karoti, pathavī pathavikāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, āpo āpokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṁ indriyāni saṅkamanti.
translation-en-sujato: This person is made up of the four primary elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of air. The faculties are transferred to space.

root-pli-ms: Āsandipañcamā purisā mataṁ ādāya gacchanti.
translation-en-sujato: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.

root-pli-ms: Yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti.
translation-en-sujato: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.

root-pli-ms: Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti, bhassantā āhutiyo.
translation-en-sujato: The bones become bleached. Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.

root-pli-ms: Dattupaññattaṁ yadidaṁ dānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Giving is a doctrine of morons.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ tucchaṁ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṁ vadanti.
translation-en-sujato: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.

root-pli-ms: Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti, na honti paraṁ maraṇā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death.’

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Ajita Kesakambala about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of annihilationism.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, ajitassa kesakambalassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Ajita Kesakambala.

root-pli-ms: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

root-pli-ms: 3.4. Pakudhakaccāyanavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.4. The Doctrine of Pakudha Kaccāyana

root-pli-ms: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena pakudho kaccāyano tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā pakudhena kaccāyanena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: One time, sir, I approached Pakudha Kaccāyana and exchanged greetings with him.
reference: bj7.98, lv1.145, ms6D_252, msdiv173, pts-cs25, sc27

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kaccāyana, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
sakkā nu kho, bho kaccāyana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said:

root-pli-ms: ‘sattime, mahārāja, kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Great king, these seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

root-pli-ms: Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
translation-en-sujato: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other.

root-pli-ms: Katame satta?
translation-en-sujato: What seven?

root-pli-ms: Pathavikāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame—
translation-en-sujato: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.

root-pli-ms: ime satta kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
translation-en-sujato: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

root-pli-ms: Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
translation-en-sujato: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or neutral feeling to each other.

root-pli-ms: Tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā, sotā vā sāvetā vā, viññātā vā viññāpetā vā.
translation-en-sujato: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.

root-pli-ms: Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṁ chindati, na koci kiñci jīvitā voropeti;
translation-en-sujato: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.

root-pli-ms: sattannaṁ tveva kāyānamantarena satthaṁ vivaramanupatatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.’
variant-pli-ms: sattannaṁ tveva → sattannaṁyeva (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with something else entirely.
reference: km14.140, lv1.148, ms6D_254, msdiv175, ndp6.50, pts-cs27, pts-vp-pli1.57, sc29

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, pakudhassa kaccāyanassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Pakudha Kaccāyana.

root-pli-ms: anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

root-pli-ms: 3.5. Nigaṇṭhanāṭaputtavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.5. The Doctrine of Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta

root-pli-ms: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhena nāṭaputtena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: One time, sir, I approached Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, nigaṇṭhaṁ nāṭaputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho aggivessana, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
sakkā nu kho, bho aggivessana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said:

root-pli-ms: ‘idha, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Great king, consider a Jain ascetic who is restrained in the fourfold restraint.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how is a Jain ascetic restrained in the fourfold restraint?

root-pli-ms: Idha, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho sabbavārivārito ca hoti, sabbavāriyutto ca, sabbavāridhuto ca, sabbavāriphuṭo ca.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a Jain ascetic is obstructed by all water, devoted to all water, shaking off all water, pervaded by all water.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold restraint.

root-pli-ms: Yato kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho evaṁ cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti;
translation-en-sujato: When a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold restraint,

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho gatatto ca yatatto ca ṭhitatto cā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: they’re called a knotless one who is self-realized, self-controlled, and steadfast.’

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṁvaraṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the fourfold restraint.
reference: dr9.75, km14.143, lv1.150, ms6D_257, msdiv178, ndp6.51, pts-cs30, pts-vp-pli1.58, sc32, sya9.76

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṁvaraṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.

root-pli-ms: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

root-pli-ms: 3.6. Sañcayabelaṭṭhaputtavāda
translation-en-sujato: 3.6. The Doctrine of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta

root-pli-ms: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā sañcayena belaṭṭhaputtena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: One time, sir, I approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta and exchanged greetings with him.
reference: cck9.74, lv1.151, ms6D_258, msdiv179, pts-cs31, sc33

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, sañcayaṁ belaṭṭhaputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho sañcaya, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
sakkā nu kho, bho sañcaya, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said:

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi paro lokoti iti ce maṁ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naṁ byākareyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Suppose you were to ask me whether there is another world. If I believed there was, I would say so.

root-pli-ms: Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no.
translation-en-sujato: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.

root-pli-ms: Natthi paro loko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Suppose you were to ask me whether there is no other world …

root-pli-ms: atthi ca natthi ca paro loko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there both is and is not another world …

root-pli-ms: nevatthi na natthi paro loko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there neither is nor is not another world …

root-pli-ms: atthi sattā opapātikā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously …

root-pli-ms: natthi sattā opapātikā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there are no beings who are reborn spontaneously …

root-pli-ms: atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there both are and are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …

root-pli-ms: nevatthi na natthi sattā opapātikā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there neither are nor are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …

root-pli-ms: atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

root-pli-ms: natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there is no fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

root-pli-ms: atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

root-pli-ms: nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

root-pli-ms: hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether a Realized One exists after death …

root-pli-ms: na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether a Realized One doesn’t exist after death …

root-pli-ms: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: whether a Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death …

root-pli-ms: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇāti iti ce maṁ pucchasi, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇāti iti ce me assa, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇāti iti te naṁ byākareyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: whether a Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. If I believed there was, I would say so.

root-pli-ms: Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
translation-en-sujato: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṁ byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with evasiveness.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
translation-en-sujato: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṁ byākāsi.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayañca imesaṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ sabbabālo sabbamūḷho.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is the most foolish and stupid of all these ascetics and brahmins!

root-pli-ms: Kathañhi nāma sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṁ byākarissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: How on earth can he answer with evasiveness when asked about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life?’

root-pli-ms: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought:

root-pli-ms: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

root-pli-ms: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, sañcayassa belaṭṭhaputtassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So I neither approved nor dismissed that statement of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta.

root-pli-ms: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

root-pli-ms: 4. Sāmaññaphala
translation-en-sujato: 4. The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: 4.1. Paṭhamasandiṭṭhikasāmaññaphala
translation-en-sujato: 4.1. The First Fruit of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: Sohaṁ, bhante, bhagavantampi pucchāmi:
translation-en-sujato: And so I ask the Buddha:

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bhante, puthusippāyatanāni
translation-en-sujato: Sir, there are many different professional fields.

root-pli-ms: seyyathidaṁ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā
translation-en-sujato: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.

root-pli-ms: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sippaphalaṁ upajīvanti,
translation-en-sujato: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, weavers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in the present life.

root-pli-ms: te tena attānaṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: With that they bring happiness and joy to themselves, their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

root-pli-ms: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in the present life?”

root-pli-ms: “Sakkā, mahārāja.
translation-en-sujato: “I can, great king.

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, great king?

root-pli-ms: idha te assa puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose you had a person who was a bondservant, a worker. They get up before you and go to bed after you, and are obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at your face.
comment-en-sujato: BB’s “ever on the lookout to see that you are satisfied” is not correct, see mukhaṁ ullokentī at MN 79, SN 56.39 VAR: kammakāro → kammakaro (bj, s1-3, km, pts1)

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: They’d think:

root-pli-ms: ‘acchariyaṁ, vata bho, abbhutaṁ, vata bho, puññānaṁ gati, puññānaṁ vipāko.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!

root-pli-ms: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso; ahampi manusso.
translation-en-sujato: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.

root-pli-ms: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe.
translation-en-sujato: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ panamhissa dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
translation-en-sujato: Whereas I’m his bondservant, his worker. I get up before him and go to bed after him, and am obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at his face.

root-pli-ms: So vatassāhaṁ puññāni kareyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I should do good deeds.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyya.
translation-en-sujato: After some time, that is what they do.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṁvuto vihareyya, manasā saṁvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.
translation-en-sujato: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.

root-pli-ms: Tañce te purisā evamāroceyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako;
variant-pli-ms: deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso → yo te puriso (bj, pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: so, deva, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto viharati, vācāya saṁvuto viharati, manasā saṁvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.
Api nu tvaṁ evaṁ vadeyyāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Would you say to them:

root-pli-ms: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be my bondservant, my worker’?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho naṁ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāmapi naṁ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidaheyyāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d arrange for their lawful guarding and protection.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, great king?

root-pli-ms: yadi evaṁ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ no vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”

root-pli-ms: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Clearly, sir, there is.”

root-pli-ms: “Idaṁ kho te, mahārāja, mayā paṭhamaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññattan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “This is the first fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life, which I point out to you.”

root-pli-ms: 4.2. Dutiyasandiṭṭhikasāmaññaphala
translation-en-sujato: 4.2. The Second Fruit of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But sir, can you point out another fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in the present life?”

root-pli-ms: “Sakkā, mahārāja.
translation-en-sujato: “I can, great king.

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, great king?
comment-en-sujato: https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/a-note-on-karakarako-rasiva-hako/5535

root-pli-ms: idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose you had a person who was a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: They’d think:

root-pli-ms: ‘acchariyaṁ vata bho, abbhutaṁ vata bho, puññānaṁ gati, puññānaṁ vipāko.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!

translation-en-sujato: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.

translation-en-sujato: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
translation-en-sujato: Whereas I’m a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.

root-pli-ms: So vatassāhaṁ puññāni kareyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I should do good deeds.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

translation-en-sujato: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They’d shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṁvuto vihareyya, manasā saṁvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.
translation-en-sujato: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.

So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto viharati, vācāya saṁvuto viharati, manasā saṁvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.
Api nu tvaṁ evaṁ vadeyyāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Would you say to them:

translation-en-sujato: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital’?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.

translation-en-sujato: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d arrange for their lawful guarding and protection.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja?
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, great king?

translation-en-sujato: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”

root-pli-ms: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Clearly, sir, there is.”

root-pli-ms: “Idaṁ kho te, mahārāja, mayā dutiyaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññattan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “This is the second fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life, which I point out to you.”

root-pli-ms: 4.3. Paṇītatarasāmaññaphala
translation-en-sujato: 4.3. The Finer Fruits of the Ascetic Life

root-pli-ms: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetuṁ imehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañcā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in the present life which is better and finer than these?”

root-pli-ms: “Sakkā, mahārāja.
translation-en-sujato: “I can, great king.

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, mahārāja, suṇohi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the king.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:
reference: csp1ed6.59, csp2ed6.59, lv1.165, ms6D_271, msdiv190, ndp6.55, sc46

root-pli-ms: “idha, mahārāja, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: “Consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
translation-en-sujato: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

root-pli-ms: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
translation-en-sujato: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
translation-en-sujato: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.
reference: dr9.82, km14.156, lv1.166, ms6D_272, msdiv191, pts-cs41, pts-vp-pli1.63, sc47, sya9.83

root-pli-ms: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
translation-en-sujato: They gain faith in the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
translation-en-sujato: and reflect:

root-pli-ms: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.

root-pli-ms: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
translation-en-sujato: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
translation-en-sujato: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
reference: cck9.81, lv1.167, ms6D_274, msdiv193, pts-cs42, sc49, vri1.56
variant-pli-ms: sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro → bhojane mattaññū (bj, mr)

root-pli-ms: 4.3.1. Sīla
translation-en-sujato: 4.3.1. Ethics

root-pli-ms: 4.3.1.1. Cūḷasīla
translation-en-sujato: 4.3.1.1. The Shorter Section on Ethics

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how, great king, is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?

root-pli-ms: Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti. Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
translation-en-sujato: They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
translation-en-sujato: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya; amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā, amūsaṁ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
variant-pli-ms: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ → pisuṇāvācaṁ (pts1ed) | samaggarato → samaggarāmo (bj) | anuppadātā → anuppādātā (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

root-pli-ms: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.

root-pli-ms: ekabhattiko hoti rattūparato virato vikālabhojanā.
translation-en-sujato: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

root-pli-ms: Naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.

root-pli-ms: Mālāgandhavilepanadhāraṇamaṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

root-pli-ms: Uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They avoid high and luxurious beds.

root-pli-ms: Jātarūparajatapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They avoid receiving gold and money,

root-pli-ms: Āmakadhaññapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: raw grains,

root-pli-ms: Āmakamaṁsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: raw meat,

root-pli-ms: Itthikumārikapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: women and girls,

root-pli-ms: Dāsidāsapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: male and female bondservants,

root-pli-ms: Ajeḷakapaṭiggahaṇā paṭivirato hoti.
