root-pli-ms: “Taggha tvaṁ, mahārāja, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ pitaraṁ dhammikaṁ dhammarājānaṁ jīvitā voropesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Indeed, great king, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to take the life of your father, a just and principled king, for the sake of sovereignty.

root-pli-ms: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, mahārāja, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
translation-en-sujato: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

root-pli-ms: Vuddhihesā, mahārāja, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: For it is growth in the training of the noble one to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the Buddha had spoken, King Ajātasattu said to him,
reference: csp1ed6.81, csp2ed6.81, lv1.234, ms6D_343, msdiv252, pts-cs101, sc115

root-pli-ms: “handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bhante, gacchāma bahukiccā mayaṁ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, now, sir, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”

root-pli-ms: “Yassadāni tvaṁ, mahārāja, kālaṁ maññasī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the king, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantassa rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Soon after the king had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
reference: km14.214, lv1.235, ms6D_344, msdiv253, pts-cs102, pts-vp-pli1.86, sc116

root-pli-ms: “khatāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā.
translation-en-sujato: “The king is broken, mendicants,
comment-en-sujato: Note that these terms are commonly used in the context of keeping sila, eg AN 3.50 etc.

root-pli-ms: Upahatāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā.
translation-en-sujato: he is ruined.

root-pli-ms: Sacāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā pitaraṁ dhammikaṁ dhammarājānaṁ jīvitā na voropessatha, imasmiññeva āsane virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ uppajjissathā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: If he had not taken the life of his father, a just and principled king, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma would have arisen in him in that very seat.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Sāmaññaphalasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dutiyaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 3
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 3

root-pli-ms: Ambaṭṭhasutta
translation-en-sujato: With Ambaṭṭha

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena icchānaṅgalaṁ nāma kosalānaṁ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Icchānaṅgala.

root-pli-ms: Tatra sudaṁ bhagavā icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
translation-en-sujato: He stayed in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.

root-pli-ms: 1. Pokkharasātivatthu
translation-en-sujato: 1. The Section on Pokkharasāti

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ukkaṭṭhaṁ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṁ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sadhaññaṁ rājabhoggaṁ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṁ rājadāyaṁ brahmadeyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the brahmin Pokkharasāti was living in Ukkaṭṭhā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.

root-pli-ms: Assosi kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti:
translation-en-sujato: Pokkharasāti heard:

root-pli-ms: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi icchānaṅgalaṁ anuppatto icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
translation-en-sujato: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala and is staying in a forest nearby.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
translation-en-sujato: He has this good reputation:

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
translation-en-sujato: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

root-pli-ms: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ, sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
translation-en-sujato: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

root-pli-ms: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

root-pli-ms: 2. Ambaṭṭhamāṇava
translation-en-sujato: 2. The Brahmin Student Ambaṭṭha

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ambaṭṭho nāma māṇavo antevāsī hoti ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo anuññātapaṭiññāto sake ācariyake tevijjake pāvacane:
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Pokkharasāti had a student named Ambaṭṭha. He was one who recited and remembered the hymns, and had mastered in the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. He had been authorized as a master in his own teacher’s scriptural heritage of the three Vedas with the words:
comment-en-sujato: For anuññātapaṭiññāta see MN 98, for tevijjake pāvacane see MN 95

root-pli-ms: “yamahaṁ jānāmi taṁ tvaṁ jānāsi;
translation-en-sujato: “What I know, you know.
comment-en-sujato: Compare the words of Alara Kalama and Uddaka Ramaputta to the bodhisatta.

root-pli-ms: yaṁ tvaṁ jānāsi tamahaṁ jānāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And what you know, I know.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Pokkharasāti addressed Ambaṭṭha,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, tāta ambaṭṭha, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi icchānaṅgalaṁ anuppatto icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe.
translation-en-sujato: “Dear Ambaṭṭha, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Icchānaṅgala and is staying in a forest nearby. …

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
‘itipi so bhagavā, arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ, sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s good to see such perfected ones.

root-pli-ms: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta ambaṭṭha, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ jānāhi, yadi vā taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ tathāsantaṁyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā.
translation-en-sujato: Please, dear Ambaṭṭha, go to the ascetic Gotama and find out whether or not he lives up to his reputation.

root-pli-ms: Yadi vā so bhavaṁ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso, tathā mayaṁ taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ vedissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Through you I shall learn about Master Gotama.”
comment-en-sujato: See my note on MN 91 referring to BB’s note on variants for this passage.

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kathaṁ panāhaṁ, bho, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ jānissāmi: ‘yadi vā taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ tathāsantaṁyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā. Yadi vā so bhavaṁ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But sir, how shall I find out whether or not the ascetic Gotama lives up to his reputation?”

root-pli-ms: “Āgatāni kho, tāta ambaṭṭha, amhākaṁ mantesu dvattiṁsa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
translation-en-sujato: “Dear Ambaṭṭha, the thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

root-pli-ms: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: He has the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—cakkaratanaṁ, hatthiratanaṁ, assaratanaṁ, maṇiratanaṁ, itthiratanaṁ, gahapatiratanaṁ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

root-pli-ms: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
translation-en-sujato: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ kho pana, tāta ambaṭṭha, mantānaṁ dātā;
translation-en-sujato: But, dear Ambaṭṭha, I am the one who gives the hymns,
comment-en-sujato: The relation between Pokkarasati and his student here is strikingly similar to the relation between the Buddha and the arahants. They know the same thing, but the Buddha is distinguished as the teacher.

root-pli-ms: tvaṁ mantānaṁ paṭiggahetā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: and you are the one who receives them.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā brāhmaṇaṁ pokkharasātiṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā vaḷavārathamāruyha sambahulehi māṇavakehi saddhiṁ yena icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍo tena pāyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied Ambaṭṭha. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Pokkharasāti, keeping him to his right. He mounted a mare-drawn chariot and, together with several students, set out for the forest near Icchānaṅgala.
comment-en-sujato: While it is not always possible to clearly distinguish manava and manavaka, in this sutta the former is always applied to Ambattha, and the latter to the rest. It seems that, as a diminutive, manavaka means “young students”, or perhaps more precisely, “students of a student”.

root-pli-ms: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṁ pāvisi.
translation-en-sujato: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and entered the monastery on foot.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti.
translation-en-sujato: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the student Ambaṭṭha went up to those mendicants and said,

root-pli-ms: “kahaṁ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaṁ gotamo viharati?
translation-en-sujato: “Gentlemen, where is Master Gotama at present?

root-pli-ms: Tañhi mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya idhūpasaṅkantā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: For we have come here to see him.”
comment-en-sujato: Compare the idiom in MN 35.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then those mendicants thought,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo abhiññātakolañño ceva abhiññātassa ca brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa antevāsī.
translation-en-sujato: “This Ambaṭṭha is from a well-known family, and he is the pupil of the well-known brahmin Pokkharasāti.

root-pli-ms: Agaru kho pana bhagavato evarūpehi kulaputtehi saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo hotī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha won’t mind having a discussion together with such gentlemen.”

root-pli-ms: Te ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They said to Ambaṭṭha,

root-pli-ms: “eso, ambaṭṭha, vihāro saṁvutadvāro, tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṁ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṁ ākoṭehi, vivarissati te bhagavā dvāran”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Ambaṭṭha, that’s his dwelling, with the door closed. Approach it quietly, without hurrying; go onto the porch, clear your throat, and knock with the latch. The Buddha will open the door.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena so vihāro saṁvutadvāro, tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṁ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṁ ākoṭesi. Vivari bhagavā dvāraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So he approached the Buddha’s dwelling and knocked, and the Buddha opened the door.

root-pli-ms: Pāvisi ambaṭṭho māṇavo. Māṇavakāpi pavisitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Ambaṭṭha and the other students entered the dwelling. The other students exchanged greetings with the Buddha, and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, sat down to one side.
comment-en-sujato: A nice little detail that ullustrates the sense of the word “sambahula”, which should normally be taken in the sense of “several”, rather than “many”. The Buddha’s kuti surely could only have accommodated a few people at a time.

root-pli-ms: Ambaṭṭho pana māṇavo caṅkamantopi nisinnena bhagavatā kañci kañci kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāreti, ṭhitopi nisinnena bhagavatā kañci kañci kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāreti.
translation-en-sujato: But while the Buddha was sitting, Ambaṭṭha spoke some polite words or other while walking around or standing.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to him,

root-pli-ms: “evaṁ nu te, ambaṭṭha, brāhmaṇehi vuddhehi mahallakehi ācariyapācariyehi saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo hoti, yathayidaṁ caraṁ tiṭṭhaṁ nisinnena mayā kiñci kiñci kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Ambaṭṭha, is this how you hold a discussion with elderly and senior brahmins, the teachers of teachers: walking around or standing while I’m sitting, speaking some polite words or other?”

root-pli-ms: 2.1. Paṭhamaibbhavāda
translation-en-sujato: 2.1. The First Use of the Word “Riffraff”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.

root-pli-ms: Gacchanto vā hi, bho gotama, gacchantena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṁ sallapitumarahati, ṭhito vā hi, bho gotama, ṭhitena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṁ sallapitumarahati, nisinno vā hi, bho gotama, nisinnena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṁ sallapitumarahati, sayāno vā hi, bho gotama, sayānena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṁ sallapitumarahati.
translation-en-sujato: For it is proper for one brahmin to converse with another while both are walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, tehipi me saddhiṁ evaṁ kathāsallāpo hoti, yathariva bhotā gotamenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But as to these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, I converse with them as I do with Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthikavato kho pana te, ambaṭṭha, idhāgamanaṁ ahosi, yāyeva kho panatthāya āgaccheyyātha, tameva atthaṁ sādhukaṁ manasi kareyyātha.
translation-en-sujato: “But Ambaṭṭha, you must have come here for some purpose. You should focus on that.
variant-pli-ms: āgaccheyyātha → āgaccheyyātho (bj, pts1ed) | manasi kareyyātha → manasi kareyyātho (bj, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Avusitavāyeva kho pana, bho, ayaṁ ambaṭṭho māṇavo vusitamānī kimaññatra avusitattā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Though this Ambaṭṭha is unqualified, he thinks he’s qualified. What is that but lack of qualifications?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavatā avusitavādena vuccamāno kupito anattamano bhagavantaṁyeva khuṁsento bhagavantaṁyeva vambhento bhagavantaṁyeva upavadamāno:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, Ambaṭṭha became angry and upset with the Buddha because of being described as unqualified. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying,

root-pli-ms: “samaṇo ca me bho gotamo pāpito bhavissatī”ti bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “caṇḍā, bho gotama, sakyajāti;
translation-en-sujato: “Master Gotama, the Sakyan clan are rude,

root-pli-ms: pharusā, bho gotama, sakyajāti;
translation-en-sujato: harsh,

root-pli-ms: lahusā, bho gotama, sakyajāti;
translation-en-sujato: touchy,

root-pli-ms: bhassā, bho gotama, sakyajāti;
translation-en-sujato: and argumentative.
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and Walshe have “violent” evidently reading rabhasa. But that word is, so far as I know, unattested elsewhere. Note that pharusa is almost always used in the context of speech, and that lahusa seems to make more sense in talking of people who are “touchy”, hard to talk to, rather than physically violent. Hence I prefer the reading bhassa, which is obviously the reading of the comm: Bhassāti bahubhāṇino. moreover, the story below hardly justifies the epithet “violent”.

root-pli-ms: ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṁ karonti, na brāhmaṇe mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyanti.
translation-en-sujato: Riffraff they are, and riffraff they remain! They don’t honor, respect, revere, worship, or venerate brahmins.
variant-pli-ms: garuṁ karonti → garukaronti (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Tayidaṁ, bho gotama, nacchannaṁ, tayidaṁ nappatirūpaṁ, yadime sakyā ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṁ karonti, na brāhmaṇe mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It is neither proper nor appropriate that the Sakyans—riffraff that they are—don’t honor, respect, revere, worship, or venerate brahmins.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha ambaṭṭho māṇavo idaṁ paṭhamaṁ sakyesu ibbhavādaṁ nipātesi.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s how Ambaṭṭha denigrated the Sakyans with the word “riffraff” for the first time.

root-pli-ms: 2.2. Dutiyaibbhavāda
translation-en-sujato: 2.2. The Second Use of the Word “Riffraff”

root-pli-ms: “Kiṁ pana te, ambaṭṭha, sakyā aparaddhun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But Ambaṭṭha, how have the Sakyans wronged you?”

root-pli-ms: “Ekamidāhaṁ, bho gotama, samayaṁ ācariyassa brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa kenacideva karaṇīyena kapilavatthuṁ agamāsiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “This one time, Master Gotama, I went to Kapilavatthu on some business for my teacher, the brahmin Pokkharasāti.

root-pli-ms: Yena sakyānaṁ sandhāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I approached the Sakyans in their meeting hall.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā sakyā ceva sakyakumārā ca sandhāgāre uccesu āsanesu nisinnā honti aññamaññaṁ aṅgulipatodakehi sañjagghantā saṅkīḷantā, aññadatthu mamaññeva maññe anujagghantā, na maṁ koci āsanenapi nimantesi.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time several Sakyans and Sakyan princes were sitting on high seats, poking each other with their fingers, giggling and playing together. In fact, they even presumed to giggle at me, and didn’t invite me to a seat.

root-pli-ms: Tayidaṁ, bho gotama, nacchannaṁ, tayidaṁ nappatirūpaṁ, yadime sakyā ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṁ karonti, na brāhmaṇe mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It is neither proper nor appropriate that the Sakyans—riffraff that they are—don’t honor, respect, revere, worship, or venerate brahmins.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha ambaṭṭho māṇavo idaṁ dutiyaṁ sakyesu ibbhavādaṁ nipātesi.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s how Ambaṭṭha denigrated the Sakyans with the word “riffraff” for the second time.

root-pli-ms: 2.3. Tatiyaibbhavāda
translation-en-sujato: 2.3. The Third Use of the Word “Riffraff”

root-pli-ms: “Laṭukikāpi kho, ambaṭṭha, sakuṇikā sake kulāvake kāmalāpinī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: “Even a little quail, Ambaṭṭha, speaks as she likes in her own nest.

root-pli-ms: Sakaṁ kho panetaṁ, ambaṭṭha, sakyānaṁ yadidaṁ kapilavatthuṁ, nārahatāyasmā ambaṭṭho imāya appamattāya abhisajjitun”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Kapilavatthu is the Sakyans own place, Ambaṭṭha. It’s not worthy of the Venerable Ambaṭṭha to lose his temper over such a small thing.”
comment-en-sujato: The Buddha’s use of ayasma, ignored by both RD and W, is noteworthy here: the Buddha is taking a conciliatory tone.

root-pli-ms: “Cattārome, bho gotama, vaṇṇā—
translation-en-sujato: “Master Gotama, there are these four castes:

root-pli-ms: khattiyā brāhmaṇā vessā suddā.
translation-en-sujato: aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers.

root-pli-ms: Imesañhi, bho gotama, catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ tayo vaṇṇā—
translation-en-sujato: Three of these castes—

root-pli-ms: khattiyā ca vessā ca suddā ca—
translation-en-sujato: aristocrats, merchants, and workers—

root-pli-ms: aññadatthu brāhmaṇasseva paricārakā sampajjanti.
translation-en-sujato: in fact succeed only in serving the brahmins.

root-pli-ms: Tayidaṁ, bho gotama, nacchannaṁ, tayidaṁ nappatirūpaṁ, yadime sakyā ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṁ karonti, na brāhmaṇe mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It is neither proper nor appropriate that the Sakyans—riffraff that they are—don’t honor, respect, revere, worship, or venerate brahmins.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha ambaṭṭho māṇavo idaṁ tatiyaṁ sakyesu ibbhavādaṁ nipātesi.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s how Ambaṭṭha denigrated the Sakyans with the word “riffraff” for the third time.

root-pli-ms: 2.4. Dāsiputtavāda
translation-en-sujato: 2.4. The Word “Son of Bondservants” is Used

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “atibāḷhaṁ kho ayaṁ ambaṭṭho māṇavo sakyesu ibbhavādena nimmādeti, yannūnāhaṁ gottaṁ puccheyyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “This Ambaṭṭha puts the Sakyans down too much by calling them riffraff. Why don’t I ask him about his own clan?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to him,

root-pli-ms: “kathaṁ gottosi, ambaṭṭhā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “What is your clan, Ambaṭṭha?”

root-pli-ms: “Kaṇhāyanohamasmi, bho gotamā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I am a Kaṇhāyana, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Porāṇaṁ kho pana te, ambaṭṭha, mātāpettikaṁ nāmagottaṁ anussarato ayyaputtā sakyā bhavanti; dāsiputto tvamasi sakyānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “But, recollecting the ancient name and clan of your mother and father, the Sakyans were the children of the masters, while you’re descended from the son of a female bondservant of the Sakyans.
comment-en-sujato: Normally I take ayyaputta as a simple honorific, but here Comm says Ayyaputtāti sāmino puttā. Dāsiputtoti gharadāsiyāva putto. Given the parallelism between these two phrases, and the fact that just below they are said to claim descent from Okkaka, it seems that the sense is not that the Sakyans were the masters, but were descended from them. Not much of a difference, I know!

root-pli-ms: Sakyā kho pana, ambaṭṭha, rājānaṁ okkākaṁ pitāmahaṁ dahanti.
translation-en-sujato: But the Sakyans claim King Okkāka as their grandfather.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ambaṭṭha, rājā okkāko yā sā mahesī piyā manāpā, tassā puttassa rajjaṁ pariṇāmetukāmo jeṭṭhakumāre raṭṭhasmā pabbājesi—
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, King Okkāka, wishing to divert the royal succession to the son of his most beloved queen, banished the elder princes from the realm—

root-pli-ms: okkāmukhaṁ karakaṇḍaṁ hatthinikaṁ sinisūraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Okkāmukha, Karakaṇḍa, Hatthinika, and Sinisūra.
variant-pli-ms: karakaṇḍaṁ → karakaṇḍuṁ (sya-all); karaṇḍuṁ (pts1ed) | sinisūraṁ → nipuraṁ (bj); sinipuraṁ (sya-all); sīnipuraṁ (pts1ed) | okkāmukhaṁ → ukkāmukhaṁ (bj, sya-all)

root-pli-ms: Te raṭṭhasmā pabbājitā himavantapasse pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahāsākasaṇḍo, tattha vāsaṁ kappesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They made their home beside a lotus pond on the slopes of the Himalayas, where there was a large teak grove.

root-pli-ms: Te jātisambhedabhayā sakāhi bhaginīhi saddhiṁ saṁvāsaṁ kappesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: For fear of diluting their lineage, they slept with their own sisters.
comment-en-sujato: For sambheda, see AN 2.9=DN 26, AN 5.103 = AN 10.45. In each case the sense is not “breaking, destroying” as you might expect, but the dissolving of boundaries, resulting in promiscuity or leaking of secrets. Comm. to DN 26 has “Sambhedanti missībhāvaṁ, mariyādabhedaṁ vā.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ambaṭṭha, rājā okkāko amacce pārisajje āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Okkāka addressed his ministers and counselors,

root-pli-ms: ‘kahaṁ nu kho, bho, etarahi kumārā sammantī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Where, sirs, have the princes settled now?’
comment-en-sujato: For this sense of sammati, see SN 11.9, SN 11.10

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi, deva, himavantapasse pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahāsākasaṇḍo, tatthetarahi kumārā sammanti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, there is a lotus pond on the slopes of the Himalayas, by a large grove of _sāka_, the teak tree. They’ve settled there.

root-pli-ms: Te jātisambhedabhayā sakāhi bhaginīhi saddhiṁ saṁvāsaṁ kappentī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: For fear of diluting their lineage, they are sleeping with their own (_saka_) sisters.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ambaṭṭha, rājā okkāko udānaṁ udānesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then, Ambaṭṭha, King Okkāka expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

root-pli-ms: ‘sakyā vata, bho, kumārā, paramasakyā vata, bho, kumārā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The princes are indeed Sakyans! The princes are indeed the best Sakyans!’
comment-en-sujato: Not, one might imagine, the kind of response one might expect from the revelation of incest in one’s children. Both RD and MW comment on the puns in this passage, but don’t, unless I am missing something, mention the incest. Most likely there was speculation about the derivation of sakya, with some suggesting it was from saka, others from sāka, and, in the inclusive way of myths, this little story attempts to reconcile them. That it includes a memory of incestuous relations among the royal families is by no means unusual in such stories.

root-pli-ms: Tadagge kho pana, ambaṭṭha, sakyā paññāyanti; so ca nesaṁ pubbapuriso.
translation-en-sujato: From that day on the Sakyans were recognized, and he was their founder.

root-pli-ms: Rañño kho pana, ambaṭṭha, okkākassa disā nāma dāsī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Now, King Okkāka had a female bondservant named Disā.

root-pli-ms: Sā kaṇhaṁ nāma janesi.
translation-en-sujato: She gave birth to a black boy.
comment-en-sujato: I’m very conflicted as to whether to include nama here! The whole passage seems to hover between treating kanha as a personal name, a description, or as a word for “demon”. I try to capture this ambiguity by using variations of black boy.

root-pli-ms: Jāto kaṇho pabyāhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: When he was born, Black Boy said:

root-pli-ms: ‘dhovatha maṁ, amma, nahāpetha maṁ amma, imasmā maṁ asucismā parimocetha, atthāya vo bhavissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Wash me, mum, bathe me! Get this filth off of me! I will be useful for you!’
comment-en-sujato: His words here are clearly meant as a dramatic contrast with Siddhattha’s birth.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana, ambaṭṭha, etarahi manussā pisāce disvā ‘pisācā’ti sañjānanti;
translation-en-sujato: Whereas these days when people see goblins they know them as goblins,

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ambaṭṭha, tena kho pana samayena manussā pisāce ‘kaṇhā’ti sañjānanti.
translation-en-sujato: in those days they knew goblins as ‘blackboys’.

root-pli-ms: Te evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: They said:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ jāto pabyāhāsi, kaṇho jāto, pisāco jāto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘He spoke as soon as he was born—a blackboy is born! A goblin is born!’

root-pli-ms: Tadagge kho pana, ambaṭṭha, kaṇhāyanā paññāyanti, so ca kaṇhāyanānaṁ pubbapuriso.
translation-en-sujato: From that day on the Kaṇhāyanas were recognized, and he was their founder.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho te, ambaṭṭha, porāṇaṁ mātāpettikaṁ nāmagottaṁ anussarato ayyaputtā sakyā bhavanti, dāsiputto tvamasi sakyānan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how, recollecting the ancient name and clan of your mother and father, the Sakyans were the children of the masters, while you’re descended from the son of a female bondservant of the Sakyans.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, te māṇavakā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, those students said to him,

root-pli-ms: “mā bhavaṁ gotamo ambaṭṭhaṁ atibāḷhaṁ dāsiputtavādena nimmādesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Master Gotama, please don’t put Ambaṭṭha down too much by calling him the son of a bondservant.

root-pli-ms: Sujāto ca, bho gotama, ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kulaputto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, bahussuto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, paṇḍito ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, pahoti ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhotā gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetun”ti.
translation-en-sujato: He’s well-born, a gentleman, learned, a good speaker, and astute. He’s capable of having a dialogue with Master Gotama about this.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā te māṇavake etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to them,

root-pli-ms: “sace kho tumhākaṁ māṇavakānaṁ evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Well, students, if you think that

root-pli-ms: ‘dujjāto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, akulaputto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, appassuto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, akalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, duppañño ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, na ca pahoti ambaṭṭho māṇavo samaṇena gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetun’ti, tiṭṭhatu ambaṭṭho māṇavo, tumhe mayā saddhiṁ mantavho asmiṁ vacane.
translation-en-sujato: Ambaṭṭha is ill-born, not a gentleman, uneducated, a poor speaker, witless, and not capable of having a dialogue with me about this, then leave him aside and you can have a dialogue with me.

root-pli-ms: Sace pana tumhākaṁ māṇavakānaṁ evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: But if you think that

root-pli-ms: ‘sujāto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kulaputto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, bahussuto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, paṇḍito ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, pahoti ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo samaṇena gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetun’ti, tiṭṭhatha tumhe;
translation-en-sujato: he’s well-born, a gentleman, learned, a good speaker, astute, and capable of having a dialogue with me about this, then you should stand aside and let him have a dialogue with me.”

root-pli-ms: ambaṭṭho māṇavo mayā saddhiṁ paṭimantetū”ti.

“Sujāto ca, bho gotama, ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kulaputto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, bahussuto ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, paṇḍito ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo, pahoti ca ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhotā gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetuṁ, tuṇhī mayaṁ bhavissāma, ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhotā gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “He is capable of having a dialogue. We will be silent, and let Ambaṭṭha have a dialogue with Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to Ambaṭṭha,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ kho pana te, ambaṭṭha, sahadhammiko pañho āgacchati, akāmā byākātabbo.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, Ambaṭṭha, there’s a legitimate question that comes up. You won’t like it, but you ought to answer anyway.

root-pli-ms: Sace tvaṁ na byākarissasi, aññena vā aññaṁ paṭicarissasi, tuṇhī vā bhavissasi, pakkamissasi vā ettheva te sattadhā muddhā phalissati.
translation-en-sujato: If you don’t answer, but dodge the issue, remain silent, or simply leave, your head will explode into seven pieces right here.
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW misconstrue the syntax here. There are three vā-s, i.e. three ways of not answering.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: kinti te sutaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ kutopabhutikā kaṇhāyanā, ko ca kaṇhāyanānaṁ pubbapuriso”ti?
translation-en-sujato: According to what you have heard from elderly and senior brahmins, the teachers of teachers, what is the origin of the Kaṇhāyanas, and who is their founder?”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, ambaṭṭho māṇavo tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, Ambaṭṭha kept silent.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: For a second time, the Buddha put the question,

root-pli-ms: “taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, kinti te sutaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ kutopabhutikā kaṇhāyanā, ko ca kaṇhāyanānaṁ pubbapuriso”ti?
Dutiyampi kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo tuṇhī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: and for a second time Ambaṭṭha kept silent.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to him,

root-pli-ms: “byākarohi dāni, ambaṭṭha, na dāni, te tuṇhībhāvassa kālo.
translation-en-sujato: “Answer now, Ambaṭṭha. Now is not the time for silence.

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, ambaṭṭha, tathāgatena yāvatatiyakaṁ sahadhammikaṁ pañhaṁ puṭṭho na byākaroti, etthevassa sattadhā muddhā phalissatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: If someone fails to answer a legitimate question when asked three times by the Buddha, their head explodes into seven pieces there and then.”

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena vajirapāṇī yakkho mahantaṁ ayokūṭaṁ ādāya ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassa upari vehāsaṁ ṭhito hoti:
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the spirit Vajirapāṇi, holding a massive iron spear, burning, blazing, and glowing, stood in the sky above Ambaṭṭha, thinking,
comment-en-sujato: Cp. MN 35

root-pli-ms: “sacāyaṁ ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavatā yāvatatiyakaṁ sahadhammikaṁ pañhaṁ puṭṭho na byākarissati, etthevassa sattadhā muddhaṁ phālessāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “If this Ambaṭṭha doesn’t answer when asked a third time, I’ll blow his head into seven pieces there and then!”

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana vajirapāṇiṁ yakkhaṁ bhagavā ceva passati ambaṭṭho ca māṇavo.
translation-en-sujato: And both the Buddha and Ambaṭṭha could see Vajirapāṇi.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto bhagavantaṁyeva tāṇaṁ gavesī bhagavantaṁyeva leṇaṁ gavesī bhagavantaṁyeva saraṇaṁ gavesī upanisīditvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Ambaṭṭha was terrified, shocked, and awestruck. Looking to the Buddha for shelter, protection, and refuge, he sat down close by the Buddha and said,

root-pli-ms: “kimetaṁ bhavaṁ gotamo āha?
translation-en-sujato: “What did you say?

root-pli-ms: Punabhavaṁ gotamo bravitū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Please repeat the question.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: kinti te sutaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ kutopabhutikā kaṇhāyanā, ko ca kaṇhāyanānaṁ pubbapuriso”ti?
translation-en-sujato: According to what you have heard from elderly and senior brahmins, the teachers of teachers, what is the origin of the Kaṇhāyanas, and who is their founder?”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva me, bho gotama, sutaṁ yatheva bhavaṁ gotamo āha.
translation-en-sujato: “I have heard, Master Gotama, that it is just as you say.

root-pli-ms: Tatopabhutikā kaṇhāyanā;
translation-en-sujato: That’s the origin of the Kaṇhāyanas,

root-pli-ms: so ca kaṇhāyanānaṁ pubbapuriso”ti.
translation-en-sujato: and that’s who their founder is.”

root-pli-ms: 2.5. Ambaṭṭhavaṁsakathā
translation-en-sujato: 2.5. The Discussion of Ambaṭṭha’s Heritage

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, te māṇavakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, those students made an uproar,
reference: csp1ed6.90, csp2ed6.90, dr9.126, ms6D_373, msdiv273, pts-cs1.22, sc27, sya9.125

root-pli-ms: “dujjāto kira, bho, ambaṭṭho māṇavo; akulaputto kira, bho, ambaṭṭho māṇavo; dāsiputto kira, bho, ambaṭṭho māṇavo sakyānaṁ. Ayyaputtā kira, bho, ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassa sakyā bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: “It turns out Ambaṭṭha is ill-born, not a gentleman, son of a Sakyan bondservant, and that the Sakyans are sons of his masters!

root-pli-ms: Dhammavādiṁyeva kira mayaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ apasādetabbaṁ amaññimhā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And it seems that the ascetic Gotama spoke only the truth, though we presumed to rebuke him!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
reference: cck9.124, km14.234, lv1.262, ms6D_374, msdiv274, pts-cs1.23, pts-vp-pli1.96, sc28

root-pli-ms: “atibāḷhaṁ kho ime māṇavakā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ dāsiputtavādena nimmādenti, yannūnāhaṁ parimoceyyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “These students put Ambaṭṭha down too much by calling him the son of a bondservant. Why don’t I get him out of this?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā te māṇavake etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Buddha said to the students,

root-pli-ms: “mā kho tumhe, māṇavakā, ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ atibāḷhaṁ dāsiputtavādena nimmādetha.
translation-en-sujato: “Students, please don’t put Ambaṭṭha down too much by calling him the son of a bondservant.

root-pli-ms: Uḷāro so kaṇho isi ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: That Black Boy was an eminent sage.

root-pli-ms: So dakkhiṇajanapadaṁ gantvā brahmamante adhīyitvā rājānaṁ okkākaṁ upasaṅkamitvā maddarūpiṁ dhītaraṁ yāci.
translation-en-sujato: He went to a southern country and memorized the Prime Spell. Then he approached King Okkāka and asked for the hand of his daughter Maddarūpī.
comment-en-sujato: Brahmamanta is of unique occurence, and neither RD’s “mystic verses” nor MW’s “mantras of the Brahmins” is adequate. the former is too vague, the second—while hardly being a translation at all—manages to get the basics wrong, as it is brahma, not brahmana. Comm says: brahmamanteti ānubhāvasampannatāya seṭṭhamante. And, while the connection to brahmanism is too obvious to need mentioning, i think it is right in saying this is a specially powerful spell.

root-pli-ms: Tassa rājā okkāko:
translation-en-sujato: The king said to him,

root-pli-ms: ‘ko nevaṁ re ayaṁ mayhaṁ dāsiputto samāno maddarūpiṁ dhītaraṁ yācatī’ti, kupito anattamano khurappaṁ sannayhi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Who the hell is this son of a bondservant to ask for the hand of my daughter!’ Angry and upset he fastened a razor-tipped arrow.

root-pli-ms: So taṁ khurappaṁ neva asakkhi muñcituṁ, no paṭisaṁharituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But he wasn’t able to either shoot it or to relax it.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, māṇavakā, amaccā pārisajjā kaṇhaṁ isiṁ upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the ministers and counselors approached the sage Black Boy and said:

root-pli-ms: ‘sotthi, bhaddante, hotu rañño;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Spare the king, sir,

root-pli-ms: sotthi, bhaddante, hotu rañño’ti.
translation-en-sujato: spare him!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Sotthi bhavissati rañño, api ca rājā yadi adho khurappaṁ muñcissati, yāvatā rañño vijitaṁ, ettāvatā pathavī undriyissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The king will be safe. But if he shoots the arrow downwards, there will be an earthquake across the entire realm.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Sotthi, bhaddante, hotu rañño, sotthi janapadassā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Spare the king, sir, and spare the country!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Sotthi bhavissati rañño, sotthi janapadassa, api ca rājā yadi uddhaṁ khurappaṁ muñcissati, yāvatā rañño vijitaṁ, ettāvatā satta vassāni devo na vassissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Both king and country will be safe. But if he shoots the arrow upwards, there will be no rain in the entire realm for seven years.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Sotthi, bhaddante, hotu rañño sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassatū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Spare the king, sir, spare the country, and let there be rain!’
comment-en-sujato: This is obviously an origin story for this prayer.

root-pli-ms: ‘Sotthi bhavissati rañño sotthi janapadassa devo ca vassissati, api ca rājā jeṭṭhakumāre khurappaṁ patiṭṭhāpetu, sotthi kumāro pallomo bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Both king and country will be safe, and the rain will fall. And if the king aims the arrow at the crown prince, he will be safe and untouched.’
comment-en-sujato: National prosperity through fake regicide. How did Frazer miss this?

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, māṇavakā, amaccā okkākassa ārocesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: So the ministers said to Okkāka:
comment-en-sujato: The use of the bare personal name for the king is highly unusual, and not capture by either RD or MW.

root-pli-ms: ‘okkāko jeṭṭhakumāre khurappaṁ patiṭṭhāpetu. Sotthi kumāro pallomo bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Okkāka must aim the arrow at the crown prince. He will be safe and untouched.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā okkāko jeṭṭhakumāre khurappaṁ patiṭṭhapesi, sotthi kumāro pallomo samabhavi.
translation-en-sujato: So King Okkāka aimed the arrow at the crown prince. And he was safe and untouched.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tassa rājā okkāko bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto brahmadaṇḍena tajjito maddarūpiṁ dhītaraṁ adāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the king was terrified, shocked, and awestruck. Scared by the prime punishment, he gave the hand of his daughter Maddarūpī.
comment-en-sujato: Again, neither RD nor MW capture brahmadanda here: it clearly harks back to brahmamantra.

root-pli-ms: Mā kho tumhe, māṇavakā, ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ atibāḷhaṁ dāsiputtavādena nimmādetha, uḷāro so kaṇho isi ahosī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Students, please don’t put Ambaṭṭha down too much by calling him the son of a bondservant. That Black Boy was an eminent sage.”
comment-en-sujato: So threatening the king and forcing an unwanted marriage is a sign of eminence?

root-pli-ms: 3. Khattiyaseṭṭhabhāva
translation-en-sujato: 3. The Supremacy of the Aristocrats

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha addressed Ambaṭṭha,

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: idha khattiyakumāro brāhmaṇakaññāya saddhiṁ saṁvāsaṁ kappeyya, tesaṁ saṁvāsamanvāya putto jāyetha.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose an aristocrat boy was to sleep with a brahmin girl, and they had a son.

root-pli-ms: Yo so khattiyakumārena brāhmaṇakaññāya putto uppanno, api nu so labhetha brāhmaṇesu āsanaṁ vā udakaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Would he receive a seat and water from the brahmins?”

root-pli-ms: “Labhetha, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “He would, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ brāhmaṇā bhojeyyuṁ saddhe vā thālipāke vā yaññe vā pāhune vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would the brahmins feed him at an offering of food for ancestors, an offering of a dish of milk-rice, a sacrifice, or a feast for guests?”

root-pli-ms: “Bhojeyyuṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “They would.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ brāhmaṇā mante vāceyyuṁ vā no vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would the brahmins teach him the hymns or not?”

root-pli-ms: “Vāceyyuṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “They would.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nussa itthīsu āvaṭaṁ vā assa anāvaṭaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would he be kept from the women or not?”
comment-en-sujato: Translation of avata here is tricky. I don’t think it means “veiled”, nor does it imply that the women are shut in, neither of which is, so far as I am aware, attested at this time. In MN 56 avata is used in reference to Upali “shutting his gate” against the Jains and opening it for the Buddhists. So here I think it basically means “excludes from close contact” (especially as a suitor). Cp DN 17, where it has a similar sense.

root-pli-ms: “Anāvaṭaṁ hissa, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “He would not.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ khattiyā khattiyābhisekena abhisiñceyyun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would the aristocrats anoint him as king?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kissa hetu”?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: “Mātito hi, bho gotama, anupapanno”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Because his maternity is unsuitable.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: idha brāhmaṇakumāro khattiyakaññāya saddhiṁ saṁvāsaṁ kappeyya, tesaṁ saṁvāsamanvāya putto jāyetha.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a brahmin boy was to sleep with an aristocrat girl, and they had a son.

root-pli-ms: Yo so brāhmaṇakumārena khattiyakaññāya putto uppanno, api nu so labhetha brāhmaṇesu āsanaṁ vā udakaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Would he receive a seat and water from the brahmins?”

root-pli-ms: “Labhetha, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “He would, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ brāhmaṇā bhojeyyuṁ saddhe vā thālipāke vā yaññe vā pāhune vā”ti?

translation-en-sujato: “They would.”

translation-en-sujato: “And would the brahmins teach him the hymns or not?”

root-pli-ms: “Vāceyyuṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “They would.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nussa itthīsu āvaṭaṁ vā assa anāvaṭaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would he be kept from the women or not?”

root-pli-ms: “Anāvaṭaṁ hissa, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “He would not.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ khattiyā khattiyābhisekena abhisiñceyyun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would the aristocrats anoint him as king?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kissa hetu”?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: “Pitito hi, bho gotama, anupapanno”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Because his paternity is unsuitable.”

root-pli-ms: “Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, itthiyā vā itthiṁ karitvā purisena vā purisaṁ karitvā khattiyāva seṭṭhā, hīnā brāhmaṇā.
translation-en-sujato: “And so, Ambaṭṭha, the aristocrats are superior and the brahmins inferior, whether comparing women with women or men with men.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: idha brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṁ kismiñcideva pakaraṇe khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā bhassapuṭena vadhitvā raṭṭhā vā nagarā vā pabbājeyyuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose the brahmins for some reason were to shave a brahmin’s head, inflict him with a sack of ashes, and banish him from the nation or the city.

root-pli-ms: Api nu so labhetha brāhmaṇesu āsanaṁ vā udakaṁ vā”ti?

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.

translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu naṁ brāhmaṇā mante vāceyyuṁ vā no vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “And would the brahmins teach him the hymns or not?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: Api nu so labhetha brāhmaṇesu āsanaṁ vā udakaṁ vā”ti?

root-pli-ms: “Anāvaṭaṁ hissa, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “He would not.”

root-pli-ms: “Ettāvatā kho, ambaṭṭha, khattiyo paramanihīnataṁ patto hoti, yadeva naṁ khattiyā khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā bhassapuṭena vadhitvā raṭṭhā vā nagarā vā pabbājenti.
translation-en-sujato: “At this point, Ambaṭṭha, that aristocrat has reached rock bottom, with head shaven, inflicted with a sack of ashes, and banished from city or nation.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, yadā khattiyo paramanihīnataṁ patto hoti, tadāpi khattiyāva seṭṭhā, hīnā brāhmaṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Yet still the aristocrats are superior and the brahmins inferior.

root-pli-ms: Brahmunā pesā, ambaṭṭha, sanaṅkumārena gāthā bhāsitā:
translation-en-sujato: Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra also spoke this verse:
variant-pli-ms: Brahmunā pesā, ambaṭṭha → brahmunāpi ambaṭṭha (bj, mr); brahmunā cesā ambaṭṭha (sya-all); brahmunāpi esā ambaṭṭha (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: ‘Khattiyo seṭṭho janetasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: ‘The aristocrat is best of those people

root-pli-ms: ye gottapaṭisārino;
translation-en-sujato: who take clan as the standard.

root-pli-ms: Vijjācaraṇasampanno,
translation-en-sujato: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

root-pli-ms: so seṭṭho devamānuse’ti.
translation-en-sujato: is best of gods and humans.’

root-pli-ms: Sā kho panesā, ambaṭṭha, brahmunā sanaṅkumārena gāthā sugītā no duggītā, subhāsitā no dubbhāsitā, atthasaṁhitā no anatthasaṁhitā, anumatā mayā.
translation-en-sujato: That verse was well sung by Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, not poorly sung; well spoken, not poorly spoken, beneficial, not harmful, and it was approved by me.

root-pli-ms: Ahampi hi, ambaṭṭha, evaṁ vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: For I also say this:

root-pli-ms: Khattiyo seṭṭho janetasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: The aristocrat is best of those people

root-pli-ms: ye gottapaṭisārino;
translation-en-sujato: who take clan as the standard.

root-pli-ms: Vijjācaraṇasampanno,
translation-en-sujato: But one accomplished in knowledge and conduct

root-pli-ms: so seṭṭho devamānuse”ti.
translation-en-sujato: is best of gods and humans.”

root-pli-ms: Bhāṇavāro paṭhamo.
4. Vijjācaraṇakathā
translation-en-sujato: 4. Knowledge and Conduct

root-pli-ms: “Katamaṁ pana taṁ, bho gotama, caraṇaṁ, katamā ca pana sā vijjā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But what, Master Gotama, is that conduct, and what is that knowledge?”
comment-en-sujato: Acc. to comm, Ambattha assumed this was referring to his own vedic lore. Hence, in the next line, I take the āya ending as locative, in agreement with yattha below.

root-pli-ms: “Na kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya jātivādo vā vuccati, gottavādo vā vuccati, mānavādo vā vuccati:
translation-en-sujato: “Ambaṭṭha, in the supreme knowledge and conduct there is no discussion of ancestry or clan or pride—

root-pli-ms: ‘arahasi vā maṁ tvaṁ, na vā maṁ tvaṁ arahasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘You deserve me’ or ‘You don’t deserve me.’

root-pli-ms: Yattha kho, ambaṭṭha, āvāho vā hoti, vivāho vā hoti, āvāhavivāho vā hoti, etthetaṁ vuccati jātivādo vā itipi gottavādo vā itipi mānavādo vā itipi:
translation-en-sujato: Wherever there is giving and taking in marriage there is such discussion.

root-pli-ms: ‘arahasi vā maṁ tvaṁ, na vā maṁ tvaṁ arahasī’ti.
Ye hi keci, ambaṭṭha, jātivādavinibaddhā vā gottavādavinibaddhā vā mānavādavinibaddhā vā āvāhavivāhavinibaddhā vā, ārakā te anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya.
translation-en-sujato: Whoever is attached to questions of ancestry or clan or pride, or to giving and taking in marriage, is far from the supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Pahāya kho, ambaṭṭha, jātivādavinibaddhañca gottavādavinibaddhañca mānavādavinibaddhañca āvāhavivāhavinibaddhañca anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya sacchikiriyā hotī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: The realization of supreme knowledge and conduct occurs when you’ve given up such things.”

root-pli-ms: “Katamaṁ pana taṁ, bho gotama, caraṇaṁ, katamā ca sā vijjā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But what, Master Gotama, is that conduct, and what is that knowledge?”
reference: csp1ed6.94, csp2ed6.94, ms6D_386, msdiv279, pts-cs2.2, sc39, vri1.87

root-pli-ms: “Idha, ambaṭṭha, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: “Ambaṭṭha, it’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
translation-en-sujato: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

root-pli-ms: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
translation-en-sujato: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
translation-en-sujato: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.

root-pli-ms: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
translation-en-sujato: They gain faith in the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: and reflect …

root-pli-ms: So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption …

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption …

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption …

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their conduct.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho taṁ, ambaṭṭha, caraṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is that conduct.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge and vision.

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti vijjāya …pe…
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their knowledge. …

root-pli-ms: nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāti,
translation-en-sujato: They understand: ‘There is no return to any state of existence.’

root-pli-ms: idampissa hoti vijjāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their knowledge.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho sā, ambaṭṭha, vijjā.
translation-en-sujato: This is that knowledge.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu ‘vijjāsampanno’ itipi, ‘caraṇasampanno’ itipi, ‘vijjācaraṇasampanno’ itipi.
translation-en-sujato: This mendicant is said to be ‘accomplished in knowledge’, and also ‘accomplished in conduct’, and also ‘accomplished in knowledge and conduct’.

root-pli-ms: Imāya ca, ambaṭṭha, vijjāsampadāya caraṇasampadāya ca aññā vijjāsampadā ca caraṇasampadā ca uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthi.
translation-en-sujato: And, Ambaṭṭha, there is no accomplishment in knowledge and conduct that is better or finer than this.

root-pli-ms: 5. Catuapāyamukha
translation-en-sujato: 5. Four Drains

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: There are these four drains that affect this supreme knowledge and conduct.
comment-en-sujato: https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/apayamukha-in-the-ebts-doesn-t-mean-path-to-a-lower-realm/5577
reference: csp1ed6.95, csp2ed6.95, ms6D_393, msdiv280, pts-cs2.3, pts-vp-pli1.101, sc46

root-pli-ms: Katamāni cattāri?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, ambaṭṭha, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaññeva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno khārividhamādāya araññāyatanaṁ ajjhogāhati:
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, take some ascetic or brahmin who, not managing to obtain this supreme knowledge and conduct, plunges into a wilderness region carrying their stuff with a shoulder-pole, thinking

root-pli-ms: ‘pavattaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: they will get by eating fallen fruit.

root-pli-ms: So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati.
translation-en-sujato: In fact they succeed only in serving someone accomplished in knowledge and conduct.
comment-en-sujato: This phrase echoes the earlier aññadatthu brāhmaṇasseva paricārakā sampajjanti

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṁ paṭhamaṁ apāyamukhaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first drain that affects this supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kudālapiṭakaṁ ādāya araññavanaṁ ajjhogāhati:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, take some ascetic or brahmin who, not managing to obtain this supreme knowledge and conduct or to get by eating fallen fruit, plunges into a wilderness region carrying a spade and basket, thinking

root-pli-ms: ‘kandamūlaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: they will get by eating tubers and fruit.

root-pli-ms: So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati.
translation-en-sujato: In fact they succeed only in serving someone accomplished in knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṁ dutiyaṁ apāyamukhaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second drain that affects this supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno gāmasāmantaṁ vā nigamasāmantaṁ vā agyāgāraṁ karitvā aggiṁ paricaranto acchati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, take some ascetic or brahmin who, not managing to obtain this supreme knowledge and conduct, or to get by eating fallen fruit, or to get by eating tubers and fruit, sets up a fire chamber in the neighborhood of a village or town and dwells there serving the sacred flame.

root-pli-ms: So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati.
translation-en-sujato: In fact they succeed only in serving someone accomplished in knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṁ tatiyaṁ apāyamukhaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third drain that affects this supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaṁ ceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno aggipāricariyañca anabhisambhuṇamāno cātumahāpathe catudvāraṁ agāraṁ karitvā acchati:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, take some ascetic or brahmin who, not managing to obtain this supreme knowledge and conduct, or to get by eating fallen fruit, or to get by eating tubers and fruit, or to serve the sacred flame, sets up a fire chamber in the central square and dwells there, thinking:

root-pli-ms: ‘yo imāhi catūhi disāhi āgamissati samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, tamahaṁ yathāsatti yathābalaṁ paṭipūjessāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘When an ascetic or brahmin comes from the four quarters, I will honor them as best I can.’

root-pli-ms: So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati.
translation-en-sujato: In fact they succeed only in serving someone accomplished in knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṁ catutthaṁ apāyamukhaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth drain that affects this supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya imāni cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four drains that affect this supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?
reference: csp1ed6.96, csp2ed6.96, km14.246, lv1.278, ms6D_397, msdiv281, pts-cs2.4, sc50, sya9.132

root-pli-ms: api nu tvaṁ imāya anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya sandissasi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Is this supreme knowledge and conduct seen in your own tradition?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.

root-pli-ms: Kocāhaṁ, bho gotama, sācariyako, kā ca anuttarā vijjācaraṇasampadā?
translation-en-sujato: Who am I and my tradition compared with the supreme knowledge and conduct?

root-pli-ms: Ārakāhaṁ, bho gotama, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya sācariyako”ti.
translation-en-sujato: We are far from that.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: api nu tvaṁ imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno khārividhamādāya araññavanamajjhogāhasi sācariyako:
translation-en-sujato: Since you’re not managing to obtain this supreme knowledge and conduct, have you with your tradition plunged into a wilderness region carrying your stuff with a shoulder-pole, thinking

root-pli-ms: ‘pavattaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: you will get by eating fallen fruit?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: api nu tvaṁ imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kudālapiṭakaṁ ādāya araññavanamajjhogāhasi sācariyako:
translation-en-sujato: Have you with your tradition … plunged into a wilderness region carrying a spade and basket, thinking

root-pli-ms: ‘kandamūlaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: you will get by eating tubers and fruit?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: api nu tvaṁ imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno gāmasāmantaṁ vā nigamasāmantaṁ vā agyāgāraṁ karitvā aggiṁ paricaranto acchasi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Have you with your tradition … set up a fire chamber in the neighborhood of a village or town and dwelt there serving the sacred flame?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: api nu tvaṁ imañceva anuttaraṁ vijjācaraṇasampadaṁ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno aggipāricariyañca anabhisambhuṇamāno cātumahāpathe catudvāraṁ agāraṁ karitvā acchasi sācariyako:
translation-en-sujato: Have you with your tradition … set up a fire chamber in the central square and dwelt there, thinking:

root-pli-ms: ‘yo imāhi catūhi disāhi āgamissati samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, taṁ mayaṁ yathāsatti yathābalaṁ paṭipūjessāmā’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘When an ascetic or brahmin comes from the four quarters, I will honor them as best I can’?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, imāya ceva tvaṁ anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya parihīno sācariyako.
translation-en-sujato: “So you with your tradition are not only inferior to the supreme knowledge and conduct,

root-pli-ms: Ye cime anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti, tato ca tvaṁ parihīno sācariyako.
translation-en-sujato: you are even inferior to the four drains that affect the supreme knowledge and conduct.

root-pli-ms: Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, ambaṭṭha, ācariyena brāhmaṇena pokkharasātinā vācā:
translation-en-sujato: But you have been told this by your teacher, the brahmin Pokkharasāti:

root-pli-ms: ‘ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, kā ca tevijjānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ sākacchā’ti attanā āpāyikopi aparipūramāno.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Who are these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman compared with conversation with the brahmins of the three knowledges?” Yet he himself has not even fulfilled one of the drains!

root-pli-ms: Passa, ambaṭṭha, yāva aparaddhañca te idaṁ ācariyassa brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa.
translation-en-sujato: See, Ambaṭṭha, how your teacher Pokkharasāti has wronged you.
comment-en-sujato: This harks back to Kiṁ pana te, ambaṭṭha, sakyā aparaddhum. BTW, this is a savage takedown.

root-pli-ms: 6. Pubbakaisibhāvānuyoga
translation-en-sujato: 6. Being Like the Sages of the Past

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇo kho pana, ambaṭṭha, pokkharasāti rañño pasenadissa kosalassa dattikaṁ bhuñjati.
translation-en-sujato: But Pokkharasāti lives off an endowment provided by King Pasenadi of Kosala.
reference: csp1ed6.97, csp2ed6.97, lv1.282, ms6D_403, msdiv283, pts-cs2.6, sc56

root-pli-ms: Tassa rājā pasenadi kosalo sammukhībhāvampi na dadāti.
translation-en-sujato: But the king won’t even grant him an audience face to face.

root-pli-ms: Yadāpi tena manteti, tirodussantena manteti.
translation-en-sujato: When he consults, he does so behind a curtain.
comment-en-sujato: Is this practice attested to elsewhere?

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, ambaṭṭha, dhammikaṁ payātaṁ bhikkhaṁ paṭiggaṇheyya, kathaṁ tassa rājā pasenadi kosalo sammukhībhāvampi na dadeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Why wouldn’t the king grant a face to face audience with someone who’d receive his legitimate presentation of food?

root-pli-ms: Passa, ambaṭṭha, yāva aparaddhañca te idaṁ ācariyassa brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa.
translation-en-sujato: See, Ambaṭṭha, how your teacher Pokkharasāti has wronged you.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?
comment-en-sujato: Here ugga must be a noun. See my note on AN 7.67. Rajanna is used fairly rarely in the suttas. According to the Sanskrit dicts, it is the old form of khattiya. But in the Pali it is an alternative for Khattiya. Given it’s age and association with arriors, chieftan seems apt.

root-pli-ms: idha rājā pasenadi kosalo hatthigīvāya vā nisinno assapiṭṭhe vā nisinno rathūpatthare vā ṭhito uggehi vā rājaññehi vā kiñcideva mantanaṁ manteyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose King Pasenadi was holding consultations with warrior-chiefs or chieftains while sitting on an elephant’s neck or on horseback, or while standing on the mat in a chariot.

root-pli-ms: So tamhā padesā apakkamma ekamantaṁ tiṭṭheyya.
translation-en-sujato: And suppose he’d get down from that place and stand aside.

root-pli-ms: Atha āgaccheyya suddo vā suddadāso vā, tasmiṁ padese ṭhito tadeva mantanaṁ manteyya:
translation-en-sujato: Then along would come a worker or their bondservant, who’d stand in the same place and continue the consultation:

root-pli-ms: ‘evampi rājā pasenadi kosalo āha, evampi rājā pasenadi kosalo āhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is what King Pasenadi says, and this too is what the king says.’

root-pli-ms: Api nu so rājabhaṇitaṁ vā bhaṇati rājamantanaṁ vā manteti?
translation-en-sujato: Though he spoke the king’s words and gave the king’s advice,
comment-en-sujato: Taking this and the next as one sentence, as per RD.

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā so assa rājā vā rājamatto vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: does that qualify him to be the king or the king’s minister?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva kho tvaṁ, ambaṭṭha, ye te ahesuṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ pubbakā isayo mantānaṁ kattāro mantānaṁ pavattāro, yesamidaṁ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ gītaṁ pavuttaṁ samihitaṁ, tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṁ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu:
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, Ambaṭṭha, the brahmin seers of the past were Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu. They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.

root-pli-ms: ‘tyāhaṁ mante adhiyāmi sācariyako’ti, tāvatā tvaṁ bhavissasi isi vā isitthāya vā paṭipannoti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
translation-en-sujato: You might imagine that, since you’ve learned their hymns by heart in your own tradition, that makes you a hermit or someone on the path to becoming a hermit. But that is not possible.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, ambaṭṭha,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?

root-pli-ms: kinti te sutaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: According to what you have heard from elderly and senior brahmins, the teachers of teachers,

root-pli-ms: ye te ahesuṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ pubbakā isayo mantānaṁ kattāro mantānaṁ pavattāro, yesamidaṁ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ gītaṁ pavuttaṁ samihitaṁ, tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṁ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu,
translation-en-sujato: did those brahmin hermits of the past—

root-pli-ms: evaṁ su te sunhātā suvilittā kappitakesamassū āmukkamaṇikuṇḍalābharaṇā odātavatthavasanā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārenti, seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, bedecked with jewels, earrings, and bracelets, dressed in white—amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, like you do today in your tradition?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “ …pe…
Evaṁ su te sālīnaṁ odanaṁ sucimaṁsūpasecanaṁ vicitakāḷakaṁ anekasūpaṁ anekabyañjanaṁ paribhuñjanti, seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Did they eat boiled fine rice, garnished with clean meat, with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces, like you do today in your tradition?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “ …pe…
Evaṁ su te veṭhakanatapassāhi nārīhi paricārenti, seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Did they amuse themselves with girls wearing thongs that show off their curves, like you do today in your tradition?”
comment-en-sujato: veṭhakanatapassāhi is otherwise unattested. At MN 55 veṭhaka evidently means “collar”. The Lokuttaravada Bhikshuni Vinaya has a rule about this, Pn 3: https://suttacentral.net/skt/skt-lo-bi-pn3. Thullananda gets out of the water and wraps herself only in a vethaka. Here this seems to be synonymous with paṭṭaka, i.e. a strip of cloth. It is allowable if used to tie on a basket, etc. Edgerton’s BHS dict does not notice this occurrence, but says of a ref in Mahavastu “something that wraps, covers: in a list of goldsmith’s products”, noting however a number of variants. Nata is “curve”, passa is “side, flank”. MW has “flounces and furbelows”, RD “fringes and furbelows round their loins”. These are hopelessly prissy descriptions of what sounds like the clothes of a stripper or lap-dancer.

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “ …pe…
Evaṁ su te kuttavālehi vaḷavārathehi dīghāhi patodalaṭṭhīhi vāhane vitudentā vipariyāyanti, seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Did they drive about in chariots drawn by mares with plaited manes, whipping and lashing them onward with long goads, like you do today in your tradition?”
comment-en-sujato: This harks back to the opening of the sutta. vitudenti vitacchenti recurs at SN 19.1, of a bird being chased and pecked at by other birds. vitudenti by itself has the same meaning at Bu Pj 4. Evidently the Buddha was pretty disgusted with this maltreatment of the poor beasts.

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “ …pe…
Evaṁ su te ukkiṇṇaparikhāsu okkhittapalighāsu nagarūpakārikāsu dīghāsivudhehi purisehi rakkhāpenti, seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Did they get men with long swords to guard them in fortresses with moats dug and barriers in place, like you do today in your tradition?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho gotama”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Gotama.”

root-pli-ms: “Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, neva tvaṁ isi na isitthāya paṭipanno sācariyako.
translation-en-sujato: “So, Ambaṭṭha, in your own tradition you are neither hermit nor someone on the path to becoming a hermit.

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, ambaṭṭha, mayi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā so maṁ pañhena, ahaṁ veyyākaraṇena sodhissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Whoever has any doubt or uncertainty about me, let them ask me and I will clear up their doubts with my answer.”

root-pli-ms: 7. Dvelakkhaṇādassana
translation-en-sujato: 7. Seeing the Two Marks

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā vihārā nikkhamma caṅkamaṁ abbhuṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha came out of his dwelling and proceeded to begin walking mindfully,
reference: csp1ed6.99, csp2ed6.99, km14.253, lv1.287, ms6D_412, msdiv287, ndp6.92, pts-cs2.11, pts-vp-pli1.106, sc65

root-pli-ms: Ambaṭṭhopi māṇavo vihārā nikkhamma caṅkamaṁ abbhuṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: and Ambaṭṭha did likewise.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ caṅkamantaṁ anucaṅkamamāno bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi.
translation-en-sujato: Then while walking beside the Buddha, Ambaṭṭha scrutinized his body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavato kāye dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
translation-en-sujato: He saw all of them except for two,

root-pli-ms: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
translation-en-sujato: which he had doubts about:

root-pli-ms: kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya ca.
translation-en-sujato: whether the private parts are retracted, and the largeness of the tongue.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “passati kho me ayaṁ ambaṭṭho māṇavo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve.
translation-en-sujato: “This brahmin student Ambaṭṭha sees all the marks except for two,

root-pli-ms: Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati—
translation-en-sujato: which he has doubts about:

root-pli-ms: kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya cā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: whether the private parts are retracted, and the largeness of the tongue.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṁ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkhāsi. Yathā addasa ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavato kosohitaṁ vatthaguyhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha used his psychic power to will that Ambaṭṭha would see his retracted private parts.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṁ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṁ jivhāya chādesi.
translation-en-sujato: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Ambaṭṭha thought,

root-pli-ms: “samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṁsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi, no aparipuṇṇehī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.”

root-pli-ms: Bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bho gotama, gacchāma, bahukiccā mayaṁ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, now, sir, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”

root-pli-ms: “Yassadāni tvaṁ, ambaṭṭha, kālaṁ maññasī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please, Ambaṭṭha, go at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo vaḷavārathamāruyha pakkāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Ambaṭṭha mounted his mare-drawn chariot and left.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ukkaṭṭhāya nikkhamitvā mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṁ sake ārāme nisinno hoti ambaṭṭhaṁyeva māṇavaṁ paṭimānento.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the brahmin Pokkharasāti had come out from Ukkaṭṭhā together with a large group of brahmins and was sitting in his own park just waiting for Ambaṭṭha.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena sako ārāmo tena pāyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Ambaṭṭha entered the park.

root-pli-ms: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā brāhmaṇaṁ pokkharasātiṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho ambaṭṭhaṁ māṇavaṁ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the brahmin Pokkharasāti on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side, and Pokkharasāti said to him:
