translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 15

root-pli-ms: Mahānidānasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Great Discourse on Causation

root-pli-ms: 1. Paṭiccasamuppāda
translation-en-sujato: 1. Dependent Origination

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.
reference: bj8.80, cck10.70, csp1ed7.47, csp2ed7.47, dr10.64, mc10.49, ms7D_190, msdiv95, ndp7.44, pts-cs1, pts-vp-pli2.55, sc1, sya10.65, vri2.43

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṁ nāma kurūnaṁ nigamo.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
variant-pli-ms: kammāsadhammaṁ nāma → kammāsadammaṁ nāma (bj, sya-all, km); kammāssadhammaṁ nāma (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

root-pli-ms: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing,

root-pli-ms: Yāva gambhīro cāyaṁ, bhante, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso ca, atha ca pana me uttānakuttānako viya khāyatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: in that this dependent origination is deep and appears deep, yet to me it seems as plain as can be.”

root-pli-ms: “Mā hevaṁ, ānanda, avaca, mā hevaṁ, ānanda, avaca.
translation-en-sujato: “Don’t say that, Ānanda, don’t say that!

root-pli-ms: Gambhīro cāyaṁ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīrāvabhāso ca.
translation-en-sujato: This dependent origination is deep and appears deep.

root-pli-ms: Etassa, ānanda, dhammassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamayaṁ pajā tantākulakajātā kulagaṇṭhikajātā muñjapabbajabhūtā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ saṁsāraṁ nātivattati.
translation-en-sujato: It is because of not understanding and not penetrating this teaching that this population has become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for old age and death?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for old age and death?’ you should answer, ‘Rebirth is a condition for old age and death.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā jātī’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for rebirth?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā jātī’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘bhavapaccayā jātī’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for rebirth?’ you should answer, ‘Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā bhavo’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for continued existence?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā bhavo’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘upādānapaccayā bhavo’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for continued existence?’ you should answer, ‘Grasping is a condition for continued existence.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā upādānan’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for grasping?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā upādānan’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘taṇhāpaccayā upādānan’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for grasping?’ you should answer, ‘Craving is a condition for grasping.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā taṇhā’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for craving?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā taṇhā’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘vedanāpaccayā taṇhā’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for craving?’ you should answer, ‘Feeling is a condition for craving.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā vedanā’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for feeling?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā vedanā’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘phassapaccayā vedanā’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for feeling?’ you should answer, ‘Contact is a condition for feeling.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā phasso’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for contact?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā phasso’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘nāmarūpapaccayā phasso’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for contact?’ you should answer, ‘Name and form are conditions for contact.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā nāmarūpan’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for name and form?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā nāmarūpan’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpan’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for name and form?’ you should answer, ‘Consciousness is a condition for name and form.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi idappaccayā viññāṇan’ti iti puṭṭhena satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for consciousness?’ you should answer, ‘There is.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁpaccayā viññāṇan’ti iti ce vadeyya, ‘nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇan’ti iccassa vacanīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If they say, ‘What is a condition for consciousness?’ you should answer, ‘Name and form are conditions for consciousness.’

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, ānanda, nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: So: name and form are conditions for consciousness. Consciousness is a condition for name and form. Name and form are conditions for contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. Feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
reference: dr10.66, ms7D_200, msdiv97, pts-cs3, pts-vp-pli2.57, sc11, sya10.67

root-pli-ms: Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

root-pli-ms: ‘Jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Rebirth is a condition for old age and death’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: csp1ed7.49, csp2ed7.49, mc10.51, ms7D_201, msdiv98, pts-cs4, sc12, vri2.45

root-pli-ms: Jāti ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no rebirth for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: devānaṁ vā devattāya, gandhabbānaṁ vā gandhabbattāya, yakkhānaṁ vā yakkhattāya, bhūtānaṁ vā bhūtattāya, manussānaṁ vā manussattāya, catuppadānaṁ vā catuppadattāya, pakkhīnaṁ vā pakkhittāya, sarīsapānaṁ vā sarīsapattāya, tesaṁ tesañca hi, ānanda, sattānaṁ tadattāya jāti nābhavissa. Sabbaso jātiyā asati jātinirodhā api nu kho jarāmaraṇaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, there were no rebirth of sentient beings into their various realms—of gods, fairies, spirits, creatures, humans, quadrupeds, birds, or reptiles, each into their own realm. When there’s no rebirth at all, with the cessation of rebirth, would old age and death still be found?”
variant-pli-ms: sarīsapānaṁ vā sarīsapattāya → siriṁsapānaṁ vā siriṁsapattāya (bj, km, pts1ed); siriṁsapānaṁ siriṁsapattāya (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo jarāmaraṇassa, yadidaṁ jāti.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of old age and death, namely rebirth.

root-pli-ms: ‘Bhavapaccayā jātī’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā bhavapaccayā jāti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Continued existence is a condition for rebirth’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: bj8.84, cck10.73, dr10.67, ms7D_202, msdiv99, ndp7.46, pts-cs5, sc13, sya10.68

root-pli-ms: Bhavo ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no continued existence for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: kāmabhavo vā rūpabhavo vā arūpabhavo vā, sabbaso bhave asati bhavanirodhā api nu kho jāti paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, continued existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, or the formless realm. When there’s no continued existence at all, with the cessation of continued existence, would rebirth still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo jātiyā, yadidaṁ bhavo.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of rebirth, namely continued existence.

root-pli-ms: ‘Upādānapaccayā bhavo’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā upādānapaccayā bhavo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Grasping is a condition for continued existence’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.

root-pli-ms: Upādānañca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no grasping for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: kāmupādānaṁ vā diṭṭhupādānaṁ vā sīlabbatupādānaṁ vā attavādupādānaṁ vā, sabbaso upādāne asati upādānanirodhā api nu kho bhavo paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self. When there’s no grasping at all, with the cessation of grasping, would continued existence still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo bhavassa, yadidaṁ upādānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of continued existence, namely grasping.

root-pli-ms: ‘Taṇhāpaccayā upādānan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Craving is a condition for grasping’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: cck10.74, dr10.68, ms7D_204, msdiv101, pts-cs7, sc15

root-pli-ms: Taṇhā ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no craving for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: rūpataṇhā saddataṇhā gandhataṇhā rasataṇhā phoṭṭhabbataṇhā dhammataṇhā, sabbaso taṇhāya asati taṇhānirodhā api nu kho upādānaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts. When there’s no craving at all, with the cessation of craving, would grasping still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo upādānassa, yadidaṁ taṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of grasping, namely craving.

root-pli-ms: ‘Vedanāpaccayā taṇhā’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā vedanāpaccayā taṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Feeling is a condition for craving’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: csp1ed7.50, csp2ed7.50, mc10.52, ms7D_205, msdiv102, ndp7.47, pts-cs8, sc16, sya10.69, vri2.46

root-pli-ms: Vedanā ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no feeling for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: cakkhusamphassajā vedanā sotasamphassajā vedanā ghānasamphassajā vedanā jivhāsamphassajā vedanā kāyasamphassajā vedanā manosamphassajā vedanā, sabbaso vedanāya asati vedanānirodhā api nu kho taṇhā paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. When there’s no feeling at all, with the cessation of feeling, would craving still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo taṇhāya, yadidaṁ vedanā.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of craving, namely feeling.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho panetaṁ, ānanda, vedanaṁ paṭicca taṇhā, taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho.
translation-en-sujato: So it is, Ānanda, that feeling is a cause of craving. Craving is a cause of seeking. Seeking is a cause of gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause of assessing. Assessing is a cause of desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause of attachment. Attachment is a cause of possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause of stinginess. Stinginess is a cause of safeguarding.
reference: bj8.86, ms7D_206, msdiv103, pts-cs9, pts-vp-pli2.59, sc17

root-pli-ms: Ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.

root-pli-ms: ‘Ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavantī’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: cck10.75, dr10.69, ms7D_207, msdiv104, pts-cs10, sc18, sya10.70

root-pli-ms: Ārakkho ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso ārakkhe asati ārakkhanirodhā api nu kho daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhaveyyun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no safeguarding for anyone anywhere. When there’s no safeguarding at all, with the cessation of safeguarding, would those many bad, unskillful things still come to be?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādānaṁ anekesaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ sambhavāya yadidaṁ ārakkho.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition for the origination of those many bad, unskillful things, namely safeguarding.

root-pli-ms: ‘Macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Stinginess is a cause of safeguarding’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: csp1ed7.51, csp2ed7.51, mc10.53, ms7D_208, msdiv105, pts-cs11, sc19

root-pli-ms: Macchariyañca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso macchariye asati macchariyanirodhā api nu kho ārakkho paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no stinginess for anyone anywhere. When there’s no stinginess at all, with the cessation of stinginess, would safeguarding still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo ārakkhassa, yadidaṁ macchariyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of safeguarding, namely stinginess.

root-pli-ms: ‘Pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Possessiveness is a cause of stinginess’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: cck10.76, dr10.70, ms7D_209, msdiv106, ndp7.48, pts-cs12, pts-vp-pli2.60, sc20, vri2.47

root-pli-ms: Pariggaho ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso pariggahe asati pariggahanirodhā api nu kho macchariyaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no possessiveness for anyone anywhere. When there’s no possessiveness at all, with the cessation of possessiveness, would stinginess still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo macchariyassa, yadidaṁ pariggaho.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of stinginess, namely possessiveness.

root-pli-ms: ‘Ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Attachment is a cause of possessiveness’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: bj8.88, ms7D_210, msdiv107, pts-cs13, sc21, sya10.71

root-pli-ms: Ajjhosānañca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso ajjhosāne asati ajjhosānanirodhā api nu kho pariggaho paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no attachment for anyone anywhere. When there’s no attachment at all, with the cessation of attachment, would possessiveness still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo pariggahassa—yadidaṁ ajjhosānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of possessiveness, namely attachment.

root-pli-ms: ‘Chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Desire and lust is a cause of attachment’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.

root-pli-ms: Chandarāgo ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso chandarāge asati chandarāganirodhā api nu kho ajjhosānaṁ paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no desire and lust for anyone anywhere. When there’s no desire and lust at all, with the cessation of desire and lust, would attachment still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo ajjhosānassa, yadidaṁ chandarāgo.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of attachment, namely desire and lust.

root-pli-ms: ‘Vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Assessing is a cause of desire and lust’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: cck10.77, dr10.71, mc10.54, ms7D_212, msdiv109, pts-cs15, pts-vp-pli2.61, sc23

root-pli-ms: Vinicchayo ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso vinicchaye asati vinicchayanirodhā api nu kho chandarāgo paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no assessing for anyone anywhere. When there’s no assessing at all, with the cessation of assessing, would desire and lust still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo chandarāgassa, yadidaṁ vinicchayo.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of desire and lust, namely assessing.

root-pli-ms: ‘Lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Gaining material possessions is a cause of assessing’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: csp1ed7.52, csp2ed7.52, ms7D_213, msdiv110, ndp7.49, pts-cs16, sc24, sya10.72

root-pli-ms: Lābho ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso lābhe asati lābhanirodhā api nu kho vinicchayo paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no gaining of material possessions for anyone anywhere. When there’s no gaining of material possessions at all, with the cessation of gaining material possessions, would assessing still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo vinicchayassa, yadidaṁ lābho.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of assessing, namely the gaining of material possessions.

root-pli-ms: ‘Pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Seeking is a cause of gaining material possessions’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: dr10.72, ms7D_214, msdiv111, pts-cs17, sc25, vri2.48

root-pli-ms: Pariyesanā ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, sabbaso pariyesanāya asati pariyesanānirodhā api nu kho lābho paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no seeking for anyone anywhere. When there’s no seeking at all, with the cessation of seeking, would the gaining of material possessions still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo lābhassa, yadidaṁ pariyesanā.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of gaining material possessions, namely seeking.

root-pli-ms: ‘Taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Craving is a cause of seeking’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: bj8.90, cck10.78, ms7D_215, msdiv112, pts-cs18, sc26

root-pli-ms: Taṇhā ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no craving for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhā, sabbaso taṇhāya asati taṇhānirodhā api nu kho pariyesanā paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence. When there’s no craving at all, with the cessation of craving, would seeking still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo pariyesanāya, yadidaṁ taṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of seeking, namely craving.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, ānanda, ime dve dhammā dvayena vedanāya ekasamosaraṇā bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: And so, Ānanda, these two things are united by the two aspects of feeling.

root-pli-ms: ‘Phassapaccayā vedanā’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā phassapaccayā vedanā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Contact is a condition for feeling’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: csp1ed7.53, csp2ed7.53, mc10.55, ms7D_216, msdiv113, pts-cs19, pts-vp-pli2.62, sc27, sya10.73

root-pli-ms: Phasso ca hi, ānanda, nābhavissa sabbena sabbaṁ sabbathā sabbaṁ kassaci kimhici, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were totally and utterly no contact for anyone anywhere.

root-pli-ms: cakkhusamphasso sotasamphasso ghānasamphasso jivhāsamphasso kāyasamphasso manosamphasso, sabbaso phasse asati phassanirodhā api nu kho vedanā paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: That is, contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. When there’s no contact at all, with the cessation of contact, would feeling still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo vedanāya, yadidaṁ phasso.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of feeling, namely contact.

root-pli-ms: ‘Nāmarūpapaccayā phasso’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā nāmarūpapaccayā phasso.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Name and form are conditions for contact’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.

root-pli-ms: Yehi, ānanda, ākārehi yehi liṅgehi yehi nimittehi yehi uddesehi nāmakāyassa paññatti hoti, tesu ākāresu tesu liṅgesu tesu nimittesu tesu uddesesu asati api nu kho rūpakāye adhivacanasamphasso paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there were none of the features, attributes, signs, and details by which the category of mental phenomena is found. Would linguistic contact still be found in the category of physical phenomena?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yehi, ānanda, ākārehi yehi liṅgehi yehi nimittehi yehi uddesehi rūpakāyassa paññatti hoti, tesu ākāresu …pe… tesu uddesesu asati api nu kho nāmakāye paṭighasamphasso paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose there were none of the features, attributes, signs, and details by which the category of physical phenomena is found. Would impingement contact still be found in the category of mental phenomena?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yehi, ānanda, ākārehi …pe… yehi uddesehi nāmakāyassa ca rūpakāyassa ca paññatti hoti, tesu ākāresu …pe… tesu uddesesu asati api nu kho adhivacanasamphasso vā paṭighasamphasso vā paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose there were none of the features, attributes, signs, and details by which the categories of mental or physical phenomena are found. Would either linguistic contact or impingement contact still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yehi, ānanda, ākārehi …pe… yehi uddesehi nāmarūpassa paññatti hoti, tesu ākāresu …pe… tesu uddesesu asati api nu kho phasso paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose there were none of the features, attributes, signs, and details by which name and form are found. Would contact still be found?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo phassassa, yadidaṁ nāmarūpaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of contact, namely name and form.

root-pli-ms: ‘Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Consciousness is a condition for name and form’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: cck10.80, mc10.56, ms7D_218, msdiv115, ndp7.51, pts-cs21, pts-vp-pli2.63, sc29

root-pli-ms: Viññāṇañca hi, ānanda, mātukucchismiṁ na okkamissatha, api nu kho nāmarūpaṁ mātukucchismiṁ samuccissathā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: If consciousness were not conceived in the mother’s womb, would name and form coagulate there?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Viññāṇañca hi, ānanda, mātukucchismiṁ okkamitvā vokkamissatha, api nu kho nāmarūpaṁ itthattāya abhinibbattissathā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “If consciousness, after being conceived in the mother’s womb, were to be miscarried, would name and form be born into this state of existence?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Viññāṇañca hi, ānanda, daharasseva sato vocchijjissatha kumārakassa vā kumārikāya vā, api nu kho nāmarūpaṁ vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjissathā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “If the consciousness of a young boy or girl were to be cut off, would name and form achieve growth, increase, and maturity?”

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo nāmarūpassa—yadidaṁ viññāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of name and form, namely consciousness.

root-pli-ms: ‘Nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇan’ti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, tadānanda, imināpetaṁ pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Name and form are conditions for consciousness’—that’s what I said. And this is a way to understand how this is so.
reference: bj8.94, csp1ed7.54, csp2ed7.54, dr10.75, ms7D_219, msdiv116, pts-cs22, pts-vp-pli2.64, sc30, sya10.75

root-pli-ms: Viññāṇañca hi, ānanda, nāmarūpe patiṭṭhaṁ na labhissatha, api nu kho āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇaṁ dukkhasamudayasambhavo paññāyethā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: If consciousness were not to become established in name and form, would the coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future—be found?”
comment-en-sujato: The question here is how the synonyms samudaya and sambhava are to be treated. This phrase only occurs elsewhere at MN 138, where we have “āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hoti”. There, in his later rendering, BB has “origination of suffering—of birth, ageing, and death in the future”. Thus he maintains a rendering that essentially collapses the synonyms. RD has “be manifested that concatenation of rebirth, old age, death and the uprising of Ill”. MW has “an arising and coming to be”. Thanissaro has “coming-into-play of the origination”. Now, dukkhasamudaya occurs a couple hundred times elsewhere, invariably in the sense “origin of suffering”. I think we should take it here in the same sense, which would agree with the syntax of RD’s rendering. Comm has “Dukkhasamudayasambhavoti dukkharāsisambhavo”, which at least suggests that dukkhasamudaya is to some degree separate from the rest. At MN 138 it is “Jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavoti jātijarāmaraṇassa ceva avasesassa ca dukkhassa nibbatti na hotīti attho”. Here, nibbatti applies equally to jati, etc. and dukkha. Also, among the PTS vll. we have “dukkhasamudayo sambhavo”.

root-pli-ms: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātihānanda, eseva hetu etaṁ nidānaṁ esa samudayo esa paccayo viññāṇassa yadidaṁ nāmarūpaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s why this is the cause, source, origin, and condition of consciousness, namely name and form.

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, jāyetha vā jīyetha vā mīyetha vā cavetha vā upapajjetha vā.
translation-en-sujato: This is the extent to which one may be reborn, grow old, die, pass away, or reappear.

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā adhivacanapatho, ettāvatā niruttipatho, ettāvatā paññattipatho, ettāvatā paññāvacaraṁ, ettāvatā vaṭṭaṁ vattati itthattaṁ paññāpanāya yadidaṁ nāmarūpaṁ saha viññāṇena aññamaññapaccayatā pavattati.
translation-en-sujato: This is how far the scope of language, terminology, and description extends; how far the sphere of wisdom extends; how far the cycle of rebirths continues so that this state of existence is to be found; namely, name and form together with consciousness.
comment-en-sujato: ettāvatā vaṭṭaṁ vattati itthattaṁ paññāpanāya is tricky. Thanissaro has “the extent to which the cycle revolves for the manifesting (discernibility) of this world”. This is tempting, but elsewhere pannapanaya is as expected governed by the genitive in such constructions, eg rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya. BB here follows comm “namapannati”. But this phrase must surely be translated with eg SN 22.56 “Ye kevalino vaṭṭaṁ tesaṁ natthi paññāpanāya.” “For consummate ones, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.” There BB has “there is no round for describing them”. At MN 22 he has “there is no [future] round for manifestation”. By his comment on SN 22.56 he is more or less agnostic on these readings. In DN 15 he has “the round turns for describing this state of being”. But I find all these renderings borderline incomprehensible. aññamaññapaccayatā pavattati. is inserted from Comm.

root-pli-ms: 2. Attapaññatti
translation-en-sujato: 2. Describing the Self

root-pli-ms: Kittāvatā ca, ānanda, attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti?
translation-en-sujato: How do those who describe the self describe it?
reference: cck10.81, ms7D_220, msdiv117, pts-cs23, sc31, vri2.50

root-pli-ms: Rūpiṁ vā hi, ānanda, parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti:
translation-en-sujato: They describe it as physical and limited:

root-pli-ms: ‘rūpī me paritto attā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My self is physical and limited.’

root-pli-ms: Rūpiṁ vā hi, ānanda, anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti:
translation-en-sujato: Or they describe it as physical and infinite:

root-pli-ms: ‘rūpī me ananto attā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My self is physical and infinite.’

root-pli-ms: Arūpiṁ vā hi, ānanda, parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti:
translation-en-sujato: Or they describe it as formless and limited:

root-pli-ms: ‘arūpī me paritto attā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My self is formless and limited.’

root-pli-ms: Arūpiṁ vā hi, ānanda, anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti:
translation-en-sujato: Or they describe it as formless and infinite:

root-pli-ms: ‘arūpī me ananto attā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My self is formless and infinite.’

root-pli-ms: Tatrānanda, yo so rūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti.
translation-en-sujato: Now, take those who describe the self as physical and limited.
reference: dr10.76, mc10.57, ms7D_221, msdiv118, pts-cs24, sc32

root-pli-ms: Etarahi vā so rūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, tattha bhāviṁ vā so rūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, ‘atathaṁ vā pana santaṁ tathattāya upakappessāmī’ti iti vā panassa hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They describe the self as physical and limited in the present; or in some future life; or else they think: ‘Though it is not like that, I will ensure it is provided with what it needs to become like that.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ santaṁ kho, ānanda, rūpiṁ parittattānudiṭṭhi anusetīti iccālaṁ vacanāya.
translation-en-sujato: This being so, it’s appropriate to say that a view of self as physical and limited underlies them.

root-pli-ms: Tatrānanda, yo so rūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti.
translation-en-sujato: Now, take those who describe the self as physical and infinite …
reference: csp1ed7.55, csp2ed7.55, ms7D_222, ndp7.52, sc33, sya10.76

root-pli-ms: Etarahi vā so rūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, tattha bhāviṁ vā so rūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, ‘atathaṁ vā pana santaṁ tathattāya upakappessāmī’ti iti vā panassa hoti.

Tatrānanda, yo so arūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti.
translation-en-sujato: formless and limited …

root-pli-ms: Etarahi vā so arūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, tattha bhāviṁ vā so arūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, ‘atathaṁ vā pana santaṁ tathattāya upakappessāmī’ti iti vā panassa hoti.
Evaṁ santaṁ kho, ānanda, arūpiṁ parittattānudiṭṭhi anusetīti iccālaṁ vacanāya.
Tatrānanda, yo so arūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti.
translation-en-sujato: formless and infinite.

root-pli-ms: Etarahi vā so arūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, tattha bhāviṁ vā so arūpiṁ anantaṁ attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti, ‘atathaṁ vā pana santaṁ tathattāya upakappessāmī’ti iti vā panassa hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They describe the self as formless and infinite in the present; or in some future life; or else they think: ‘Though it is not like that, I will ensure it is provided with what it needs to become like that.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ santaṁ kho, ānanda, arūpiṁ anantattānudiṭṭhi anusetīti iccālaṁ vacanāya.
translation-en-sujato: This being so, it’s appropriate to say that a view of self as formless and infinite underlies them.

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā kho, ānanda, attānaṁ paññapento paññapeti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how those who describe the self describe it.

translation-en-sujato: formless and limited …

root-pli-ms: ‘arūpī me paritto attā’ti.
Arūpiṁ vā hi, ānanda, anantaṁ attānaṁ na paññapento na paññapeti:
translation-en-sujato: formless and infinite:

root-pli-ms: ‘arūpī me ananto attā’ti.

root-pli-ms: Etarahi vā so rūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ na paññapento na paññapeti, tattha bhāviṁ vā so rūpiṁ parittaṁ attānaṁ na paññapento na paññapeti, ‘atathaṁ vā pana santaṁ tathattāya upakappessāmī’ti iti vā panassa na hoti.
Evaṁ santaṁ kho, ānanda, rūpiṁ parittattānudiṭṭhi nānusetīti iccālaṁ vacanāya.
