root-pli-ms: “Kathaṁ pana, bhante ānanda, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjantī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But how do they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse?”

root-pli-ms: “Rañño, vāseṭṭhā, cakkavattissa sarīraṁ ahatena vatthena veṭhenti, ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena veṭhenti, vihatena kappāsena veṭhetvā ahatena vatthena veṭhenti.
translation-en-sujato: “They wrap a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse with unworn cloth, then with uncarded cotton, then again with unworn cloth.

root-pli-ms: Etena upāyena pañcahi yugasatehi rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṁ veṭhetvā āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjitvā sabbagandhānaṁ citakaṁ karitvā rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṁ jhāpenti.
translation-en-sujato: In this way they wrap the corpse with five hundred double-layers. Then they place it in an iron case filled with oil and close it up with another case. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of fragrant substances, they cremate the corpse.

root-pli-ms: Cātumahāpathe rañño cakkavattissa thūpaṁ karonti.
translation-en-sujato: They build a monument for the wheel-turning monarch at the crossroads.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, vāseṭṭhā, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho, vāseṭṭhā, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti, evaṁ tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjitabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Proceed in the same way with the Realized One’s corpse.

root-pli-ms: Cātumahāpathe tathāgatassa thūpo kātabbo.
translation-en-sujato: A monument for the Realized One is to be built at the crossroads.

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye mālaṁ vā gandhaṁ vā cuṇṇakaṁ vā āropessanti vā abhivādessanti vā cittaṁ vā pasādessanti, tesaṁ taṁ bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: When someone there lifts up garlands or fragrance or powder, or bows, or inspires confidence in their heart, that will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā purise āṇāpesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Mallas ordered their men,

root-pli-ms: “tena hi, bhaṇe, mallānaṁ vihataṁ kappāsaṁ sannipātethā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “So then, my men, collect uncarded cotton.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīraṁ ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena veṭhesuṁ, vihatena kappāsena veṭhetvā ahatena vatthena veṭhesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So the Mallas wrapped the Buddha’s corpse,

root-pli-ms: Etena upāyena pañcahi yugasatehi bhagavato sarīraṁ veṭhetvā āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjitvā sabbagandhānaṁ citakaṁ karitvā bhagavato sarīraṁ citakaṁ āropesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and placed it in an iron case filled with oil. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of fragrant substances, they lifted the corpse on to the pyre.

root-pli-ms: 38. Mahākassapattheravatthu
translation-en-sujato: 38. Mahākassapa’s Arrival

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākassapo pāvāya kusināraṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was traveling along the road from Pāvā to Kusinārā together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Then he left the road and sat at the root of a tree.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro ājīvako kusinārāya mandāravapupphaṁ gahetvā pāvaṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time a certain Ājīvaka ascetic had picked up a Flame Tree flower in Kusinārā and was traveling along the road to Pāvā.
comment-en-sujato: This is probably the ultimate source for the Zen story about the Buddha, Mahakassapa, and a flower.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho āyasmā mahākassapo taṁ ājīvakaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ, disvā taṁ ājīvakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Mahākassapa saw him coming off in the distance and said to him,

root-pli-ms: “apāvuso, amhākaṁ satthāraṁ jānāsī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Reverend, might you know about our Teacher?”

root-pli-ms: “Āmāvuso, jānāmi, ajja sattāhaparinibbuto samaṇo gotamo.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, reverend. Seven days ago the ascetic Gotama became fully extinguished.

root-pli-ms: Tato me idaṁ mandāravapupphaṁ gahitan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: From there I picked up this Flame Tree flower.”

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye te bhikkhū avītarāgā appekacce bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṁ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:
translation-en-sujato: Some of the mendicants there, with arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented,

root-pli-ms: “atikhippaṁ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṁ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṁ cakkhuṁ loke antarahito”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Too soon the Blessed One has become fully extinguished! Too soon the Holy One has become fully extinguished! Too soon the seer has vanished from the world!”

root-pli-ms: Ye pana te bhikkhū vītarāgā, te satā sampajānā adhivāsenti:
translation-en-sujato: But the mendicants who were free of desire endured, mindful and aware, thinking,

root-pli-ms: “aniccā saṅkhārā, taṁ kutettha labbhā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?”

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena subhaddo nāma vuddhapabbajito tassaṁ parisāyaṁ nisinno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time a monk named Subhadda, who had gone forth when old, was sitting in that assembly.
reference: csp1ed7.134, csp2ed7.134, ms7D_511, msdiv232, pts-cs6.20, pts-vp-pli2.163, sc258, sya10.189

root-pli-ms: Atha kho subhaddo vuddhapabbajito te bhikkhū etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to those mendicants,

root-pli-ms: “alaṁ, āvuso, mā socittha, mā paridevittha, sumuttā mayaṁ tena mahāsamaṇena. Upaddutā ca homa:
translation-en-sujato: “Enough, reverends, do not grieve or lament. We’re well rid of that Great Ascetic harassing us:
comment-en-sujato: The syntax here is obscure to me. Confusingly, both the former and latter parts of the sentence normally take the instrumental: “sumuttāhaṁ buddhena”; but also “tena homi upadduto”. The Sanskrit is much clearer: “muktāḥ smas tataḥ kaukṛtikān mahallāt || ya evam āha || idaṁ vo bhikṣavaḥ karaṇīyam idam akaraṇīyam”

root-pli-ms: ‘idaṁ vo kappati, idaṁ vo na kappatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is allowable for you; this is not allowable for you.’

root-pli-ms: Idāni pana mayaṁ yaṁ icchissāma, taṁ karissāma, yaṁ na icchissāma, na taṁ karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well, now we shall do what we want and not do what we don’t want.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Mahākassapa addressed the mendicants,

root-pli-ms: “alaṁ, āvuso, mā socittha, mā paridevittha.
translation-en-sujato: “Enough, reverends, do not grieve or lament.

root-pli-ms: Nanu etaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā paṭikacceva akkhātaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Did the Buddha not prepare us for this when he explained that

root-pli-ms: ‘sabbeheva piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo’.
translation-en-sujato: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kutettha, āvuso, labbhā. ‘Yaṁ taṁ jātaṁ bhūtaṁ saṅkhataṁ palokadhammaṁ, taṁ tathāgatassāpi sarīraṁ mā palujjī’ti, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to fall apart should not fall apart, even the Realized One’s body?”

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena cattāro mallapāmokkhā sīsaṁnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time four of the leading Mallas, having bathed their heads and dressed in unworn clothes, said,

root-pli-ms: “mayaṁ bhagavato citakaṁ āḷimpessāmā”ti na sakkonti āḷimpetuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “We shall light the Buddha’s funeral pyre.” But they were unable to do so.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The Mallas said to Anuruddha,

root-pli-ms: “ko nu kho, bhante anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo, yenime cattāro mallapāmokkhā sīsaṁnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
translation-en-sujato: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why these four Mallian leaders are unable to light the Buddha’s funeral pyre?”

root-pli-ms: ‘mayaṁ bhagavato citakaṁ āḷimpessāmā’ti na sakkonti āḷimpetun”ti?
“Aññathā kho, vāseṭṭhā, devatānaṁ adhippāyo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Vāseṭṭhas, the deities have a different plan.”

root-pli-ms: “Kathaṁ pana, bhante, devatānaṁ adhippāyo”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But sir, what is the deities’ plan?”

root-pli-ms: “Devatānaṁ kho, vāseṭṭhā, adhippāyo:
translation-en-sujato: “The deities’ plan is this:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ āyasmā mahākassapo pāvāya kusināraṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
translation-en-sujato: Venerable Mahākassapa is traveling along the road from Pāvā to Kusinārā together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants.

root-pli-ms: Na tāva bhagavato citako pajjalissati, yāvāyasmā mahākassapo bhagavato pāde sirasā na vandissatī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha’s funeral pyre shall not burn until he bows with his head at the Buddha’s feet.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā, bhante, devatānaṁ adhippāyo, tathā hotū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, let it be as the deities plan.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena kusinārā makuṭabandhanaṁ nāma mallānaṁ cetiyaṁ, yena bhagavato citako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṁ citakaṁ padakkhiṇaṁ katvā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Mahākassapa came to the Mallian shrine named Makuṭabandhana at Kusinārā and approached the Buddha’s funeral pyre. Arranging his robe over one shoulder and raising his joined palms, he respectfully circled the Buddha three times, keeping him on his right, and bowed with his head to the Buddha’s feet.

root-pli-ms: Tānipi kho pañcabhikkhusatāni ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṁ citakaṁ padakkhiṇaṁ katvā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And the five hundred mendicants did likewise.

root-pli-ms: Vandite ca panāyasmatā mahākassapena tehi ca pañcahi bhikkhusatehi sayameva bhagavato citako pajjali.
translation-en-sujato: And when Mahākassapa and the five hundred mendicants bowed the Buddha’s funeral pyre burst into flames all by itself.

root-pli-ms: Jhāyamānassa kho pana bhagavato sarīrassa yaṁ ahosi chavīti vā cammanti vā maṁsanti vā nhārūti vā lasikāti vā, tassa neva chārikā paññāyittha, na masi;
translation-en-sujato: And when the Buddha’s corpse was cremated no ash or soot was found from outer or inner skin, flesh, sinews, or synovial fluid.

root-pli-ms: sarīrāneva avasissiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Only the relics remained.
comment-en-sujato: Anandajoti has “neither charcoal was evident, nor was ash of the body left over.”, yielding a strikingly different sense. But the idiom as ountuated here is found in a number of places, including below. Further, sarīrāneva must be plural in accord with the use following: sarīrānaṁ. Previously, sarira (corpse) is singular only.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati, na masi;
translation-en-sujato: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.

root-pli-ms: evameva bhagavato sarīrassa jhāyamānassa yaṁ ahosi chavīti vā cammanti vā maṁsanti vā nhārūti vā lasikāti vā, tassa neva chārikā paññāyittha, na masi;
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when the Buddha’s corpse was cremated no ash or soot was found from outer or inner skin, flesh, sinews, or synovial fluid.

root-pli-ms: sarīrāneva avasissiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Only the relics remained.

root-pli-ms: Tesañca pañcannaṁ dussayugasatānaṁ dveva dussāni na ḍayhiṁsu yañca sabbaabbhantarimaṁ yañca bāhiraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And of those five hundred pairs of garments only two were not burnt: the innermost and the outermost.
variant-pli-ms: dveva dussāni na ḍayhiṁsu → dveva dussāni ḍayhiṁsu (si, sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Daḍḍhe ca kho pana bhagavato sarīre antalikkhā udakadhārā pātubhavitvā bhagavato citakaṁ nibbāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: But when the Buddha’s corpse was consumed the funeral pyre was extinguished by a stream of water that appeared in the sky,

root-pli-ms: Udakasālatopi abbhunnamitvā bhagavato citakaṁ nibbāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: by water dripping from the sal trees,

root-pli-ms: Kosinārakāpi mallā sabbagandhodakena bhagavato citakaṁ nibbāpesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and by the Mallas’ fragrant water.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīrāni sattāhaṁ sandhāgāre sattipañjaraṁ karitvā dhanupākāraṁ parikkhipāpetvā naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkariṁsu garuṁ kariṁsu mānesuṁ pūjesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Mallas made a cage of spears for the Buddha’s relics in the meeting hall and surrounded it with a buttress of bows. For seven days they honored, respected, revered, and venerated them with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances.

root-pli-ms: 39. Sarīradhātuvibhajana
translation-en-sujato: 39. Distributing the Relics

root-pli-ms: Assosi kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto:
translation-en-sujato: King Ajātasattu of Magadha heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesi:
translation-en-sujato: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo ahampi khattiyo, ahampi arahāmi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, ahampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so am I. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho vesālikā licchavī:
translation-en-sujato: The Licchavis of Vesālī also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho vesālikā licchavī kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho kapilavatthuvāsī sakyā:
translation-en-sujato: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho kapilavatthuvāsī sakyā kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā amhākaṁ ñātiseṭṭho, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was our foremost relative. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho allakappakā bulayo:
translation-en-sujato: The Bulas of Allakappa also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho allakappakā bulayo kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho rāmagāmakā koḷiyā:
translation-en-sujato: The Koḷiyans of Rāmagāma also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rāmagāmakā koḷiyā kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosi kho veṭṭhadīpako brāhmaṇo:
translation-en-sujato: The brahmin of Veṭhadīpa also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho veṭṭhadīpako brāhmaṇo kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesi:
translation-en-sujato: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo ahampismi brāhmaṇo, ahampi arahāmi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, ahampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and I am a brahmin. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho pāveyyakā mallā:
translation-en-sujato: The Mallas of Pāvā also heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, kosinārakā mallā te saṅghe gaṇe etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When they had spoken, the Mallas of Kusinārā said to those various groups:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā amhākaṁ gāmakkhette parinibbuto, na mayaṁ dassāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha became fully extinguished in our village district. We will not give away a share of his relics.”
comment-en-sujato: Anandajoti’s “we will not see a share” is incorrect. This is the future second plural of dadati.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, doṇo brāhmaṇo te saṅghe gaṇe etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then Doṇa the brahmin said to those various groups:

root-pli-ms: “Suṇantu bhonto mama ekavācaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “Hear, sirs, a single word from me.

root-pli-ms: Amhāka buddho ahu khantivādo;
translation-en-sujato: Our Buddha’s teaching was acceptance.

root-pli-ms: Na hi sādhu yaṁ uttamapuggalassa,
translation-en-sujato: It would not be good to fight over

root-pli-ms: Sarīrabhāge siyā sampahāro.
translation-en-sujato: a share of the supreme person’s relics.

root-pli-ms: Sabbeva bhonto sahitā samaggā,
translation-en-sujato: Let us make eight portions, good sirs,

root-pli-ms: Sammodamānā karomaṭṭhabhāge;
translation-en-sujato: rejoicing in unity and harmony.

root-pli-ms: Vitthārikā hontu disāsu thūpā,
translation-en-sujato: Let there be monuments far and wide,

root-pli-ms: Bahū janā cakkhumato pasannā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: so many folk may gain faith in the Seer!”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, tvaññeva bhagavato sarīrāni aṭṭhadhā samaṁ savibhattaṁ vibhajāhī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, brahmin, you yourself should fairly divide the Buddha’s relics in eight portions.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho doṇo brāhmaṇo tesaṁ saṅghānaṁ gaṇānaṁ paṭissutvā bhagavato sarīrāni aṭṭhadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhajitvā te saṅghe gaṇe etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sirs,” replied Doṇa to those various groups. He divided the relics as asked and said to them,

root-pli-ms: “imaṁ me bhonto tumbaṁ dadantu ahampi tumbassa thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sirs, please give me the urn, and I shall build a monument for it and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: Adaṁsu kho te doṇassa brāhmaṇassa tumbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So they gave Doṇa the urn.

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho pippalivaniyā moriyā:
translation-en-sujato: The Moras of Pippalivana heard

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira kusinārāyaṁ parinibbuto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that the Buddha had become fully extinguished at Kusinārā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho pippalivaniyā moriyā kosinārakānaṁ mallānaṁ dūtaṁ pāhesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

root-pli-ms: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgaṁ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

root-pli-ms: “Natthi bhagavato sarīrānaṁ bhāgo, vibhattāni bhagavato sarīrāni.
translation-en-sujato: “There is no portion of the Buddha’s relics left, they have already been portioned out.

root-pli-ms: Ito aṅgāraṁ harathā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Here, take the embers.”

root-pli-ms: Te tato aṅgāraṁ hariṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: So they took the embers.

root-pli-ms: 40. Dhātuthūpapūjā
translation-en-sujato: 40. Venerating the Relics

root-pli-ms: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājagahe bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha,

root-pli-ms: Vesālikāpi licchavī vesāliyaṁ bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Licchavis of Vesālī,

root-pli-ms: Kapilavatthuvāsīpi sakyā kapilavatthusmiṁ bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu,

root-pli-ms: Allakappakāpi bulayo allakappe bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Bulas of Allakappa,

root-pli-ms: Rāmagāmakāpi koḷiyā rāmagāme bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Koḷiyans of Rāmagāma,

root-pli-ms: Veṭṭhadīpakopi brāhmaṇo veṭṭhadīpe bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akāsi.
translation-en-sujato: the brahmin of Veṭhadīpa,

root-pli-ms: Pāveyyakāpi mallā pāvāyaṁ bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Mallas of Pāvā,

root-pli-ms: Kosinārakāpi mallā kusinārāyaṁ bhagavato sarīrānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the Mallas of Kusinārā,

root-pli-ms: Doṇopi brāhmaṇo tumbassa thūpañca mahañca akāsi.
translation-en-sujato: the brahmin Doṇa,

root-pli-ms: Pippalivaniyāpi moriyā pippalivane aṅgārānaṁ thūpañca mahañca akaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: and the Moriyas of Pippalivana built monuments for them and conducted memorial services.

root-pli-ms: Iti aṭṭha sarīrathūpā navamo tumbathūpo dasamo aṅgārathūpo.
translation-en-sujato: Thus there were eight monuments for the relics, a ninth for the urn, and a tenth for the embers.

root-pli-ms: Evametaṁ bhūtapubbanti.
translation-en-sujato: That is how it was in those days.

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhadoṇaṁ cakkhumato sarīraṁ,
translation-en-sujato: There were eight shares of the Seer’s relics.

root-pli-ms: Sattadoṇaṁ jambudīpe mahenti;
translation-en-sujato: Seven were worshipped throughout India.

root-pli-ms: Ekañca doṇaṁ purisavaruttamassa,
translation-en-sujato: But one share of the most excellent of men

root-pli-ms: Rāmagāme nāgarājā maheti.
translation-en-sujato: was worshipped in Rāmagāma by a dragon king.

root-pli-ms: Ekāhi dāṭhā tidivehi pūjitā,
translation-en-sujato: One tooth is venerated by the gods of the Three and Thirty,

root-pli-ms: Ekā pana gandhārapure mahīyati;
translation-en-sujato: and one is worshipped in the city of Gandhāra;

root-pli-ms: Kāliṅgarañño vijite punekaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: another one in the realm of the Kaliṅga King,

root-pli-ms: Ekaṁ pana nāgarājā maheti.
translation-en-sujato: and one is worshipped by a dragon king.

root-pli-ms: Tasseva tejena ayaṁ vasundharā,
translation-en-sujato: Through their glory this rich earth

root-pli-ms: Āyāgaseṭṭhehi mahī alaṅkatā;
translation-en-sujato: is adorned with the best of offerings.
comment-en-sujato: Anandajoti’s “like a most excellent hall” is incorrect. see CPD.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ imaṁ cakkhumato sarīraṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Thus the Seer’s corpse

root-pli-ms: Susakkataṁ sakkatasakkatehi.
translation-en-sujato: is well honored by the honorable.

root-pli-ms: Devindanāgindanarindapūjito,
translation-en-sujato: It’s venerated by lords of gods, dragons, and spirits;

root-pli-ms: Manussindaseṭṭhehi tatheva pūjito;
translation-en-sujato: and likewise venerated by the finest lords of men.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ vandatha pañjalikā labhitvā,
translation-en-sujato: Honor it with joined palms when you get the chance,
variant-pli-ms: Taṁ vandatha → taṁ taṁ vandatha (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: Buddho have kappasatehi dullabhoti.
translation-en-sujato: for a Buddha is rare even in a hundred eons.

root-pli-ms: Cattālīsa samā dantā,
translation-en-sujato: Altogether forty even teeth,

root-pli-ms: kesā lomā ca sabbaso;
translation-en-sujato: and the body hair and head hair,

root-pli-ms: Devā hariṁsu ekekaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: were carried off individually by gods

root-pli-ms: cakkavāḷaparamparāti.
translation-en-sujato: across the universe.

root-pli-ms: Mahāparinibbānasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ tatiyaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 17
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 17

root-pli-ms: Mahāsudassanasutta
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kusinārāyaṁ viharati upavattane mallānaṁ sālavane antarena yamakasālānaṁ parinibbānasamaye.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his final extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

root-pli-ms: “mā, bhante, bhagavā imasmiṁ khuddakanagarake ujjaṅgalanagarake sākhānagarake parinibbāyi.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, please don’t become fully extinguished in this little hamlet, this jungle hamlet, this branch hamlet.

root-pli-ms: Santi, bhante, aññāni mahānagarāni.
translation-en-sujato: There are other great cities such as

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—campā, rājagahaṁ, sāvatthi, sāketaṁ, kosambī, bārāṇasī;
translation-en-sujato: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, Sāketa, Kosambī, and Benares.

root-pli-ms: ettha bhagavā parinibbāyatu.
translation-en-sujato: Let the Buddha become fully extinguished there.

root-pli-ms: Ettha bahū khattiyamahāsālā brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatimahāsālā tathāgate abhippasannā, te tathāgatassa sarīrapūjaṁ karissantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: There are many well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders there who are devoted to the Buddha. They will perform the rites of venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”

root-pli-ms: “Mā hevaṁ, ānanda, avaca; mā hevaṁ, ānanda, avaca:
translation-en-sujato: “Don’t say that, Ānanda! Don’t say that

root-pli-ms: ‘khuddakanagarakaṁ ujjaṅgalanagarakaṁ sākhānagarakan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: this is a little hamlet, a jungle hamlet, a branch hamlet.

root-pli-ms: 1. Kusāvatīrājadhānī
translation-en-sujato: 1. The Capital City of Kusāvatī

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano nāma ahosi khattiyo muddhāvasitto cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time there was a king named Mahāsudassana whose dominion extended to all four sides, and who achieved stability in the country.

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa ayaṁ kusinārā kusāvatī nāma rājadhānī ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: His capital was this Kusinārā, which at the time was named Kusāvatī.

root-pli-ms: Puratthimena ca pacchimena ca dvādasayojanāni āyāmena, uttarena ca dakkhiṇena ca sattayojanāni vitthārena.
translation-en-sujato: It stretched for twelve leagues from east to west, and seven leagues from north to south.

root-pli-ms: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
translation-en-sujato: The royal capital of Kusāvatī was successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, devānaṁ āḷakamandā nāma rājadhānī iddhā ceva hoti phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇayakkhā ca subhikkhā ca;
translation-en-sujato: It was just like Āḷakamandā, the royal capital of the gods, which is successful, prosperous, populous, full of spirits, with plenty of food.
variant-pli-ms: iddhā ceva hoti phītā ca → iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca (sya-all, km); iddhā ceva phītā ca (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, kusāvatī rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī dasahi saddehi avivittā ahosi divā ceva rattiñca, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Kusāvatī was never free of ten sounds by day or night, namely:

root-pli-ms: hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena bherisaddena mudiṅgasaddena vīṇāsaddena gītasaddena saṅkhasaddena sammasaddena pāṇitāḷasaddena ‘asnātha pivatha khādathā’ti dasamena saddena.
translation-en-sujato: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry, ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.

root-pli-ms: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī sattahi pākārehi parikkhittā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Kusāvatī was encircled by seven ramparts:

root-pli-ms: Eko pākāro sovaṇṇamayo, eko rūpiyamayo, eko veḷuriyamayo, eko phalikamayo, eko lohitaṅkamayo, eko masāragallamayo, eko sabbaratanamayo.
translation-en-sujato: one made of gold, one made of silver, one made of beryl, one made of crystal, one made of ruby, one made of emerald, and one made of all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Kusāvatiyā, ānanda, rājadhāniyā catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ dvārāni ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It had four gates,

root-pli-ms: Ekaṁ dvāraṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ, ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ, ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ, ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Ekekasmiṁ dvāre satta satta esikā nikhātā ahesuṁ tiporisaṅgā tiporisanikhātā dvādasaporisā ubbedhena.
translation-en-sujato: At each gate there were seven pillars, three fathoms deep and four fathoms high,
comment-en-sujato: Readings vary. Skt SF 245 has saptapauruṣā ardhacaturthapauruṣāś ca nikhātā

root-pli-ms: Ekā esikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī sattahi tālapantīhi parikkhittā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: It was surrounded by seven rows of palm trees,

root-pli-ms: Ekā tālapanti sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa tālassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho ahosi, rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden palms had trunks of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa tālassa rūpiyamayo khandho ahosi, sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver palms had trunks of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa tālassa veḷuriyamayo khandho ahosi, phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The beryl palms had trunks of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa tālassa phalikamayo khandho ahosi, veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The crystal palms had trunks of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Lohitaṅkamayassa tālassa lohitaṅkamayo khandho ahosi, masāragallamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The ruby palms had trunks of ruby, and leaves and fruits of emerald.

root-pli-ms: Masāragallamayassa tālassa masāragallamayo khandho ahosi, lohitaṅkamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The emerald palms had trunks of emerald, and leaves and fruits of ruby.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaratanamayassa tālassa sabbaratanamayo khandho ahosi, sabbaratanamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The palms of all precious things had trunks of all precious things, and leaves and fruits of all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Tāsaṁ kho panānanda, tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
translation-en-sujato: When those rows of palm trees were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
translation-en-sujato: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, tāsaṁ tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṁ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tāsaṁ tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddena paricāresuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And any addicts, libertines, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.
comment-en-sujato: The sense isn’t that clear, but I think the idea is that they hung out listening to the sweet sounds rather than do worse things.

root-pli-ms: 2. Sattaratanasamannāgata
translation-en-sujato: 2. The Seven Treasures

root-pli-ms: 2.1. Cakkaratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.1. The Wheel Treasure

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano sattahi ratanehi samannāgato ahosi catūhi ca iddhīhi.
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana possessed seven treasures and four blessings.

root-pli-ms: Katamehi sattahi?
translation-en-sujato: What seven?

root-pli-ms: Idhānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa
translation-en-sujato: On a fifteenth day sabbath, King Mahāsudassana had bathed his head and gone upstairs in the stilt longhouse to observe the sabbath.
comment-en-sujato: On tenses: this is specific historical instance, so I use past tense. Where it is an abstract description of all wheel-truning monarchs, I use the present tense to denote an eternal or mythic present.

root-pli-ms: dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pāturahosi sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And the heavenly wheel-treasure appeared to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.

root-pli-ms: Disvā rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, the king thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ: “yassa rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pātubhavati sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ, so hoti rājā cakkavattī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Assaṁ nu kho ahaṁ rājā cakkavattī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā vāmena hatthena suvaṇṇabhiṅkāraṁ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena cakkaratanaṁ abbhukkiri:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana, rising from his seat and arranging his robe over one shoulder, took a ceremonial vase in his left hand and besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying:

root-pli-ms: ‘pavattatu bhavaṁ cakkaratanaṁ, abhivijinātu bhavaṁ cakkaratanan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṁ puratthimaṁ disaṁ pavatti, anvadeva rājā mahāsudassano saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya, yasmiṁ kho panānanda, padese cakkaratanaṁ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā mahāsudassano vāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: Then the wheel-treasure rolled towards the east. And the king followed it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
variant-pli-ms: pavatti → pavattati (sya-all, km, mr) | anvadeva → anudeva (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: Ye kho panānanda, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to him and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṁ te, mahārāja, sakaṁ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

root-pli-ms: Rājā mahāsudassano evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: The king said,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṁ na ādātabbaṁ, kāmesu micchā na caritabbā, musā na bhaṇitabbā, majjaṁ na pātabbaṁ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
comment-en-sujato: Bhunjati at MN 98 must relate to the problematic yathābhuttañca bhuñjatha in MN 129, DN 17, and DN 26. Most translators have, implausibly, “eat”. At MN 98, Norman has “enjoy” while BB has “govern”. But the meaning probably is similar to the archaic English form “use”, in the legal sense of “the benefit or profit of lands”. Thus yathābhuttañca bhuñjatha means “use as has been used”, i.e. “don’t increase taxes”.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho panānanda, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño mahāsudassanassa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter became his vassals.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṁ puratthimaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ pavatti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolled towards the south. …

root-pli-ms: dakkhiṇaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā pacchimaṁ disaṁ pavatti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the west. …

root-pli-ms: pacchimaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā uttaraṁ disaṁ pavatti, anvadeva rājā mahāsudassano saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions.

root-pli-ms: Yasmiṁ kho panānanda, padese cakkaratanaṁ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā mahāsudassano vāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho panānanda, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to him and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṁ te, mahārāja, sakaṁ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

root-pli-ms: Rājā mahāsudassano evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: The king said,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṁ na ādātabbaṁ, kāmesu micchā na caritabbā, musā na bhaṇitabbā, majjaṁ na pātabbaṁ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’

root-pli-ms: Ye kho panānanda, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño mahāsudassanassa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And so the opposing rulers of the northern quarter became his vassals.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, cakkaratanaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ abhivijinitvā kusāvatiṁ rājadhāniṁ paccāgantvā rañño mahāsudassanassa antepuradvāre atthakaraṇapamukhe akkhāhataṁ maññe aṭṭhāsi rañño mahāsudassanassa antepuraṁ upasobhayamānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returned to the royal capital of Kusāvatī. There it stood still by the gate to Mahāsudassana’s royal compound at the High Court as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
comment-en-sujato: I think upasobhayati means to literally light up.

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the wheel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.2. Hatthiratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.2. The Elephant Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa hatthiratanaṁ pāturahosi
translation-en-sujato: Next, the elephant-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: sabbaseto sattappatiṭṭho iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo uposatho nāma nāgarājā.
translation-en-sujato: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, touching the ground in seven places, a king of elephants named Sabbath.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ disvā rañño mahāsudassanassa cittaṁ pasīdi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing him, the king was impressed,

root-pli-ms: ‘bhaddakaṁ vata bho hatthiyānaṁ, sace damathaṁ upeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This would truly be a fine elephant vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, hatthiratanaṁ—seyyathāpi nāma gandhahatthājāniyo dīgharattaṁ suparidanto; evameva damathaṁ upagacchi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the elephant-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred elephant that had been tamed for a long time.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva hatthiratanaṁ vīmaṁsamāno pubbaṇhasamayaṁ abhiruhitvā samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ anuyāyitvā kusāvatiṁ rājadhāniṁ paccāgantvā pātarāsamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same elephant-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ hatthiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the elephant-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.3. Assaratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.3. The Horse-Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa assaratanaṁ pāturahosi
translation-en-sujato: Next, the horse-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: sabbaseto kāḷasīso muñjakeso iddhimā vehāsaṅgamo valāhako nāma assarājā.
translation-en-sujato: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, with head of black and mane like woven reeds, a royal steed named Thundercloud.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ disvā rañño mahāsudassanassa cittaṁ pasīdi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing him, the king was impressed,

root-pli-ms: ‘bhaddakaṁ vata bho assayānaṁ sace damathaṁ upeyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This would truly be a fine horse vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, assaratanaṁ seyyathāpi nāma bhaddo assājāniyo dīgharattaṁ suparidanto; evameva damathaṁ upagacchi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the horse-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred horse that had been tamed for a long time.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva assaratanaṁ vīmaṁsamāno pubbaṇhasamayaṁ abhiruhitvā samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ anuyāyitvā kusāvatiṁ rājadhāniṁ paccāgantvā pātarāsamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same horse-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ assaratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the horse-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.4. Maṇiratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.4. The Jewel Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa maṇiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Next, the jewel-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: So ahosi maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno.
translation-en-sujato: It was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.

root-pli-ms: Tassa kho panānanda, maṇiratanassa ābhā samantā yojanaṁ phuṭā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And the radiance of that jewel spread all-round for a league.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva maṇiratanaṁ vīmaṁsamāno caturaṅginiṁ senaṁ sannayhitvā maṇiṁ dhajaggaṁ āropetvā rattandhakāratimisāya pāyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same jewel-treasure, mobilized his army of four divisions and, with the jewel hoisted on his banner, set out in the dark of the night.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho panānanda, samantā gāmā ahesuṁ, te tenobhāsena kammante payojesuṁ divāti maññamānā.
translation-en-sujato: Then the villagers around them set off to work, thinking that it was day.

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ maṇiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the jewel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.5. Itthiratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.5. The Woman Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa itthiratanaṁ pāturahosi
translation-en-sujato: Next, the woman-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷikā nāccodātā atikkantā mānusivaṇṇaṁ appattā dibbavaṇṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: She was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. She was neither too tall nor too short; neither too thin nor too fat; neither too dark nor too light. She outdid human beauty without reaching divine beauty.
variant-pli-ms: mānusivaṇṇaṁ → mānusaṁ vaṇṇaṁ (bj, pts1ed); mānussīvaṇṇaṁ (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa evarūpo kāyasamphasso hoti, seyyathāpi nāma tūlapicuno vā kappāsapicuno vā.
translation-en-sujato: And her touch was like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok.

root-pli-ms: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa sīte uṇhāni gattāni honti, uṇhe sītāni.
translation-en-sujato: When it was cool her limbs were warm, and when it was warm her limbs were cool.

root-pli-ms: Tassa kho panānanda, itthiratanassa kāyato candanagandho vāyati, mukhato uppalagandho.
translation-en-sujato: The fragrance of sandal floated from her body, and lotus from her mouth.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho panānanda, itthiratanaṁ rañño mahāsudassanassa pubbuṭṭhāyinī ahosi pacchānipātinī kiṅkārapaṭissāvinī manāpacārinī piyavādinī.
translation-en-sujato: She got up before the king and went to bed after him, and was obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho panānanda, itthiratanaṁ rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ manasāpi no aticari, kuto pana kāyena.
translation-en-sujato: The woman-treasure did not betray the wheel-turning monarch even in thought, still less in deed.
variant-pli-ms: aticari → aticārī (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed); aticarī (mr)

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ itthiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the woman-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.6. Gahapatiratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.6. The Householder Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa gahapatiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Next, the householder-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: Tassa kammavipākajaṁ dibbacakkhu pāturahosi yena nidhiṁ passati sassāmikampi assāmikampi.
translation-en-sujato: The power of clairvoyance manifested in him as a result of past deeds, by which he sees hidden treasure, both owned and ownerless.

root-pli-ms: So rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: He approached the king and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘appossukko tvaṁ, deva, hohi, ahaṁ te dhanena dhanakaraṇīyaṁ karissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Relax, sire. I will take care of the treasury.’

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tameva gahapatiratanaṁ vīmaṁsamāno nāvaṁ abhiruhitvā majjhe gaṅgāya nadiyā sotaṁ ogāhitvā gahapatiratanaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same householder-treasure, boarded a boat and sailed to the middle of the Ganges river. Then he said to the householder-treasure,

root-pli-ms: ‘attho me, gahapati, hiraññasuvaṇṇenā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Householder, I need gold coins and bullion.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tena hi, mahārāja, ekaṁ tīraṁ nāvā upetū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, great king, draw the boat up to one shore.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Idheva me, gahapati, attho hiraññasuvaṇṇenā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s right here, householder, that I need gold coins and bullion.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, ānanda, gahapatiratanaṁ ubhohi hatthehi udakaṁ omasitvā pūraṁ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa kumbhiṁ uddharitvā rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then that householder-treasure, immersing both hands in the water, pulled up a pot full of gold coin and bullion, and said to the king,

root-pli-ms: ‘alamettāvatā, mahārāja, katamettāvatā, mahārāja, pūjitamettāvatā, mahārājā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is this sufficient, great king? Has enough been done, great king, enough offered?’

root-pli-ms: Rājā mahāsudassano evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: The king said,

root-pli-ms: ‘alamettāvatā, gahapati, katamettāvatā, gahapati, pūjitamettāvatā, gahapatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘That is sufficient, householder. Enough has been done, enough offered.’

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the householder-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 2.7. Pariṇāyakaratana
translation-en-sujato: 2.7. The Counselor Treasure

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa pariṇāyakaratanaṁ pāturahosi
translation-en-sujato: Next, the counselor-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
reference: bj8.276, csp1ed7.145, csp2ed7.145, ms7D_548, msdiv251, pts-cs1.18, sc14

root-pli-ms: paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upayāpetabbaṁ upayāpetuṁ, apayāpetabbaṁ apayāpetuṁ, ṭhapetabbaṁ ṭhapetuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: He was astute, competent, intelligent, and capable of getting the king to appoint who should be appointed, dismiss who should be dismissed, and retain who should be retained.

root-pli-ms: So rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: He approached the king and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘appossukko tvaṁ, deva, hohi, ahamanusāsissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Relax, sire. I shall issue instructions.’

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa evarūpaṁ pariṇāyakaratanaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Such is the counselor-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imehi sattahi ratanehi samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: These are the seven treasures possessed by King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 3. Catuiddhisamannāgata
translation-en-sujato: 3. The Four Blessings

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano catūhi iddhīhi samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana possessed four blessings.

root-pli-ms: Katamāhi catūhi iddhīhi?
translation-en-sujato: And what are the four blessings?

root-pli-ms: Idhānanda, rājā mahāsudassano abhirūpo ahosi dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato ativiya aññehi manussehi.
translation-en-sujato: He was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty, more so than other people.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya paṭhamāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first blessing.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dīghāyuko ahosi ciraṭṭhitiko ativiya aññehi manussehi.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, he was long-lived, more so than other people.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya dutiyāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second blessing.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano appābādho ahosi appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya ativiya aññehi manussehi.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, he was rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digested well, being neither too hot nor too cold, more so than other people.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya tatiyāya iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third blessing.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṁ piyo ahosi manāpo.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, he was as dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pitā puttānaṁ piyo hoti manāpo;
translation-en-sujato: as a father is to his children.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṁ piyo ahosi manāpo.
Raññopi, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa brāhmaṇagahapatikā piyā ahesuṁ manāpā.
translation-en-sujato: And the brahmins and householders were as dear to the king

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pitu puttā piyā honti manāpā;
translation-en-sujato: as children are to their father.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, raññopi mahāsudassanassa brāhmaṇagahapatikā piyā ahesuṁ manāpā.
Bhūtapubbaṁ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano caturaṅginiyā senāya uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana went with his army of four divisions to visit a park.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, brāhmaṇagahapatikā rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then the brahmins and householders went up to him and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ataramāno, deva, yāhi, yathā taṁ mayaṁ cirataraṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Slow down, Your Majesty, so we may see you longer!’

root-pli-ms: Rājāpi, ānanda, mahāsudassano sārathiṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: And the king addressed his charioteer,

root-pli-ms: ‘ataramāno, sārathi, rathaṁ pesehi, yathā ahaṁ brāhmaṇagahapatike cirataraṁ passeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Drive slowly, charioteer, so I can see the brahmins and householders longer!’

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāya catutthiyā iddhiyā samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth blessing.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano imāhi catūhi iddhīhi samannāgato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four blessings possessed by King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: 4. Dhammapāsādapokkharaṇī
translation-en-sujato: 4. Lotus Ponds in the Palace of Principle

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ imāsu tālantarikāsu dhanusate dhanusate pokkharaṇiyo māpeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I have lotus ponds built between the palms, at intervals of a hundred bow lengths?’

root-pli-ms: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsu tālantarikāsu dhanusate dhanusate pokkharaṇiyo.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Tā kho panānanda, pokkharaṇiyo catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ iṭṭhakāhi citā ahesuṁ—
translation-en-sujato: The lotus ponds were lined with tiles of four colors,

root-pli-ms: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Tāsu kho panānanda, pokkharaṇīsu cattāri cattāri sopānāni ahesuṁ catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: And four flights of stairs of four colors descended into each lotus pond,

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ sopānaṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Tā kho panānanda, pokkharaṇiyo dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhittā ahesuṁ ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
translation-en-sujato: Those lotus ponds were surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ imāsu pokkharaṇīsu evarūpaṁ mālaṁ ropāpeyyaṁ uppalaṁ padumaṁ kumudaṁ puṇḍarīkaṁ sabbotukaṁ sabbajanassa anāvaṭan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I plant flowers in the lotus ponds such as blue water lilies, and lotuses of pink, yellow, and white, blooming all year round, and accessible to the public?’

root-pli-ms: Ropāpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsu pokkharaṇīsu evarūpaṁ mālaṁ uppalaṁ padumaṁ kumudaṁ puṇḍarīkaṁ sabbotukaṁ sabbajanassa anāvaṭaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ imāsaṁ pokkharaṇīnaṁ tīre nhāpake purise ṭhapeyyaṁ, ye āgatāgataṁ janaṁ nhāpessantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I appoint bath attendants to help bathe the people who come to bathe in the lotus ponds?’

root-pli-ms: Ṭhapesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsaṁ pokkharaṇīnaṁ tīre nhāpake purise, ye āgatāgataṁ janaṁ nhāpesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ imāsaṁ pokkharaṇīnaṁ tīre evarūpaṁ dānaṁ paṭṭhapeyyaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I set up charities on the banks of the lotus ponds,

root-pli-ms: annaṁ annaṭṭhikassa, pānaṁ pānaṭṭhikassa, vatthaṁ vatthaṭṭhikassa, yānaṁ yānaṭṭhikassa, sayanaṁ sayanaṭṭhikassa, itthiṁ itthiṭṭhikassa, hiraññaṁ hiraññaṭṭhikassa, suvaṇṇaṁ suvaṇṇaṭṭhikassā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: so that those in need of food, drink, clothes, vehicles, beds, women, gold, or silver can get what they need?’
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW rather prudishly have “wives” for itthi, but more likely this was state-sponsored prostitution, which we know from the Vinaya was a thing.

root-pli-ms: Paṭṭhapesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tāsaṁ pokkharaṇīnaṁ tīre evarūpaṁ dānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: annaṁ annaṭṭhikassa, pānaṁ pānaṭṭhikassa, vatthaṁ vatthaṭṭhikassa, yānaṁ yānaṭṭhikassa, sayanaṁ sayanaṭṭhikassa, itthiṁ itthiṭṭhikassa, hiraññaṁ hiraññaṭṭhikassa, suvaṇṇaṁ suvaṇṇaṭṭhikassa.
Atha kho, ānanda, brāhmaṇagahapatikā pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ ādāya rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then the brahmins and householders came to the king bringing abundant wealth and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘idaṁ, deva, pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ devaññeva uddissa ābhataṁ, taṁ devo paṭiggaṇhatū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, this abundant wealth is specially for you alone; may Your Highness accept it!’
comment-en-sujato: As DN 5.

root-pli-ms: ‘Alaṁ, bho, mamapidaṁ pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṁ, tañca vo hotu, ito ca bhiyyo harathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s enough raised for me through regular taxes. Let this be for you; and here, take even more!’

root-pli-ms: Te raññā paṭikkhittā ekamantaṁ apakkamma evaṁ samacintesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the king turned them down, they withdrew to one side to think up a plan,

root-pli-ms: ‘na kho etaṁ amhākaṁ patirūpaṁ, yaṁ mayaṁ imāni sāpateyyāni punadeva sakāni gharāni paṭihareyyāma.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It wouldn’t be proper for us to take this abundant wealth back to our own homes.

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṁ māpeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we build a home for King Mahāsudassana?’

root-pli-ms: Te rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: They went up to the king and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘nivesanaṁ te, deva, māpessāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We shall have a home built for you, sire!’

root-pli-ms: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tuṇhībhāvena.
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana consented in silence.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, sakko devānamindo rañño mahāsudassanassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya vissakammaṁ devaputtaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: And then Sakka, lord of gods, knowing what the king was thinking, addressed the god Vissakamma,
reference: cck10.223, csp1ed7.148, csp2ed7.148, dr10.210, ms7D_562, msdiv256, pts-cs1.25, pts-vp-pli2.181, sc28, sya10.209

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma vissakamma, rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṁ māpehi dhammaṁ nāma pāsādan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, dear Vissakamma, build a palace named Principle as a home for King Mahāsudassana.’
comment-en-sujato: I think the point of naming the palace, etc. “Dhamma” is to emphasize, not rihteousness in terms of ethical scrupulousness, but the fact thet the king was subject to a higher set of natural laws, i.e. principles.

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṁsesu antarahito rañño mahāsudassanassa purato pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Vissakamma. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the gods of the Thirty-Three and appeared in front of King Mahāsudassana.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Vissakamma said to the king,

root-pli-ms: ‘nivesanaṁ te, deva, māpessāmi dhammaṁ nāma pāsādan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I shall build a palace named Principle as a home for you, sire.’

root-pli-ms: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano tuṇhībhāvena.
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana consented in silence.

root-pli-ms: Māpesi kho, ānanda, vissakammo devaputto rañño mahāsudassanassa nivesanaṁ dhammaṁ nāma pāsādaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And so that’s what Vissakamma did.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo puratthimena pacchimena ca yojanaṁ āyāmena ahosi. Uttarena dakkhiṇena ca aḍḍhayojanaṁ vitthārena.
translation-en-sujato: The Palace of Principle stretched for a league from east to west, and half a league from north to south.

root-pli-ms: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa tiporisaṁ uccatarena vatthu citaṁ ahosi catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ iṭṭhakāhi—
translation-en-sujato: It was lined with tiles of four colors, three fathoms high,

root-pli-ms: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa caturāsītithambhasahassāni ahesuṁ catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It had 84,000 pillars of four colors,

root-pli-ms: eko thambho sovaṇṇamayo, eko rūpiyamayo, eko veḷuriyamayo, eko phalikamayo.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ phalakehi santhato ahosi—
translation-en-sujato: It was covered with panels of four colors,

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ phalakaṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ, ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ, ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ, ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Dhammassa, ānanda, pāsādassa catuvīsati sopānāni ahesuṁ catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It had twenty-four staircases of four colors,

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ sopānaṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ, ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ, ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ, ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṁ veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Dhamme, ānanda, pāsāde caturāsītikūṭāgārasahassāni ahesuṁ catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It had 84,000 chambers of four colors,
comment-en-sujato: For this sense of kutagara, cp. MN 37

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ, ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ, ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ, ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamaye kūṭāgāre rūpiyamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, rūpiyamaye kūṭāgāre sovaṇṇamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, veḷuriyamaye kūṭāgāre dantamayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi, phalikamaye kūṭāgāre sāramayo pallaṅko paññatto ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: In each chamber a couch was spread: in the golden chamber a couch of silver; in the silver chamber a couch of beryl; in the beryl chamber a couch of ivory; in the crystal chamber a couch of hardwood.
comment-en-sujato: Not that the typical idiom for pannatte asane means to “spread out” a cloth, etc. for sitting. Here, it means that the hard couches were made up with cloths and cushions.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre rūpiyamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa rūpiyamayo khandho sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: At the door of the golden chamber stood a palm tree of silver, with trunk of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sovaṇṇamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho, rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: At the door of the silver chamber stood a palm tree of gold, with trunk of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre phalikamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa phalikamayo khandho, veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: At the door of the beryl chamber stood a palm tree of crystal, with trunk of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre veḷuriyamayo tālo ṭhito ahosi, tassa veḷuriyamayo khandho, phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: At the door of the crystal chamber stood a palm tree of beryl, with trunk of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sabbasovaṇṇamayaṁ tālavanaṁ māpeyyaṁ, yattha divāvihāraṁ nisīdissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I build a grove of golden palm trees at the door to the great foyer, where I can sit for the day?’

root-pli-ms: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre sabbasovaṇṇamayaṁ tālavanaṁ, yattha divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhitto ahosi, ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
translation-en-sujato: The Palace of Principle was surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ, sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo, ānanda, pāsādo dvīhi kiṅkiṇikajālehi parikkhitto ahosi—
translation-en-sujato: The Palace of Principle was surrounded by two nets of bells,

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ jālaṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold and silver.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa jālassa rūpiyamayā kiṅkiṇikā ahesuṁ, rūpiyamayassa jālassa sovaṇṇamayā kiṅkiṇikā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The golden net had bells of silver, and the silver net had bells of gold.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, kiṅkiṇikajālānaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
translation-en-sujato: When those nets of bells were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti, vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
translation-en-sujato: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, tesaṁ kiṅkiṇikajālānaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṁ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tesaṁ kiṅkiṇikajālānaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddena paricāresuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And any addicts, libertines, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.

root-pli-ms: Niṭṭhito kho panānanda, dhammo pāsādo duddikkho ahosi musati cakkhūni.
translation-en-sujato: When it was finished, the palace was hard to look at, dazzling to the eyes,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṁ abbhussakkamāno duddikkho hoti musati cakkhūni;
translation-en-sujato: like the sun rising in a clear and cloudless sky in the last month of the rainy season.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, dhammo pāsādo duddikkho ahosi musati cakkhūni.
Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ dhammassa pāsādassa purato dhammaṁ nāma pokkharaṇiṁ māpeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I build a lotus pond named Principle in front of the palace?’

root-pli-ms: Māpesi kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dhammassa pāsādassa purato dhammaṁ nāma pokkharaṇiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī puratthimena pacchimena ca yojanaṁ āyāmena ahosi, uttarena dakkhiṇena ca aḍḍhayojanaṁ vitthārena.
translation-en-sujato: The Lotus Pond of Principle stretched for a league from east to west, and half a league from north to south.

root-pli-ms: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ iṭṭhakāhi citā ahosi—
translation-en-sujato: It was lined with tiles of four colors,

root-pli-ms: ekā iṭṭhakā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Dhammāya, ānanda, pokkharaṇiyā catuvīsati sopānāni ahesuṁ catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It had twenty-four staircases of four colors,

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ sopānaṁ sovaṇṇamayaṁ, ekaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ, ekaṁ veḷuriyamayaṁ, ekaṁ phalikamayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa sopānassa sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden stairs had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa sopānassa rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver stairs had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa sopānassa veḷuriyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ phalikamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The beryl stairs had posts of beryl, and banisters and finials of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa sopānassa phalikamayā thambhā ahesuṁ veḷuriyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The crystal stairs had posts of crystal, and banisters and finials of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī dvīhi vedikāhi parikkhittā ahosi—ekā vedikā sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā.
translation-en-sujato: It was surrounded by two balustrades, made of gold and silver.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayāya vedikāya sovaṇṇamayā thambhā ahesuṁ rūpiyamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden balustrades had posts of gold, and banisters and finials of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayāya vedikāya rūpiyamayā thambhā ahesuṁ sovaṇṇamayā sūciyo ca uṇhīsañca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver balustrades had posts of silver, and banisters and finials of gold.

root-pli-ms: Dhammā, ānanda, pokkharaṇī sattahi tālapantīhi parikkhittā ahosi—
translation-en-sujato: It was surrounded by seven rows of palm trees,

root-pli-ms: ekā tālapanti sovaṇṇamayā, ekā rūpiyamayā, ekā veḷuriyamayā, ekā phalikamayā, ekā lohitaṅkamayā, ekā masāragallamayā, ekā sabbaratanamayā.
translation-en-sujato: made of gold, silver, beryl, crystal, ruby, emerald, and all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Sovaṇṇamayassa tālassa sovaṇṇamayo khandho ahosi rūpiyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The golden palms had trunks of gold, and leaves and fruits of silver.

root-pli-ms: Rūpiyamayassa tālassa rūpiyamayo khandho ahosi sovaṇṇamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The silver palms had trunks of silver, and leaves and fruits of gold.

root-pli-ms: Veḷuriyamayassa tālassa veḷuriyamayo khandho ahosi phalikamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The beryl palms had trunks of beryl, and leaves and fruits of crystal.

root-pli-ms: Phalikamayassa tālassa phalikamayo khandho ahosi veḷuriyamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The crystal palms had trunks of crystal, and leaves and fruits of beryl.

root-pli-ms: Lohitaṅkamayassa tālassa lohitaṅkamayo khandho ahosi masāragallamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The ruby palms had trunks of ruby, and leaves and fruits of emerald.

root-pli-ms: Masāragallamayassa tālassa masāragallamayo khandho ahosi lohitaṅkamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The emerald palms had trunks of emerald, and leaves and fruits of ruby.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaratanamayassa tālassa sabbaratanamayo khandho ahosi, sabbaratanamayāni pattāni ca phalāni ca.
translation-en-sujato: The palms of all precious things had trunks of all precious things, and leaves and fruits of all precious things.

root-pli-ms: Tāsaṁ kho panānanda, tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi, vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
translation-en-sujato: When those rows of palm trees were blown by the wind they sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭitāḷitassa sukusalehi samannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
translation-en-sujato: like a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, ānanda, tāsaṁ tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddo ahosi vaggu ca rajanīyo ca khamanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
Ye kho panānanda, tena samayena kusāvatiyā rājadhāniyā dhuttā ahesuṁ soṇḍā pipāsā, te tāsaṁ tālapantīnaṁ vāteritānaṁ saddena paricāresuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And any addicts, libertines, or drunkards in Kusāvatī at that time were entertained by that sound.

root-pli-ms: Niṭṭhite kho panānanda, dhamme pāsāde niṭṭhitāya dhammāya ca pokkharaṇiyā rājā mahāsudassano ‘ye tena samayena samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā’, te sabbakāmehi santappetvā dhammaṁ pāsādaṁ abhiruhi.
translation-en-sujato: When the palace and its lotus pond were finished, King Mahāsudassana served those who were reckoned as true ascetics and brahmins with all they desired. Then he ascended the Palace of Principle.
variant-pli-ms: pokkharaṇiyā rājā mahāsudassano ‘ye → ye kho panānanda (sya-all, km, pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro.
5. Jhānasampatti
translation-en-sujato: 5. Attaining Absorption

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,
reference: bj8.288, cck10.229, csp1ed7.152, csp2ed7.152, ms7D_575, msdiv260, ndp7.142, pts-cs2.1, pts-vp-pli2.186, sc40

root-pli-ms: ‘kissa nu kho me idaṁ kammassa phalaṁ kissa kammassa vipāko, yenāhaṁ etarahi evaṁmahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Of what deed of mine is this the fruit and result, that I am now so mighty and powerful?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘tiṇṇaṁ kho me idaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ tiṇṇaṁ kammānaṁ vipāko, yenāhaṁ etarahi evaṁmahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: ‘It is the fruit and result of three kinds of deeds:

root-pli-ms: dānassa damassa saṁyamassā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: giving, self-control, and restraint.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano yena mahāviyūhaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvāre ṭhito udānaṁ udānesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then he went to the great foyer, stood at the door, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
comment-en-sujato: This passage shows that the mahavihuya was some kind of structure at the entrance to the palace, hence lobby, foyer, etc.

root-pli-ms: ‘tiṭṭha, kāmavitakka, tiṭṭha, byāpādavitakka, tiṭṭha, vihiṁsāvitakka.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Stop here, sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts—

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā, kāmavitakka, ettāvatā, byāpādavitakka, ettāvatā, vihiṁsāvitakkā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: no further!’
