root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ pavisitvā sovaṇṇamaye pallaṅke nisinno vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then he entered the great foyer and sat on the golden couch. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, he entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsi, sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedesi, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And with the fading away of rapture, he entered and remained in the third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

root-pli-ms: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā nikkhamitvā sovaṇṇamayaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ pavisitvā rūpiyamaye pallaṅke nisinno
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana left the great foyer and entered the golden chamber, where he sat on the golden couch.
reference: csp1ed7.153, csp2ed7.153, ms7D_578, msdiv262, pts-cs2.4, pts-vp-pli2.187, sc43, sya10.216

root-pli-ms: mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā vihāsi. Tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: He meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way he spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around, to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …

root-pli-ms: muditāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: He meditated spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

root-pli-ms: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā vihāsi. Tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: He meditated spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: 6. Caturāsītinagarasahassādi
translation-en-sujato: 6. Of All Cities

root-pli-ms: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti nagarasahassāni ahesuṁ kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: King Mahāsudassana had 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni ahesuṁ dhammapāsādappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 palaces, with the Palace of Principle foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni ahesuṁ mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 chambers, with the great foyer foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni ahesuṁ sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 couches made of gold, silver, ivory, and hardwood. They were spread with woollen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.
comment-en-sujato: This segment breaks the expected pattern and is probably corrupt.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti nāgasahassāni ahesuṁ sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 bull elephants with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal bull elephant named Sabbath foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti assasahassāni ahesuṁ sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 horses with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the royal steed named Thundercloud foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti rathasahassāni ahesuṁ sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 chariots upholstered with the hide of lions, tigers, and leopards, and cream rugs, with gold adornments and banners, covered with gold netting, with the chariot named Triumph foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti maṇisahassāni ahesuṁ maṇiratanappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 jewels, with the jewel-treasure foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti itthisahassāni ahesuṁ subhaddādevippamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 women, with Queen Subhaddā foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni ahesuṁ gahapatiratanappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 householders, with the householder-treasure foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni ahesuṁ anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 aristocrat vassals, with the counselor-treasure foremost.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti dhenusahassāni ahesuṁ duhasandanāni kaṁsūpadhāraṇāni;
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 milk-cows with silken reins and bronze pails.
comment-en-sujato: Re. dukūlasandhanāni with vll. as noted here, BB at AN 9.20 has has “jute tethers”, noting “Mp does not provide a gloss and PED does not offer a useful definition under any of those readings. But in PED sandāna is defined as “cord, tether, fetter.””. At SN 22.96 he has “tethers of fine jute”. However, jute is a coarse cloth and can hardly be meant here. Skt dictionaries consistently say “Woven silk, silk-garment, a very fine garment in general”, which fits with our context. The only commentarial gloss I can find for this is that on SN 22.96, which says “Dukūlasandānānīti dukūlasantharāni”. But this yields the sense, “cover or mat”, which may be right, but is less than convincing. At MN 98, a reference missed by PTS dict, we have sandāna as part of the equipment of a horse that is cut by one who is freed. There I render as “reins”, and this seems apt here too.

root-pli-ms: caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni ahesuṁ khomasukhumānaṁ kappāsikasukhumānaṁ koseyyasukhumānaṁ kambalasukhumānaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: He had 8,400,000,000 fine cloths of linen, silk, wool, and cotton.

root-pli-ms: rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni ahesuṁ sāyaṁ pātaṁ bhattābhihāro abhihariyittha.
translation-en-sujato: He had 84,000 servings of food, which were presented to him as offerings in the morning and evening.
variant-pli-ms: rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa → idaṁ pāṭho pts1ed potthake natthi

root-pli-ms: Tena kho panānanda, samayena rañño mahāsudassanassa caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchanti.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time his 84,000 royal elephants came to attend on him in the morning and evening.
reference: cck10.232, csp1ed7.154, csp2ed7.154, dr10.218, ms7D_580, msdiv264, ndp7.144, pts-cs2.6, pts-vp-pli2.189, sc45

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then King Mahāsudassana thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘imāni kho me caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchanti, yannūna vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṁ dvecattālīsaṁ nāgasahassāni sakiṁ sakiṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgaccheyyun’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘What if instead half of the elephants took turns to attend on me at the end of each century?’
comment-en-sujato: Perhaps the oddest detail in an odd sutta. Maybe the sound of the elephants disturbed his meditation?

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano pariṇāyakaratanaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: He instructed the counselor-treasure to do this, and so it was done.

root-pli-ms: ‘imāni kho me, samma pariṇāyakaratana, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchanti, tena hi, samma pariṇāyakaratana, vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṁ dvecattālīsaṁ nāgasahassāni sakiṁ sakiṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchantū’ti.
‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, pariṇāyakaratanaṁ rañño mahāsudassanassa paccassosi.
Atha kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa aparena samayena vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena dvecattālīsaṁ dvecattālīsaṁ nāgasahassāni sakiṁ sakiṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgamaṁsu.
7. Subhaddādeviupasaṅkamana
translation-en-sujato: 7. The Visit of Queen Subhaddā

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddāya deviyā bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, Queen Subhaddā thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘ciraṁ diṭṭho kho me rājā mahāsudassano. Yannūnāhaṁ rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It is long since I have seen the king. Why don’t I go to see him?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī itthāgāraṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So the queen addressed the ladies of the harem,

root-pli-ms: ‘etha tumhe sīsāni nhāyatha pītāni vatthāni pārupatha.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, bathe your heads and dress in yellow.

root-pli-ms: Ciraṁ diṭṭho no rājā mahāsudassano, rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, ayye’ti kho, ānanda, itthāgāraṁ subhaddāya deviyā paṭissutvā sīsāni nhāyitvā pītāni vatthāni pārupitvā yena subhaddā devī tenupasaṅkami.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, ma’am,’ replied the ladies of the harem. They did as she asked and returned to the queen.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī pariṇāyakaratanaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the queen addressed the counselor-treasure,

root-pli-ms: ‘kappehi, samma pariṇāyakaratana, caturaṅginiṁ senaṁ, ciraṁ diṭṭho no rājā mahāsudassano, rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Dear counselor-treasure, please ready the army with four divisions. It is long since we saw the king, and we shall go to see him.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devī’ti kho, ānanda, pariṇāyakaratanaṁ subhaddāya deviyā paṭissutvā caturaṅginiṁ senaṁ kappāpetvā subhaddāya deviyā paṭivedesi:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, my queen,’ he replied, and did as he was asked. He informed the queen,

root-pli-ms: ‘kappitā kho, devi, caturaṅginī senā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘My queen, the army with four divisions is ready,

root-pli-ms: yassadāni kālaṁ maññasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: please go at your convenience.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī caturaṅginiyā senāya saddhiṁ itthāgārena yena dhammo pāsādo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṁ pāsādaṁ abhiruhitvā yena mahāviyūhaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ tenupasaṅkami.
translation-en-sujato: Then Queen Subhaddā together with the ladies of the harem went with the army to the Palace of Principle. She ascended the palace and went to the great foyer,

root-pli-ms: Upasaṅkamitvā mahāviyūhassa kūṭāgārassa dvārabāhaṁ ālambitvā aṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: where she stood leaning against a door-post.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano saddaṁ sutvā:
translation-en-sujato: Hearing them, the king thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ nu kho mahato viya janakāyassa saddo’ti mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā nikkhamanto addasa subhaddaṁ deviṁ dvārabāhaṁ ālambitvā ṭhitaṁ, disvāna subhaddaṁ deviṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: ‘What’s that, it sounds like a big crowd!’ Coming out of the foyer he saw Queen Subhaddā leaning against a door-post and said to her,

root-pli-ms: ‘ettheva, devi, tiṭṭha mā pāvisī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Please stay there, my queen, don’t enter in here.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then he addressed a certain man,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā sovaṇṇamayaṁ pallaṅkaṁ nīharitvā sabbasovaṇṇamaye tālavane paññapehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, mister, bring the golden couch from the great foyer and set it up in the golden palm grove.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, ānanda, so puriso rañño mahāsudassanassa paṭissutvā mahāviyūhā kūṭāgārā sovaṇṇamayaṁ pallaṅkaṁ nīharitvā sabbasovaṇṇamaye tālavane paññapesi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappesi pāde pādaṁ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
translation-en-sujato: The king laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddāya deviyā etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Queen Subhaddā thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘vippasannāni kho rañño mahāsudassanassa indriyāni, parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto, mā heva kho rājā mahāsudassano kālamakāsī’ti rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: ‘The king’s faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of his skin is pure and bright. Let him not pass away!’ She said to him,
comment-en-sujato: Oddly, both RD and MW read the aorist as past tense, when it is governed by mā.

root-pli-ms: ‘Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

root-pli-ms: Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
translation-en-sujato: Arouse desire for these! Take an interest in life!’

root-pli-ms: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: And she likewise urged the king to live on by taking an interest in all his possessions as described above.

root-pli-ms: Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.

Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi, jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.

Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti maṇisahassāni maṇiratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti itthisahassāni itthiratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni gahapatiratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti dhenusahassāni duhasandanāni kaṁsūpadhāraṇāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni khomasukhumānaṁ kappāsikasukhumānaṁ koseyyasukhumānaṁ kambalasukhumānaṁ.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi, jīvite apekkhaṁ karohi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ bhattābhihāro abhihariyati.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ janehi jīvite apekkhaṁ karohī’ti.
Evaṁ vutte, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano subhaddaṁ deviṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the queen had spoken, the king said to her,

root-pli-ms: ‘Dīgharattaṁ kho maṁ tvaṁ, devi, iṭṭhehi kantehi piyehi manāpehi samudācarittha;
translation-en-sujato: ‘For a long time, my queen, you have spoken to me with loving, desirable, pleasant, and agreeable words.

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana maṁ tvaṁ pacchime kāle aniṭṭhehi akantehi appiyehi amanāpehi samudācarasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And yet in my final hour, your words are undesirable, unpleasant, and disagreeable!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kathaṁ carahi taṁ, deva, samudācarāmī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Then how exactly, Your Majesty, am I to speak to you?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ kho maṁ tvaṁ, devi, samudācara:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Like this, my queen:

root-pli-ms: “sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṁ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.
comment-en-sujato: Cp AN 6.16, where this advice is given by Nakulamata.

root-pli-ms: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

root-pli-ms: Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!”’

root-pli-ms: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: And so on for all the king’s possessions.

root-pli-ms: Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.

Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.

Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.

Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti maṇisahassāni maṇiratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti itthisahassāni subhaddādevippamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni gahapatiratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti dhenusahassāni duhasandanāni kaṁsūpadhāraṇāni.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni khomasukhumānaṁ kappāsikasukhumānaṁ koseyyasukhumānaṁ kambalasukhumānaṁ.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ bhattābhihāro abhihariyati.
Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsī”’ti.
Evaṁ vutte, ānanda, subhaddā devī parodi assūni pavattesi.
translation-en-sujato: When the king had spoken, Queen Subhaddā cried and burst out in tears.
comment-en-sujato: Just in case anyone thinks this is sexist, note that this is the only time in the nikayas that this phrase is used of a woman.
reference: bj8.298, csp1ed7.158, csp2ed7.158, ms7D_586, msdiv268, pts-cs2.12, sc51

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, subhaddā devī assūni puñchitvā rājānaṁ mahāsudassanaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Wiping away her tears, the queen said to the king:
variant-pli-ms: puñchitvā → pamajjitvā (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed); puñjitvā (mr)

root-pli-ms: ‘Sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṁ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.

translation-en-sujato: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

root-pli-ms: Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!’

root-pli-ms: Imāni te, deva, caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: And she continued, listing all the king’s possessions.

Ettha, deva, chandaṁ pajaha jīvite apekkhaṁ mākāsi.

8. Brahmalokūpagama
translation-en-sujato: 8. Rebirth in the Brahmā Realm

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano na cirasseva kālamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Not long after that, King Mahāsudassana passed away.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā manuññaṁ bhojanaṁ bhuttāvissa bhattasammado hoti; evameva kho, ānanda, rañño mahāsudassanassa māraṇantikā vedanā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And the feeling he had close to death was like a householder or their child falling asleep after eating a delectable meal.

root-pli-ms: Kālaṅkato ca, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano sugatiṁ brahmalokaṁ upapajji.
translation-en-sujato: When he passed away King Mahāsudassana was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Rājā, ānanda, mahāsudassano caturāsīti vassasahassāni kumārakīḷaṁ kīḷi.
translation-en-sujato: Ānanda, King Mahāsudassana played children’s games for 84,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Caturāsīti vassasahassāni oparajjaṁ kāresi.
translation-en-sujato: He ruled as viceroy for 84,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Caturāsīti vassasahassāni rajjaṁ kāresi.
translation-en-sujato: He ruled as king for 84,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Caturāsīti vassasahassāni gihibhūto dhamme pāsāde brahmacariyaṁ cari.
translation-en-sujato: He led the spiritual life as a layman in the Palace of Principle for 84,000 years.
variant-pli-ms: brahmacariyaṁ cari → brahmacariyaṁ ācari (sya-all, km); brahmacariyamacari (mr) | gihibhūto → gihībhūto (bj, pts1ed); gīhibhūto (km)

root-pli-ms: So cattāro brahmavihāre bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā brahmalokūpago ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And having developed the four Brahmā meditations, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho panānanda, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Now, Ānanda, you might think:
reference: cck10.241, csp1ed7.160, csp2ed7.160, dr10.226, ms7D_589, msdiv270, pts-cs2.14, pts-vp-pli2.197, sc54, sya10.226

root-pli-ms: ‘añño nūna tena samayena rājā mahāsudassano ahosī’ti,
translation-en-sujato: ‘Surely King Mahāsudassana must have been someone else at that time?’

root-pli-ms: na kho panetaṁ, ānanda, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ. Ahaṁ tena samayena rājā mahāsudassano ahosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like that. I myself was King Mahāsudassana at that time.

root-pli-ms: Mama tāni caturāsīti nagarasahassāni kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti pāsādasahassāni dhammapāsādappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassāni mahāviyūhakūṭāgārappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassāni sovaṇṇamayāni rūpiyamayāni dantamayāni sāramayāni gonakatthatāni paṭikatthatāni paṭalikatthatāni kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇāni sauttaracchadāni ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni, mama tāni caturāsīti nāgasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni uposathanāgarājappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti assasahassāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni valāhakaassarājappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti rathasahassāni sīhacammaparivārāni byagghacammaparivārāni dīpicammaparivārāni paṇḍukambalaparivārāni sovaṇṇālaṅkārāni sovaṇṇadhajāni hemajālapaṭicchannāni vejayantarathappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti maṇisahassāni maṇiratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti itthisahassāni subhaddādevippamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti gahapatisahassāni gahapatiratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti khattiyasahassāni anuyantāni pariṇāyakaratanappamukhāni, mama tāni caturāsīti dhenusahassāni duhasandanāni kaṁsūpadhāraṇāni, mama tāni caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassāni khomasukhumānaṁ kappāsikasukhumānaṁ koseyyasukhumānaṁ kambalasukhumānaṁ, mama tāni caturāsīti thālipākasahassāni sāyaṁ pātaṁ bhattābhihāro abhihariyittha.
translation-en-sujato: Mine were the 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost. And mine were all the other possessions.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsītinagarasahassānaṁ ekaññeva taṁ nagaraṁ hoti, yaṁ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṁ kusāvatī rājadhānī.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 cities, I only stayed in one, the capital Kusāvatī.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti pāsādasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so pāsādo hoti, yaṁ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṁ dhammo pāsādo.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 mansions, I only dwelt in one, the Palace of Principle.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti kūṭāgārasahassānaṁ ekaññeva taṁ kūṭāgāraṁ hoti, yaṁ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi yadidaṁ mahāviyūhaṁ kūṭāgāraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 chambers, I only dwelt in the great foyer.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti pallaṅkasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so pallaṅko hoti, yaṁ tena samayena paribhuñjāmi yadidaṁ sovaṇṇamayo vā rūpiyamayo vā dantamayo vā sāramayo vā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 couches, I only used one, made of gold or silver or ivory or heartwood.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti nāgasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so nāgo hoti, yaṁ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṁ uposatho nāgarājā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 bull elephants, I only rode one, the royal bull elephant named Sabbath.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti assasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so asso hoti, yaṁ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṁ valāhako assarājā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 horses, I only rode one, the royal horse named Thundercloud.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti rathasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so ratho hoti, yaṁ tena samayena abhiruhāmi yadidaṁ vejayantaratho.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 chariots, I only rode one, the chariot named Triumph.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti itthisahassānaṁ ekāyeva sā itthī hoti, yā tena samayena paccupaṭṭhāti khattiyānī vā vessinī vā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 women, I was only served by one, a maiden of the aristocratic or merchant classes.
comment-en-sujato: https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/is-there-such-a-word-as-velamika/2952

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti vatthakoṭisahassānaṁ ekaṁyeva taṁ dussayugaṁ hoti, yaṁ tena samayena paridahāmi khomasukhumaṁ vā kappāsikasukhumaṁ vā koseyyasukhumaṁ vā kambalasukhumaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 8,400,000,000 cloths, I only wore one pair, made of fine linen, cotton, silk, or wool.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ kho panānanda, caturāsīti thālipākasahassānaṁ ekoyeva so thālipāko hoti, yato nāḷikodanaparamaṁ bhuñjāmi tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Of those 84,000 servings of food, I only had one, eating at most a serving of rice and suitable sauce.

root-pli-ms: Passānanda, sabbete saṅkhārā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā.
translation-en-sujato: See, Ānanda! All those conditioned phenomena have passed, ceased, and perished.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ aniccā kho, ānanda, saṅkhārā;
translation-en-sujato: So impermanent are conditions,

root-pli-ms: evaṁ addhuvā kho, ānanda, saṅkhārā;
translation-en-sujato: so unstable are conditions,

root-pli-ms: evaṁ anassāsikā kho, ānanda, saṅkhārā.
translation-en-sujato: so unreliable are conditions.

root-pli-ms: Yāvañcidaṁ, ānanda, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṁ, alaṁ virajjituṁ, alaṁ vimuccituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.

root-pli-ms: Chakkhattuṁ kho panāhaṁ, ānanda, abhijānāmi imasmiṁ padese sarīraṁ nikkhipitaṁ, tañca kho rājāva samāno cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato, ayaṁ sattamo sarīranikkhepo.
translation-en-sujato: Six times, Ānanda, I recall having laid down my body at this place. And the seventh time was as a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, at which time my dominion extended to all four sides, I achieved stability in the country, and I possessed the seven treasures.

root-pli-ms: Na kho panāhaṁ, ānanda, taṁ padesaṁ samanupassāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yattha tathāgato aṭṭhamaṁ sarīraṁ nikkhipeyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But Ānanda, I do not see any place in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans where the Realized One would lay down his body for the eighth time.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

root-pli-ms: “Aniccā vata saṅkhārā,
translation-en-sujato: “Oh! Conditions are impermanent,

root-pli-ms: uppādavayadhammino;
translation-en-sujato: their nature is to rise and fall;

root-pli-ms: Uppajjitvā nirujjhanti,
translation-en-sujato: having arisen, they cease;

root-pli-ms: tesaṁ vūpasamo sukho”ti.
translation-en-sujato: their stilling is true bliss.”

root-pli-ms: Mahāsudassanasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ catutthaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 18
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 18

root-pli-ms: Janavasabhasutta
translation-en-sujato: With Janavasabha

root-pli-ms: 1. Nātikiyādibyākaraṇa
translation-en-sujato: 1. Declaring the Rebirths of People From Nādika and Elsewhere

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying at Nādika in the brick house.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā parito parito janapadesu paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti kāsikosalesu vajjimallesu cetivaṁsesu kurupañcālesu majjhasūrasenesu:
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the Buddha was explaining the rebirths of devotees all over the nations; the Kāsis and Kosalans, Vajjis and Mallas, Cetīs and Vaṁsas, Kurus and Pañcālas, Macchas and Sūrasenas:

root-pli-ms: “asu amutra upapanno, asu amutra upapanno.
translation-en-sujato: “This one was reborn here, while that one was reborn there.

root-pli-ms: Paropaññāsa nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
translation-en-sujato: Over fifty devotees in Nādika have passed away having ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

root-pli-ms: Sādhikā navuti nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
translation-en-sujato: More than ninety devotees in Nādika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Sātirekāni pañcasatāni nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: In excess of five hundred devotees in Nādika have passed away having ended three fetters. They’re stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho nātikiyā paricārakā:
translation-en-sujato: When the devotees of Nādika heard about the Buddha’s

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira parito parito janapadesu paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti kāsikosalesu vajjimallesu cetivaṁsesu kurupañcālesu majjhasūrasenesu:
‘asu amutra upapanno, asu amutra upapanno.
Paropaññāsa nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
Sādhikā navuti nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
Sātirekāni pañcasatāni nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā’”ti.
Tena ca nātikiyā paricārakā attamanā ahesuṁ pamuditā pītisomanassajātā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā.
translation-en-sujato: answers to those questions, they were uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Assosi kho āyasmā ānando:
translation-en-sujato: Venerable Ānanda heard of the Buddha’s statements and the Nādikans’ happiness.

root-pli-ms: “bhagavā kira parito parito janapadesu paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti kāsikosalesu vajjimallesu cetivaṁsesu kurupañcālesu majjhasūrasenesu:
‘asu amutra upapanno, asu amutra upapanno.
Paropaññāsa nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
Sādhikā navuti nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
Sātirekāni pañcasatāni nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā’ti.
Tena ca nātikiyā paricārakā attamanā ahesuṁ pamuditā pītisomanassajātā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
2. Ānandaparikathā
translation-en-sujato: 2. Ānanda’s Suggestion

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmato ānandassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Ānanda thought,

root-pli-ms: “ime kho panāpi ahesuṁ māgadhakā paricārakā bahū ceva rattaññū ca abbhatītā kālaṅkatā.
translation-en-sujato: “But there were also Magadhan devotees—many, and of long standing too—who have passed away.
variant-pli-ms: kho panāpi → tena kho panāpi (sya-all); te kho panapi (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Suññā maññe aṅgamagadhā aṅgamāgadhakehi paricārakehi abbhatītehi kālaṅkatehi.
translation-en-sujato: You’d think that Aṅga and Magadha were empty of devotees who have passed away!

root-pli-ms: Te kho panāpi ahesuṁ buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārino.
translation-en-sujato: But they too had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Te abbhatītā kālaṅkatā bhagavatā abyākatā;
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha hasn’t declared their passing.

root-pli-ms: tesampissa sādhu veyyākaraṇaṁ, bahujano pasīdeyya, tato gaccheyya sugatiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It would be good to do so, for many people would gain confidence, and so be reborn in a good place.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho panāpi ahosi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro dhammiko dhammarājā hito brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṁ negamānañceva jānapadānañca.
translation-en-sujato: That King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha was a just and principled king who benefited the brahmins and householders of town and country.

root-pli-ms: Apissudaṁ manussā kittayamānarūpā viharanti:
translation-en-sujato: People still sing his praises:

root-pli-ms: ‘evaṁ no so dhammiko dhammarājā sukhāpetvā kālaṅkato, evaṁ mayaṁ tassa dhammikassa dhammarañño vijite phāsu viharimhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘That just and principled king, who made us so happy, has passed away. Life was good under his dominion.’

root-pli-ms: So kho panāpi ahosi buddhe pasanno dhamme pasanno saṅghe pasanno sīlesu paripūrakārī.
translation-en-sujato: He too had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled his ethics.

root-pli-ms: Apissudaṁ manussā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: People say:

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva maraṇakālāpi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro bhagavantaṁ kittayamānarūpo kālaṅkato’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Until his dying day, King Bimbisāra sang the Buddha’s praises!’

root-pli-ms: So abbhatīto kālaṅkato bhagavatā abyākato.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha hasn’t declared his passing.

root-pli-ms: Tassapissa sādhu veyyākaraṇaṁ bahujano pasīdeyya, tato gaccheyya sugatiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It would be good to do so, for many people would gain confidence, and so be reborn in a good place.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavato kho pana sambodhi magadhesu.
translation-en-sujato: Besides, the Buddha was awakened in Magadha;

root-pli-ms: Yattha kho pana bhagavato sambodhi magadhesu, kathaṁ tatra bhagavā māgadhake paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu na byākareyya.
translation-en-sujato: so why hasn’t he declared the rebirth of the Magadhan devotees?

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā ce kho pana māgadhake paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu na byākareyya, dīnamanā tenassu māgadhakā paricārakā;
translation-en-sujato: If he fails to do so, they will be dejected.”

root-pli-ms: yena kho panassu dīnamanā māgadhakā paricārakā kathaṁ te bhagavā na byākareyyā”ti?

Idamāyasmā ānando māgadhake paricārake ārabbha eko raho anuvicintetvā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṁ paccuṭṭhāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: After pondering the fate of the Magadhan devotees alone in private, Ānanda rose at the crack of dawn and went to see the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his concerns, finishing by saying,

root-pli-ms: “sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante:
‘bhagavā kira parito parito janapadesu paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu byākaroti kāsikosalesu vajjimallesu cetivaṁsesu kurupañcālesu majjhasūrasenesu:
“asu amutra upapanno, asu amutra upapanno.
Paropaññāsa nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
Sādhikā navuti nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
Sātirekāni pañcasatāni nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇāti.
Tena ca nātikiyā paricārakā attamanā ahesuṁ pamuditā pītisomanassajātā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”’ti.
Ime kho panāpi, bhante, ahesuṁ māgadhakā paricārakā bahū ceva rattaññū ca abbhatītā kālaṅkatā.
Suññā maññe aṅgamagadhā aṅgamāgadhakehi paricārakehi abbhatītehi kālaṅkatehi.
Te kho panāpi, bhante, ahesuṁ buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārino, te abbhatītā kālaṅkatā bhagavatā abyākatā.
Tesampissa sādhu veyyākaraṇaṁ, bahujano pasīdeyya, tato gaccheyya sugatiṁ.
Ayaṁ kho panāpi, bhante, ahosi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro dhammiko dhammarājā hito brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṁ negamānañceva jānapadānañca.
Apissudaṁ manussā kittayamānarūpā viharanti:
‘evaṁ no so dhammiko dhammarājā sukhāpetvā kālaṅkato.
Evaṁ mayaṁ tassa dhammikassa dhammarañño vijite phāsu viharimhā’ti.
So kho panāpi, bhante, ahosi buddhe pasanno dhamme pasanno saṅghe pasanno sīlesu paripūrakārī.
Apissudaṁ manussā evamāhaṁsu:
‘yāva maraṇakālāpi rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro bhagavantaṁ kittayamānarūpo kālaṅkato’ti.
So abbhatīto kālaṅkato bhagavatā abyākato;
tassapissa sādhu veyyākaraṇaṁ, bahujano pasīdeyya, tato gaccheyya sugatiṁ.
Bhagavato kho pana, bhante, sambodhi magadhesu.
Yattha kho pana, bhante, bhagavato sambodhi magadhesu, kathaṁ tatra bhagavā māgadhake paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu na byākareyya?
Bhagavā ce kho pana, bhante, māgadhake paricārake abbhatīte kālaṅkate upapattīsu na byākareyya, dīnamanā tenassu māgadhakā paricārakā;
yena kho panassu dīnamanā māgadhakā paricārakā kathaṁ te bhagavā na byākareyyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Why hasn’t the Buddha declared the rebirth of the Magadhan devotees? If he fails to do so, they will be dejected.”

root-pli-ms: Idamāyasmā ānando māgadhake paricārake ārabbha bhagavato sammukhā parikathaṁ katvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Ānanda, after making this suggestion regarding the Magadhan devotees, got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
comment-en-sujato: The term parikatha is unusual, and must convey some nuance of the speech. In the Vinaya it means a “hint”, while it may also be taken as “round-about talk”. I think “suggestion” works well here.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante āyasmante ānande pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya nātikaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
translation-en-sujato: Soon after Ānanda had left, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Nādika for alms.
reference: cck10.250, csp1ed7.166, csp2ed7.166, dr10.234, mc10.176, ms7D_601, msdiv278, pts-cs7, pts-vp-pli2.205, sc6

root-pli-ms: Nātike piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto pāde pakkhāletvā giñjakāvasathaṁ pavisitvā māgadhake paricārake ārabbha aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasikatvā sabbaṁ cetasā samannāharitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi:
translation-en-sujato: He wandered for alms in Nādika. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he washed his feet and entered the brick house. He paid heed, paid attention, and concentrated wholeheartedly on the fate of Magadhan devotees, and sat on the seat spread out, thinking,
comment-en-sujato: Normally aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasikatvā sabbaṁ cetasā samannāharitvā is used of listening to Dhamma.
variant-pli-ms: aṭṭhiṁ katvā → aṭṭhikatvā (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed) | sabbaṁ cetasā → sabbaṁ cetaso (bj, sya-all, km); sabbacetaso (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: “gatiṁ nesaṁ jānissāmi abhisamparāyaṁ, yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I shall know their destiny, where they are reborn in the next life.”

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho bhagavā māgadhake paricārake:
translation-en-sujato: And he saw where they had been reborn.

root-pli-ms: “yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā”ti.
Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito giñjakāvasathā nikkhamitvā vihārapacchāyāyaṁ paññatte āsane nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat. Emerging from the brick house, he sat on the seat spread out in the shade of the porch.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
reference: bj8.314, ms7D_602, msdiv279, pts-cs8, sc7, sya10.235

root-pli-ms: “upasantapadisso, bhante, bhagavā bhātiriva bhagavato mukhavaṇṇo vippasannattā indriyānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, you look so serene; your face seems to shine owing to the clarity of your faculties.

root-pli-ms: Santena nūnajja, bhante, bhagavā vihārena vihāsī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Have you been abiding in a peaceful meditation today, sir?”

root-pli-ms: “Yadeva kho me tvaṁ, ānanda, māgadhake paricārake ārabbha sammukhā parikathaṁ katvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto, tadevāhaṁ nātike piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto pāde pakkhāletvā giñjakāvasathaṁ pavisitvā māgadhake paricārake ārabbha aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasikatvā sabbaṁ cetasā samannāharitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha then recounted what had happened since speaking to Ānanda, revealing that he had seen the destiny of the Magadhan devotees. He continued:

root-pli-ms: ‘gatiṁ nesaṁ jānissāmi abhisamparāyaṁ, yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.
Addasaṁ kho ahaṁ, ānanda, māgadhake paricārake ‘yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā’ti.
3. Janavasabhayakkha
translation-en-sujato: 3. Janavasabha the Spirit

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, ānanda, antarahito yakkho saddamanussāvesi:
translation-en-sujato: “Then, Ānanda an invisible spirit called out:

root-pli-ms: ‘janavasabho ahaṁ, bhagavā;
translation-en-sujato: ‘I am Janavasabha, Blessed One!
comment-en-sujato: Janavasabha = “Minotaur”.

root-pli-ms: janavasabho ahaṁ, sugatā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: I am Janavasabha, Holy One!’

root-pli-ms: Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, ānanda, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ nāmadheyyaṁ sutaṁ yadidaṁ janavasabho”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Ānanda, do you recall having previously heard such a name as Janavasabha?”
comment-en-sujato: namadheyya means “name (borne by someone or something” ), not “one who bears the name” as per both RD and MW; see MN 50

root-pli-ms: “Na kho ahaṁ, bhante, abhijānāmi ito pubbe evarūpaṁ nāmadheyyaṁ sutaṁ yadidaṁ janavasabhoti, api ca me, bhante, lomāni haṭṭhāni ‘janavasabho’ti nāmadheyyaṁ sutvā.
translation-en-sujato: “No, sir. But when I heard the word, I got goosebumps!

root-pli-ms: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: I thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘na hi nūna so orako yakkho bhavissati yadidaṁ evarūpaṁ nāmadheyyaṁ supaññattaṁ yadidaṁ janavasabho’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This must be no ordinary spirit to bear such an exalted name as Janavasabha.’”

root-pli-ms: “Anantarā kho, ānanda, saddapātubhāvā uḷāravaṇṇo me yakkho sammukhe pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: “After making himself heard while invisible, Ānanda, a very beautiful spirit appeared in front of me.
comment-en-sujato: Note, ularavanna doesn’t in and of itself mean some kind of celestial phenomenon. At MN 96 it occurs of regular beautiful people, see my not there.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyakampi saddamanussāvesi:
translation-en-sujato: And for a second time he called out:

root-pli-ms: ‘bimbisāro ahaṁ, bhagavā;
translation-en-sujato: ‘I am Bimbisāra, Blessed One!

root-pli-ms: bimbisāro ahaṁ, sugatāti.
translation-en-sujato: I am Bimbisāra, Holy One!

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ sattamaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, vessavaṇassa mahārājassa sahabyataṁ upapajjāmi, so tato cuto manussarājā bhavituṁ pahomi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh time I have been reborn in the company of the Great King Vessavaṇa. After passing away from there, I am now able to become a king of non-humans.
comment-en-sujato: Readings are varied, and this seems to me the sense.
variant-pli-ms: manussarājā bhavituṁ pahomi → so ito cuto manussesu rājā bhavituṁ pahomi (sya-all, km); amanussarājā divi homi (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Ito satta tato satta,
translation-en-sujato: Seven from here, seven from there—

root-pli-ms: saṁsārāni catuddasa;
translation-en-sujato: fourteen transmigrations in all.
comment-en-sujato: It’s rare to see samsara used as a countable noun.

root-pli-ms: Nivāsamabhijānāmi,
translation-en-sujato: That’s how many past lives

root-pli-ms: yattha me vusitaṁ pure.
translation-en-sujato: I can recollect.

root-pli-ms: Dīgharattaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, avinipāto avinipātaṁ sañjānāmi, āsā ca pana me santiṭṭhati sakadāgāmitāyā’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: For a long time I’ve known that I won’t be reborn in the underworld, but that I still hope to become a once-returner.’

root-pli-ms: “Acchariyamidaṁ āyasmato janavasabhassa yakkhassa, abbhutamidaṁ āyasmato janavasabhassa yakkhassa.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s incredible and amazing that you, the venerable spirit Janavasabha, should say:

root-pli-ms: ‘Dīgharattaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, avinipāto avinipātaṁ sañjānāmī’ti ca vadesi, ‘āsā ca pana me santiṭṭhati sakadāgāmitāyā’ti ca vadesi, kutonidānaṁ panāyasmā janavasabho yakkho evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ visesādhigamaṁ sañjānātī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “For a long time I’ve been aware that I won’t be reborn in the underworld” and also “But I still hope to become a once-returner.” But from what source do you know that you’ve achieved such a high distinction?’
comment-en-sujato: Note that in this idiom, the verb varies from sañjānāti, jānāti, pajānāti, and sampajānāti.

root-pli-ms: “‘Na aññatra, bhagavā, tava sāsanā, na aññatra, sugata, tava sāsanā;
translation-en-sujato: ‘None other than the Blessed One’s instruction! None other than the Holy One’s instruction!
comment-en-sujato: Cp SN 2.24 where a similar phrase answers a similar question.

root-pli-ms: yadagge ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavati ekantikato abhippasanno, tadagge ahaṁ, bhante, dīgharattaṁ avinipāto avinipātaṁ sañjānāmi, āsā ca pana me santiṭṭhati sakadāgāmitāya.
translation-en-sujato: From the day I had absolute devotion to the Buddha I have known that I won’t be reborn in the underworld, but that I still hope to become a once-returner.

root-pli-ms: Idhāhaṁ, bhante, vessavaṇena mahārājena pesito virūḷhakassa mahārājassa santike kenacideva karaṇīyena addasaṁ bhagavantaṁ antarāmagge giñjakāvasathaṁ pavisitvā māgadhake paricārake ārabbha aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasikatvā sabbaṁ cetasā samannāharitvā nisinnaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Just now, sir, I had been sent out by the great king Vessavaṇa to the great king Virūḷhaka’s presence on some business, and on the way I saw the Buddha giving his attention to the fate of the Magadhan devotees.

root-pli-ms: “gatiṁ nesaṁ jānissāmi abhisamparāyaṁ, yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā”ti.
Anacchariyaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhante, yaṁ vessavaṇassa mahārājassa tassaṁ parisāyaṁ bhāsato sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: But it comes as no surprise that I have heard and learned the fate of the Magadhan devotees in the presence of the great king Vessavaṇa as he was speaking to his assembly.

root-pli-ms: “yaṅgatikā te bhavanto yaṁabhisamparāyā”ti.
Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: It occurred to me,

root-pli-ms: “bhagavantañca dakkhāmi, idañca bhagavato ārocessāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I shall see the Buddha and inform him of this.”

root-pli-ms: Ime kho me, bhante, dvepaccayā bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: These are the two reasons I’ve come to see the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: 4. Devasabhā
translation-en-sujato: 4. The Council of the Gods

root-pli-ms: Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni tadahuposathe pannarase vassūpanāyikāya puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā.
translation-en-sujato: Sir, it was more than a few days ago—on the fifteenth day sabbath on the full moon day at the entry to the rainy season—when all the gods of the Thirty-Three were sitting together in the Hall of Justice.

root-pli-ms: Mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti.
translation-en-sujato: A large assembly of gods was sitting all around, and the Four Great Kings were there.
variant-pli-ms: dibbaparisā → dibbā parisā (pts1ed) | samantato nisinnā honti → sannisinnā honti (bj); sannisinnā honti sannipatitā (mr)

root-pli-ms: Puratthimāya disāya dhataraṭṭho mahārājā pacchimābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Dhataraṭṭha was seated to the east, facing west, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: dakkhiṇāya disāya virūḷhako mahārājā uttarābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Virūḷhaka was seated to the south, facing north, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: pacchimāya disāya virūpakkho mahārājā puratthābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Virūpakkha was seated to the west, facing east, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: uttarāya disāya vessavaṇo mahārājā dakkhiṇābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā.
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Vessavaṇa was seated to the north, facing south, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti. Idaṁ nesaṁ hoti āsanasmiṁ;
translation-en-sujato: When the gods of the Thirty-Three have a gathering like this, that is how they are seated.

root-pli-ms: atha pacchā amhākaṁ āsanaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: After that come our seats.

root-pli-ms: Ye te, bhante, devā bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā adhunūpapannā tāvatiṁsakāyaṁ, te aññe deve atirocanti vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Sir, those gods who had been recently reborn in the company of the Thirty-Three after leading the spiritual life under the Buddha outshone the other gods in beauty and glory.

root-pli-ms: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā:
translation-en-sujato: The gods of the Thirty-Three were uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,

root-pli-ms: “dibbā vata bho kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, celebrated with these verses:

root-pli-ms: “Modanti vata bho devā,
translation-en-sujato: “The gods rejoice—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching;

root-pli-ms: Nave deve ca passantā,
translation-en-sujato: and seeing the new gods,

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇavante yasassine;
translation-en-sujato: so beautiful and glorious,

root-pli-ms: Sugatasmiṁ brahmacariyaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: who have come here after leading

root-pli-ms: caritvāna idhāgate.
translation-en-sujato: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Te aññe atirocanti,
translation-en-sujato: They outshine the others

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇena yasasāyunā;
translation-en-sujato: in beauty, glory, and lifespan.

root-pli-ms: Sāvakā bhūripaññassa,
translation-en-sujato: Here are the distinguished disciples

root-pli-ms: visesūpagatā idha.
translation-en-sujato: of he whose wisdom is vast.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ disvāna nandanti,
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, they delight—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching.”

root-pli-ms: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā bhiyyoso mattāya attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā
translation-en-sujato: The gods of the Thirty-Three were even more uplifted and overjoyed at that, saying:

root-pli-ms: “dibbā vata, bho, kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, yenatthena devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, taṁ atthaṁ cintayitvā taṁ atthaṁ mantayitvā vuttavacanāpi taṁ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṁ atthe honti. Paccānusiṭṭhavacanāpi taṁ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṁ atthe honti,
translation-en-sujato: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three, having considered and deliberated on the matter for which they were seated together in the Hall of Justice, advised and instructed the Four Great Kings on the subject.

root-pli-ms: sakesu sakesu āsanesu ṭhitā avipakkantā.
translation-en-sujato: And each stood at his own seat without departing.
comment-en-sujato: For vipakkamati re the gods, see MN 127.

root-pli-ms: Te vuttavākyā rājāno,
translation-en-sujato: The Kings were instructed,

root-pli-ms: paṭiggayhānusāsaniṁ;
translation-en-sujato: and heeded good advice.

root-pli-ms: Vippasannamanā santā,
translation-en-sujato: With clear and peaceful minds,

root-pli-ms: aṭṭhaṁsu samhi āsaneti.
translation-en-sujato: they stood by their own seats.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, uttarāya disāya uḷāro āloko sañjāyi, obhāso pāturahosi atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then in the northern quarter a magnificent light arose and radiance appeared, surpassing the glory of the gods.
comment-en-sujato: Cp DN 11.
reference: bj8.320, cck10.255, ms7D_616, msdiv283, pts-cs15, sc21

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three,

root-pli-ms: “yathā kho, mārisā, nimittāni dissanti, uḷāro āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavati, brahmā pātubhavissati. Brahmuno hetaṁ pubbanimittaṁ pātubhāvāya yadidaṁ āloko sañjāyati obhāso pātubhavatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “As indicated by the signs—light arising and radiance appearing—Brahmā will appear. For this is the precursor for the appearance of Brahmā, namely light arising and radiance appearing.”

root-pli-ms: Yathā nimittā dissanti,
translation-en-sujato: As indicated by the signs,

root-pli-ms: brahmā pātubhavissati;
translation-en-sujato: Brahmā will appear.

root-pli-ms: Brahmuno hetaṁ nimittaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: For this is the sign of Brahmā:

root-pli-ms: obhāso vipulo mahāti.
translation-en-sujato: a light vast and great.

root-pli-ms: 5. Sanaṅkumārakathā
translation-en-sujato: 5. On Sanaṅkumāra

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā yathāsakesu āsanesu nisīdiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three sat in their own seats, saying,
reference: csp1ed7.170, csp2ed7.170, dr10.239, mc10.180, ms7D_618, msdiv284, pts-cs16, pts-vp-pli2.210, sc23

root-pli-ms: “obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “We shall find out what has caused that light, and having realized it we shall go to it.”
comment-en-sujato: The point of this passage is obscure to me. It seems to be an inversion of the passage where the Buddha meets the group of five at Varanasi. There, they agree to not greet the Buddha, but do so anyway. Here, they agree to meet Brahma, but end up staying in their seats. For vipāko bhavissati, cp. DN 1.

root-pli-ms: Cattāropi mahārājāno yathāsakesu āsanesu nisīdiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And the Four Great Kings did likewise.

root-pli-ms: “obhāsametaṁ ñassāma yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā”ti.
Idaṁ sutvā devā tāvatiṁsā ekaggā samāpajjiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Hearing that, the gods of the Thirty-Three agreed in unison,

root-pli-ms: “obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “We shall find out what has caused that light, and having realized it we shall go to it.”

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā pātubhavati.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, he does so after manifesting in a solid corporeal form.
comment-en-sujato: Cp. AN 3.127

root-pli-ms: Yo kho pana, bhante, brahmuno pakativaṇṇo anabhisambhavanīyo so devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ cakkhupathasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: For the gods of the Thirty-Three aren’t able to see a Brahmā’s normal appearance.
comment-en-sujato: Lit: Brahmā’s normal appearance is imperceptible in the visual field of the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, sovaṇṇo viggaho mānusaṁ viggahaṁ atirocati;
translation-en-sujato: as a golden statue outshines the human form.
comment-en-sujato: Viggaha as “body, form” is found in the Vedas and Upanishads.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, yadā brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, na tassaṁ parisāyaṁ koci devo abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, not a single god in that assembly greets him by bowing down or rising up or inviting him to a seat.

root-pli-ms: Sabbeva tuṇhībhūtā pañjalikā pallaṅkena nisīdanti:
translation-en-sujato: They all sit silently on their couches with their joined palms raised, thinking,

root-pli-ms: “yassadāni devassa pallaṅkaṁ icchissati brahmā sanaṅkumāro, tassa devassa pallaṅke nisīdissatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Now Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra will sit on the couch of whatever god he chooses.”

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, bhante, devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ; uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And the god on whose couch Brahmā sits is overjoyed and brimming with happiness,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto adhunābhisitto rajjena, uḷāraṁ so labhati vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati somanassapaṭilābhaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: like a king on the day of his coronation.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, yassa devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā kumāravaṇṇī hutvā pañcasikho devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra manifested in a solid corporeal form, taking on the appearance of the youth Pañcasikha, and appeared to the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: So vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Rising into the air, he sat cross-legged in the sky,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso supaccatthate vā pallaṅke same vā bhūmibhāge pallaṅkena nisīdeyya;
translation-en-sujato: like a strong man might sit cross-legged on a well-appointed couch or on level ground.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing the joy of those gods, Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra celebrated with these verses:

root-pli-ms: “Modanti vata bho devā,
translation-en-sujato: “The gods rejoice—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching;

root-pli-ms: Nave deve ca passantā,
translation-en-sujato: and seeing the new gods,

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇavante yasassine;
translation-en-sujato: so beautiful and glorious,

root-pli-ms: Sugatasmiṁ brahmacariyaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: who have come here after leading

root-pli-ms: caritvāna idhāgate.
translation-en-sujato: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Te aññe atirocanti,
translation-en-sujato: They outshine the others

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇena yasasāyunā;
translation-en-sujato: in beauty, glory, and lifespan.

root-pli-ms: Sāvakā bhūripaññassa,
translation-en-sujato: Here are the distinguished disciples

root-pli-ms: visesūpagatā idha.
translation-en-sujato: of he whose wisdom is vast.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ disvāna nandanti,
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, they delight—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching!”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha;
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.
comment-en-sujato: Bhāsittha is 3rd singular aorist middle voice.

root-pli-ms: imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti vissaṭṭho ca viññeyyo ca mañju ca savanīyo ca bindu ca avisārī ca gambhīro ca ninnādī ca.
translation-en-sujato: And while he was speaking on that topic, his voice had eight qualities: it was clear, comprehensible, charming, audible, rounded, undistorted, deep, and resonant.
comment-en-sujato: Cp. MN 91

root-pli-ms: Yathāparisaṁ kho pana, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sarena viññāpeti; na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati.
translation-en-sujato: He makes sure his voice is intelligible as far as the assembly goes, but it doesn’t extend outside the assembly.

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, bhante, evaṁ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti, so vuccati “brahmassaro”ti.
translation-en-sujato: When someone has a voice like this, they’re said to have the voice of Brahmā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro tettiṁse attabhāve abhinimminitvā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ paccekapallaṅkesu pallaṅkena nisīditvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, having manifested thirty-three corporeal forms, sat down on the couches of each of the gods of the Thirty-Three and addressed them,
reference: cck10.258, mc10.182, ms7D_626, pts-cs20, pts-vp-pli2.212, sc31
variant-pli-ms: pallaṅkena → paccekapallaṅkesu paccekapallaṅkena (si, mr), paccekapallaṅke (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: “taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think about how much the Buddha has acted for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans?

root-pli-ms: Ye hi keci, bho, buddhaṁ saraṇaṁ gatā dhammaṁ saraṇaṁ gatā saṅghaṁ saraṇaṁ gatā sīlesu paripūrakārino te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā appekacce paranimmitavasavattīnaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti, appekacce nimmānaratīnaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti, appekacce tusitānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti, appekacce yāmānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti, appekacce tāvatiṁsānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti, appekacce cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjanti.
translation-en-sujato: For consider those who have gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and have fulfilled their ethics. When their bodies break up, after death, some are reborn in the company of the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others, some with the Gods Who Love to Create, some with the Joyful Gods, some with the Gods of Yama, some with the Gods of the Thirty-Three, and some with the Gods of the Four Great Kings.

root-pli-ms: Ye sabbanihīnaṁ kāyaṁ paripūrenti, te gandhabbakāyaṁ paripūrentī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And at the very least they swell the hosts of the fairies.”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha;
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.
reference: bj8.324, csp1ed7.172, csp2ed7.172, ms7D_627, msdiv286, pts-cs21, sc32

root-pli-ms: imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato ghosoyeva devā maññanti:
translation-en-sujato: And while he was speaking on that topic, each of the gods fancied,

root-pli-ms: “yvāyaṁ mama pallaṅke svāyaṁ ekova bhāsatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The one sitting on my couch is the only one speaking.”

root-pli-ms: Ekasmiṁ bhāsamānasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: When one is speaking,

root-pli-ms: sabbe bhāsanti nimmitā;
translation-en-sujato: all the forms speak.

root-pli-ms: Ekasmiṁ tuṇhimāsīne,
translation-en-sujato: When one sits in silence,

root-pli-ms: sabbe tuṇhī bhavanti te.
translation-en-sujato: they all remain silent.

root-pli-ms: Tadāsu devā maññanti,
translation-en-sujato: But those gods imagine—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Yvāyaṁ mama pallaṅkasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: that the one on their seat

root-pli-ms: svāyaṁ ekova bhāsatīti.
translation-en-sujato: is the only one to speak.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro ekattena attānaṁ upasaṁharati, ekattena attānaṁ upasaṁharitvā sakkassa devānamindassa pallaṅke pallaṅkena nisīditvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: The Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra merged into one corporeal form. Then he sat on the couch of Sakka, lord of gods, and addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:

root-pli-ms: 6. Bhāvitaiddhipāda
translation-en-sujato: 6. Developing the Bases of Psychic Power

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāva supaññattā cime tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro iddhipādā paññattā iddhipahutāya iddhivisavitāya iddhivikubbanatāya.
translation-en-sujato: “What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think about how much the four bases of psychic power have been clearly described by the Blessed One—the one who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—for the multiplication, generation, and transformation of corporeal forms through psychic power?
comment-en-sujato: This is an odd idiom. Cp. MN 51, where yava supannatta is clearly meant in the sense of an exclamation. Here tam kim mannanti is used, unlike in the Buddha’s discourses, as a rhetorical device, not a genuine question. It almost seems like Brahma is being depicted as adopting the Buddha’s rhetoric, but not being very good at it!

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha bho bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: Vīriyasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti.
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: Cittasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti.
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: Vīmaṁsāsamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti.
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro iddhipādā paññattā iddhipahutāya iddhivisavitāya iddhivikubbanatāya.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four bases of psychic power that have been clearly described by the Buddha, for the multiplication, generation, and transformation of corporeal forms through psychic power.

root-pli-ms: Ye hi keci bho atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhosuṁ, sabbe te imesaṁyeva catunnaṁ iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā.
translation-en-sujato: All the ascetics and brahmins in the past,

root-pli-ms: Yepi hi keci bho anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhossanti, sabbe te imesaṁyeva catunnaṁ iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā.
translation-en-sujato: future,

root-pli-ms: Yepi hi keci bho etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhonti, sabbe te imesaṁyeva catunnaṁ iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā.
translation-en-sujato: or present who wield the many kinds of psychic power do so by developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power.

root-pli-ms: Passanti no, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, mamapimaṁ evarūpaṁ iddhānubhāvan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: gentlemen, do you see such psychic might and power in me?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, mahābrahme”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, Great Brahmā.”

root-pli-ms: “Ahampi kho bho imesaṁyeva catunnañca iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā evaṁ mahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I too became so mighty and powerful by developing and cultivating these four bases of psychic power.”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha.
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsitvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: And having spoken about that, he addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:

root-pli-ms: 7. Tividhaokāsādhigama
translation-en-sujato: 7. The Three Openings

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tayo okāsādhigamā anubuddhā sukhassādhigamāya.
translation-en-sujato: “What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think about how much the Buddha has understood the three opportunities for achieving happiness?

root-pli-ms: Katame tayo?
translation-en-sujato: What three?

root-pli-ms: Idha bho ekacco saṁsaṭṭho viharati kāmehi saṁsaṭṭho akusalehi dhammehi.
translation-en-sujato: First, take someone who lives mixed up with sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena ariyadhammaṁ suṇāti, yoniso manasi karoti, dhammānudhammaṁ paṭipajjati.
translation-en-sujato: After some time they hear the noble teaching, properly attend to how it applies to them, and practice accordingly.

root-pli-ms: So ariyadhammassavanaṁ āgamma yonisomanasikāraṁ dhammānudhammappaṭipattiṁ asaṁsaṭṭho viharati kāmehi asaṁsaṭṭho akusalehi dhammehi.
translation-en-sujato: They live aloof from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.

root-pli-ms: Tassa asaṁsaṭṭhassa kāmehi asaṁsaṭṭhassa akusalehi dhammehi uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: That gives rise to pleasure, and more than pleasure, happiness,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bho, pamudā pāmojjaṁ jāyetha;
translation-en-sujato: like the joy that’s born from gladness.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bho, asaṁsaṭṭhassa kāmehi asaṁsaṭṭhassa akusalehi dhammehi uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
Ayaṁ kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamo okāsādhigamo anubuddho sukhassādhigamāya.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first opportunity for achieving happiness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bho, idhekaccassa oḷārikā kāyasaṅkhārā appaṭippassaddhā honti, oḷārikā vacīsaṅkhārā appaṭippassaddhā honti, oḷārikā cittasaṅkhārā appaṭippassaddhā honti.
translation-en-sujato: Next, take someone whose coarse physical, verbal, and mental processes have not died down.
reference: csp1ed7.174, csp2ed7.174, ms7D_634, pts-cs24, pts-vp-pli2.215, sc39

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena ariyadhammaṁ suṇāti, yoniso manasi karoti, dhammānudhammaṁ paṭipajjati.
translation-en-sujato: After some time they hear the teaching of the noble ones, properly attend to how it applies to them, and practice accordingly.

root-pli-ms: Tassa ariyadhammassavanaṁ āgamma yonisomanasikāraṁ dhammānudhammappaṭipattiṁ oḷārikā kāyasaṅkhārā paṭippassambhanti, oḷārikā vacīsaṅkhārā paṭippassambhanti, oḷārikā cittasaṅkhārā paṭippassambhanti.
translation-en-sujato: Their coarse physical, verbal, and mental processes die down.

root-pli-ms: Tassa oḷārikānaṁ kāyasaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā oḷārikānaṁ vacīsaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā oḷārikānaṁ cittasaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: That gives rise to pleasure, and more than pleasure, happiness,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bho, pamudā pāmojjaṁ jāyetha;
translation-en-sujato: like the joy that’s born from gladness.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho bho oḷārikānaṁ kāyasaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā oḷārikānaṁ vacīsaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā oḷārikānaṁ cittasaṅkhārānaṁ paṭippassaddhiyā uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
Ayaṁ kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dutiyo okāsādhigamo anubuddho sukhassādhigamāya.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second opportunity for achieving happiness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bho, idhekacco ‘idaṁ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘idaṁ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: Next, take someone who doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful,

root-pli-ms: ‘Idaṁ sāvajjaṁ idaṁ anavajjaṁ, idaṁ sevitabbaṁ idaṁ na sevitabbaṁ, idaṁ hīnaṁ idaṁ paṇītaṁ, idaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: what is blameworthy and what is blameless, what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated, what is inferior and what is superior, and what is on the side of dark and the side of bright.

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena ariyadhammaṁ suṇāti, yoniso manasi karoti, dhammānudhammaṁ paṭipajjati.
translation-en-sujato: After some time they hear the teaching of the noble ones, properly attend to how it applies to them, and practice accordingly.

root-pli-ms: So ariyadhammassavanaṁ āgamma yonisomanasikāraṁ dhammānudhammappaṭipattiṁ, ‘idaṁ kusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘idaṁ akusalan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: They truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful, and so on.

root-pli-ms: ‘Idaṁ sāvajjaṁ idaṁ anavajjaṁ, idaṁ sevitabbaṁ idaṁ na sevitabbaṁ, idaṁ hīnaṁ idaṁ paṇītaṁ, idaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: Knowing and seeing like this, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.

root-pli-ms: Tassa avijjāvirāgā vijjuppādā uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: That gives rise to pleasure, and more than pleasure, happiness,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bho, pamudā pāmojjaṁ jāyetha;
translation-en-sujato: like the joy that’s born from gladness.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bho, avijjāvirāgā vijjuppādā uppajjati sukhaṁ, sukhā bhiyyo somanassaṁ.
Ayaṁ kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tatiyo okāsādhigamo anubuddho sukhassādhigamāya.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third opportunity for achieving happiness.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tayo okāsādhigamā anubuddhā sukhassādhigamāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the three opportunities for achieving happiness that have been understood by the Buddha.”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha,
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.

root-pli-ms: imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsitvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: And having spoken about that, he addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:

root-pli-ms: 8. Catusatipaṭṭhāna
translation-en-sujato: 8. Mindfulness Meditation

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāva supaññattā cime tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro satipaṭṭhānā paññattā kusalassādhigamāya.
