translation-en-sujato: “What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think about how much the Buddha has clearly described the four kinds of mindfulness meditation for achieving what is skillful?

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bho, bhikkhu ajjhattaṁ kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body internally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ kāye kāyānupassī viharanto tattha sammā samādhiyati, sammā vippasīdati.
translation-en-sujato: As they meditate in this way, they become rightly immersed in that, and rightly serene.

root-pli-ms: So tattha sammā samāhito sammā vippasanno bahiddhā parakāye ñāṇadassanaṁ abhinibbatteti.
translation-en-sujato: Then they give rise to knowledge and vision of other people’s bodies externally.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally …

root-pli-ms: bahiddhā paravedanāsu ñāṇadassanaṁ abhinibbatteti.
translation-en-sujato: Then they give rise to knowledge and vision of other people’s feelings externally.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ citte cittānupassī viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally …

root-pli-ms: bahiddhā paracitte ñāṇadassanaṁ abhinibbatteti.
translation-en-sujato: Then they give rise to knowledge and vision of other people’s minds externally.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of principles internally—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ dhammesu dhammānupassī viharanto tattha sammā samādhiyati, sammā vippasīdati.
translation-en-sujato: As they meditate in this way, they become rightly immersed in that, and rightly serene.

root-pli-ms: So tattha sammā samāhito sammā vippasanno bahiddhā paradhammesu ñāṇadassanaṁ abhinibbatteti.
translation-en-sujato: Then they give rise to knowledge and vision of other people’s principles externally.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, bho, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro satipaṭṭhānā paññattā kusalassādhigamāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that the Buddha has clearly described for achieving what is skillful.”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha.
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsitvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: And having spoken about that, he addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:

root-pli-ms: 9. Sattasamādhiparikkhāra
translation-en-sujato: 9. Seven Prerequisites of Immersion

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāva supaññattā cime tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena satta samādhiparikkhārā sammāsamādhissa paribhāvanāya sammāsamādhissa pāripūriyā.
translation-en-sujato: “What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think about how much the Buddha has clearly described the seven prerequisites of immersion for the development and fulfillment of right immersion?

root-pli-ms: Katame satta?
translation-en-sujato: What seven?

root-pli-ms: Sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati.
translation-en-sujato: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Yā kho, bho, imehi sattahaṅgehi cittassa ekaggatā parikkhatā, ayaṁ vuccati, bho, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso itipi saparikkhāro itipi.
translation-en-sujato: Unification of mind with these seven factors as prerequisites is called noble right immersion ‘with its vital conditions’ and ‘with its prerequisites’.
comment-en-sujato: Note that these are quadruple-nested quotes!

root-pli-ms: Sammādiṭṭhissa, bho, sammāsaṅkappo pahoti, sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācā pahoti, sammāvācassa sammākammanto pahoti. Sammākammantassa sammāājīvo pahoti, sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmo pahoti, sammāvāyāmassa sammāsati pahoti, sammāsatissa sammāsamādhi pahoti, sammāsamādhissa sammāñāṇaṁ pahoti, sammāñāṇassa sammāvimutti pahoti.
translation-en-sujato: Right view gives rise to right thought. Right thought gives rise to right speech. Right speech gives rise to right action. Right action gives rise to right livelihood. Right livelihood gives rise to right effort. Right effort gives rise to right mindfulness. Right mindfulness gives rise to right immersion. Right immersion gives rise to right knowledge. Right knowledge gives rise to right freedom.

root-pli-ms: Yañhi taṁ, bho, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: If anything should be rightly described as

root-pli-ms: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi apārutā amatassa dvārā’ti idameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
translation-en-sujato: ‘a teaching that’s well explained by the Buddha, visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves; and the doors to the deathless are flung open,’ it’s this.
comment-en-sujato: The whole passage here, like much in Brahma’s speech, is a bit off. I don’t think the translation should gloss over the clumsiness.

root-pli-ms: Svākkhāto hi, bho, bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko, akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi apārutā amatassa dvārā.
translation-en-sujato: For the teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves—and the doors of the deathless are flung open.

root-pli-ms: Ye hi keci, bho, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatā, dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgatā, saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgatā, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgatā, ye cime opapātikā dhammavinītā sātirekāni catuvīsatisatasahassāni māgadhakā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Whoever has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and has the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones; and whoever is spontaneously reborn, and is trained in the teaching; in excess of 2,400,000 such Magadhan devotees have passed away having ended three fetters. They’re stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.

root-pli-ms: Atthi cevettha sakadāgāmino.
translation-en-sujato: And there are once-returners here, too.

root-pli-ms: Atthāyaṁ itarā pajā,
translation-en-sujato: And as for other people

root-pli-ms: puññābhāgāti me mano;
translation-en-sujato: who I think have shared in merit—

root-pli-ms: Saṅkhātuṁ nopi sakkomi,
translation-en-sujato: I couldn’t even number them,

root-pli-ms: musāvādassa ottappan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: for fear of speaking falsely.”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro bhāsittha, imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato vessavaṇassa mahārājassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke. And while he was speaking on that topic, this thought came to the great king Vessavaṇa,

root-pli-ms: “acchariyaṁ vata bho, abbhutaṁ vata bho, evarūpopi nāma uḷāro satthā bhavissati, evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ dhammakkhānaṁ, evarūpā uḷārā visesādhigamā paññāyissantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, it’s amazing! That there should be such a magnificent Teacher, and such a magnificent exposition of the teaching! And that such achievements of high distinction should be made known!”

root-pli-ms: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro vessavaṇassa mahārājassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya vessavaṇaṁ mahārājānaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: And then Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, knowing what the great king Vessavaṇa was thinking, said to him,

root-pli-ms: “taṁ kiṁ maññati bhavaṁ vessavaṇo mahārājā atītampi addhānaṁ evarūpo uḷāro satthā ahosi, evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ dhammakkhānaṁ, evarūpā uḷārā visesādhigamā paññāyiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: “What does Great King Vessavaṇa think? In the past, too, there was such a magnificent Teacher, and such a magnificent exposition of the teaching! And such achievements of high distinction were made known!

root-pli-ms: Anāgatampi addhānaṁ evarūpo uḷāro satthā bhavissati, evarūpaṁ uḷāraṁ dhammakkhānaṁ, evarūpā uḷārā visesādhigamā paññāyissantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: In the future, too, there will be such a magnificent Teacher, and such a magnificent exposition of the teaching! And such achievements of high distinction will be made known!”

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ abhāsi, imamatthaṁ vessavaṇo mahārājā brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ bhāsato sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ sayaṁ parisāyaṁ ārocesi’”.
translation-en-sujato: That, sir, is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke to the gods of the Thirty-Three. And the great king Vessavaṇa, having heard and learned it in the presence of Brahmā as he was speaking on that topic, informed his own assembly.’”
reference: csp1ed7.177, csp2ed7.177, ms7D_641, msdiv292, ndp7.164, pts-cs29, pts-vp-pli2.219, sc46

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ janavasabho yakkho vessavaṇassa mahārājassa sayaṁ parisāyaṁ bhāsato sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
translation-en-sujato: And the spirit Janavasabha, having heard and learned it in the presence of the great king Vessavaṇa as he was speaking on that topic to his own assembly, informed the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ bhagavā janavasabhassa yakkhassa sammukhā sutvā sammukhā paṭiggahetvā sāmañca abhiññāya āyasmato ānandassa ārocesi, imamatthamāyasmā ānando bhagavato sammukhā sutvā sammukhā paṭiggahetvā ārocesi bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And the Buddha, having heard and learned it in the presence of the spirit Janavasabha, and also from his own direct knowledge, informed Venerable Ānanda. And Venerable Ānanda, having heard and learned it in the presence of the Buddha, informed the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

root-pli-ms: Tayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṁ bāhujaññaṁ puthubhūtaṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitanti.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s how this spiritual life has become successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Janavasabhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ pañcamaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 19
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 19

root-pli-ms: Mahāgovindasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Great Steward

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho pañcasikho gandhabbaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṁ gijjhakūṭaṁ pabbataṁ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbaputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then, late at night, the fairy Pañcasikha, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

root-pli-ms: “yaṁ kho me, bhante, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ, ārocemi taṁ bhagavato”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I would tell you of what I heard and learned directly from the gods of the Thirty-Three.”

root-pli-ms: “Ārocehi me tvaṁ, pañcasikhā”ti bhagavā avoca.
translation-en-sujato: “Tell me, Pañcasikha,” said the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: 1. Devasabhā
translation-en-sujato: 1. The Council of the Gods

root-pli-ms: “Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni tadahuposathe pannarase pavāraṇāya puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā;
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, it was more than a few days ago—on the fifteenth day sabbath on the full moon day at the invitation to admonish held at the end of the rainy season—when all the gods of the Thirty-Three were sitting together in the Hall of Justice.
reference: cck10.269, dr10.251, ms7D_645, msdiv294, pts-cs2, pts-vp-pli2.221, sc2, sya10.253

root-pli-ms: mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti;
translation-en-sujato: A large assembly of gods was sitting all around, and the Four Great Kings were there.

root-pli-ms: puratthimāya disāya dhataraṭṭho mahārājā pacchimābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Dhataraṭṭha was seated to the east, facing west, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: dakkhiṇāya disāya virūḷhako mahārājā uttarābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Virūḷhaka was seated to the south, facing north, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: pacchimāya disāya virūpakkho mahārājā puratthābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Virūpakkha was seated to the west, facing east, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: uttarāya disāya vessavaṇo mahārājā dakkhiṇābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā.
translation-en-sujato: The Great King Vessavaṇa was seated to the north, facing south, in front of his gods.

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti, idaṁ nesaṁ hoti āsanasmiṁ;
translation-en-sujato: When the gods of the Thirty-Three have a gathering like this, that is how they are seated.

root-pli-ms: atha pacchā amhākaṁ āsanaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: After that come our seats.

root-pli-ms: Ye te, bhante, devā bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā adhunūpapannā tāvatiṁsakāyaṁ, te aññe deve atirocanti vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Sir, those gods who had been recently reborn in the company of the Thirty-Three after leading the spiritual life under the Buddha outshine the other gods in beauty and glory.
reference: csp1ed7.179, csp2ed7.179, mc10.190, ms7D_646, pts-cs3, sc3, vri2.163

root-pli-ms: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā;
translation-en-sujato: The gods of the Thirty-Three were uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘dibbā vata bho kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle!’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, celebrated with these verses:

root-pli-ms: ‘Modanti vata bho devā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘The gods rejoice—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching;

root-pli-ms: Nave deve ca passantā,
translation-en-sujato: and seeing the new gods,

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇavante yasassine;
translation-en-sujato: so beautiful and glorious,

root-pli-ms: Sugatasmiṁ brahmacariyaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: who have come here after leading

root-pli-ms: caritvāna idhāgate.
translation-en-sujato: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Te aññe atirocanti,
translation-en-sujato: They outshine the others

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇena yasasāyunā;
translation-en-sujato: in beauty, glory, and lifespan.

root-pli-ms: Sāvakā bhūripaññassa,
translation-en-sujato: Here are the distinguished disciples

root-pli-ms: visesūpagatā idha.
translation-en-sujato: of he whose wisdom is vast.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ disvāna nandanti,
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, they delight—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammatan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching!’

root-pli-ms: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā bhiyyoso mattāya attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā;
translation-en-sujato: The gods of the Thirty-Three were even more uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘dibbā vata bho, kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle!’

root-pli-ms: 2. Aṭṭhayathābhuccavaṇṇa
translation-en-sujato: 2. Eight Genuine Praises

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed them,

root-pli-ms: ‘iccheyyātha no tumhe, mārisā, tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sotun’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Gentlemen, would you like to hear eight genuine praises of the Buddha?’
comment-en-sujato: For yathabhucca vanna, see DN1

root-pli-ms: ‘Icchāma mayaṁ, mārisa, tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sotun’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Indeed we would, sir.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka proffered these eight genuine praises of the Buddha:

root-pli-ms: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What do the good gods of the Thirty-Three think

root-pli-ms: Yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: about how much the Buddha has acted for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans?

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ bahujanahitāya paṭipannaṁ bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (1)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has such compassion for the world, apart from the Buddha.
comment-en-sujato: This context shows that the yavanca idiom really must be taken as “the extent to which”. Surely the text cannot be saying that the Buddha is the only teacher who acts out of compassion; it must be that he does so to a greater extent.

root-pli-ms: Svākkhāto kho pana tena bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha has explained the teaching well—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
reference: bj8.338, csp1ed7.180, csp2ed7.180, ms7D_655, pts-cs6, sc12

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ opaneyyikassa dhammassa desetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (2)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who explains such a relevant teaching, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: “Idaṁ kusalan”ti kho pana tena bhagavatā supaññattaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti supaññattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha has clearly described what is skillful and what is unskillful,

root-pli-ms: “Idaṁ sāvajjaṁ idaṁ anavajjaṁ, idaṁ sevitabbaṁ idaṁ na sevitabbaṁ, idaṁ hīnaṁ idaṁ paṇītaṁ, idaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan”ti supaññattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: what is blameworthy and what is blameless, what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated, what is inferior and what is superior, and what is on the side of dark and the side of bright.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjasevitabbāsevitabbahīnapaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgānaṁ dhammānaṁ paññāpetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (3)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes all these things, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Supaññattā kho pana tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā, saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha has clearly described the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples. And extinguishment and the practice come together,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma gaṅgodakaṁ yamunodakena saṁsandati sameti;
translation-en-sujato: as the waters of the Ganges come together and converge with the waters of the Yamuna.

root-pli-ms: evameva supaññattā tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā, saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
Evaṁ nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya paññāpetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (4)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Abhinipphanno kho pana tassa bhagavato lābho abhinipphanno siloko, yāva maññe khattiyā sampiyāyamānarūpā viharanti, vigatamado kho pana so bhagavā āhāraṁ āhāreti.
translation-en-sujato: Also, possessions and popularity have accrued to the Buddha, so much that you’d think it would thrill even the aristocrats. But he takes his food free of vanity.
comment-en-sujato: Comm: sampiyāyamānarūpā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā
reference: cck10.272, mc10.192, ms7D_658, pts-cs9, pts-vp-pli2.224, sc15

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vigatamadaṁ āhāraṁ āharayamānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (5)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who takes their food so free of vanity, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Laddhasahāyo kho pana so bhagavā sekhānañceva paṭipannānaṁ khīṇāsavānañca vusitavataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha has gained companions, both trainees who are practicing, and those with defilements ended who have completed their journey.

root-pli-ms: Te bhagavā apanujja ekārāmataṁ anuyutto viharati.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha is committed to the joy of solitude, but doesn’t send them away.
comment-en-sujato: CPD: ekârāmatā, f. [BHS ts.], the state of delighting in solitude. Comm to MN 122 says “Pacchābhatte pana divāṭṭhānaṁ sammajjitvā sudhotahatthapādo mūlakammaṭṭhānaṁ gahetvā ekārāmatamanuyutto bhikkhu buddhasāsane sobhati”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ ekārāmataṁ anuyuttaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (6)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, so committed to the joy of solitude, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Yathāvādī kho pana so bhagavā tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī, iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha does as he says, and says as he does, thus: he does as he says, and says as he does.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ dhammānudhammappaṭipannaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (7)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so practices in line with the teaching, apart from the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Tiṇṇavicikiccho kho pana so bhagavā vigatakathaṅkatho pariyositasaṅkappo ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Also, the Buddha has gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision. He has achieved all he wished for regarding the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.
comment-en-sujato: pariyositasaṅkappo is a synonym of the more normal paripuṇṇasaṅkappo
reference: csp1ed7.181, csp2ed7.181, ms7D_661, ndp7.168, pts-cs12, sc18

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ tiṇṇavicikicchaṁ vigatakathaṅkathaṁ pariyositasaṅkappaṁ ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā’ti. (8)
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has achieved these things, apart from the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: These are the eight genuine praises of the Buddha proffered by Sakka.

root-pli-ms: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā bhiyyoso mattāya attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sutvā.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing them, the gods of the Thirty-Three were even more uplifted and overjoyed.

root-pli-ms: Tatra, bhante, ekacce devā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then some gods thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘aho vata, mārisā, cattāro sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṁ dhammañca deseyyuṁ yathariva bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘If only four fully awakened Buddhas might arise in the world and teach the Dhamma, just like the Blessed One!

root-pli-ms: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

root-pli-ms: Ekacce devā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Other gods thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘tiṭṭhantu, mārisā, cattāro sammāsambuddhā, aho vata, mārisā, tayo sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṁ dhammañca deseyyuṁ yathariva bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Let alone four fully awakened Buddhas; if only three fully awakened Buddhas,

root-pli-ms: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
Ekacce devā evamāhaṁsu:
‘tiṭṭhantu, mārisā, tayo sammāsambuddhā, aho vata, mārisā, dve sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṁ dhammañca deseyyuṁ yathariva bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: or two fully awakened Buddhas might arise in the world and teach the Dhamma, just like the Blessed One!

root-pli-ms: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṁse etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When they said this, Sakka said,
reference: bj8.342, csp1ed7.182, csp2ed7.182, dr10.255, mc10.193, ms7D_663, msdiv298, pts-cs14, pts-vp-pli2.225, sc20

root-pli-ms: ‘aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ, mārisā, anavakāso, yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjeyyuṁ, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s impossible, gentlemen, for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time.

root-pli-ms: Aho vata, mārisā, so bhagavā appābādho appātaṅko ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭheyya.
translation-en-sujato: May that Blessed One be healthy and well, and remain with us for a long time!

root-pli-ms: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of compassion for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, yenatthena devā tāvatiṁsā sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, taṁ atthaṁ cintayitvā taṁ atthaṁ mantayitvā vuttavacanāpi taṁ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṁ atthe honti.
translation-en-sujato: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three, having considered and deliberated on the matter for which they were seated together in the Hall of Justice, advised and instructed the Four Great Kings on the subject.

root-pli-ms: Paccānusiṭṭhavacanāpi taṁ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṁ atthe honti, sakesu sakesu āsanesu ṭhitā avipakkantā.
translation-en-sujato: And each stood at their own seat without departing.

root-pli-ms: Te vuttavākyā rājāno,
translation-en-sujato: The Kings were instructed,

root-pli-ms: paṭiggayhānusāsaniṁ;
translation-en-sujato: and heeded good advice.

root-pli-ms: Vippasannamanā santā,
translation-en-sujato: With clear and peaceful minds,

root-pli-ms: aṭṭhaṁsu samhi āsaneti.
translation-en-sujato: they stood by their own seats.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, uttarāya disāya uḷāro āloko sañjāyi, obhāso pāturahosi atikkammeva devānaṁ devānubhāvaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then in the northern quarter a magnificent light arose and radiance appeared, surpassing the glory of the gods.
reference: cck10.274, ms7D_665, msdiv299, ndp7.169, pts-cs15, sc22, sya10.258

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three,

root-pli-ms: ‘yathā kho, mārisā, nimittāni dissanti, uḷāro āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavati, brahmā pātubhavissati;
translation-en-sujato: ‘As indicated by the signs—light arising and radiance appearing—Brahmā will appear. For this is the precursor for the appearance of Brahmā, namely light arising and radiance appearing.’

root-pli-ms: brahmuno hetaṁ pubbanimittaṁ pātubhāvāya, yadidaṁ āloko sañjāyati obhāso pātubhavatīti.
Yathā nimittā dissanti,
translation-en-sujato: As indicated by the signs,

root-pli-ms: brahmā pātubhavissati;
translation-en-sujato: Brahmā will appear.

root-pli-ms: Brahmuno hetaṁ nimittaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: For this is the sign of Brahmā:

root-pli-ms: obhāso vipulo mahā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: a light vast and great.

root-pli-ms: 3. Sanaṅkumārakathā
translation-en-sujato: 3. On Sanaṅkumāra

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā yathāsakesu āsanesu nisīdiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three sat in their own seats, saying,
reference: mc10.194, ms7D_667, msdiv300, pts-cs16, pts-vp-pli2.226, sc24

root-pli-ms: ‘obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and having realized it we shall go to it.’

root-pli-ms: Cattāropi mahārājāno yathāsakesu āsanesu nisīdiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And the Four Great Kings did likewise.

root-pli-ms: ‘obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā’ti.
Idaṁ sutvā devā tāvatiṁsā ekaggā samāpajjiṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Hearing that, the gods of the Thirty-Three agreed in unison,

root-pli-ms: ‘obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and having realized it we shall go to it.’

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā pātubhavati.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, he does so after manifesting in a solid corporeal form,

root-pli-ms: Yo kho pana, bhante, brahmuno pakativaṇṇo, anabhisambhavanīyo so devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ cakkhupathasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: for the gods of the Thirty-Three aren’t able to see a Brahmā’s normal appearance.

root-pli-ms: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, so vaṇṇo viggaho mānusaṁ viggahaṁ atirocati;
translation-en-sujato: as a golden statue outshines the human form.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, yadā brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, na tassaṁ parisāyaṁ koci devo abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti.
translation-en-sujato: When Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the Thirty-Three, not a single god in that assembly greets him by bowing down or rising up or inviting him to a seat.

root-pli-ms: Sabbeva tuṇhībhūtā pañjalikā pallaṅkena nisīdanti:
translation-en-sujato: They all sit silently on their couches with their joined palms raised, thinking,

root-pli-ms: ‘yassadāni devassa pallaṅkaṁ icchissati brahmā sanaṅkumāro, tassa devassa pallaṅke nisīdissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Now Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra will sit on the couch of whatever god he chooses.’

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, bhante, devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And the god on whose couch Brahmā sits is overjoyed and brimming with happiness,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto adhunābhisitto rajjena, uḷāraṁ so labhati vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati somanassapaṭilābhaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: like a king on the day of his coronation.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, yassa devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā antarahito imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing the joy of those gods, Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra celebrated with these verses:

root-pli-ms: ‘Modanti vata bho devā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘The gods rejoice—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching;

root-pli-ms: Nave deve ca passantā,
translation-en-sujato: and seeing the new gods,

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇavante yasassine;
translation-en-sujato: so beautiful and glorious,

root-pli-ms: Sugatasmiṁ brahmacariyaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: who have come here after leading

root-pli-ms: caritvāna idhāgate.
translation-en-sujato: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Te aññe atirocanti,
translation-en-sujato: They outshine the others

root-pli-ms: vaṇṇena yasasāyunā;
translation-en-sujato: in beauty, glory, and lifespan.

root-pli-ms: Sāvakā bhūripaññassa,
translation-en-sujato: Here are the distinguished disciples

root-pli-ms: visesūpagatā idha.
translation-en-sujato: of he whose wisdom is vast.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ disvāna nandanti,
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, they delight—

root-pli-ms: tāvatiṁsā sahindakā;
translation-en-sujato: the Thirty-Three with their Lord—

root-pli-ms: Tathāgataṁ namassantā,
translation-en-sujato: revering the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: dhammassa ca sudhammatan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: and the natural excellence of the teaching!’

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro abhāsittha.
translation-en-sujato: That is the topic on which Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra spoke.
reference: bj8.346, csp1ed7.184, csp2ed7.184, ms7D_673, msdiv301, pts-cs18, pts-vp-pli2.228, sc30, sya10.260

root-pli-ms: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti vissaṭṭho ca viññeyyo ca mañju ca savanīyo ca bindu ca avisārī ca gambhīro ca ninnādī ca.
translation-en-sujato: And while he was speaking on that topic, his voice had eight qualities: it was clear, comprehensible, charming, audible, rounded, undistorted, deep, and resonant.

root-pli-ms: Yathāparisaṁ kho pana, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sarena viññāpeti, na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati.
translation-en-sujato: He makes sure his voice is intelligible as far as the assembly goes, but it doesn’t extend outside the assembly.

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho pana, bhante, evaṁ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti, so vuccati ‘brahmassaro’ti.
translation-en-sujato: When someone has a voice like this, they’re said to have the voice of Brahmā.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three said to Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra,

root-pli-ms: ‘sādhu, mahābrahme, etadeva mayaṁ saṅkhāya modāma;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Good, Great Brahmā! Knowing this, we rejoice.
comment-en-sujato: Comm: Saṅkhāya modāmāti jānitvā modāma

root-pli-ms: atthi ca sakkena devānamindena tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhuccā vaṇṇā bhāsitā;
translation-en-sujato: And there are the eight genuine praises of the Buddha spoken by Sakka—

root-pli-ms: te ca mayaṁ saṅkhāya modāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: knowing them, too, we rejoice.’

root-pli-ms: 4. Aṭṭhayathābhuccavaṇṇa
translation-en-sujato: 4. Eight Genuine Praises

root-pli-ms: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then Brahmā said to Sakka,

root-pli-ms: ‘sādhu, devānaminda, mayampi tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe suṇeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It would be good, lord of gods, if I could also hear the eight genuine praises of the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, mahābrahme’ti kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Saying, ‘Yes, Great Brahmā,’ Sakka repeated the eight genuine praises for him.

root-pli-ms: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññati, bhavaṁ mahābrahmā?
Yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.

Evaṁ bahujanahitāya paṭipannaṁ bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (1)
Svākkhāto kho pana tena bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi.
Evaṁ opaneyyikassa dhammassa desetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (2)

“Idaṁ kusalan”ti kho pana tena bhagavatā supaññattaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti supaññattaṁ, “idaṁ sāvajjaṁ idaṁ anavajjaṁ, idaṁ sevitabbaṁ idaṁ na sevitabbaṁ, idaṁ hīnaṁ idaṁ paṇītaṁ, idaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan”ti supaññattaṁ.
reference: bj8.348, mc10.196, ms7D_677, pts-cs22, pts-vp-pli2.229, sc34

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjasevitabbāsevitabbahīnapaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgānaṁ dhammānaṁ paññāpetāraṁ.
Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (3)
Supaññattā kho pana tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
Seyyathāpi nāma gaṅgodakaṁ yamunodakena saṁsandati sameti;
evameva supaññattā tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
Evaṁ nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya paññāpetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (4)
Abhinipphanno kho pana tassa bhagavato lābho abhinipphanno siloko, yāva maññe khattiyā sampiyāyamānarūpā viharanti.
Vigatamado kho pana so bhagavā āhāraṁ āhāreti.
Evaṁ vigatamadaṁ āhāraṁ āharayamānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (5)
Laddhasahāyo kho pana so bhagavā sekhānañceva paṭipannānaṁ khīṇāsavānañca vusitavataṁ, te bhagavā apanujja ekārāmataṁ anuyutto viharati.
Evaṁ ekārāmataṁ anuyuttaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (6)
Yathāvādī kho pana so bhagavā tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī;
iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
Evaṁ dhammānudhammappaṭippannaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā. (7)
Tiṇṇavicikiccho kho pana so bhagavā vigatakathaṅkatho pariyositasaṅkappo ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
reference: mc10.197, ms7D_682, ndp7.172, pts-cs27, pts-vp-pli2.230, sc39

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ tiṇṇavicikicchaṁ vigatakathaṅkathaṁ pariyositasaṅkappaṁ ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā’ti. (8)
Ime kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
Tena sudaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro attamano hoti pamudito pītisomanassajāto bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sutvā.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing them, Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā kumāravaṇṇī hutvā pañcasikho devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra manifested in a solid corporeal form, taking on the appearance of the youth Pañcasikha, and appeared to the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: So vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Rising into the air, he sat cross-legged in the sky,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso supaccatthate vā pallaṅke same vā bhūmibhāge pallaṅkena nisīdeyya;
translation-en-sujato: like a strong man might sit cross-legged on a well-appointed couch or on level ground.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There he addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:

root-pli-ms: 5. Govindabrāhmaṇavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 5. The Story of the Steward

root-pli-ms: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāva dīgharattaṁ mahāpaññova so bhagavā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘What do the gods of the Thirty-Three think about the extent of the Buddha’s great wisdom?

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bho, rājā disampati nāma ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, there was a king named Disampati.

root-pli-ms: Disampatissa rañño govindo nāma brāhmaṇo purohito ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: He had a brahmin high priest named the Steward.

root-pli-ms: Disampatissa rañño reṇu nāma kumāro putto ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Disampati’s son was the prince named Reṇu,
comment-en-sujato: Neither RD nor MW catch the detail that the roles of the sons are specified.

root-pli-ms: Govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: while the Steward’s son was the student named Jotipāla.

root-pli-ms: Iti reṇu ca rājaputto jotipālo ca māṇavo aññe ca cha khattiyā iccete aṭṭha sahāyā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: There were Reṇu the prince, Jotipāla the student, and six other aristocrats; these eight became friends.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṁ accayena govindo brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: In due course the brahmin Steward passed away.

root-pli-ms: Govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate rājā disampati paridevesi:
translation-en-sujato: At his passing, King Disampati lamented,
comment-en-sujato: Both MW and RD say the king “mourned for” Govinda. But from the context, all he cares about is that he doesn’t get to do what he likes!

root-pli-ms: “yasmiṁ vata, bho, mayaṁ samaye govinde brāhmaṇe sabbakiccāni sammā vossajjitvā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, tasmiṁ no samaye govindo brāhmaṇo kālaṅkato”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “At a time when I have relinquished all my duties to the brahmin Steward and amuse myself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, he passes away!”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bho, reṇu rājaputto rājānaṁ disampatiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, Prince Reṇu said to him,

root-pli-ms: “mā kho tvaṁ, deva, govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate atibāḷhaṁ paridevesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Sire, don’t lament too much at the Steward’s passing.

root-pli-ms: Atthi, deva, govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto paṇḍitataro ceva pitarā, alamatthadasataro ceva pitarā;
translation-en-sujato: He has a son named Jotipāla, who is even more astute and expert than his father.

root-pli-ms: yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi, tepi jotipālasseva māṇavassa anusāsaniyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: He should manage the affairs that were managed by his father.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, kumārā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Is that so, my prince?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, devā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sire.”

root-pli-ms: 6. Mahāgovindavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 6. The Story of the Great Steward

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So King Disampati addressed one of his men,

root-pli-ms: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ evaṁ vadehi:
translation-en-sujato: “Please, mister, go to the student Jotipāla, and say to him,

root-pli-ms: ‘bhavamatthu bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ, rājā disampati bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Best wishes, Jotipāla! You are summoned by King Disampati; he wants to see you.’”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso disampatissa rañño paṭissutvā yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: “bhavamatthu bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ, rājā disampati bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo”ti.
“Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, jotipālo māṇavo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena rājā disampati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā disampatinā raññā saddhiṁ sammodi;
translation-en-sujato: Then Jotipāla went to the king and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho, bho, jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ rājā disampati etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the king said to him,

root-pli-ms: “anusāsatu no bhavaṁ jotipālo, mā no bhavaṁ jotipālo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: “May you, Jotipāla, manage my affairs—please don’t turn me down!

root-pli-ms: Pettike taṁ ṭhāne ṭhapessāmi, govindiye abhisiñcissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall appoint you to your father’s position, and anoint you as Steward.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, so jotipālo māṇavo disampatissa rañño paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied Jotipāla.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ govindiye abhisiñci, taṁ pettike ṭhāne ṭhapesi.
translation-en-sujato: So the king anointed him as Steward and appointed him to his father’s position.

root-pli-ms: Abhisitto jotipālo māṇavo govindiye pettike ṭhāne ṭhapito yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati, yepissa pitā atthe nānusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati;
translation-en-sujato: After his appointment, the Steward Jotipāla managed both the affairs that his father had managed, and other affairs that his father had not managed.
comment-en-sujato: Following MS reading rather than PTS here: it seems equired by the context that he does more than his father.

root-pli-ms: yepissa pitā kammante abhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti, yepissa pitā kammante nābhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti.
translation-en-sujato: He organized both the works that his father had organized, and other works that his father had not organized.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ manussā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: When people noticed this they said,

root-pli-ms: “govindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo, mahāgovindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The brahmin is indeed a Steward, a Great Steward!”

root-pli-ms: Iminā kho evaṁ, bho, pariyāyena jotipālassa māṇavassa govindo mahāgovindotveva samaññā udapādi.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s how the student Jotipāla came to be known as the Great Steward.

root-pli-ms: 6.1. Rajjasaṁvibhajana
translation-en-sujato: 6.1. Dividing the Realm

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,

root-pli-ms: “disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: “King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint Prince Reṇu as king.

root-pli-ms: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ evaṁ vadetha:
translation-en-sujato: Come, sirs, go to Prince Reṇu and say,

root-pli-ms: ‘mayaṁ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā, yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Prince Reṇu, we are your friends, dear, beloved, and cherished. We have shared your joys and sorrows.

root-pli-ms: Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṁ reṇuṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint you as king.

root-pli-ms: Sace bhavaṁ reṇu rajjaṁ labhetha, saṁvibhajetha no rajjenā’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: If you should gain kingship, share it with us.’”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the six aristocrats. They went to Prince Reṇu and put the proposal to him.

root-pli-ms: “mayaṁ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā;
yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ.
Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana bho jānāti jīvitaṁ?
Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṁ reṇuṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
Sace bhavaṁ reṇu rajjaṁ labhetha, saṁvibhajetha no rajjenā”ti.
“Ko nu kho, bho, añño mama vijite sukho bhavetha, aññatra bhavantebhi?
translation-en-sujato: The prince replied, “Who else, sirs, in my realm ought to prosper if not you?
comment-en-sujato: Following PTS reading.
variant-pli-ms: sukho bhavetha → sukha medhetha (bj); sukhaṁ bhaveyyātha (sya-all, km); sukhamedheyyātha (pts1ed); sukhā bhaveyyātha (mr)

root-pli-ms: Sacāhaṁ, bho, rajjaṁ labhissāmi, saṁvibhajissāmi vo rajjenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: If I gain kingship, I will share it with you all.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṁ accayena rājā disampati kālamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: In due course King Disampati passed away.

root-pli-ms: Disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ rajje abhisiñciṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: At his passing, the king-makers anointed Prince Reṇu as king.

root-pli-ms: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
translation-en-sujato: But after being anointed, King Reṇu amused himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,

root-pli-ms: “disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato.
translation-en-sujato: “King Disampati has passed away.

root-pli-ms: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
translation-en-sujato: But after being anointed, King Reṇu amused himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

root-pli-ms: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti, madanīyā kāmā?
translation-en-sujato: Who knows the intoxicating power of sensual pleasures?

root-pli-ms: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ evaṁ vadetha:
translation-en-sujato: Come, sirs, go to Prince Reṇu and say,

root-pli-ms: ‘disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṁ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṁ taṁ vacanan’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, King Disampati has passed away, and you have been anointed as king. Do you remember what you said?’”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the six aristocrats. They went to Prince Reṇu and said,

root-pli-ms: “disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṁ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṁ taṁ vacanan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, King Disampati has passed away, and you have been anointed as king. Do you remember what you said?”

root-pli-ms: “Sarāmahaṁ, bho, taṁ vacanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “I remember, sirs.

root-pli-ms: Ko nu kho, bho, pahoti imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhajitun”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Who is able to neatly divide into seven equal parts this great land, so broad in the north and narrow as the front of a cart in the south?”
comment-en-sujato: T8 is identical: 其界廣闊。正南南隅，其界狹略，猶如車形. DA 3 is briefer: 此閻浮提地， 內廣外狹

root-pli-ms: “Ko nu kho, bho, añño pahoti, aññatra mahāgovindena brāhmaṇenā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Who else, sir, if not the Great Steward?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, reṇu rājā aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So King Reṇu addressed one of his men,

root-pli-ms: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ evaṁ vadehi:
translation-en-sujato: “Please, mister, go to the brahmin Great Steward and say that

root-pli-ms: ‘rājā taṁ, bhante, reṇu āmantetī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: King Reṇu summons him.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: “rājā taṁ, bhante, reṇu āmantetī”ti.
“Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇunā raññā saddhiṁ sammodi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward went to the king and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho, bho, mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ reṇu rājā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the king said to him,

root-pli-ms: “etu, bhavaṁ govindo imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhajatū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Come, let the good Steward neatly divide into seven equal parts this great land, so broad in the north and narrow as the front of a cart in the south.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho bho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhaji.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the Great Steward, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: Sabbāni sakaṭamukhāni paṭṭhapesi.
translation-en-sujato: All were set up like the fronts of carts,
comment-en-sujato: Neither RD nor MW translate this line. See https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/how-to-divide-india-like-a-plie/5832

root-pli-ms: Tatra sudaṁ majjhe reṇussa rañño janapado hoti.
translation-en-sujato: with King Reṇu’s nation in the center.

root-pli-ms: Dantapuraṁ kaliṅgānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Dantapura for the Kaliṅgas;

root-pli-ms: assakānañca potanaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: Potana for the Assakas;

root-pli-ms: Mahesayaṁ avantīnaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Mahissati for the Avantis;

root-pli-ms: sovīrānañca rorukaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Roruka for the Sovīras;

root-pli-ms: Mithilā ca videhānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Mithila for the Videhas;

root-pli-ms: campā aṅgesu māpitā;
translation-en-sujato: Campā was made for the Aṅgas;

root-pli-ms: Bārāṇasī ca kāsīnaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: and Varanasi for the Kāsīs:

root-pli-ms: ete govindamāpitāti.
translation-en-sujato: these were laid out by the Steward.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yathāsakena lābhena attamanā ahesuṁ paripuṇṇasaṅkappā:
translation-en-sujato: Then those six aristocrats were delighted with their respective gains, having achieved all they wished for,
reference: csp1ed7.190, csp2ed7.190, dr10.266, ms7D_692, msdiv310, ndp7.176, pts-vp-pli2.236, sc49, vri2.173

root-pli-ms: “yaṁ vata no ahosi icchitaṁ, yaṁ ākaṅkhitaṁ, yaṁ adhippetaṁ, yaṁ abhipatthitaṁ, taṁ no laddhan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “We have received exactly what we wanted, what we wished for, what we desired, what we yearned for.”

root-pli-ms: Sattabhū brahmadatto ca,
translation-en-sujato: Sattabhū and Brahmadatta,

root-pli-ms: vessabhū bharato saha;
translation-en-sujato: Vessabhū and Bharata,

root-pli-ms: Reṇu dve dhataraṭṭhā ca,
translation-en-sujato: Reṇu and the two Dhataraṭṭhas:

root-pli-ms: tadāsuṁ satta bhāradhāti.
translation-en-sujato: these are the seven Bhāratas.

root-pli-ms: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro niṭṭhito.
translation-en-sujato: The first recitation section is finished.

root-pli-ms: 6.2. Kittisaddaabbhuggamana
translation-en-sujato: 6.2. A Good Reputation

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the six aristocrats approached the Great Steward and said,

root-pli-ms: “yathā kho bhavaṁ govindo reṇussa rañño sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo.
translation-en-sujato: “Steward, just as you are King Reṇu’s friend, dear, beloved, and cherished,

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho bhavaṁ govindo amhākampi sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo, anusāsatu no bhavaṁ govindo;
translation-en-sujato: you are also our friend.

root-pli-ms: mā no bhavaṁ govindo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Would you manage our affairs? Please don’t turn us down!”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tesaṁ channaṁ khattiyānaṁ paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sirs,” replied the Great Steward.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo satta ca rājāno khattiye muddhāvasitte rajje anusāsi, satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsāle satta ca nhātakasatāni mante vācesi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward managed the realms of the seven kings. And he taught seven well-to-do brahmins, and seven hundred bathed initiates to recite the hymns.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa aparena samayena evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchi:
translation-en-sujato: After some time he got this good reputation,
reference: cck10.286, csp1ed7.191, csp2ed7.191, dr10.267, ms7D_696, msdiv312, pts-cs38, pts-vp-pli2.237, sc52, sya10.270, vri2.174

root-pli-ms: “sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “The Great Steward sees Brahmā in person! The Great Steward discusses, converses, and consults with Brahmā in person!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: The Great Steward thought,

root-pli-ms: “mayhaṁ kho evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
translation-en-sujato: “I have the reputation

root-pli-ms: ‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: of seeing Brahmā in person, and discussing with him in person.

root-pli-ms: Na kho panāhaṁ brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.
translation-en-sujato: But I don’t.

root-pli-ms: Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said:

root-pli-ms: ‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Whoever goes on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practices the absorption on compassion sees Brahmā and discusses with him.’

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyeyyaṁ, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyeyyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I do that?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Great Steward went to King Reṇu and told him of the situation, saying,

root-pli-ms: “mayhaṁ kho, bho, evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
Na kho panāhaṁ, bho, brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.
Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.
Icchāmahaṁ, bho, vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyituṁ, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyituṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I wish to go on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practice the absorption on compassion.

root-pli-ms: namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena bhattābhihārenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: No one should approach me, except for the one who brings my meal.”

root-pli-ms: “Yassadāni bhavaṁ govindo kālaṁ maññatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats to put the same proposal, and received the same reply.
reference: ms7D_698, msdiv314, pts-cs40, pts-vp-pli2.238, sc54, sya10.271

root-pli-ms: “mayhaṁ kho, bho, evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
Na kho panāhaṁ, bho, brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.
Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ,
‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.
Icchāmahaṁ, bho, vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyituṁ, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyituṁ;
namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena bhattābhihārenā”ti.
“Yassadāni bhavaṁ govindo kālaṁ maññatī”ti.
Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā satta ca nhātakasatāni tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsāle satta ca nhātakasatāni etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He also went to the seven well-to-do brahmins and seven hundred bathed initiates and put to them the same proposal, adding,

root-pli-ms: “mayhaṁ kho, bho, evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
Na kho panāhaṁ, bho, brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.
Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti, brahmunā sallapati, brahmunā mantetī’ti.
Tena hi, bho, yathāsute yathāpariyatte mante vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karotha, aññamaññañca mante vācetha;
translation-en-sujato: “Sirs, recite the hymns in detail as you have learned and memorized them, and teach each other how to recite.”

root-pli-ms: icchāmahaṁ, bho, vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyituṁ, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyituṁ;
namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena bhattābhihārenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And they too said,

root-pli-ms: “Yassadāni bhavaṁ govindo kālaṁ maññatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena cattārīsā bhariyā sādisiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā cattārīsā bhariyā sādisiyo etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward went to his forty equal wives to put the same proposal to them, and received the same reply.

root-pli-ms: “mayhaṁ kho, bhotī, evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
Na kho panāhaṁ, bhotī, brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.
Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ
‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti, brahmunā sallapati, brahmunā mantetī’ti,
icchāmahaṁ, bhotī, vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyituṁ, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyituṁ;
namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena bhattābhihārenā”ti.
“Yassadāni bhavaṁ govindo kālaṁ maññatī”ti.
Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo puratthimena nagarassa navaṁ sandhāgāraṁ kārāpetvā vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyi, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyi;
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward had a new meeting hall built to the east of his citadel, where he went on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practiced the absorption on compassion.
reference: cck10.290, csp1ed7.193, csp2ed7.193, ms7D_701, msdiv317, pts-cs43, sc57

root-pli-ms: nāssudha koci upasaṅkamati aññatra ekena bhattābhihārena.
translation-en-sujato: And no one approached him except the one who brought him meals.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena ahudeva ukkaṇṭhanā ahu paritassanā:
translation-en-sujato: But then, when the four months had passed, the Great Steward became dissatisfied and anxious,

root-pli-ms: “sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “I have heard that brahmins of the past said that

root-pli-ms: ‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: whoever goes on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practices the absorption on compassion sees Brahmā and discusses with him.

root-pli-ms: Na kho panāhaṁ brahmānaṁ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi na brahmunā sallapāmi na brahmunā mantemī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But I neither see Brahmā nor discuss with him.”

root-pli-ms: 6.3. Brahmunāsākacchā
translation-en-sujato: 6.3. A Discussion With Brahmā

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, brahmā sanaṅkumāro mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And then Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra, knowing what the Great Steward was thinking, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Brahmā realm and reappeared in the Great Steward’s presence.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa ahudeva bhayaṁ ahu chambhitattaṁ ahu lomahaṁso yathā taṁ adiṭṭhapubbaṁ rūpaṁ disvā.
translation-en-sujato: At that, the Great Steward became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end, as he had never seen such a sight before.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: So he addressed Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra in verse:

root-pli-ms: “Vaṇṇavā yasavā sirimā,
translation-en-sujato: “Who might you be, sir,

root-pli-ms: ko nu tvamasi mārisa;
translation-en-sujato: so beautiful, glorious, majestic?

root-pli-ms: Ajānantā taṁ pucchāma,
translation-en-sujato: Not knowing, I ask—

root-pli-ms: kathaṁ jānemu taṁ mayan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: how am I to know who you are?”

root-pli-ms: “Maṁ ve kumāraṁ jānanti,
translation-en-sujato: “In the Brahmā realm they know me

root-pli-ms: brahmaloke sanantanaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: as ‘The Eternal Youth’.

root-pli-ms: Sabbe jānanti maṁ devā,
translation-en-sujato: All the gods know me thus,

root-pli-ms: evaṁ govinda jānahi”.
translation-en-sujato: and so you should know me, Steward.”

root-pli-ms: “Āsanaṁ udakaṁ pajjaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “A Brahmā deserves a seat and water,

root-pli-ms: madhusākañca brahmuno;
translation-en-sujato: foot-salve, and sweet cakes.

root-pli-ms: Agghe bhavantaṁ pucchāma,
translation-en-sujato: Sir, I ask you to please accept

root-pli-ms: agghaṁ kurutu no bhavaṁ”.
translation-en-sujato: these gifts of hospitality.”

root-pli-ms: “Paṭiggaṇhāma te agghaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “I accept the gifts of hospitality

root-pli-ms: yaṁ tvaṁ govinda bhāsasi;
translation-en-sujato: of which you speak.

root-pli-ms: Diṭṭhadhammahitatthāya,
translation-en-sujato: I grant you the opportunity

root-pli-ms: samparāya sukhāya ca;
translation-en-sujato: to ask whatever you desire—

root-pli-ms: Katāvakāso pucchassu,
translation-en-sujato: about welfare and benefit in this life,

root-pli-ms: yaṁ kiñci abhipatthitan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: or happiness in lives to come.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Great Steward thought,
reference: cck10.291, csp1ed7.194, csp2ed7.194, mc10.206, ms7D_707, msdiv319, pts-cs45, pts-vp-pli2.241, sc63

root-pli-ms: “katāvakāso khomhi brahmunā sanaṅkumārena.
translation-en-sujato: “Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra has granted me an opportunity.

root-pli-ms: Kiṁ nu kho ahaṁ brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ puccheyyaṁ diṭṭhadhammikaṁ vā atthaṁ samparāyikaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Should I ask him about what is beneficial for this life or lives to come?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then he thought,

root-pli-ms: “kusalo kho ahaṁ diṭṭhadhammikānaṁ atthānaṁ, aññepi maṁ diṭṭhadhammikaṁ atthaṁ pucchanti.
translation-en-sujato: “I’m a skilled in what is beneficial for this life, and others even ask me about it.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ samparāyikaññeva atthaṁ puccheyyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I ask Brahmā about the benefit that specifically applies to lives to come?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: So he addressed Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra in verse:

root-pli-ms: “Pucchāmi brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “I’m in doubt, so I ask Brahmā—who is free of doubt—

root-pli-ms: Kaṅkhī akaṅkhiṁ paravediyesu;
translation-en-sujato: about things one may learn from another.

root-pli-ms: Katthaṭṭhito kimhi ca sikkhamāno,
translation-en-sujato: Standing on what, training in what

root-pli-ms: Pappoti macco amataṁ brahmalokan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: may a mortal reach the deathless Brahmā realm?”

root-pli-ms: “Hitvā mamattaṁ manujesu brahme,
translation-en-sujato: “He among men, O brahmin, has given up possessions,
comment-en-sujato: brahme is the normal vocative for brahmā. However in verse it is sometimes used as vocative for brahmaṇa, too. See Snp 5.6, Ja 456, and several other Jatakas.

root-pli-ms: Ekodibhūto karuṇedhimutto;
translation-en-sujato: become one, compassionate,

root-pli-ms: Nirāmagandho virato methunasmā,
translation-en-sujato: free from the stench of decay, and refraining from sex.

root-pli-ms: Etthaṭṭhito ettha ca sikkhamāno;
translation-en-sujato: Standing on that, training in that

root-pli-ms: Pappoti macco amataṁ brahmalokan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: a mortal may reach the deathless Brahmā realm.”

root-pli-ms: “‘Hitvā mamattan’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I understand what ‘giving up possessions’ means.

root-pli-ms: Idhekacco appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati,
translation-en-sujato: It’s when someone gives up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: iti ‘hitvā mamattan’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how I understand ‘giving up possessions’.

root-pli-ms: ‘Ekodibhūto’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Sir, I understand what ‘oneness’ means.

root-pli-ms: Idhekacco vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: It’s when someone frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

root-pli-ms: iti ‘ekodibhūto’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how I understand ‘oneness’.

root-pli-ms: ‘Karuṇedhimutto’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Sir, I understand what ‘compassionate’ means.

root-pli-ms: Idhekacco karuṇāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadhotiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ karuṇāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when someone meditates spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Iti ‘karuṇedhimutto’ti ahaṁ, bhoto, ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how I understand ‘compassionate’.

root-pli-ms: Āmagandhe ca kho ahaṁ, bhoto, bhāsamānassa na ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: But I don’t understand what you say about the stench of decay.

root-pli-ms: Ke āmagandhā manujesu brahme,
translation-en-sujato: What among men, O Brahmā, is the stench of decay?

root-pli-ms: Ete avidvā idha brūhi dhīra;
translation-en-sujato: I don’t understand, so tell me, wise one:

root-pli-ms: Kenāvaṭā vāti pajā kurutu,
translation-en-sujato: wrapped in what do people stink,
variant-pli-ms: kurutu → kurūrā (bj); kururū (sya-all, km); kuruṭṭharū (pts1ed); kurūru (?) | Kenāvaṭā → kenāvutā (bj); kenāvuṭā (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: Āpāyikā nivutabrahmalokā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: headed for hell, shut out of the Brahmā realm?”

root-pli-ms: “Kodho mosavajjaṁ nikati ca dubbho,
translation-en-sujato: “Anger, lies, fraud, and deceit,

root-pli-ms: Kadariyatā atimāno usūyā;
translation-en-sujato: miserliness, vanity, jealousy,

root-pli-ms: Icchā vivicchā paraheṭhanā ca,
translation-en-sujato: desire, stinginess, harassing others,
comment-en-sujato: PTS, followed by RD and MW, read vicikiccha, which is evidently a mistake. comm: taṇhālakkhaṇā icchā ca, macchariyalakkhaṇā vivicchā ca

root-pli-ms: Lobho ca doso ca mado ca moho;
translation-en-sujato: greed, hate, pride, and delusion—

root-pli-ms: Etesu yuttā anirāmagandhā,
translation-en-sujato: those bound to such things have the stench of decay;

root-pli-ms: Āpāyikā nivutabrahmalokā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: they’re headed for hell, shut out of the Brahmā realm.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kho ahaṁ, bhoto, āmagandhe bhāsamānassa ājānāmi. Te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
translation-en-sujato: “As I understand what you say about the stench of decay, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness!”

root-pli-ms: “Yassadāni bhavaṁ govindo kālaṁ maññatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

root-pli-ms: 6.4. Reṇurājaāmantanā
translation-en-sujato: 6.4. Informing King Reṇu

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the Great Steward went to King Reṇu and said,

root-pli-ms: “aññaṁ dāni bhavaṁ purohitaṁ pariyesatu, yo bhoto rajjaṁ anusāsissati.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, please now find another high priest to manage the affairs of state for you.

root-pli-ms: Icchāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
translation-en-sujato: As I understand what Brahmā says about the stench of decay, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: “Āmantayāmi rājānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: I announce to King Reṇu,

root-pli-ms: reṇuṁ bhūmipatiṁ ahaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: the lord of the land:

root-pli-ms: Tvaṁ pajānassu rajjena,
translation-en-sujato: you must learn how to rule,

root-pli-ms: nāhaṁ porohicce rame”.
translation-en-sujato: for I no longer care for my ministry.”

root-pli-ms: “Sace te ūnaṁ kāmehi,
translation-en-sujato: “If you’re lacking any pleasures,

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ paripūrayāmi te;
