root-pli-ms: Yo taṁ hiṁsati vāremi,
translation-en-sujato: I’ll protect you from any harm,

root-pli-ms: bhūmisenāpati ahaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: for I command the nation’s army.

root-pli-ms: Tuvaṁ pitā ahaṁ putto,
translation-en-sujato: You are my father, I am your son!

root-pli-ms: mā no govinda pājahi”.
translation-en-sujato: O Steward, please don’t leave!”

root-pli-ms: “Namatthi ūnaṁ kāmehi,
translation-en-sujato: “I’m lacking no pleasures,

root-pli-ms: hiṁsitā me na vijjati;
translation-en-sujato: and no-one is harming me.

root-pli-ms: Amanussavaco sutvā,
translation-en-sujato: I’ve heard a non-human voice,

root-pli-ms: tasmāhaṁ na gahe rame”.
translation-en-sujato: so I no longer care for lay life.”

root-pli-ms: “Amanusso kathaṁvaṇṇo,
translation-en-sujato: “What was that non-human like?

root-pli-ms: kiṁ te atthaṁ abhāsatha;
translation-en-sujato: What did he say to you,

root-pli-ms: Yañca sutvā jahāsi no,
translation-en-sujato: hearing which you would abandon

root-pli-ms: gehe amhe ca kevalī”.
translation-en-sujato: our house and all our people?”

root-pli-ms: “Upavutthassa me pubbe,
translation-en-sujato: “Before entering this retreat,

root-pli-ms: yiṭṭhukāmassa me sato;
translation-en-sujato: I only liked to sacrifice.

root-pli-ms: Aggi pajjalito āsi,
translation-en-sujato: I kindled the sacred flame,

root-pli-ms: kusapattaparitthato.
translation-en-sujato: strewn about with kusa grass.

root-pli-ms: Tato me brahmā pāturahu,
translation-en-sujato: But then Brahmā appeared to me,

root-pli-ms: brahmalokā sanantano;
translation-en-sujato: the Eternal Youth from the Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: So me pañhaṁ viyākāsi,
translation-en-sujato: He answered my question,

root-pli-ms: taṁ sutvā na gahe rame”.
translation-en-sujato: hearing which I no longer care for lay life.”

root-pli-ms: “Saddahāmi ahaṁ bhoto,
translation-en-sujato: “I have faith, O Steward,

root-pli-ms: yaṁ tvaṁ govinda bhāsasi;
translation-en-sujato: in that of which you speak.

root-pli-ms: Amanussavaco sutvā,
translation-en-sujato: Having heard a non-human voice,

root-pli-ms: kathaṁ vattetha aññathā.
translation-en-sujato: what else could you do?

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ anuvattissāma,
translation-en-sujato: We will follow your example,

root-pli-ms: satthā govinda no bhavaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: Steward, be my Teacher!

root-pli-ms: Maṇi yathā veḷuriyo,
translation-en-sujato: Like a gem of beryl—

root-pli-ms: akāco vimalo subho;
translation-en-sujato: flawless, immaculate, beautiful—

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ suddhā carissāma,
translation-en-sujato: that’s how pure we shall live,

root-pli-ms: govindassānusāsaneti.
translation-en-sujato: in the Steward’s dispensation.

root-pli-ms: Sace bhavaṁ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma.
translation-en-sujato: If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

root-pli-ms: Atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
6.5. Chakhattiyaāmantanā
translation-en-sujato: 6.5. Informing the Six Aristocrats

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:

root-pli-ms: “aññaṁ dāni bhavanto purohitaṁ pariyesantu, yo bhavantānaṁ rajje anusāsissati.
translation-en-sujato: “Sirs, please now find another high priest to manage the affairs of state for you.

root-pli-ms: Icchāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
translation-en-sujato: As I understand what Brahmā says about the stench of decay, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā ekamantaṁ apakkamma evaṁ samacintesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the six aristocrats withdrew to one side and thought up a plan,

root-pli-ms: “ime kho brāhmaṇā nāma dhanaluddhā;
translation-en-sujato: “These brahmins are really greedy for wealth.

root-pli-ms: yannūna mayaṁ mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ dhanena sikkheyyāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we try to persuade him with wealth?”

root-pli-ms: Te mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: They returned to the Great Steward and said,

root-pli-ms: “saṁvijjati kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ, tato bhoto yāvatakena attho, tāvatakaṁ āharīyatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “In these seven kingdoms there is abundant wealth. We’ll get you as much as you want.”

root-pli-ms: “Alaṁ, bho, mamapidaṁ pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ bhavantānaṁyeva vāhasā.
translation-en-sujato: “Enough, sirs. I already have abundant wealth, owing to my lords.

root-pli-ms: Tamahaṁ sabbaṁ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.”

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā,
pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.

root-pli-ms: “ime kho brāhmaṇā nāma itthiluddhā;
translation-en-sujato: “These brahmins are really greedy for women.

root-pli-ms: yannūna mayaṁ mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ itthīhi sikkheyyāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we try to persuade him with women?”

root-pli-ms: Te mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: They returned to the Great Steward and said,

root-pli-ms: “saṁvijjanti kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtā itthiyo, tato bhoto yāvatikāhi attho, tāvatikā ānīyatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “In these seven kingdoms there are many women. We’ll get you as many as you want.”

root-pli-ms: “Alaṁ, bho, mamapimā cattārīsā bhariyā sādisiyo.
translation-en-sujato: “Enough, sirs. I already have forty equal wives.

root-pli-ms: “aññaṁ dāni bhavanto ācariyaṁ pariyesantu, yo bhavantānaṁ mante vācessati.
translation-en-sujato: “Sirs, please now find another teacher to teach you to recite the hymns.

root-pli-ms: Icchāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

root-pli-ms: “Mā bhavaṁ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
translation-en-sujato: “Please don’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness!

root-pli-ms: Pabbajjā, bho, appesakkhā ca appalābhā ca;
translation-en-sujato: The life of one gone forth is of little influence or profit,

root-pli-ms: brahmaññaṁ mahesakkhañca mahālābhañcā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: whereas the life of a brahmin is of great influence and profit.”

root-pli-ms: “Mā bhavanto evaṁ avacuttha: ‘pabbajjā appesakkhā ca appalābhā ca, brahmaññaṁ mahesakkhañca mahālābhañcā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Please, sirs, don’t say that.

root-pli-ms: Ko nu kho, bho, aññatra mayā mahesakkhataro vā mahālābhataro vā.
translation-en-sujato: Who has greater influence and profit than myself?

root-pli-ms: Ahañhi, bho, etarahi rājāva raññaṁ brahmāva brāhmaṇānaṁ devatāva gahapatikānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: For now I am like a king to kings, like Brahmā to brahmins, like a deity to householders.

root-pli-ms: Tamahaṁ sabbaṁ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
translation-en-sujato: As I understand what Brahmā says about the stench of decay, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajissāmahaṁ, bho, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

root-pli-ms: “Sace bhavaṁ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

translation-en-sujato: 6.7. Informing the Wives

root-pli-ms: “yā bhotīnaṁ icchati, sakāni vā ñātikulāni gacchatu aññaṁ vā bhattāraṁ pariyesatu.
translation-en-sujato: “Ladies, please do whatever you wish, whether returning to your own families, or finding another husband.

root-pli-ms: Icchāmahaṁ, bhotī, agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
translation-en-sujato: As I understand what Brahmā says about the stench of decay, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajissāmahaṁ, bhotī, agārasmā anagāriyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

root-pli-ms: “Tvaññeva no ñāti ñātikāmānaṁ, tvaṁ pana bhattā bhattukāmānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “You are the only family we want! You are the only husband we want!

root-pli-ms: Sace bhavaṁ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: If you are going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

root-pli-ms: 6.8. Mahāgovindapabbajjā
translation-en-sujato: 6.8. The Great Steward Goes Forth

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tassa sattāhassa accayena kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
translation-en-sujato: When a week had passed, the Great Steward shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Pabbajitaṁ pana mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ satta ca rājāno khattiyā muddhāvasittā satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā satta ca nhātakasatāni cattārīsā ca bhariyā sādisiyo anekāni ca khattiyasahassāni anekāni ca brāhmaṇasahassāni anekāni ca gahapatisahassāni anekehi ca itthāgārehi itthiyo kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitaṁ anupabbajiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And when he had gone forth, the seven anointed aristocrat kings, the seven brahmins with seven hundred initiates, the forty equal wives, and many thousands of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and many harem women shaved off their hair and beards, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Tāya sudaṁ, bho, parisāya parivuto mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmanigamarājadhānīsu cārikaṁ carati.
translation-en-sujato: Escorted by that assembly, the Great Steward wandered on tour among the villages, towns, and capital cities.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho pana, bho, tena samayena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā upasaṅkamati, tattha rājāva hoti raññaṁ, brahmāva brāhmaṇānaṁ, devatāva gahapatikānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And at that time, whenever he arrived at a village or town, he was like a king to kings, like Brahmā to brahmins, like a deity to householders.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena manussā khipanti vā upakkhalanti vā.
translation-en-sujato: And whenever people sneezed or tripped over

root-pli-ms: Te evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: they’d say:

root-pli-ms: “namatthu mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa, namatthu satta purohitassā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Homage to the Great Steward! Homage to the high priest for the seven!”

root-pli-ms: Mahāgovindo, bho, brāhmaṇo mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā vihāsi, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And the Great Steward meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …

root-pli-ms: muditāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: rejoicing …

root-pli-ms: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā …pe… abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
translation-en-sujato: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Sāvakānañca brahmalokasahabyatāya maggaṁ desesi.
translation-en-sujato: And he taught his disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, bho, tena samayena mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa sāvakā sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājāniṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Those of his disciples who completely understood the Great Steward’s instructions,

root-pli-ms: Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ brahmalokaṁ upapajjiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: at the breaking up of the body, after death, were reborn in the Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājāniṁsu, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā appekacce paranimmitavasavattīnaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: Of those disciples who only partly understood the Great Steward’s instructions, some were reborn in the company of the Gods Who Control the Creations of Others,

root-pli-ms: appekacce nimmānaratīnaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: while some were reborn in the company of the Gods Who Love to Create,

root-pli-ms: appekacce tusitānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: or the Joyful Gods,

root-pli-ms: appekacce yāmānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: or the Gods of Yama,

root-pli-ms: appekacce tāvatiṁsānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: or the Gods of the Thirty-Three,

root-pli-ms: appekacce cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: or the Gods of the Four Great Kings.

root-pli-ms: ye sabbanihīnaṁ kāyaṁ paripūresuṁ te gandhabbakāyaṁ paripūresuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And at the very least they swelled the hosts of the fairies.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bho, sabbesaṁyeva tesaṁ kulaputtānaṁ amoghā pabbajjā ahosi avañjhā saphalā saudrayā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.’

root-pli-ms: Sarati taṁ bhagavā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Do you remember this, Blessed One?”

root-pli-ms: “Sarāmahaṁ, pañcasikha.
translation-en-sujato: “I remember, Pañcasikha.
reference: bj8.380, cck10.302, ms7D_741, msdiv329, pts-cs61, sc97

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ tena samayena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo ahosiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I myself was the brahmin Great Steward at that time.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ tesaṁ sāvakānaṁ brahmalokasahabyatāya maggaṁ desesiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And I taught those disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Brahmā.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṁ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati, yāvadeva brahmalokūpapattiyā.
translation-en-sujato: But that spiritual path of mine doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
translation-en-sujato: But this spiritual path does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Katamañca taṁ, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati?
translation-en-sujato: And what is the spiritual path that leads to extinguishment?

root-pli-ms: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
translation-en-sujato: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho taṁ, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the spiritual path that leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana me, pañcasikha, sāvakā sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, te āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti;
translation-en-sujato: Those of my disciples who completely understand my instructions realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, te pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātikā honti tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
translation-en-sujato: Of those disciples who only partly understand my instructions, some, with the ending of the five lower fetters, become reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

root-pli-ms: Ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino honti sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Some, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā honti avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
translation-en-sujato: And some, with the ending of three fetters, become stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, pañcasikha, sabbesaṁyeva imesaṁ kulaputtānaṁ amoghā pabbajjā avañjhā saphalā saudrayā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamano pañcasikho gandhabbaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
translation-en-sujato: Delighted, the fairy Pañcasikha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

root-pli-ms: Mahāgovindasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 20
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 20

root-pli-ms: Mahāsamayasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Great Congregation

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Great Wood, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.

root-pli-ms: dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṁ dassanāya bhikkhusaṅghañca.
translation-en-sujato: And most of the deities from ten solar systems had gathered to see the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho catunnaṁ suddhāvāsakāyikānaṁ devatānaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then four deities of the Pure Abodes, aware of what was happening, thought:

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ kho bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;
dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṁ dassanāya bhikkhusaṅghañca.
Yannūna mayampi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike paccekaṁ gāthaṁ bhāseyyāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Why don’t we go to the Buddha and each recite a verse in his presence?”
variant-pli-ms: paccekaṁ gāthaṁ → paccekagāthā (si); paccekagāthaṁ (sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tā devatā seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—suddhāvāsesu devesu antarahitā bhagavato purato pāturahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the Pure Abodes and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tā devatā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: They bowed to the Buddha and stood to one side.

root-pli-ms: Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṁ gāthaṁ abhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Standing to one side, one deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

root-pli-ms: “Mahāsamayo pavanasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “There’s a great congregation in the woods,

root-pli-ms: Devakāyā samāgatā;
translation-en-sujato: a host of gods have assembled.

root-pli-ms: Āgatamha imaṁ dhammasamayaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: We’ve come to this righteous congregation

root-pli-ms: Dakkhitāye aparājitasaṅghan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: to see the invincible Saṅgha!”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṁ gāthaṁ abhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

root-pli-ms: “Tatra bhikkhavo samādahaṁsu,
translation-en-sujato: “The mendicants there are immersed in samādhi,

root-pli-ms: Cittamattano ujukaṁ akaṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: they’ve straightened out their own minds.
variant-pli-ms: ujukaṁ akaṁsu → ujukamakaṁsu (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Sārathīva nettāni gahetvā,
translation-en-sujato: Like a charioteer who has taken the reins,

root-pli-ms: Indriyāni rakkhanti paṇḍitā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: the astute ones protect their senses.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṁ gāthaṁ abhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

root-pli-ms: “Chetvā khīlaṁ chetvā palighaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: “Having cut the stake and cut the bar,

root-pli-ms: Indakhīlaṁ ūhacca manejā;
translation-en-sujato: they’re unstirred, with boundary pillar uprooted.

root-pli-ms: Te caranti suddhā vimalā,
translation-en-sujato: They live pure and immaculate,

root-pli-ms: Cakkhumatā sudantā susunāgā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: the young dragons tamed by the seer.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṁ gāthaṁ abhāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Then another deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
reference: csp1ed7.204, csp2ed7.204, ms7D_753, ndp7.190, pts-vp-pli2.255, sc8

root-pli-ms: “Ye keci buddhaṁ saraṇaṁ gatāse,
translation-en-sujato: “Anyone who has gone to the Buddha for refuge

root-pli-ms: Na te gamissanti apāyabhūmiṁ;
translation-en-sujato: won’t go to a plane of loss.

root-pli-ms: Pahāya mānusaṁ dehaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: After giving up this human body,

root-pli-ms: Devakāyaṁ paripūressantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: they swell the hosts of gods.”

root-pli-ms: 1. Devatāsannipāta
translation-en-sujato: 1. The Gathering of Deities

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

root-pli-ms: “yebhuyyena, bhikkhave, dasasu lokadhātūsu devatā sannipatitā honti, tathāgataṁ dassanāya bhikkhusaṅghañca.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants, most of the deities from ten solar systems have gathered to see the Realized One and the mendicant Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: Yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṁ etapparamāyeva devatā sannipatitā ahesuṁ seyyathāpi mayhaṁ etarahi.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddhas of the past had, and the Buddhas of the future will have, gatherings of deities that are at most like the gathering for me now.

root-pli-ms: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṁ etapparamāyeva devatā sannipatitā bhavissanti seyyathāpi mayhaṁ etarahi.
Ācikkhissāmi, bhikkhave, devakāyānaṁ nāmāni;
translation-en-sujato: I shall declare the names of the heavenly hosts;

root-pli-ms: kittayissāmi, bhikkhave, devakāyānaṁ nāmāni;
translation-en-sujato: I shall extol the names of the heavenly hosts;

root-pli-ms: desessāmi, bhikkhave, devakāyānaṁ nāmāni.
translation-en-sujato: I shall teach the names of the heavenly hosts.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasikarotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:

root-pli-ms: “Silokamanukassāmi,
translation-en-sujato: “I shall invoke a paean of praise!
comment-en-sujato: anukassami isn’t anukaroti as per PTS dict, but anu-kasati = anu + √kṛṣ as per CPD, see http://sanskritdictionary.com/anukar%E1%B9%A3a%E1%B8%A5/1647/4

root-pli-ms: yattha bhummā tadassitā;
translation-en-sujato: Where the earth-gods dwell,

root-pli-ms: Ye sitā girigabbharaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: there, in mountain caves,

root-pli-ms: pahitattā samāhitā.
translation-en-sujato: resolute and composed,

root-pli-ms: Puthūsīhāva sallīnā,
translation-en-sujato: dwell many like lonely lions,

root-pli-ms: lomahaṁsābhisambhuno;
translation-en-sujato: who have mastered their fears.

root-pli-ms: Odātamanasā suddhā,
translation-en-sujato: Their minds are bright and pure,

root-pli-ms: vippasannamanāvilā.
translation-en-sujato: clear and undisturbed.”

root-pli-ms: Bhiyyo pañcasate ñatvā,
translation-en-sujato: The teacher knew that over five hundred

root-pli-ms: vane kāpilavatthave;
translation-en-sujato: were in the wood at Kapilavatthu.

root-pli-ms: Tato āmantayī satthā,
translation-en-sujato: Therefore he addressed

root-pli-ms: sāvake sāsane rate.
translation-en-sujato: the disciples who love the teaching:

root-pli-ms: ‘Devakāyā abhikkantā,
translation-en-sujato: “The heavenly hosts have come forth;

root-pli-ms: te vijānātha bhikkhavo’;
translation-en-sujato: mendicants, you should be aware of them.”

root-pli-ms: Te ca ātappamakaruṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Those monks became keen,

translation-en-sujato: hearing the Buddha’s instruction.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ pāturahu ñāṇaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Knowledge manifested in them,

translation-en-sujato: seeing those non-human beings.

translation-en-sujato: Some saw a hundred,

root-pli-ms: sahassaṁ atha sattariṁ.
translation-en-sujato: a thousand, even seventy thousand,

root-pli-ms: Sataṁ eke sahassānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: while some saw a hundred thousand

root-pli-ms: amanussānamaddasuṁ;
translation-en-sujato: non-human beings.

root-pli-ms: Appekenantamaddakkhuṁ,
translation-en-sujato: But some saw an endless number

root-pli-ms: disā sabbā phuṭā ahuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: spread out in every direction.

root-pli-ms: Tañca sabbaṁ abhiññāya,

root-pli-ms: vavatthitvāna cakkhumā;
translation-en-sujato: and distinguished by the Seer.

translation-en-sujato: Therefore he addressed

translation-en-sujato: mendicants, you should be aware of them.

translation-en-sujato: I shall extol them for you,

root-pli-ms: girāhi anupubbaso’.
translation-en-sujato: with lyrics in proper order.

translation-en-sujato: There are seven thousand spirits,

translation-en-sujato: earth-gods of Kapilavatthu.

translation-en-sujato: to the meeting of mendicants in the wood.

translation-en-sujato: spirits of different colors.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans; east of Rājagaha there’s a brahmin village named Ambasaṇḍā, north of which, on Mount Vediyaka, is the Indasāla cave.
comment-en-sujato: Comm says the sala = sal tree. RD dismisses the Sanskritization as śaila. Note, however, that the subsequent publication of Skt fragments by Waldschmidt confirms this reading: chailaguhāyām at https://suttacentral.net/skt/sf241.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena sakkassa devānamindassa ussukkaṁ udapādi bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Sakka, the lord of gods, became eager to see the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakkassa devānamindassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: He thought,

root-pli-ms: “kahaṁ nu kho bhagavā etarahi viharati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ magadhesu viharantaṁ pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: He saw that the Buddha was at the Indasāla cave,

root-pli-ms: Disvāna deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, mārisā, bhagavā magadhesu viharati, pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Good sirs, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Indasāla cave.

root-pli-ms: Yadi pana, mārisā, mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho devā tāvatiṁsā sakkassa devānamindassa paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, lord,” replied the gods.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ āmantesi:

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavā magadhesu viharati pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate indasālaguhāyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Dear Pañcasikha, the Buddha is staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Indasāla cave.

root-pli-ms: Yadi pana, tāta pañcasikha, mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyāma arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: What if we were to go and see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya sakkassa devānamindassa anucariyaṁ upāgami.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, lord,” replied the fairy Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went as Sakka’s attendant.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakko devānamindo devehi tāvatiṁsehi parivuto pañcasikhena gandhabbadevaputtena purakkhato—
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka went at the head of a retinue consisting of the gods of the Thirty-Three and the fairy Pañcasikha.

root-pli-ms: seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṁsesu antarahito magadhesu pācīnato rājagahassa ambasaṇḍā nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tassuttarato vediyake pabbate paccuṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the heaven of the gods of the Thirty-Three and landed on Mount Vediyaka north of Ambasaṇḍā.

translation-en-sujato: Now at that time a dazzling light appeared over Mount Vediyaka and Ambasaṇḍā, as happens through the glory of the gods.

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena indasālaguhā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, lord,” replied the fairy Pañcasikha. Taking his arched harp made from the pale timber of wood-apple, he went to the Indasāla cave. When he had drawn near, he stood to one side, thinking,

root-pli-ms: “Ekamidaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ bhagavā uruvelāyaṁ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
translation-en-sujato: “This one time, sir, when you were first awakened, you were staying near Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho panāhaṁ, bhante, samayena bhaddā nāma sūriyavacchasā timbaruno gandhabbarañño dhītā, tamabhikaṅkhāmi.
translation-en-sujato: And at that time I was in love with the lady named Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, the daughter of the fairy king Timbaru.

root-pli-ms: Sā kho pana, bhante, bhaginī parakāminī hoti;
translation-en-sujato: But the sister desired another—
comment-en-sujato: The use of bhagini is obviously conventional here, but is nonetheless curious.

root-pli-ms: sikhaṇḍī nāma mātalissa saṅgāhakassa putto, tamabhikaṅkhati.
translation-en-sujato: it was Mātali the charioteer’s son named Sikhaḍḍī who she loved.

root-pli-ms: Yato kho ahaṁ, bhante, taṁ bhaginiṁ nālatthaṁ kenaci pariyāyena.
translation-en-sujato: Since I couldn’t win that sister by any means,

root-pli-ms: Athāhaṁ beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ ādāya yena timbaruno gandhabbarañño nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṁ assāvesiṁ, imā ca gāthā abhāsiṁ buddhūpasañhitā dhammūpasañhitā saṅghūpasañhitā arahantūpasañhitā kāmūpasañhitā—
translation-en-sujato: I took my arched harp to Timbaru’s home, where I played those verses.

root-pli-ms: Vande te pitaraṁ bhadde,
timbaruṁ sūriyavacchase;
Yena jātāsi kalyāṇī,
ānandajananī mama.
…pe…
Sālaṁva na ciraṁ phullaṁ,
pitaraṁ te sumedhase;
Vandamāno namassāmi,
yassāsetādisī pajāti.
Evaṁ vutte, bhante, bhaddā sūriyavacchasā maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When I finished, Suriyavacchasā said to me,

root-pli-ms: ‘na kho me, mārisa, so bhagavā sammukhā diṭṭho, api ca sutoyeva me so bhagavā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sudhammāyaṁ sabhāyaṁ upanaccantiyā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Dear sir, I have not personally seen the Buddha. But I did hear about him when I went to dance for the gods of the Thirty-Three in the Hall of Justice.

root-pli-ms: Yato kho tvaṁ, mārisa, taṁ bhagavantaṁ kittesi, hotu no ajja samāgamo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Since you extol the Buddha, let us meet up today.’

root-pli-ms: Soyeva no, bhante, tassā bhaginiyā saddhiṁ samāgamo ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s when I met up with that sister.

root-pli-ms: Na ca dāni tato pacchā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But we have not met since.”

root-pli-ms: 2. Sakkūpasaṅkama
translation-en-sujato: 2. The Approach of Sakka

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakkassa devānamindassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka, lord of gods, thought,

root-pli-ms: “paṭisammodati pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto bhagavatā, bhagavā ca pañcasikhenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Pañcasikha is exchanging pleasantries with the Buddha.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbadevaputtaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So he addressed Pañcasikha,

root-pli-ms: “abhivādehi me tvaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, bhagavantaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “My dear Pañcasikha, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:

root-pli-ms: ‘sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.’”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bhaddantavā”ti kho pañcasikho gandhabbadevaputto sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādeti:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, lord,” replied Pañcasikha. He bowed to the Buddha and said,

root-pli-ms: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ sukhī hotu, pañcasikha, sakko devānamindo sāmacco saparijano;
translation-en-sujato: “So may Sakka with his ministers and retinue be happy, Pañcasikha,” said the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: sukhakāmā hi devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “for all want to be happy—whether gods, humans, demons, dragons, fairies, or any of the other diverse creatures there may be.”

root-pli-ms: Evañca pana tathāgatā evarūpe mahesakkhe yakkhe abhivadanti.
translation-en-sujato: For that is how the Realized Ones salute such illustrious spirits.

root-pli-ms: Abhivadito sakko devānamindo bhagavato indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And being saluted by the Buddha, Sakka entered the Indasāla cave, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.

root-pli-ms: Devāpi tāvatiṁsā indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And the gods of the Thirty-Three did likewise,

root-pli-ms: Pañcasikhopi gandhabbadevaputto indasālaguhaṁ pavisitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: as did Pañcasikha.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena indasālaguhā visamā santī samā samapādi, sambādhā santī urundā samapādi, andhakāro guhāyaṁ antaradhāyi, āloko udapādi yathā taṁ devānaṁ devānubhāvena.
translation-en-sujato: And at that time the uneven places were evened out, the cramped places were opened up, the darkness vanished and light appeared, as happens through the glory of the gods.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha said to Sakka,

root-pli-ms: “acchariyamidaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa, abbhutamidaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa tāva bahukiccassa bahukaraṇīyassa yadidaṁ idhāgamanan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible and amazing that you, the venerable Kosiya, who has so many duties and so much to do, should come here.”

root-pli-ms: “Cirapaṭikāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo; api ca devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehi byāvaṭo; evāhaṁ nāsakkhiṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “For a long time I’ve wanted to go and see the Buddha, but I wasn’t able, being prevented by my many duties and responsibilities for the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: Ekamidaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati salaḷāgārake.
translation-en-sujato: This one time, sir, the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.

root-pli-ms: Atha khvāhaṁ, bhante, sāvatthiṁ agamāsiṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
translation-en-sujato: Then I went to Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana, bhante, samayena bhagavā aññatarena samādhinā nisinno hoti, bhūjati ca nāma vessavaṇassa mahārājassa paricārikā bhagavantaṁ paccupaṭṭhitā hoti, pañjalikā namassamānā tiṭṭhati.
translation-en-sujato: But at that time the Buddha was sitting immersed in some kind of meditation. And a divine maiden of Great King Vessavaṇa named Bhūjati was attending on the Buddha, standing there paying homage to him with joined palms.
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW have “wife” for paricarika. But from MN 37 we know that the paricarika was a maid attending on a nymph.

root-pli-ms: Atha khvāhaṁ, bhante, bhūjatiṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: So I said to her,

root-pli-ms: ‘abhivādehi me tvaṁ, bhagini, bhagavantaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sister, please bow to the Buddha for me, saying:

root-pli-ms: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, Sakka, lord of gods, with his ministers and retinue, bows with his head at your feet.”’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, sā bhūjati maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When I said this, she said to me,

root-pli-ms: ‘akālo kho, mārisa, bhagavantaṁ dassanāya;
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: paṭisallīno bhagavā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: as he’s in retreat.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tena hi, bhagini, yadā bhagavā tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito hoti, atha mama vacanena bhagavantaṁ abhivādehi:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sister, please convey my message when the Buddha emerges from that immersion.’

root-pli-ms: “sakko, bhante, devānamindo sāmacco saparijano bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”’ti.
Kacci me sā, bhante, bhaginī bhagavantaṁ abhivādesi?
translation-en-sujato: I hope that sister bowed to you?

root-pli-ms: Sarati bhagavā tassā bhaginiyā vacanan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Do you remember what she said?”

root-pli-ms: “Abhivādesi maṁ sā, devānaminda, bhaginī, sarāmahaṁ tassā bhaginiyā vacanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “She did bow, lord of gods, and I remember what she said.

root-pli-ms: Api cāhaṁ āyasmato nemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I also remember that it was the sound of your chariot wheels that pulled me out of that immersion.”

root-pli-ms: “Ye te, bhante, devā amhehi paṭhamataraṁ tāvatiṁsakāyaṁ upapannā, tesaṁ me sammukhā sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the gods who were reborn in the host of the Thirty-Three before me:

root-pli-ms: ‘yadā tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘When a Realized One arises in the world, perfected and fully awakened, the heavenly hosts swell, while the demon hosts dwindle.’

root-pli-ms: Taṁ me idaṁ, bhante, sakkhidiṭṭhaṁ yato tathāgato loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dibbā kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyāti.
translation-en-sujato: And I have seen this with my own eyes.

root-pli-ms: 2.1. Gopakavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 2.1. The Story of Gopikā

root-pli-ms: Idheva, bhante, kapilavatthusmiṁ gopikā nāma sakyadhītā ahosi buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī.
translation-en-sujato: Right here in Kapilavatthu there was a Sakyan lady named Gopikā who had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled her ethics.

root-pli-ms: Sā itthittaṁ virājetvā purisattaṁ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā.
translation-en-sujato: Losing her attachment to femininity, she developed masculinity. When her body broke up, after death, she was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
variant-pli-ms: itthittaṁ → itthicittaṁ (cck, pts1ed); itthīcittaṁ (sya1ed, sya2ed, km) | purisattaṁ → purisacittaṁ (sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ amhākaṁ puttattaṁ ajjhupagatā.
translation-en-sujato: In the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three she became one of my sons.

root-pli-ms: Tatrapi naṁ evaṁ jānanti:
translation-en-sujato: There they knew him as

root-pli-ms: ‘gopako devaputto, gopako devaputto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: the god Gopaka.

root-pli-ms: Aññepi, bhante, tayo bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapannā.
translation-en-sujato: Meanwhile three others, mendicants who had led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior fairy realm.

root-pli-ms: Te pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārayamānā amhākaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgacchanti amhākaṁ pāricariyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: There they amused themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, and became my servants and attendants.

root-pli-ms: Te amhākaṁ upaṭṭhānaṁ āgate amhākaṁ pāricariyaṁ gopako devaputto paṭicodesi:
translation-en-sujato: At that, Gopaka scolded them,

root-pli-ms: ‘kutomukhā nāma tumhe, mārisā, tassa bhagavato dhammaṁ assuttha—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Where on earth were you at, good sirs, when you heard the Buddha’s teaching!
comment-en-sujato: kutomukha contrasts with sammukha. Comm: “kutomukhāti bhagavati abhimukhe dhammaṁ desente tumhe kutomukhā kiṁ aññā vihitā ito cito ca olokayamānā udāhu niddāyamānā?” Alternatively, and perhaps more likely, it means “who on earth taught you the dhamma?”

root-pli-ms: ahañhi nāma itthikā samānā buddhe pasannā dhamme pasannā saṅghe pasannā sīlesu paripūrakārinī itthittaṁ virājetvā purisattaṁ bhāvetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ sakkassa devānamindassa puttattaṁ ajjhupagatā.
translation-en-sujato: For while I was still a woman I had confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and had fulfilled my ethics. I lost my attachment to femininity and developed masculinity. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. In the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three I became one of Sakka’s sons.

root-pli-ms: Idhāpi maṁ evaṁ jānanti:
translation-en-sujato: Here they know me as

root-pli-ms: “gopako devaputto gopako devaputto”ti.
translation-en-sujato: the god Gopaka.

root-pli-ms: Tumhe pana, mārisā, bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ caritvā hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapannā.
translation-en-sujato: But you, having led the spiritual life under the Buddha, were reborn in the inferior fairy realm.’

root-pli-ms: Duddiṭṭharūpaṁ vata bho addasāma, ye mayaṁ addasāma sahadhammike hīnaṁ gandhabbakāyaṁ upapanne’ti.
Tesaṁ, bhante, gopakena devaputtena paṭicoditānaṁ dve devā diṭṭheva dhamme satiṁ paṭilabhiṁsu kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ, eko pana devo kāme ajjhāvasi.
translation-en-sujato: When scolded by Gopaka, two of those gods in that very life gained mindfulness leading to the host of Brahmā’s Ministers. But one god remained attached to sensuality.
comment-en-sujato: It seems that the patilabhimsu must serve duty for the two phrases, an unusual construction in prose. Either that or a verb for rebirth has been omitted. Comm: 'Tattha diṭṭheva dhammeti tasmiññeva attabhāve jhānasatiṁ paṭilabhiṁsu. Tattheva ṭhatvā cutā pana kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ brahmapurohitasarīraṁ paṭilabhiṁsūti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.'

root-pli-ms: ‘Upāsikā cakkhumato ahosiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: ‘I was a laywoman disciple of the seer,

root-pli-ms: Nāmampi mayhaṁ ahu “gopikā”ti;
translation-en-sujato: and my name was Gopikā.

root-pli-ms: Buddhe ca dhamme ca abhippasannā,
translation-en-sujato: I was devoted to the Buddha and the teaching,

root-pli-ms: Saṅghañcupaṭṭhāsiṁ pasannacittā.
translation-en-sujato: and I faithfully served the Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: Tasseva buddhassa sudhammatāya,
translation-en-sujato: Because of the excellence of the Buddha’s teaching,

root-pli-ms: Sakkassa puttomhi mahānubhāvo;
translation-en-sujato: I’m now a mighty, splendid son of Sakka,

root-pli-ms: Mahājutīko tidivūpapanno,
translation-en-sujato: reborn among the Three and Thirty.

root-pli-ms: Jānanti maṁ idhāpi “gopako”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And here they know me as Gopaka.

root-pli-ms: Athaddasaṁ bhikkhavo diṭṭhapubbe,
translation-en-sujato: Then I saw some mendicants who I’d seen before,

root-pli-ms: Gandhabbakāyūpagate vasīne;
translation-en-sujato: dwelling in the host of fairies.

root-pli-ms: Imehi te gotamasāvakāse,
translation-en-sujato: When I used to be a human,

root-pli-ms: Ye ca mayaṁ pubbe manussabhūtā.
translation-en-sujato: they were disciples of Gotama.

root-pli-ms: Annena pānena upaṭṭhahimhā,
translation-en-sujato: I served them with food and drink,

root-pli-ms: Pādūpasaṅgayha sake nivesane;
translation-en-sujato: and clasped their feet in my own home.

root-pli-ms: Kutomukhā nāma ime bhavanto,
translation-en-sujato: Where on earth were they at

root-pli-ms: Buddhassa dhammāni paṭiggahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: when they learned the Buddha’s teachings?
variant-pli-ms: Buddhassa dhammāni paṭiggahesuṁ → buddhassa dhammaṁ na paṭiggahesuṁ (sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Paccattaṁ veditabbo hi dhammo,
translation-en-sujato: For each must know for themselves the teaching

root-pli-ms: Sudesito cakkhumatānubuddho;
translation-en-sujato: so well-taught, realized by the seer.

root-pli-ms: Ahañhi tumheva upāsamāno,
translation-en-sujato: I was one who followed you,

root-pli-ms: Sutvāna ariyāna subhāsitāni.
translation-en-sujato: having heard the fine words of the noble ones.

root-pli-ms: Sakkassa puttomhi mahānubhāvo,
translation-en-sujato: I’m now a mighty, splendid son of Sakka,

root-pli-ms: Mahājutīko tidivūpapanno;
translation-en-sujato: reborn among the Three and Thirty.

root-pli-ms: Tumhe pana seṭṭhamupāsamānā,
translation-en-sujato: But you followed the best of men,

root-pli-ms: Anuttaraṁ brahmacariyaṁ caritvā.
translation-en-sujato: and led the supreme spiritual life,

root-pli-ms: Hīnaṁ kāyaṁ upapannā bhavanto,
translation-en-sujato: but still you’re born in this lesser realm,

root-pli-ms: Anānulomā bhavatūpapatti;
translation-en-sujato: a rebirth not befitting.

root-pli-ms: Duddiṭṭharūpaṁ vata addasāma,
translation-en-sujato: It’s a sorry sight I see, good sirs,

root-pli-ms: Sahadhammike hīnakāyūpapanne.
translation-en-sujato: fellow Buddhists in a lesser realm.

root-pli-ms: Gandhabbakāyūpagatā bhavanto,
translation-en-sujato: Reborn in the host of fairies,

root-pli-ms: Devānamāgacchatha pāricariyaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: you only wait upon the gods.

root-pli-ms: Agāre vasato mayhaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Meanwhile, I dwelt in a house—

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ passa visesataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: but see my distinction now!

root-pli-ms: Itthī hutvā svajja pumomhi devo,
translation-en-sujato: Having been a woman now I’m a male god,

root-pli-ms: Dibbehi kāmehi samaṅgibhūto’;
translation-en-sujato: blessed with heavenly sensual pleasures.’

root-pli-ms: Te coditā gotamasāvakena,
translation-en-sujato: Scolded by that disciple of Gotama,

root-pli-ms: Saṁvegamāpādu samecca gopakaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: when they understood Gopaka, they were struck with urgency.

root-pli-ms: ‘Handa viyāyāma byāyāma,
translation-en-sujato: ‘Let’s strive, let’s try hard—
variant-pli-ms: byāyāma → viyāyamāma (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed) | viyāyāma → byāyamāma (bj); vigāyāma (sya-all, km); vitāyāma (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Mā no mayaṁ parapessā ahumhā’;
translation-en-sujato: we won’t serve others any more!’

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ duve vīriyamārabhiṁsu,
translation-en-sujato: Two of them aroused energy,

root-pli-ms: Anussaraṁ gotamasāsanāni.
translation-en-sujato: recalling the Buddha’s instructions.

root-pli-ms: Idheva cittāni virājayitvā,
translation-en-sujato: Right away they became dispassionate,

root-pli-ms: Kāmesu ādīnavamaddasaṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: seeing the drawbacks in sensual pleasures.

root-pli-ms: Te kāmasaṁyojanabandhanāni,
translation-en-sujato: The fetters and bonds of sensual pleasures—

root-pli-ms: Pāpimayogāni duraccayāni.
translation-en-sujato: the ties of the Wicked One so hard to break—

root-pli-ms: Nāgova sannāni guṇāni chetvā,
translation-en-sujato: they burst them like a bull elephant his ropes,
variant-pli-ms: sannāni guṇāni → sandānaguṇāni (bj, pts1ed); santāni guṇāni (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: Deve tāvatiṁse atikkamiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: and passed right over the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: Saindā devā sapajāpatikā,
translation-en-sujato: The gods with Inda and Pajāpati

root-pli-ms: Sabbe sudhammāya sabhāyupaviṭṭhā.
translation-en-sujato: were all gathered in the Hall of Justice.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ nisinnānaṁ abhikkamiṁsu,
translation-en-sujato: As they sat there, they passed over them,

root-pli-ms: Vīrā virāgā virajaṁ karontā;
translation-en-sujato: the heroes desireless, practicing purity.

root-pli-ms: Te disvā saṁvegamakāsi vāsavo,
translation-en-sujato: Seeing them, Vāsava was struck with a sense of urgency;

root-pli-ms: Devābhibhū devagaṇassa majjhe.
translation-en-sujato: the master of gods in the midst of the group said,

root-pli-ms: ‘Imehi te hīnakāyūpapannā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘These were born in the lesser fairy realm,

root-pli-ms: Deve tāvatiṁse abhikkamanti’;
translation-en-sujato: but now they pass us by!’

root-pli-ms: Saṁvegajātassa vaco nisamma,
translation-en-sujato: Heeding the speech of one so moved,

root-pli-ms: So gopako vāsavamajjhabhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Gopaka addressed Vāsava,

root-pli-ms: ‘Buddho janindatthi manussaloke,
translation-en-sujato: ‘There is a Buddha, a lord of men, in the world.
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW seem to take janinda as vocative, ignoring jan’. But Sakka is devinda, not janinda; and comm says Janindanti sabbalokuttamaṁ

root-pli-ms: Kāmābhibhū sakyamunīti ñāyati;
translation-en-sujato: Known as the Sakyan Sage, he’s mastered the senses.

root-pli-ms: Tasseva te puttā satiyā vihīnā,
translation-en-sujato: Those sons of his were bereft of mindfulness;

root-pli-ms: Coditā mayā te satimajjhalatthuṁ’.
translation-en-sujato: but when scolded by me they gained it back.
comment-en-sujato: end quote in MS is incorrect.

root-pli-ms: Tiṇṇaṁ tesaṁ āvasinettha eko,
translation-en-sujato: Of the three, there is one who remains

root-pli-ms: Gandhabbakāyūpagato vasīno;
translation-en-sujato: dwelling in the host of fairies.

root-pli-ms: Dve ca sambodhipathānusārino,
translation-en-sujato: But two, recollecting the path to awakening,

root-pli-ms: Devepi hīḷenti samāhitattā.
translation-en-sujato: serene, spurn even the gods.’
comment-en-sujato: The end point of Gopaka’s speech is hard to determine, as there is no close ti. MS places it on the previous verse, but this seems unlikely, as this verse is still telling the basic story. RD and MW place it after namassama below. But this seems unlikely, as Gopaka uses the singular referring to himself, where Sakka often uses the plural. Moreover, the logic flows better if we end it here. The next line refers to the “exposition of the teaching”, which must mean Gopaka’s teaching. Also, RD and MW’s idea that this is “The Truth may yet be realized” is wrong.

root-pli-ms: Etādisī dhammappakāsanettha,
translation-en-sujato: The teaching’s explained in such a way
comment-en-sujato: The feminine etadisi is hard to explain. It occurs rarely, one occurrence being earlier in this sutta, where it applies to Suriyavacchasa. Here, however, Gopaka has already become a man; having labored this point, it seems odd to just ignore it. More likely dhammappakasanā is feminine. This use is fairly common in later texts (it occurs at the conclusion of the Tika for this sutta—Sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā). Comm seems to want it to apply to both the disciple and the teaching: Etādisī dhammappakāsanetthāti ettha sāsane evarūpā dhammappakāsanā, yāya sāvakā etehi guṇehi samannāgatā honti.

root-pli-ms: Na tattha kiṅkaṅkhati koci sāvako;
translation-en-sujato: that not a single disciple doubts it.

root-pli-ms: Nitiṇṇaoghaṁ vicikicchachinnaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: We venerate the Buddha, the victor, lord of men,

root-pli-ms: Buddhaṁ namassāma jinaṁ janindaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: who has crossed the flood and cut off doubt.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ te dhammaṁ idhaññāya,
translation-en-sujato: They attained to distinction fitting

root-pli-ms: visesaṁ ajjhagaṁsu te;
translation-en-sujato: the extent to which they understood the teaching here.

root-pli-ms: Kāyaṁ brahmapurohitaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Two of them mastered the distinction of

root-pli-ms: duve tesaṁ visesagū.
translation-en-sujato: the host of Brahmā’s Ministers.

root-pli-ms: Tassa dhammassa pattiyā,
translation-en-sujato: We have come here, dear sir,

root-pli-ms: āgatamhāsi mārisa;
translation-en-sujato: to realize this same teaching.

root-pli-ms: Katāvakāsā bhagavatā,
translation-en-sujato: If the Buddha would give me a chance,

root-pli-ms: pañhaṁ pucchemu mārisā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I would ask a question, dear sir.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha thought,

root-pli-ms: “dīgharattaṁ visuddho kho ayaṁ yakkho, yaṁ kiñci maṁ pañhaṁ pucchissati, sabbaṁ taṁ atthasañhitaṁyeva pucchissati, no anatthasañhitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “For a long time now this spirit has led a pure life. Any question he asks me will be beneficial, not useless.

root-pli-ms: Yañcassāhaṁ puṭṭho byākarissāmi, taṁ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And he will quickly understand any answer I give to his question.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

root-pli-ms: “Puccha vāsava maṁ pañhaṁ,

root-pli-ms: yaṁ kiñci manasicchasi;
translation-en-sujato: whatever you want.

root-pli-ms: Tassa tasseva pañhassa,
translation-en-sujato: I’ll solve each and every

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ antaṁ karomi te”ti.

root-pli-ms: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro niṭṭhito.

root-pli-ms: “Kiṁsaṁyojanā nu kho, mārisa, devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā, te:
translation-en-sujato: “Dear sir, what fetters bind the gods, humans, demons, dragons, fairies—and any of the other diverse creatures—

root-pli-ms: ‘averā adaṇḍā asapattā abyāpajjā viharemu averino’ti iti ca nesaṁ hoti, atha ca pana saverā sadaṇḍā sasapattā sabyāpajjā viharanti saverino”ti?
translation-en-sujato: so that, though they wish to be free of enmity, violence, hostility, and hate, they still have enmity, violence, hostility, and hate?”

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ pañhaṁ apucchi.
translation-en-sujato: Such was Sakka’s question to the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Tassa bhagavā pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi:
translation-en-sujato: And the Buddha answered him:

root-pli-ms: “Issāmacchariyasaṁyojanā kho, devānaminda, devā manussā asurā nāgā gandhabbā ye caññe santi puthukāyā, te:
translation-en-sujato: “Lord of gods, the fetters of jealousy and stinginess bind the gods, humans, demons, dragons, fairies—and any of the other diverse creatures—

root-pli-ms: ‘averā adaṇḍā asapattā abyāpajjā viharemu averino’ti iti ca nesaṁ hoti, atha ca pana saverā sadaṇḍā sasapattā sabyāpajjā viharanti saverino”ti.

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.

root-pli-ms: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandi anumodi:

root-pli-ms: “evametaṁ, bhagavā, evametaṁ, sugata.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

root-pli-ms: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:

reference: mc10.237, ms7D_878, msdiv358, ndp7.207, pts-cs2.2, pts-vp-pli2.277, sc54

root-pli-ms: “Issāmacchariyaṁ pana, mārisa, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “But dear sir, what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of jealousy and stinginess?

root-pli-ms: kismiṁ sati issāmacchariyaṁ hoti;
translation-en-sujato: When what exists is there jealousy and stinginess?

root-pli-ms: kismiṁ asati issāmacchariyaṁ na hotī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: When what doesn’t exist is there no jealousy and stinginess?”

root-pli-ms: “Issāmacchariyaṁ kho, devānaminda, piyāppiyanidānaṁ piyāppiyasamudayaṁ piyāppiyajātikaṁ piyāppiyapabhavaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “The liked and the disliked, lord of gods, are the source of jealousy and stinginess.

root-pli-ms: piyāppiye sati issāmacchariyaṁ hoti,
translation-en-sujato: When the liked and the disliked exist there is jealousy and stinginess.

root-pli-ms: piyāppiye asati issāmacchariyaṁ na hotī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: When the liked and the disliked don’t exist there is no jealousy and stinginess.”

root-pli-ms: “Piyāppiyaṁ pana, mārisa, kiṁnidānaṁ kiṁsamudayaṁ kiṁjātikaṁ kiṁpabhavaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “But dear sir, what is the source of what is liked and disliked?”

root-pli-ms: kismiṁ sati piyāppiyaṁ hoti;
kismiṁ asati piyāppiyaṁ na hotī”ti?
“Piyāppiyaṁ kho, devānaminda, chandanidānaṁ chandasamudayaṁ chandajātikaṁ chandapabhavaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: “Desire is the source of what is liked and disliked.”

root-pli-ms: chande sati piyāppiyaṁ hoti;
chande asati piyāppiyaṁ na hotī”ti.
“Chando pana, mārisa, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo;
translation-en-sujato: “But what is the source of desire?”

root-pli-ms: kismiṁ sati chando hoti;
kismiṁ asati chando na hotī”ti?
“Chando kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno vitakkasamudayo vitakkajātiko vitakkapabhavo;
translation-en-sujato: “Thought is the source of desire.”

root-pli-ms: vitakke sati chando hoti;
vitakke asati chando na hotī”ti.
“Vitakko pana, mārisa, kiṁnidāno kiṁsamudayo kiṁjātiko kiṁpabhavo;
translation-en-sujato: “But what is the source of thought?”

root-pli-ms: kismiṁ sati vitakko hoti;
kismiṁ asati vitakko na hotī”ti?
“Vitakko kho, devānaminda, papañcasaññāsaṅkhānidāno papañcasaññāsaṅkhāsamudayo papañcasaññāsaṅkhājātiko papañcasaññāsaṅkhāpabhavo;
translation-en-sujato: “Concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions are the source of thoughts.”

root-pli-ms: papañcasaññāsaṅkhāya sati vitakko hoti;
papañcasaññāsaṅkhāya asati vitakko na hotī”ti.
“Kathaṁ paṭipanno pana, mārisa, bhikkhu papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhasāruppagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ paṭipanno hotī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But how does a mendicant fittingly practice for the cessation of concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions?”

root-pli-ms: “Somanassampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: “Lord of gods, there are two kinds of happiness, I say:

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
translation-en-sujato: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

translation-en-sujato: There are two kinds of sadness, I say:

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.

root-pli-ms: Somanassampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: Why did I say that there are two kinds of happiness?

root-pli-ms: Tattha yaṁ jaññā somanassaṁ
translation-en-sujato: Take a happiness of which you know:
comment-en-sujato: RD and MW both read this passage as applying to the Buddha, evidently taking jaññā to be absolutive. But cp. AN 9.6, where the identical idiom is used. There it cannot be the Buddha, so jaññā must be optative 3 singular. BB renders “If one knows of a person”. Note that I designed my rendering so as to enable breaking up the otherwise unwieldy sentence.

root-pli-ms: ‘imaṁ kho me somanassaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpaṁ somanassaṁ na sevitabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘When I cultivate this kind of happiness, unskillful qualities grow, and skillful qualities decline.’ You should not cultivate that kind of happiness.

root-pli-ms: Tattha yaṁ jaññā somanassaṁ
translation-en-sujato: Take a happiness of which you know:

root-pli-ms: Somanassampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti.
