root-pli-ms: ‘imaṁ kho me kāyasamācāraṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo kāyasamācāro sevitabbo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘When I cultivate this kind of bodily conduct, unskillful qualities decline, and skillful qualities grow.’ You should cultivate that kind of bodily conduct.

root-pli-ms: Kāyasamācārampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: That’s why I said there are two kinds of bodily behavior.

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti
iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
Vacīsamācārampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: Why did I say that there are two kinds of verbal behavior?

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
Tattha yaṁ jaññā vacīsamācāraṁ ‘imaṁ kho me vacīsamācāraṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpo vacīsamācāro na sevitabbo.
translation-en-sujato: You should not cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

root-pli-ms: Tattha yaṁ jaññā vacīsamācāraṁ ‘imaṁ kho me vacīsamācāraṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpo vacīsamācāro sevitabbo.
translation-en-sujato: And you should cultivate the kind of verbal behavior which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

root-pli-ms: Vacīsamācārampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: That’s why I said there are two kinds of verbal behavior.

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti
iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
Pariyesanaṁpāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: Why did I say that there are two kinds of search?

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ, kiñcetaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ?
Tattha yaṁ jaññā pariyesanaṁ ‘imaṁ kho me pariyesanaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evarūpā pariyesanā na sevitabbā.
translation-en-sujato: You should not cultivate the kind of search which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

root-pli-ms: Tattha yaṁ jaññā pariyesanaṁ ‘imaṁ kho me pariyesanaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evarūpā pariyesanā sevitabbā.
translation-en-sujato: And you should cultivate the kind of search which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

root-pli-ms: Pariyesanaṁpāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: That’s why I said there are two kinds of search.

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampīti
iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttaṁ.
Evaṁ paṭipanno kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu pātimokkhasaṁvarāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant practices for restraint in the monastic code.”

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.

root-pli-ms: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,

root-pli-ms: “evametaṁ, bhagavā, evametaṁ, sugata.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

root-pli-ms: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”

root-pli-ms: 2.4. Indriyasaṁvara
translation-en-sujato: 2.4. Sense Restraint

root-pli-ms: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:
translation-en-sujato: And then Sakka asked another question:

root-pli-ms: “Kathaṁ paṭipanno pana, mārisa, bhikkhu indriyasaṁvarāya paṭipanno hotī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But dear sir, how does a mendicant practice for restraint of the sense faculties?”

root-pli-ms: “Cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: “Lord of gods, I say that there are two kinds of sight known by the eye:

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
translation-en-sujato: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.

root-pli-ms: Sotaviññeyyaṁ saddampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: There are two kinds of sound known by the ear …

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
Ghānaviññeyyaṁ gandhampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: smells known by the nose …

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
Jivhāviññeyyaṁ rasampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: tastes known by the tongue …

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
Kāyaviññeyyaṁ phoṭṭhabbampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: touches known by the body …

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampi.
Manoviññeyyaṁ dhammampāhaṁ, devānaminda, duvidhena vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: thoughts known by the mind:

root-pli-ms: sevitabbampi, asevitabbampī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: that which you should cultivate, and that which you should not cultivate.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the Buddha said this, Sakka said to him:

root-pli-ms: “Imassa kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṁ vitthārena atthaṁ ājānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement:
comment-en-sujato: Sakka switches from marisa to bhante here, and back to marisa below. This is probably a sign of sloppy editing. The whole passage is found at MN 114, where bhante is used, and this suggests it was imported from there.

root-pli-ms: Yathārūpaṁ, bhante, cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpaṁ cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpaṁ na sevitabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: You should not cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

root-pli-ms: Yathārūpañca kho, bhante, cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpaṁ cakkhuviññeyyaṁ rūpaṁ sevitabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And you should cultivate the kind of sight known by the eye which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

root-pli-ms: Yathārūpañca kho, bhante, sotaviññeyyaṁ saddaṁ sevato …pe…
translation-en-sujato: You should not cultivate the kind of sound,

root-pli-ms: ghānaviññeyyaṁ gandhaṁ sevato …
translation-en-sujato: smell,

root-pli-ms: jivhāviññeyyaṁ rasaṁ sevato …
translation-en-sujato: taste,

root-pli-ms: kāyaviññeyyaṁ phoṭṭhabbaṁ sevato …
translation-en-sujato: touch,

root-pli-ms: manoviññeyyaṁ dhammaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, evarūpo manoviññeyyo dhammo na sevitabbo.
translation-en-sujato: or thought known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to grow while skillful qualities decline.

root-pli-ms: Yathārūpañca kho, bhante, manoviññeyyaṁ dhammaṁ sevato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, evarūpo manoviññeyyo dhammo sevitabbo.
translation-en-sujato: And you should cultivate the kind of thought known by the mind which causes unskillful qualities to decline while skillful qualities grow.

root-pli-ms: Imassa kho me, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṁ vitthārena atthaṁ ājānato
translation-en-sujato: Sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

root-pli-ms: tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttari pañhaṁ apucchi:
translation-en-sujato: And then Sakka asked another question:

root-pli-ms: “Sabbeva nu kho, mārisa, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Dear sir, do all ascetics and brahmins have the same doctrine, ethics, desires, and attachments?”
comment-en-sujato: RD, MW, and Thanissaro all take this as “same doctrine”, etc. This is probably right, but it is not a simple as it seems. Normally ekanta has the sense of “exclusively, solely”. That doesn’t make sense here, and the text may be corrupt. Skt at SF 241 has na haiva sarvasatvā ekakāmā ekacchandāḥ, which is more expected. Taken literally, ekanta could mean “of one aim”. This would then be a slightly different question: “(though we know that they appear different, nevertheless) is the end result of spiritual practice the same?” It seems comm has this in mind at least for the first term, but it is unclear to me whether it intended this analysis to be applied to each term: “Ekantavādāti ekoyeva anto vādassa etesaṁ, na dvedhā gatavādāti ekantavādā, ekaññeva vadantīti pucchati. Ekantasīlāti ekācārā. Ekantachandāti ekaladdhikā. Ekantaajjhosānāti ekantapariyosānā.”

root-pli-ms: “Na kho, devānaminda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “No, lord of gods, they do not.”

root-pli-ms: “Kasmā pana, mārisa, na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Why not?”

root-pli-ms: “Anekadhātu nānādhātu kho, devānaminda, loko.
translation-en-sujato: “The world has many and diverse elements.

root-pli-ms: Tasmiṁ anekadhātunānādhātusmiṁ loke yaṁ yadeva sattā dhātuṁ abhinivisanti, taṁ tadeva thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharanti:
translation-en-sujato: Whatever element sentient beings insist on in this world of many and diverse elements, they obstinately stick to it, insisting that:

root-pli-ms: ‘idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’

root-pli-ms: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekantavādā ekantasīlā ekantachandā ekantaajjhosānā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have the same doctrine, ethics, desires, and attachments.”

root-pli-ms: “Sabbeva nu kho, mārisa, samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Dear sir, have all ascetics and brahmins reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal?”

root-pli-ms: “Na kho, devānaminda, sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “No, lord of gods, they have not.”

root-pli-ms: “Kasmā pana, mārisa, na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Why not?”

root-pli-ms: “Ye kho, devānaminda, bhikkhū taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttā te accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā.
translation-en-sujato: “Those mendicants who are freed through the ending of craving have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.

root-pli-ms: Tasmā na sabbe samaṇabrāhmaṇā accantaniṭṭhā accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosānā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s why not all ascetics and brahmins have reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal.”

root-pli-ms: Itthaṁ bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa pañhaṁ puṭṭho byākāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Such was the Buddha’s answer to Sakka.

root-pli-ms: Attamano sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandi anumodi:
translation-en-sujato: Delighted, Sakka approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, saying,

root-pli-ms: “evametaṁ, bhagavā, evametaṁ, sugata.
translation-en-sujato: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!

root-pli-ms: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhā vigatā kathaṅkathā bhagavato pañhaveyyākaraṇaṁ sutvā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hearing the Buddha’s answer, I’ve gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision.”

root-pli-ms: Itiha sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: And then Sakka asked another question:

root-pli-ms: “Ejā, bhante, rogo, ejā gaṇḍo, ejā sallaṁ, ejā imaṁ purisaṁ parikaḍḍhati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
translation-en-sujato: “Passion, sir, is a disease, an abscess, a dart. Passion drags a person to be reborn in life after life.

root-pli-ms: Tasmā ayaṁ puriso uccāvacamāpajjati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s why a person finds themselves in states high and low.

root-pli-ms: Yesāhaṁ, bhante, pañhānaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu okāsakammampi nālatthaṁ, te me bhagavatā byākatā.
translation-en-sujato: Elsewhere, among other ascetics and brahmins, I wasn’t even given a chance to ask these questions that the Buddha has answered.

root-pli-ms: Dīgharattānusayitañca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ, tañca bhagavatā abbuḷhan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: The dart of doubt and uncertainty has lain within me for a long time, but the Buddha has plucked it out.”
variant-pli-ms: pana → yañca pana (sya-all, km); yañca pana (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, devānaminda, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Lord of gods, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, ime pañhe aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I do, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kathaṁ pana te, devānaminda, byākaṁsu? Sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “If you wouldn’t mind, lord of gods, tell me how they answered.”

root-pli-ms: “Na kho me, bhante, garu yatthassa bhagavā nisinno bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, devānaminda, bhāsassū”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, speak then, lord of gods.”

root-pli-ms: “Yesvāhaṁ, bhante, maññāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇā āraññikā pantasenāsanāti, tyāhaṁ upasaṅkamitvā ime pañhe pucchāmi, te mayā puṭṭhā na sampāyanti, asampāyantā mamaṁyeva paṭipucchanti:
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I approached those who I imagined were ascetics and brahmins living in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. But they could not answer, and they even questioned me in return:

root-pli-ms: ‘ko nāmo āyasmā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What is the venerable’s name?’

root-pli-ms: Tesāhaṁ puṭṭho byākaromi:
translation-en-sujato: So I answered them:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho, mārisa, sakko devānamindo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Dear sir, I am Sakka, lord of gods.’

root-pli-ms: Te mamaṁyeva uttari paṭipucchanti:
translation-en-sujato: So they asked me another question:

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ panāyasmā, devānaminda, kammaṁ katvā imaṁ ṭhānaṁ patto’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But lord of gods, what deed brought you to this position?’

root-pli-ms: Tesāhaṁ yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: So I taught them the Dhamma as I had learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Te tāvatakeneva attamanā honti:
translation-en-sujato: And they were pleased with just that much:

root-pli-ms: ‘sakko ca no devānamindo diṭṭho, yañca no apucchimhā, tañca no byākāsī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We have seen Sakka, lord of gods! And he answered our questions!’

root-pli-ms: Te aññadatthu mamaṁyeva sāvakā sampajjanti, na cāhaṁ tesaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Invariably, they become my disciples, I don’t become theirs.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ kho pana, bhante, bhagavato sāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But sir, I am the Buddha’s disciple, a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”

root-pli-ms: 2.5. Somanassapaṭilābhakathā
translation-en-sujato: 2.5. On Feeling Happy

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, devānaminda, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Lord of gods, do you recall ever feeling such joy and happiness before?”
reference: bj8.430, dr10.316, ms7D_909, msdiv368, pts-vp-pli2.285, sc85

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I do, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tvaṁ, devānaminda, abhijānāsi ito pubbe evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But how?”

root-pli-ms: “Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhante, devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: “Once upon a time, sir, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
variant-pli-ms: samupabyūḷho → samūpabyuḷho (cck); samupabyuḷho (sya1ed, sya2ed, km); samūpabbūḷho (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Tasmiṁ kho pana, bhante, saṅgāme devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājayiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.

root-pli-ms: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: It occurred to me as victor,

root-pli-ms: ‘yā ceva dāni dibbā ojā yā ca asurā ojā, ubhayametaṁ devā paribhuñjissantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Now the gods shall enjoy both the nectar of the gods and the nectar of the demons.’

root-pli-ms: So kho pana me, bhante, vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho sadaṇḍāvacaro sasatthāvacaro na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati.
translation-en-sujato: But sir, that joy and happiness is in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Yo kho pana me ayaṁ, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṁ sutvā vedapaṭilābho somanassapaṭilābho, so adaṇḍāvacaro asatthāvacaro ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But the joy and happiness I feel listening to the Buddha’s teaching is not in the sphere of the rod and the sword. It does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiṁ pana tvaṁ, devānaminda, atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedesī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But lord of gods, what reason do you see for speaking of such joy and happiness?”

root-pli-ms: “Cha kho ahaṁ, bhante, atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: “I see six reasons to speak of such joy and happiness, sir.

root-pli-ms: Idheva tiṭṭhamānassa,
translation-en-sujato: While staying right here,

root-pli-ms: devabhūtassa me sato;
translation-en-sujato: remaining in the godly form,

root-pli-ms: Punarāyu ca me laddho,
translation-en-sujato: I have gained an extended life:
comment-en-sujato: This is odd, and i am not sure what it means. MW says “The chance, by kamma, of another earthly life”, but there is no mention of chance, kamma, or earthly. Comm says: “Punarāyu ca me laddhoti puna aññena kammavipākena me jīvitaṁ laddhanti, iminā attano cutabhāvaṁ ceva upapannabhāvañca āvikaroti.” But what? Everyone gets reborn anyway, the point of Buddhism is to stop rebirth. Moreover, the nbext verse speaks of rebirth. Perhaps, rather, it simply means that the merit of Dhamma has extended his stay in his current fortunate birth.

root-pli-ms: evaṁ jānāhi mārisa.
translation-en-sujato: know this, dear sir.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, paṭhamaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first reason.

root-pli-ms: Cutāhaṁ diviyā kāyā,
translation-en-sujato: When I fall from the heavenly host,

root-pli-ms: āyuṁ hitvā amānusaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: leaving behind the non-human life,

root-pli-ms: Amūḷho gabbhamessāmi,
translation-en-sujato: I shall consciously go to a new womb,

root-pli-ms: yattha me ramatī mano.
translation-en-sujato: wherever my mind delights.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, dutiyaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second reason.

root-pli-ms: Svāhaṁ amūḷhapaññassa,
translation-en-sujato: Living happily under the guidance

root-pli-ms: viharaṁ sāsane rato;
translation-en-sujato: of the one of unclouded wisdom,

root-pli-ms: Ñāyena viharissāmi,
translation-en-sujato: I shall practice according to method,

root-pli-ms: sampajāno paṭissato.
translation-en-sujato: aware and mindful.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, tatiyaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third reason.

root-pli-ms: Ñāyena me carato ca,
translation-en-sujato: And if awakening should arise

root-pli-ms: sambodhi ce bhavissati;
translation-en-sujato: as I practice according to the method,

root-pli-ms: Aññātā viharissāmi,
translation-en-sujato: I shall live as one who understands,

root-pli-ms: sveva anto bhavissati.
translation-en-sujato: and my end shall come right there.
comment-en-sujato: Comm: Sveva anto bhavissatīti so eva me manussaloke anto bhavissatīti.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, catutthaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth reason.

root-pli-ms: Cutāhaṁ mānusā kāyā,
translation-en-sujato: When I fall from the human realm,

root-pli-ms: āyuṁ hitvāna mānusaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: leaving behind the human life,

root-pli-ms: Puna devo bhavissāmi,
translation-en-sujato: I shall become a god again,

root-pli-ms: devalokamhi uttamo.
translation-en-sujato: in the supreme heaven realm.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, pañcamaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth reason.

root-pli-ms: Te paṇītatarā devā,
translation-en-sujato: They are the finest of gods,

root-pli-ms: akaniṭṭhā yasassino;
translation-en-sujato: the glorious Akaniṭṭhas.

root-pli-ms: Antime vattamānamhi,
translation-en-sujato: So long as my final life goes on,

root-pli-ms: so nivāso bhavissati.
translation-en-sujato: there my home will be.

root-pli-ms: Imaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, chaṭṭhaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth reason.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho ahaṁ, bhante, cha atthavase sampassamāno evarūpaṁ vedapaṭilābhaṁ somanassapaṭilābhaṁ pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: Seeing these six reasons I speak of such joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Apariyositasaṅkappo,
translation-en-sujato: My wishes unfulfilled,
reference: csp1ed7.229, csp2ed7.229, ms7D_925, msdiv370, pts-cs2.9, sc101

root-pli-ms: vicikiccho kathaṅkathī;
translation-en-sujato: doubting and undecided,

root-pli-ms: Vicariṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: I wandered for such a long time,

root-pli-ms: anvesanto tathāgataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: in search of the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: Yassu maññāmi samaṇe,
translation-en-sujato: I imagined that ascetics

root-pli-ms: pavivittavihārino;
translation-en-sujato: living in seclusion

root-pli-ms: Sambuddhā iti maññāno,
translation-en-sujato: must surely be awakened,

root-pli-ms: gacchāmi te upāsituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: so I went to sit near them.

root-pli-ms: ‘Kathaṁ ārādhanā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: ‘How is there success?

root-pli-ms: kathaṁ hoti virādhanā’;
translation-en-sujato: How is there failure?’

root-pli-ms: Iti puṭṭhā na sampāyanti,
translation-en-sujato: But they couldn’t answer such questions

root-pli-ms: magge paṭipadāsu ca.
translation-en-sujato: about the path and practice.

root-pli-ms: Tyassu yadā maṁ jānanti,
translation-en-sujato: And when they found out that I

root-pli-ms: sakko devānamāgato;
translation-en-sujato: was Sakka, come from the gods,

root-pli-ms: Tyassu mameva pucchanti,
translation-en-sujato: they questioned me instead about

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ katvā pāpuṇī idaṁ’.
translation-en-sujato: the deed that brought me to this state.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ yathāsutaṁ dhammaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: I taught them the Dhamma

root-pli-ms: desayāmi jane sutaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: as I had learned it among men.

root-pli-ms: Tena attamanā honti,
translation-en-sujato: They were delighted with that, saying:

root-pli-ms: ‘diṭṭho no vāsavoti ca’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We’ve seen Vāsava!’

root-pli-ms: Yadā ca buddhamaddakkhiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Now since I’ve seen the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: vicikicchāvitāraṇaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: who helps us overcome doubt,

root-pli-ms: Somhi vītabhayo ajja,
translation-en-sujato: today, free of fear,

root-pli-ms: sambuddhaṁ payirupāsiya.
translation-en-sujato: I pay homage to the awakened one.

root-pli-ms: Taṇhāsallassa hantāraṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Destroyer of the dart of craving,

root-pli-ms: buddhaṁ appaṭipuggalaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: the Buddha is unrivaled.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ vande mahāvīraṁ,
translation-en-sujato: I bow to the great hero,

root-pli-ms: buddhamādiccabandhunaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ karomasi brahmuno,
translation-en-sujato: Just as Brahmā is worshipped

root-pli-ms: samaṁ devehi mārisa;
translation-en-sujato: by the gods, dear sir,

root-pli-ms: Tadajja tuyhaṁ kassāma,
translation-en-sujato: today we shall worship you—

root-pli-ms: handa sāmaṁ karoma te.
translation-en-sujato: come, let us bow to you!
comment-en-sujato: Sāmaṁ karomāti namakkāraṁ karoma

root-pli-ms: Tvameva asi sambuddho,
translation-en-sujato: You alone are the Awakened!
variant-pli-ms: Tvameva asi → tvameva sivaṁ (sya-all, km); tuvamevasi (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: tuvaṁ satthā anuttaro;
translation-en-sujato: You are the Teacher supreme!

root-pli-ms: Sadevakasmiṁ lokasmiṁ,
translation-en-sujato: In the world with its gods,

root-pli-ms: natthi te paṭipuggalo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is no-one like you.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pañcasikhaṁ gandhabbaputtaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka addressed the fairy Pañcasikha,
reference: csp1ed7.230, csp2ed7.230, ms7D_934, msdiv371, ndp7.216, pts-cs2.10, sc110

root-pli-ms: “bahūpakāro kho mesi tvaṁ, tāta pañcasikha, yaṁ tvaṁ bhagavantaṁ paṭhamaṁ pasādesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Dear Pañcasikha, you were very helpful to me, since you first charmed the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: Tayā, tāta, paṭhamaṁ pasāditaṁ pacchā mayaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamimhā arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: after which I went to see him.

root-pli-ms: Pettike vā ṭhāne ṭhapayissāmi, gandhabbarājā bhavissasi, bhaddañca te sūriyavacchasaṁ dammi, sā hi te abhipatthitā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall appoint you to your father’s position—you shall be king of the fairies. And I give you Bhaddā Suriyavaccasā, who you love so much.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sakko devānamindo pāṇinā pathaviṁ parāmasitvā tikkhattuṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then Sakka, touching the ground with his hand, expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:

root-pli-ms: “Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
translation-en-sujato: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
translation-en-sujato: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”

root-pli-ms: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne sakkassa devānamindassa virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi:
translation-en-sujato: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Sakka, lord of gods:

root-pli-ms: “yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

root-pli-ms: Aññesañca asītiyā devatāsahassānaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: And also for another 80,000 deities.

root-pli-ms: iti ye sakkena devānamindena ajjhiṭṭhapañhā puṭṭhā, te bhagavatā byākatā.
translation-en-sujato: Such were the questions Sakka was invited to ask, and which were answered by the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Tasmā imassa veyyākaraṇassa sakkapañhātveva adhivacananti.
translation-en-sujato: And that’s why the name of this discussion is “Sakka’s Questions”.

root-pli-ms: Sakkapañhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ aṭṭhamaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 23
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 23

root-pli-ms: Pāyāsisutta
translation-en-sujato: With Pāyāsi

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā kumārakassapo kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena setabyā nāma kosalānaṁ nagaraṁ tadavasari.
translation-en-sujato: At one time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a Kosalan citadel named Setavyā.

root-pli-ms: Tatra sudaṁ āyasmā kumārakassapo setabyāyaṁ viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
translation-en-sujato: He stayed in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño setabyaṁ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṁ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ sadhaññaṁ rājabhoggaṁ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṁ rājadāyaṁ brahmadeyyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the chieftain Pāyāsi was living in Setavyā. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.

root-pli-ms: 1. Pāyāsirājaññavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 1. On Pāyāsi

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsissa rājaññassa evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Pāyāsi had the following harmful misconception:

root-pli-ms: “itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “There’s no afterlife. No beings are reborn spontaneously. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā:
translation-en-sujato: The brahmins and householders of Setavyā heard,

root-pli-ms: “samaṇo khalu bho kumārakassapo samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṁ anuppatto setabyāyaṁ viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
translation-en-sujato: “It seems the ascetic Kassapa the Prince—a disciple of the ascetic Gotama—is staying in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
translation-en-sujato: He has this good reputation:

root-pli-ms: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā ca.
translation-en-sujato: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
variant-pli-ms: vuddho → vudho (bj); buddho (sya-all, km, mr); vuḍḍho (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṁ arahataṁ dassanaṁ hotī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṁsapāvanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then, having departed Setavyā, they formed into companies and headed north to the grove.
variant-pli-ms: yena siṁsapāvanaṁ → yena sīsapāvanaṁ (sya-all, km); tenupasaṅkamanti (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena pāyāsi rājañño uparipāsāde divāseyyaṁ upagato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the chieftain Pāyāsi had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
reference: csp1ed7.254, csp2ed7.254, mc10.271, ms7D_1092, msdiv408, pts-cs3, sc3, vri2.238

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte uttarenamukhe gacchante yena siṁsapāvanaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: He saw the brahmins and householders heading north towards the grove,

root-pli-ms: disvā khattaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: and addressed his steward,

root-pli-ms: “kiṁ nu kho, bho khatte, setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā setabyāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā uttarenamukhā gacchanti yena siṁsapāvanan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “My steward, why are the brahmins and householders heading north towards the grove?”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo kumārakassapo, samaṇassa gotamassa sāvako kosalesu cārikaṁ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi setabyaṁ anuppatto setabyāyaṁ viharati uttarena setabyaṁ siṁsapāvane.
translation-en-sujato: “The ascetic Kassapa the Prince—a disciple of the ascetic Gotama—is staying in the grove of Indian Rosewood to the north of Setavyā.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
translation-en-sujato: He has this good reputation:

root-pli-ms: ‘paṇḍito byatto medhāvī bahussuto cittakathī kalyāṇapaṭibhāno vuddho ceva arahā cā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘He is astute, competent, intelligent, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
variant-pli-ms: arahā cā’ti → arahā ca (sya-all, km, mr)

root-pli-ms: Tamete bhavantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamantī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re going to see that Kassapa the Prince.”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, bho khatte, yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṁ vadehi:
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:

root-pli-ms: ‘pāyāsi, bho, rājañño evamāha—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sirs, the chieftain Pāyāsi asks

root-pli-ms: āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Kassapa the Prince.’

root-pli-ms: Purā samaṇo kumārakassapo setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike bāle abyatte saññāpeti:
translation-en-sujato: Before Kassapa the Prince convinces those foolish and incompetent brahmins and householders that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds—

root-pli-ms: Natthi hi, bho khatte, paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
translation-en-sujato: for none of these things are true!”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so khattā pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yena setabyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā setabyake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the steward, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: “pāyāsi, bho, rājañño evamāha, āgamentu kira bhavanto, pāyāsipi rājañño samaṇaṁ kumārakassapaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī”ti.

Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño setabyakehi brāhmaṇagahapatikehi parivuto yena siṁsapāvanaṁ yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhiṁ sammodi, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: Then Pāyāsi escorted by the brahmins and householders, went up to Kassapa the Prince, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
reference: bj8.508, cck10.371, csp1ed7.255, csp2ed7.255, mc10.272, ms7D_1094, msdiv409, pts-cs4, pts-vp-pli2.319, sc5, sya10.355

root-pli-ms: Setabyakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce āyasmantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu;
translation-en-sujato: Before sitting down to one side, some of the brahmins and householders of Setavyā bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward Kassapa the Prince, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

root-pli-ms: appekacce āyasmatā kumārakassapena saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu;
sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
Appekacce yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
Appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
2. Natthikavāda
translation-en-sujato: 2. Nihilism

root-pli-ms: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho pāyāsi rājañño āyasmantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Seated to one side, the chieftain Pāyāsi said to Venerable Kassapa the Prince,
reference: dr10.352, ms7D_1095, msdiv410, ndp7.238, pts-cs5, sc6, vri2.239

root-pli-ms: “ahañhi, bho kassapa, evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
translation-en-sujato: “Master Kassapa, this is my doctrine and view:

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no afterlife. No beings are reborn spontaneously. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds.’”

root-pli-ms: “Nāhaṁ, rājañña, evaṁvādiṁ evaṁdiṭṭhiṁ addasaṁ vā assosiṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, chieftain, I’ve never seen or heard of anyone holding such a doctrine or view.

root-pli-ms: Kathañhi nāma evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: For how on earth can anyone say such a thing?

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti?
2.1. Candimasūriyaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.1. The Simile of the Moon and Sun

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, rājañña,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, chieftain?

root-pli-ms: ime candimasūriyā imasmiṁ vā loke parasmiṁ vā, devā vā te manussā vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Are the moon and sun in this world or the other world? Are they gods or humans?”

root-pli-ms: “Ime, bho kassapa, candimasūriyā parasmiṁ loke, na imasmiṁ; devā te na manussā”ti.

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kissa hetu”?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: “Asuci, bho kassapa, gūthakūpo asuci ceva asucisaṅkhāto ca duggandho ca duggandhasaṅkhāto ca jeguccho ca jegucchasaṅkhāto ca paṭikūlo ca paṭikūlasaṅkhāto cā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Because that sewer is filthy, stinking, disgusting, and repulsive, and it’s regarded as such.”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva kho, rājañña, manussā devānaṁ asucī ceva asucisaṅkhātā ca, duggandhā ca duggandhasaṅkhātā ca, jegucchā ca jegucchasaṅkhātā ca, paṭikūlā ca paṭikūlasaṅkhātā ca.
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, chieftain, to the gods, human beings are filthy, stinking, disgusting, and repulsive, and are regarded as such.

root-pli-ms: Yojanasataṁ kho, rājañña, manussagandho deve ubbādhati.
translation-en-sujato: The smell of humans reaches the gods even a hundred leagues away.
comment-en-sujato: Follow PTS reading ubbāhati. Cf. AN 3.93 for the sense “transport”. RD had “ofends”, while MW just omits this sentence.

root-pli-ms: Kiṁ pana te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā te āgantvā ārocessanti:
translation-en-sujato: What then of your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who are reborn in a higher realm after doing good things? Will they come back to tell you that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti?
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife?

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: “atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññāti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idha me, bho kassapa, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā,
translation-en-sujato: “Well, I have friends and colleagues, relatives and kin who refrain from killing living creatures and so on.

root-pli-ms: te aparena samayena ābādhikā honti dukkhitā bāḷhagilānā.
translation-en-sujato: Some time later they become sick, suffering, gravely ill.

root-pli-ms: Yadāhaṁ jānāmi:
translation-en-sujato: When I know that

root-pli-ms: ‘na dānime imamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhahissantī’ti tyāhaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: they will not recover from their illness, I go to them and say,

root-pli-ms: ‘santi kho, bho, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sirs, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

root-pli-ms: “ye te pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjanti devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Those who refrain from killing living creatures and so on are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three.”

root-pli-ms: Bhavanto kho pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā.
translation-en-sujato: You do all these things.

root-pli-ms: Sace tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ saccaṁ vacanaṁ, bhavanto kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissanti, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If what those ascetics and brahmins say is true, when your body breaks up, after death, you’ll be reborn in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: Sace, bho, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyyātha devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ, yena me āgantvā āroceyyātha:
translation-en-sujato: If that happens, sirs, come and tell me that

root-pli-ms: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.

root-pli-ms: Bhavanto kho pana me saddhāyikā paccayikā, yaṁ bhavantehi diṭṭhaṁ, yathā sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ evametaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: I trust you and believe you. Anything you see will be just as if I’ve seen it for myself.’

root-pli-ms: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā neva āgantvā ārocenti, na pana dūtaṁ pahiṇanti.
translation-en-sujato: They agree to this. But they don’t come back to tell me, nor do they send a messenger.

root-pli-ms: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: This is how I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: 2.4. Tāvatiṁsadevaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.4. The Simile of the Gods of the Thirty-Three

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi; yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho pana, rājañña, mānussakaṁ vassasataṁ, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ eso eko rattindivo, tāya rattiyā tiṁsarattiyo māso, tena māsena dvādasamāsiyo saṁvaccharo, tena saṁvaccharena dibbaṁ vassasahassaṁ devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ āyuppamāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: A hundred human years are equivalent to one day and night for the gods of the Thirty-Three. Thirty such days make a month, and twelve months make a year. The gods of the Thirty Three have a lifespan of a thousand such years.
comment-en-sujato: 36,000,000 years, if anyone’s counting.
variant-pli-ms: rattindivo → rattidivo (mr) | mānussakaṁ → mānusakaṁ (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Ye te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Now, as to your friends who are reborn in the company of the gods of the Thirty-Three after doing good things.

root-pli-ms: Sace pana tesaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
translation-en-sujato: If they think,

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva mayaṁ dve vā tīṇi vā rattindivā dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, atha mayaṁ pāyāsissa rājaññassa gantvā āroceyyāma:
translation-en-sujato: ‘First I’ll amuse myself for two or three days, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation. Then I’ll go back to Pāyāsi and tell him that

root-pli-ms: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.’

root-pli-ms: Api nu te āgantvā āroceyyuṁ—
translation-en-sujato: Would they come back to tell you that

root-pli-ms: itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho kassapa.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Kassapa.

root-pli-ms: Api hi mayaṁ, bho kassapa, ciraṁ kālaṅkatāpi bhaveyyāma.
translation-en-sujato: For I would be long dead by then.

root-pli-ms: Ko panetaṁ bhoto kassapassa āroceti:
translation-en-sujato: But Master Kassapa, who has told you

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā.
translation-en-sujato: that the gods of the Thirty-Three exist, or that they have such a long life span?

root-pli-ms: Na mayaṁ bhoto kassapassa saddahāma:
translation-en-sujato: I don’t believe you.”

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā”ti.
2.5. Jaccandhaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.5. Blind From Birth

root-pli-ms: “Seyyathāpi, rājañña, jaccandho puriso na passeyya kaṇha—sukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṁ, na passeyya tārakāni rūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
translation-en-sujato: “Chieftain, suppose there was a person blind from birth. They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: They’d say,

root-pli-ms: ‘natthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, natthi kaṇhasukkānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no such thing as dark and bright sights, and no-one who sees them.

root-pli-ms: Natthi nīlakāni rūpāni, natthi nīlakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: There’s no such thing as blue,

root-pli-ms: Natthi pītakāni rūpāni, natthi pītakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: yellow,

root-pli-ms: Natthi lohitakāni rūpāni, natthi lohitakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: red,

root-pli-ms: Natthi mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, natthi mañjiṭṭhakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: magenta,

root-pli-ms: Natthi samavisamaṁ, natthi samavisamassa dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: even and uneven ground,

root-pli-ms: Natthi tārakāni rūpāni, natthi tārakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: stars,

root-pli-ms: Natthi candimasūriyā, natthi candimasūriyānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: moon and sun, and no-one who sees these things.

root-pli-ms: Ahametaṁ na jānāmi, ahametaṁ na passāmi, tasmā taṁ natthī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: I don’t know it or see it, therefore it doesn’t exist.’

root-pli-ms: Sammā nu kho so, rājañña, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Would they be speaking rightly?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho kassapa.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Kassapa.

root-pli-ms: Atthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, atthi kaṇhasukkānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: There are such things as dark and bright sights, and one who sees them.

root-pli-ms: Atthi nīlakāni rūpāni, atthi nīlakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And those other things are real, too, as is the one who sees them.

root-pli-ms: atthi samavisamaṁ, atthi samavisamassa dassāvī.
Atthi tārakāni rūpāni, atthi tārakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
Atthi candimasūriyā, atthi candimasūriyānaṁ dassāvī.
translation-en-sujato: So it’s not right to say this:

root-pli-ms: ‘Ahametaṁ na jānāmi, ahametaṁ na passāmi, tasmā taṁ natthī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I don’t know it or see it, therefore it doesn’t exist.’”

root-pli-ms: Na hi so, bho kassapa, sammā vadamāno vadeyyā”ti.
“Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, jaccandhūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ evaṁ vadesi.
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, chieftain, when you tell me you don’t believe me you seem like the blind man in the simile.

root-pli-ms: Ko panetaṁ bhoto kassapassa āroceti:
‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā, ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā?
Na mayaṁ bhoto kassapassa saddahāma:
‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā”ti.
“Na kho, rājañña, evaṁ paro loko daṭṭhabbo, yathā tvaṁ maññasi iminā maṁsacakkhunā.
translation-en-sujato: You can’t see the other world the way you think, with the eye of the flesh.
comment-en-sujato: MS quotes are incorrect.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho te, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti, te tattha appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā dibbacakkhuṁ visodhenti.
translation-en-sujato: There are ascetics and brahmins who live in the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, they purify the divine eye, the power of clairvoyance.

root-pli-ms: Te dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena imañceva lokaṁ passanti parañca satte ca opapātike.
translation-en-sujato: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see this world and the other world, and sentient beings who are spontaneously reborn.

root-pli-ms: Evañca kho, rājañña, paro loko daṭṭhabbo;
translation-en-sujato: That’s how to see the other world,

root-pli-ms: na tveva yathā tvaṁ maññasi iminā maṁsacakkhunā.
translation-en-sujato: not how you think, with the eye of the flesh.

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idhāhaṁ, bho kassapa, passāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇe sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme jīvitukāme amaritukāme sukhakāme dukkhapaṭikūle.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, I see ascetics and brahmins who are ethical, of good character, who want to live and don’t want to die, who want to be happy and recoil from pain.

root-pli-ms: Tassa mayhaṁ, bho kassapa, evaṁ hoti—
translation-en-sujato: I think to myself,

root-pli-ms: sace kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā evaṁ jāneyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: ‘If those ascetics and brahmins knew that

root-pli-ms: ‘ito no matānaṁ seyyo bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: things were going to be better for them after death,

root-pli-ms: Idānime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā visaṁ vā khādeyyuṁ, satthaṁ vā āhareyyuṁ, ubbandhitvā vā kālaṁ kareyyuṁ, papāte vā papateyyuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they’d drink poison, slit their wrists, hang themselves, or throw themselves off a cliff.

root-pli-ms: Yasmā ca kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā na evaṁ jānanti:
translation-en-sujato: They mustn’t know that

root-pli-ms: ‘ito no matānaṁ seyyo bhavissatī’ti, tasmā ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā jīvitukāmā amaritukāmā sukhakāmā dukkhapaṭikūlā attānaṁ na mārenti.
translation-en-sujato: things are going to be better for them after death. That’s why they are ethical, of good character, wanting to live and not wanting to die, wanting to be happy and recoiling from pain.’
variant-pli-ms: attānaṁ na mārenti → etthantare pāṭho sya-all, km, pts1ed potthakesu natthi

root-pli-ms: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: This is the method by which I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: 2.6. Gabbhinīupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.6. The Simile of the Pregnant Woman

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa dve pajāpatiyo ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, a certain brahmin had two wives.

root-pli-ms: Ekissā putto ahosi dasavassuddesiko vā dvādasavassuddesiko vā, ekā gabbhinī upavijaññā.
translation-en-sujato: One had a son ten or twelve years of age, while the other was pregnant and nearing her time.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the brahmin passed away.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the youth said to his mother’s co-wife,

root-pli-ms: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Madam, all the wealth, grain, silver, and gold is mine,

root-pli-ms: natthi tuyhettha kiñci.
translation-en-sujato: and you get nothing.

root-pli-ms: Pitu me, bhoti, dāyajjaṁ niyyādehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Transfer to me my father’s inheritance.’
comment-en-sujato: RD’s translation of this is correct, MW’s is wrong.
variant-pli-ms: me → pitu me santako (sya-all, km) | niyyādehī’ti → niyyātehīti (bj); nīyyātehīti (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, sā brāhmaṇī taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: But the brahmin lady said,

root-pli-ms: ‘āgamehi tāva, tāta, yāva vijāyāmi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Wait, my dear, until I give birth.

root-pli-ms: Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;
translation-en-sujato: If it’s a boy, one portion shall be his.

root-pli-ms: sace kumārikā bhavissati, sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: If it’s a girl, she will be your reward.’
comment-en-sujato: RD and MW follow comm in saying she’ll be his servant. But upabhunj means to enjoy, make use of, have sex with,, or get as reward. I think the salaciousness is deliberate.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: But for a second time,

root-pli-ms: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
natthi tuyhettha kiñci.
Pitu me, bhoti, dāyajjaṁ niyyādehī’ti.
Dutiyampi kho sā brāhmaṇī taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
‘āgamehi tāva, tāta, yāva vijāyāmi.
Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;
sace kumārikā bhavissati sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.
Tatiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: and a third time, the youth insisted that the entire inheritance must be his.

root-pli-ms: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
natthi tuyhettha kiñci.
Pitu me, bhoti, dāyajjaṁ niyyādehī’ti.
Atha kho sā brāhmaṇī satthaṁ gahetvā ovarakaṁ pavisitvā udaraṁ opādesi:
translation-en-sujato: So the brahmin lady took a knife, went to her bedroom, and sliced open her belly, thinking,
comment-en-sujato: read opāṭesi

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva vijāyāmi yadi vā kumārako yadi vā kumārikā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Until I give birth, whether it’s a boy or a girl!’
comment-en-sujato: MW and RD follow PTS reading yava janami. But surely the phrase is meant to echo yava vijayami above. The phrase is not 100% coherent, which is understandable given the circumstances.

root-pli-ms: Sā attānañceva jīvitañca gabbhañca sāpateyyañca vināsesi.
translation-en-sujato: She destroyed her own life and that of the fetus, as well as any wealth.

root-pli-ms: Yathā taṁ bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṁ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṁ gavesantī, evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesanto;
translation-en-sujato: Being foolish and incompetent, she sought an inheritance irrationally and fell to ruin and disaster. In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you’re seeking the other world irrationally and will fall to ruin and disaster,

root-pli-ms: seyyathāpi sā brāhmaṇī bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṁ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṁ gavesantī.
translation-en-sujato: just like that brahmin lady.

root-pli-ms: Na kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā apakkaṁ paripācenti;
translation-en-sujato: Good ascetics and brahmins don’t force what is unripe to ripen;

root-pli-ms: api ca paripākaṁ āgamenti.
translation-en-sujato: rather, they wait for it to ripen.

root-pli-ms: Paṇḍitānaṁ attho hi, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ sīlavantānaṁ kalyāṇadhammānaṁ jīvitena.
translation-en-sujato: For the life of clever ascetics and brahmins is beneficial.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti tathā tathā bahuṁ puññaṁ pasavanti, bahujanahitāya ca paṭipajjanti bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So long as they remain, good ascetics and brahmins make much merit, and act for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ te, bhante, coro āgucārī;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

root-pli-ms: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Punish him as you will.’

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṁ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṁ karitvā uddhanaṁ āropetvā aggiṁ dethā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sirs, place this man in a pot while he’s still alive. Close up the mouth, bind it up with damp leather, and seal it with a thick coat of damp clay. Then lift it up on a stove and light the fire.’
comment-en-sujato: Note uddhanaṁ āropetvā is “on to a stove “not” in an oven”.

root-pli-ms: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṁ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṁ karitvā uddhanaṁ āropetvā aggiṁ denti.
translation-en-sujato: They agree, and do what I ask.

root-pli-ms: Yadā mayaṁ jānāma ‘kālaṅkato so puriso’ti, atha naṁ kumbhiṁ oropetvā ubbhinditvā mukhaṁ vivaritvā saṇikaṁ nillokema:
translation-en-sujato: When we know that that man has passed away, we lift down the pot and break it open, uncover the mouth, and slowly peek inside, thinking,

root-pli-ms: ‘appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Hopefully we’ll see his soul escaping.’

root-pli-ms: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passāma.
translation-en-sujato: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

root-pli-ms: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: This is how I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: 2.7. Supinakaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.7. The Simile of the Dream

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

root-pli-ms: Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, rājañña, divā seyyaṁ upagato supinakaṁ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Do you recall ever having a midday nap and seeing delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds in a dream?”

root-pli-ms: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bho kassapa, divāseyyaṁ upagato supinakaṁ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I do, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Rakkhanti taṁ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “At that time were you guarded by hunchbacks, dwarves, midgets, and younglings?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho kassapa, rakkhanti maṁ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “I was.”

root-pli-ms: “Api nu tā tuyhaṁ jīvaṁ passanti pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But did they see your soul entering or leaving?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho kassapa”.
translation-en-sujato: “No they did not.”

root-pli-ms: “Tā hi nāma, rājañña, tuyhaṁ jīvantassa jīvantiyo jīvaṁ na passissanti pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: “So if they couldn’t even see your soul entering or leaving while you were still alive,

root-pli-ms: Kiṁ pana tvaṁ kālaṅkatassa jīvaṁ passissasi pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: how could you see the soul of a dead man?

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife, there are beings reborn spontaneously, and there is a fruit or result of good and bad deeds.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: “atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ te, bhante, coro āgucārī;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

root-pli-ms: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Punish him as you will.’

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṁ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulethā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sirs, weigh this man with scales while he’s still alive. Then strangle him with a bowstring, and when he’s dead, weigh him again.’

root-pli-ms: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṁ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulenti.
translation-en-sujato: They agree, and do what I ask.

root-pli-ms: Yadā so jīvati, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
translation-en-sujato: So long as they are alive, they’re lighter, softer, more flexible.

root-pli-ms: Yadā pana so kālaṅkato hoti tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
translation-en-sujato: But when they die they become heavier, stiffer, less flexible.

translation-en-sujato: This is how I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
