root-pli-ms: 2.8. Santattaayoguḷaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.8. The Simile of the Hot Iron Ball

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, puriso divasaṁ santattaṁ ayoguḷaṁ ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ tulāya tuleyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a person was to heat an iron ball all day until it was burning, blazing, and glowing, and then they weigh it with scales.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aparena samayena sītaṁ nibbutaṁ tulāya tuleyya.
translation-en-sujato: After some time, when it had cooled and become extinguished, they’d weigh it again.

root-pli-ms: Kadā nu kho so ayoguḷo lahutaro vā hoti mudutaro vā kammaññataro vā, yadā vā āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, yadā vā sīto nibbuto”ti?
translation-en-sujato: When would that iron ball be lighter, softer, and more workable—when it’s burning or when it’s cool?”

root-pli-ms: “Yadā so, bho kassapa, ayoguḷo tejosahagato ca hoti vāyosahagato ca āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
translation-en-sujato: “So long as the iron ball is full of heat and air—burning, blazing, and glowing—it’s lighter, softer, and more workable.

root-pli-ms: Yadā pana so ayoguḷo neva tejosahagato hoti na vāyosahagato sīto nibbuto, tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro cā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But when it lacks heat and air—cooled and extinguished—it’s heavier, stiffer, and less workable.”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṁ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, so long as this body is full of life and warmth and consciousness it’s lighter, softer, and more flexible.

root-pli-ms: Yadā panāyaṁ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti na usmāsahagato na viññāṇasahagato tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
translation-en-sujato: But when it lacks life and warmth and consciousness it’s heavier, stiffer, and less flexible.

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ te, bhante, coro āgucārī;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal.

root-pli-ms: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Punish him as you will.’

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ anupahacca chaviñca cammañca maṁsañca nhāruñca aṭṭhiñca aṭṭhimiñjañca jīvitā voropetha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sirs, take this man’s life without injuring his outer skin, inner skin, flesh, sinews, bones, or marrow. Hopefully we’ll see his soul escaping.’

root-pli-ms: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ anupahacca chaviñca …pe… jīvitā voropenti.
translation-en-sujato: They agree, and do what I ask.

root-pli-ms: Yadā so āmato hoti, tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: When he’s half-dead, I tell them to
comment-en-sujato: Āmato hotīti addhamato marituṁ āraddho hoti

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ uttānaṁ nipātetha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: lay him on his back in hope of seeing his soul escape.

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ purisaṁ uttānaṁ nipātenti.
translation-en-sujato: They do so.

root-pli-ms: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passāma.
translation-en-sujato: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I tell them to

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ avakujjaṁ nipātetha …
translation-en-sujato: lay him bent over,

root-pli-ms: passena nipātetha …
translation-en-sujato: to lay him on his side,

root-pli-ms: dutiyena passena nipātetha …
translation-en-sujato: to lay him on the other side;

root-pli-ms: uddhaṁ ṭhapetha …
translation-en-sujato: to stand him upright,

root-pli-ms: omuddhakaṁ ṭhapetha …
translation-en-sujato: to stand him upside down;

root-pli-ms: pāṇinā ākoṭetha …
translation-en-sujato: to strike him with fists,

root-pli-ms: leḍḍunā ākoṭetha …
translation-en-sujato: stones,

root-pli-ms: daṇḍena ākoṭetha …
translation-en-sujato: rods,

root-pli-ms: satthena ākoṭetha …
translation-en-sujato: and swords;

root-pli-ms: odhunātha sandhunātha niddhunātha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: and to give him a good shaking in hope of seeing his soul escape.

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ purisaṁ odhunanti sandhunanti niddhunanti.
translation-en-sujato: They do all these things.

root-pli-ms: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passāma.
translation-en-sujato: But we don’t see his soul escaping.

root-pli-ms: Tassa tadeva cakkhu hoti te rūpā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: For him the eye itself is present, and so are those sights. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.
comment-en-sujato: Cp. AN 9.37, where this is more aptly describing a deep meditation. AS MW notes, this seems arbitrary here.

root-pli-ms: Tadeva sotaṁ hoti te saddā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: The ear itself is present, and so are those sounds. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

root-pli-ms: Tadeva ghānaṁ hoti te gandhā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: The nose itself is present, and so are those smells. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

root-pli-ms: Sāva jivhā hoti te rasā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: The tongue itself is present, and so are those tastes. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

root-pli-ms: Sveva kāyo hoti te phoṭṭhabbā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: The body itself is present, and so are those touches. Yet he does not experience that sense-field.

root-pli-ms: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: This is how I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: 2.9. Saṅkhadhamaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.9. The Simile of the Horn Blower

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro saṅkhadhamo saṅkhaṁ ādāya paccantimaṁ janapadaṁ agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, a certain horn blower took his horn and traveled to a borderland,

root-pli-ms: So yena aññataro gāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā majjhe gāmassa ṭhito tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipitvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: where he went to a certain village. Standing in the middle of the village, he sounded his horn three times, then placed it on the ground and sat down to one side.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the people of the borderland thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘ambho kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘What is making this sound, so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, infatuating, and captivating?’

root-pli-ms: Sannipatitvā taṁ saṅkhadhamaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They gathered around the horn blower and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ambho, kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Mister, what is making this sound, so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, infatuating, and captivating?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Eso kho, bho, saṅkho nāma yasseso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The sound is made by this, which is called a horn.’

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ saṅkhaṁ uttānaṁ nipātesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They laid that horn on its back, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘vadehi, bho saṅkha, vadehi, bho saṅkhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Speak, good horn! Speak, good horn!’

root-pli-ms: Neva so saṅkho saddamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: But still the horn made no sound.

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ saṅkhaṁ avakujjaṁ nipātesuṁ, passena nipātesuṁ, dutiyena passena nipātesuṁ, uddhaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, omuddhakaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, pāṇinā ākoṭesuṁ, leḍḍunā ākoṭesuṁ, daṇḍena ākoṭesuṁ, satthena ākoṭesuṁ, odhuniṁsu sandhuniṁsu niddhuniṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then they lay the horn bent over, they lay it on its side, they lay it on its other side; they stood it upright, they stood it upside down; they struck it with fists, stones, rods, and swords; and they gave it a good shake, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘vadehi, bho saṅkha, vadehi, bho saṅkhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Speak, good horn! Speak, good horn!’

root-pli-ms: Neva so saṅkho saddamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: But still the horn made no sound.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa saṅkhadhamassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: So the horn blower thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva bālā ime paccantajanapadā manussā, kathañhi nāma ayoniso saṅkhasaddaṁ gavesissantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How foolish are these borderland folk! For how can they seek the sound of a horn so irrationally?’

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ pekkhamānānaṁ saṅkhaṁ gahetvā tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ ādāya pakkāmi.
translation-en-sujato: And as they looked on, he picked up the horn, sounded it three times, and took it away with him.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the people of the borderland thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yadā kira, bho, ayaṁ saṅkho nāma purisasahagato ca hoti vāyāmasahagato ca vāyusahagato ca, tadāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karoti, yadā panāyaṁ saṅkho neva purisasahagato hoti na vāyāmasahagato na vāyusahagato, nāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘So, it seems, when what is called a horn is accompanied by a person, effort, and wind, it makes a sound. But when these things are absent it makes no sound.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṁ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā abhikkamatipi paṭikkamatipi tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi seyyampi kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṁ passati, sotenapi saddaṁ suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṁ sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ vijānāti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, so long as this body is full of life and warmth and consciousness it walks back and forth, stands, sits, and lies down. It sees sights with the eye, hears sounds with the ear, smells odors with the nose, tastes flavors with the tongue, feels touches with the body, and knows thoughts with the mind.

root-pli-ms: Yadā panāyaṁ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti, na usmāsahagato, na viññāṇasahagato, tadā neva abhikkamati na paṭikkamati na tiṭṭhati na nisīdati na seyyaṁ kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṁ na passati, sotenapi saddaṁ na suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ na ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṁ na sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ na phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ na vijānāti.
translation-en-sujato: But when it lacks life and warmth and consciousness it does none of these things.

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
translation-en-sujato: By this method, too, it ought to be proven that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there is an afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I think that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: “Atthi pana, rājañña, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Can you prove it?”

root-pli-ms: atthi, bho kassapa, pariyāyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “I can.”

root-pli-ms: yathā kathaṁ viya, rājaññā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “How, exactly, chieftain?”

root-pli-ms: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
translation-en-sujato: “Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to me, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ te, bhante, coro āgucārī, imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, this is a bandit, a criminal. Punish him as you will.’

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa chaviṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sirs, cut open this man’s outer skin. Hopefully we might see his soul.’

root-pli-ms: Te tassa purisassa chaviṁ chindanti.
translation-en-sujato: They cut open his outer skin,

root-pli-ms: Nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ passāma.
translation-en-sujato: but we see no soul.

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: I say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa cammaṁ chindatha, maṁsaṁ chindatha, nhāruṁ chindatha, aṭṭhiṁ chindatha, aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, sirs, cut open his inner skin, flesh, sinews, bones, or marrow. Hopefully we’ll see his soul.’

root-pli-ms: Te tassa purisassa aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindanti, nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ passeyyāma.
translation-en-sujato: They do so, but we see no soul.

root-pli-ms: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: This is how I prove that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife.”

root-pli-ms: 2.10. Aggikajaṭilaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.10. The Simile of the Fire-Worshiping Matted-Hair Ascetic

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro aggiko jaṭilo araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyā sammati.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, a certain fire-worshiping matted-hair ascetic settled in a leaf hut in a wilderness region.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, rājañña, aññataro janapade sattho vuṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then a caravan came out from a certain country.
variant-pli-ms: sattho → satthavāso (sya-all, km) | janapade sattho → janapado satthavāso (sya-all, km); janapadapadeso (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so sattho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa assamassa sāmantā ekarattiṁ vasitvā pakkāmi.
translation-en-sujato: It stayed for one night not far from that ascetic’s hermitage, and then moved on.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: The ascetic thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūnāhaṁ yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkameyyaṁ, appeva nāmettha kiñci upakaraṇaṁ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t I go to that caravan’s campsite? Hopefully I’ll find something useful there.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo kālasseva vuṭṭhāya yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā addasa tasmiṁ satthavāse daharaṁ kumāraṁ mandaṁ uttānaseyyakaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So he went, and he saw a young baby boy abandoned there.

root-pli-ms: Disvānassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: When he saw this he thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘na kho me taṁ patirūpaṁ yaṁ me pekkhamānassa manussabhūto kālaṅkareyya;
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s not proper for me to look on while a human being dies.

root-pli-ms: yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādeyyaṁ poseyyaṁ vaḍḍheyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I bring this boy back to my hermitage, nurse him, nourish him, and raise him?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādesi posesi vaḍḍhesi.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Yadā so dārako dasavassuddesiko vā hoti dvādasavassuddesiko vā, atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa janapade kañcideva karaṇīyaṁ uppajji.
translation-en-sujato: When the boy was ten or twelve years old, the ascetic had some business come up in the country.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So he said to the boy,

root-pli-ms: ‘icchāmahaṁ, tāta, janapadaṁ gantuṁ;
translation-en-sujato: ‘My dear, I wish to go to the country.

root-pli-ms: aggiṁ, tāta, paricareyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Serve the sacred flame.

root-pli-ms: Mā ca te aggi nibbāyi.
translation-en-sujato: Do not extinguish it.

root-pli-ms: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: But if you should extinguish it, here is the hatchet, the firewood, and the bundle of drill-sticks. Light the fire and serve it.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ evaṁ anusāsitvā janapadaṁ agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And having instructed the boy, the ascetic went to the country.

root-pli-ms: Tassa khiḍḍāpasutassa aggi nibbāyi.
translation-en-sujato: But the boy was so engrossed in his play, the fire went out.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tassa dārakassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: He thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘pitā kho maṁ evaṁ avaca:
translation-en-sujato: ‘My father told me to serve the sacred flame.

root-pli-ms: “aggiṁ, tāta, paricareyyāsi.
Mā ca te aggi nibbāyi.
Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsī”ti.
Yannūnāhaṁ aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I light it again and serve it?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so dārako araṇisahitaṁ vāsiyā tacchi:
translation-en-sujato: So he chopped the bundle of drill-sticks with the hatchet, thinking,

root-pli-ms: ‘appeva nāma aggiṁ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Hopefully I’ll get a fire!’

root-pli-ms: Neva so aggiṁ adhigacchi.
translation-en-sujato: But he still got no fire.

root-pli-ms: Araṇisahitaṁ dvidhā phālesi, tidhā phālesi, catudhā phālesi, pañcadhā phālesi, dasadhā phālesi, satadhā phālesi, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ akāsi, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesi, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuni:
translation-en-sujato: He split the bundle of drill-sticks into two, three, four, five, ten, or a hundred parts. He chopped them into splinters, pounded them in a mortar, and swept them away in a strong wind, thinking,
variant-pli-ms: opuni → opuṇi (bj); ophuni (sya-all, km, mr) | satadhā → vīsatidhā (sya-all, km)

root-pli-ms: ‘appeva nāma aggiṁ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Hopefully I’ll get a fire!’

root-pli-ms: Neva so aggiṁ adhigacchi.
translation-en-sujato: But he still got no fire.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo janapade taṁ karaṇīyaṁ tīretvā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the matted-hair ascetic, having concluded his business in the country, returned to his own hermitage, and said to the boy,

root-pli-ms: ‘kacci te, tāta, aggi na nibbuto’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘I trust, my dear, that the fire didn’t go out?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Idha me, tāta, khiḍḍāpasutassa aggi nibbāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And the boy told him what had happened.

root-pli-ms: Tassa me etadahosi:
“pitā kho maṁ evaṁ avaca aggiṁ, tāta, paricareyyāsi.
Mā ca te, tāta, aggi nibbāyi.
Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsīti.
Yannūnāhaṁ aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyan”ti.
Atha khvāhaṁ, tāta, araṇisahitaṁ vāsiyā tacchiṁ:
“appeva nāma aggiṁ adhigaccheyyan”ti.
Nevāhaṁ aggiṁ adhigacchiṁ.

Araṇisahitaṁ dvidhā phālesiṁ, tidhā phālesiṁ, catudhā phālesiṁ, pañcadhā phālesiṁ, dasadhā phālesiṁ, satadhā phālesiṁ, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ akāsiṁ, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesiṁ, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuniṁ:
“appeva nāma aggiṁ adhigaccheyyan”ti.
Nevāhaṁ aggiṁ adhigacchin’ti.
Atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the ascetic thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva bālo ayaṁ dārako abyatto, kathañhi nāma ayoniso aggiṁ gavesissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How foolish is this boy, how incompetent! For how can he seek a fire so irrationally?’

root-pli-ms: Tassa pekkhamānassa araṇisahitaṁ gahetvā aggiṁ nibbattetvā taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So while the boy looked on, he took a bundle of fire-sticks, lit the fire, and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘evaṁ kho, tāta, aggi nibbattetabbo.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Dear boy, this is how to light a fire.

root-pli-ms: Na tveva yathā tvaṁ bālo abyatto ayoniso aggiṁ gavesī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Not the foolish and incompetent way you sought it so irrationally.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesissasi.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you seek the other world irrationally.
comment-en-sujato: Note that verb tenses in this passage very in editions: I translate according to the sense.

root-pli-ms: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

root-pli-ms: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.

root-pli-ms: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
translation-en-sujato: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

root-pli-ms: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
“itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”’ti.
Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
translation-en-sujato: If I let go of this harmful misconception, people will say,

root-pli-ms: ‘yāva bālo pāyāsi rājañño abyatto duggahitagāhī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How foolish is the chieftain Pāyāsi, how incompetent, that he should hold on to a mistake!’

root-pli-ms: Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”

root-pli-ms: 2.11. Dvesatthavāhaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.11. The Simile of the Two Caravan Leaders

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, mahāsakaṭasattho sakaṭasahassaṁ puratthimā janapadā pacchimaṁ janapadaṁ agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, a large caravan of a thousand wagons traveled from a country in the east to the west.

root-pli-ms: So yena yena gacchi, khippaṁyeva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ haritakapaṇṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Wherever they went they quickly used up the grass, wood, water, and the green foliage.

root-pli-ms: Tasmiṁ kho pana satthe dve satthavāhā ahesuṁ eko pañcannaṁ sakaṭasatānaṁ, eko pañcannaṁ sakaṭasatānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Now, that caravan had two leaders, each in charge of five hundred wagons.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ satthavāhānaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: They thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho mahāsakaṭasattho sakaṭasahassaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is a large caravan of a thousand wagons.

root-pli-ms: te mayaṁ yena yena gacchāma, khippameva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ haritakapaṇṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Wherever we go we quickly use up the grass, wood, water, and the green foliage.

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ imaṁ satthaṁ dvidhā vibhajeyyāma—
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we split the caravan in two halves?’

root-pli-ms: ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni ekato pañca sakaṭasatānī’ti.
Te taṁ satthaṁ dvidhā vibhajiṁsu ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni, ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they did.

root-pli-ms: Eko satthavāho bahuṁ tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca āropetvā satthaṁ payāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: One caravan leader, having prepared much grass, wood, and water, started the caravan.

root-pli-ms: Dvīhatīhapayāto kho pana so sattho addasa purisaṁ kāḷaṁ lohitakkhaṁ sannaddhakalāpaṁ kumudamāliṁ allavatthaṁ allakesaṁ kaddamamakkhitehi cakkehi bhadrena rathena paṭipathaṁ āgacchantaṁ, disvā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: After two or three days’ journey he saw a dark man with red eyes coming the other way in a donkey cart with muddy wheels. He was armored with a quiver and wreathed with yellow lotus, his clothes and hair all wet. Seeing him, he said,
comment-en-sujato: Read gadrabharathena

root-pli-ms: ‘kuto, bho, āgacchasī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, where do you come from?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Amukamhā janapadā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘From such and such a country.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kuhiṁ gamissasī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘And where are you going?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Amukaṁ nāma janapadan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘To the country named so and so.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kacci, bho, purato kantāre mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But has there been much rain in the desert up ahead?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho, purato kantāre mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho, āsittodakāni vaṭumāni, bahu tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Indeed there has, sir. The paths are sprinkled with water, and there is much grass, wood, and water.

root-pli-ms: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi sīghaṁ sīghaṁ gacchatha, mā yoggāni kilamitthā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Toss out your grass, wood, and water. Your wagons will move swiftly when lightly-laden, so don’t tire your draught teams.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so satthavāho satthike āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So the caravan leader addressed his drivers,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, bho, puriso evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: ‘This man says that

root-pli-ms: “purato kantāre mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho, āsittodakāni vaṭumāni, bahu tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca.
translation-en-sujato: there has been much rain in the desert up ahead.

root-pli-ms: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi sīghaṁ sīghaṁ gacchatha, mā yoggāni kilamitthā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: He advises us to toss out the grass, wood, and water. The wagons will move swiftly when lightly-laden, and won’t tire our draught teams.

root-pli-ms: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi satthaṁ payāpethā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: So let’s toss out the grass, wood, and water and restart the caravan with lightly-laden wagons.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā chaḍḍetvā purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni lahubhārehi sakaṭehi satthaṁ payāpesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, sir,’ the drivers replied, and that’s what they did.

root-pli-ms: Te paṭhamepi satthavāse na addasaṁsu tiṇaṁ vā kaṭṭhaṁ vā udakaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: But in the caravan’s first campsite they saw no grass, wood, or water.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: And in the second,

root-pli-ms: tatiyepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: third,

root-pli-ms: catutthepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: fourth,

root-pli-ms: pañcamepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: fifth,

root-pli-ms: chaṭṭhepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: sixth,

root-pli-ms: sattamepi satthavāse na addasaṁsu tiṇaṁ vā kaṭṭhaṁ vā udakaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: and seventh campsites they saw no grass, wood, or water.

root-pli-ms: Sabbeva anayabyasanaṁ āpajjiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And all fell to ruin and disaster.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca tasmiṁ satthe ahesuṁ manussā vā pasū vā, sabbe so yakkho amanusso bhakkhesi.
translation-en-sujato: And the men and beasts in that caravan were all devoured by that non-human spirit.

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikāneva sesāni.
translation-en-sujato: Only their bones remained.

root-pli-ms: Yadā aññāsi dutiyo satthavāho:
translation-en-sujato: Now, when the second caravan leader knew that

root-pli-ms: ‘bahunikkhanto kho, bho, dāni so sattho’ti bahuṁ tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca āropetvā satthaṁ payāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: the first caravan was well underway, he prepared much grass, wood, and water and started the caravan.

root-pli-ms: Dvīhatīhapayāto kho pana so sattho addasa purisaṁ kāḷaṁ lohitakkhaṁ sannaddhakalāpaṁ kumudamāliṁ allavatthaṁ allakesaṁ kaddamamakkhitehi cakkehi bhadrena rathena paṭipathaṁ āgacchantaṁ, disvā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: After two or three days’ journey he saw a dark man with red eyes coming the other way in a donkey cart with muddy wheels. He was armored with a quiver and wreathed with yellow lotus, his clothes and hair all wet. Seeing him, he said,

root-pli-ms: ‘Amukamhā janapadā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘From such and such a country.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kuhiṁ gamissasī’ti?

root-pli-ms: ‘Amukaṁ nāma janapadan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘To the country named so and so.’

translation-en-sujato: ‘Indeed there has, sir. The paths are sprinkled with water, and there is much grass, wood, and water.

root-pli-ms: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi sīghaṁ sīghaṁ gacchatha, mā yoggāni kilamitthā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Toss out your grass, wood, and water. Your wagons will move swiftly when lightly-laden, so don’t tire your draught teams.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so satthavāho satthike āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So the caravan leader addressed his drivers,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, bho, puriso evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: ‘This man says that

root-pli-ms: “purato kantāre mahāmegho abhippavuṭṭho, āsittodakāni vaṭumāni, bahu tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca.
translation-en-sujato: there has been much rain in the desert up ahead.

root-pli-ms: Chaḍḍetha, bho, purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, lahubhārehi sakaṭehi sīghaṁ sīghaṁ gacchatha; mā yoggāni kilamitthā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: He advises us to toss out the grass, wood, and water. The wagons will move swiftly when lightly-laden, and won’t tire our draught teams.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ bho puriso neva amhākaṁ mitto, na ñātisālohito, kathaṁ mayaṁ imassa saddhāya gamissāma.
translation-en-sujato: But this person is neither our friend nor relative. How can we proceed out of trust in him?

root-pli-ms: Na vo chaḍḍetabbāni purāṇāni tiṇāni kaṭṭhāni udakāni, yathābhatena bhaṇḍena satthaṁ payāpetha.
translation-en-sujato: We shouldn’t toss out any grass, wood, or water, but continue with our goods laden as before.

root-pli-ms: Na no purāṇaṁ chaḍḍessāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: We shall not toss out any old stock.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā yathābhatena bhaṇḍena satthaṁ payāpesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, sir,’ the drivers replied, and they restarted the caravan with the goods laden as before.

root-pli-ms: Te paṭhamepi satthavāse na addasaṁsu tiṇaṁ vā kaṭṭhaṁ vā udakaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: And in the caravan’s first campsite they saw no grass, wood, or water.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: And in the second,

translation-en-sujato: third,

root-pli-ms: catutthepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: fourth,

root-pli-ms: pañcamepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: fifth,

root-pli-ms: chaṭṭhepi satthavāse …
translation-en-sujato: sixth,

root-pli-ms: sattamepi satthavāse na addasaṁsu tiṇaṁ vā kaṭṭhaṁ vā udakaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: and seventh campsites they saw no grass, wood, or water.

root-pli-ms: Tañca satthaṁ addasaṁsu anayabyasanaṁ āpannaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And they saw the other caravan that had come to ruin.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca tasmiṁ satthepi ahesuṁ manussā vā pasū vā, tesañca aṭṭhikāneva addasaṁsu tena yakkhena amanussena bhakkhitānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And they saw the bones of the men and beasts who had been devoured by that non-human spirit.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so satthavāho satthike āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: So the caravan leader addressed his drivers,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho, bho, sattho anayabyasanaṁ āpanno, yathā taṁ tena bālena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This caravan came to ruin, as happens when guided by a foolish caravan leader.

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, bho, yānamhākaṁ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā, yāni imasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, sirs, toss out any of our merchandise that’s of little value, and take what’s valuable from this caravan.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā yāni sakasmiṁ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā yāni tasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyitvā sotthinā taṁ kantāraṁ nitthariṁsu, yathā taṁ paṇḍitena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, sir’ replied the drivers, and that’s what they did. They crossed over the desert safely, as happens when guided by an astute caravan leader.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesanto, seyyathāpi so purimo satthavāho.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, chieftain, being foolish and incompetent, you will come to ruin seeking the other world irrationally, like the first caravan leader.

root-pli-ms: Yepi tava sotabbaṁ saddhātabbaṁ maññissanti, tepi anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissanti, seyyathāpi te satthikā.
translation-en-sujato: And those who think you’re worth listening to and trusting will also come to ruin, like the drivers.
variant-pli-ms: saddhātabbaṁ → saddahātabbaṁ (bj, pts1ed, mr) | tava → te (mr)

root-pli-ms: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

root-pli-ms: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.
reference: ms7D_1126, msdiv431, ndp7.258, pts-cs24, pts-vp-pli2.347, sc37, sya10.385, vri2.256

root-pli-ms: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
translation-en-sujato: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

root-pli-ms: “itipi natthi paro loko …pe… vipāko”’ti.
Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
‘yāva bālo pāyāsi rājañño, abyatto duggahitagāhī’ti.
Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”

root-pli-ms: 2.12. Gūthabhārikaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.12. The Simile of the Dung-Carrier

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro sūkaraposako puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, a certain swineherd went from his own village to another village.

root-pli-ms: Tattha addasa pahūtaṁ sukkhagūthaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: There he saw a large pile of dry dung abandoned.

root-pli-ms: Disvānassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: He thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho pahūto sukkhagūtho chaḍḍito, mama ca sūkarabhattaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: ‘This pile of dry dung can serve as food for my pigs.

root-pli-ms: yannūnāhaṁ ito sukkhagūthaṁ hareyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I carry it off?’

root-pli-ms: So uttarāsaṅgaṁ pattharitvā pahūtaṁ sukkhagūthaṁ ākiritvā bhaṇḍikaṁ bandhitvā sīse ubbāhetvā agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: So he spread out his upper robe, shoveled the dry dung onto it, tied it up into a bundle, lifted it on to his head, and went on his way.

root-pli-ms: Tassa antarāmagge mahāakālamegho pāvassi.
translation-en-sujato: While on his way a large sudden storm poured down.

root-pli-ms: So uggharantaṁ paggharantaṁ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṁ ādāya agamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Smeared with leaking, oozing dung down to his fingernails, he kept on carrying the load of dung.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ manussā disvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: When people saw him they said,

root-pli-ms: ‘kacci no tvaṁ, bhaṇe, ummatto, kacci viceto, kathañhi nāma uggharantaṁ paggharantaṁ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṁ harissasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Have you gone mad, sir? Have you lost your mind? For how can you, smeared with leaking, oozing dung down to your fingernails, keep on carrying that load of dung?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tumhe khvettha, bhaṇe, ummattā, tumhe vicetā, tathā hi pana me sūkarabhattan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘You’re the mad ones, sirs! You’re the ones who’ve lost your minds! For this will serve as food for my pigs.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, gūthabhārikūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the dung carrier in the simile.

root-pli-ms: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

root-pli-ms: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.

root-pli-ms: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
translation-en-sujato: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

root-pli-ms: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
“itipi natthi paro loko …pe… vipāko”’ti.
Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
‘yāva bālo pāyāsi rājañño abyatto duggahitagāhī’ti.
Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”

root-pli-ms: 2.13. Akkhadhuttakaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.13. The Simile of the Gamblers

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi,
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, dve akkhadhuttā akkhehi dibbiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, two gamblers were playing with dice.

root-pli-ms: Eko akkhadhutto āgatāgataṁ kaliṁ gilati.
translation-en-sujato: One gambler, every time they made a bad throw, swallowed the dice.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taṁ akkhadhuttaṁ āgatāgataṁ kaliṁ gilantaṁ, disvā taṁ akkhadhuttaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The second gambler saw him, and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘tvaṁ kho, samma, ekantikena jināsi, dehi me, samma, akkhe pajohissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well, my friend, you’ve won it all! Give me the dice, I will offer them as sacrifice.’
comment-en-sujato: Comm says “Pajjohissāmīti pajjohanaṁ karissāmi, balikammaṁ karissāmīti attho”, which is followed by RD and MW. Tika says “Pajjohananti pakārehi juhanakammaṁ. Taṁ pana balidānavasena karīyatīti āha ‘‘balikamma’’nti.” DA 7, instead, simply has 今日且停，明當更共試.

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa akkhe pādāsi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, my friend,’ the gambler replied, and gave them.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so akkhadhutto akkhe visena paribhāvetvā taṁ akkhadhuttaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Having soaked the dice in poison, the gambler said to the other,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi kho, samma, akkhehi dibbissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, my friend, let’s play dice.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, my friend,’ the other gambler replied.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyampi kho te akkhadhuttā akkhehi dibbiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And for a second time the gamblers played with dice.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyampi kho so akkhadhutto āgatāgataṁ kaliṁ gilati.
translation-en-sujato: And for the second time, every time they made a bad throw, that gambler swallowed the dice.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taṁ akkhadhuttaṁ dutiyampi āgatāgataṁ kaliṁ gilantaṁ, disvā taṁ akkhadhuttaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The second gambler saw him, and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘Littaṁ paramena tejasā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘The man swallows the dice without realizing

root-pli-ms: Gilamakkhaṁ puriso na bujjhati;
translation-en-sujato: they’re smeared with burning poison.

root-pli-ms: Gila re gila pāpadhuttaka,
translation-en-sujato: Swallow, you bloody cheat, swallow!
variant-pli-ms: gila pāpadhuttaka → gilare pāpadhuttā (sya-all, km); gili re pāpadhuttaka (mr)

root-pli-ms: Pacchā te kaṭukaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Soon you’ll know the bitter fruit!’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, akkhadhuttakūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the gambler in the simile.

root-pli-ms: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

root-pli-ms: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

root-pli-ms: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Even though Master Kassapa says this, still I’m not able to let go of that harmful misconception.

root-pli-ms: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
translation-en-sujato: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows my views, and so do foreign kings.

root-pli-ms: ‘pāyāsi rājañño evaṁvādī evaṁdiṭṭhī:
“itipi natthi paro loko …pe… vipāko”’ti.
Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
‘yāva bālo pāyāsi rājañño abyatto duggahitagāhī’ti.
Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall carry on with this view out of anger, contempt, and spite!”

root-pli-ms: 2.14. Sāṇabhārikaupamā
translation-en-sujato: 2.14. The Simile of the Man Who Carried Hemp

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi, rājañña, upamaṁ te karissāmi,
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, chieftain, I shall give you a simile.

root-pli-ms: upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro janapado vuṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, the inhabitants of a certain country emigrated.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then one friend said to another,

root-pli-ms: ‘āyāma, samma, yena so janapado tenupasaṅkamissāma, appeva nāmettha kiñci dhanaṁ adhigaccheyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, my friend, let’s go to that country. Hopefully we’ll get some riches there!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, my friend,’ the other replied.

root-pli-ms: Te yena so janapado, yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu, tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: They went to that country, and to a certain place in a village. There they saw a pile of abandoned sunn hemp. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,
comment-en-sujato: Comm: “Gāmapaṭṭanti vuṭṭhitagāmapadeso vuccati. ‘‘Gāmapada’’ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho”

root-pli-ms: ‘idaṁ kho, samma, pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandha, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandhissāmi, ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is a pile of abandoned sunn hemp. Well then, my friend, you make up a bundle of hemp, and I’ll make one too. Let’s both take a bundle of hemp and go on.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paṭissutvā sāṇabhāraṁ bandhitvā te ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, my friend,’ he said. Carrying their bundles of hemp they went to another place in the village.

root-pli-ms: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There they saw much sunn hemp thread abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

root-pli-ms: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ, idaṁ pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This pile of abandoned sunn hemp thread is just what we wanted the hemp for!

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our bundles of hemp, and both take a bundle of hemp thread and go on.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me, tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve already carried this bundle of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’
comment-en-sujato: The sunk cost fallacy!

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: So one friend abandoned their bundle of hemp and picked up a bundle of hemp thread.

root-pli-ms: Te yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: They went to another place in the village.

root-pli-ms: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There they saw much sunn hemp cloth abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

root-pli-ms: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ vā sāṇasuttaṁ vā, imā pahūtā sāṇiyo chaḍḍitā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This pile of abandoned sunn hemp cloth is just what we wanted the hemp and hemp thread for!

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇasuttabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇibhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our bundles, and both take a bundle of hemp cloth and go on.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me, tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve already carried this bundle of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇasuttabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā sāṇibhāraṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: So one friend abandoned their bundle of hemp thread and picked up a bundle of hemp cloth.

root-pli-ms: Te yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: They went to another place in the village.

root-pli-ms: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ khomaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: There they saw a pile of flax, and by turn,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ khomasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: linen thread,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ khomadussaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: linen cloth,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ kappāsaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: silk,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ kappāsikasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: silk thread,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ kappāsikadussaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: silk cloth,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ ayaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: iron,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ lohaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: copper,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ tipuṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: tin,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ sīsaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: lead,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ sajjhaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā …
translation-en-sujato: silver,

root-pli-ms: pahūtaṁ suvaṇṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: and gold abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,

root-pli-ms: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ vā sāṇasuttaṁ vā sāṇiyo vā khomaṁ vā khomasuttaṁ vā khomadussaṁ vā kappāsaṁ vā kappāsikasuttaṁ vā kappāsikadussaṁ vā ayaṁ vā lohaṁ vā tipuṁ vā sīsaṁ vā sajjhaṁ vā, idaṁ pahūtaṁ suvaṇṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This pile of gold is just what we wanted all those other things for!

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sajjhabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho suvaṇṇabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our bundles, and both take a bundle of gold and go on.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve already carried this bundle of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so sahāyako sajjhabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā suvaṇṇabhāraṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: So one friend abandoned their bundle of silver and picked up a bundle of gold.

root-pli-ms: Te yena sako gāmo tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Then they returned to their own village.

root-pli-ms: Tattha yo so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya agamāsi, tassa neva mātāpitaro abhinandiṁsu, na puttadārā abhinandiṁsu, na mittāmaccā abhinandiṁsu, na ca tatonidānaṁ sukhaṁ somanassaṁ adhigacchi.
translation-en-sujato: When one friend returned with a bundle of sunn hemp, they didn’t please their parents, their partners and children, or their friends and colleagues. And they got no pleasure and happiness on that account.

root-pli-ms: Yo pana so sahāyako suvaṇṇabhāraṁ ādāya agamāsi, tassa mātāpitaropi abhinandiṁsu, puttadārāpi abhinandiṁsu, mittāmaccāpi abhinandiṁsu, tatonidānañca sukhaṁ somanassaṁ adhigacchi.
translation-en-sujato: But when the other friend returned with a bundle of gold, they pleased their parents, their partners and children, and their friends and colleagues. And they got much pleasure and happiness on that account.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, sāṇabhārikūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the hemp-carrier in the simile.

root-pli-ms: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!

root-pli-ms: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

root-pli-ms: 3. Saraṇagamana
translation-en-sujato: 3. Going for Refuge

root-pli-ms: “Purimeneva ahaṁ opammena bhoto kassapassa attamano abhiraddho.
translation-en-sujato: “I was delighted and satisfied with your very first simile, Master Kassapa!

root-pli-ms: Api cāhaṁ imāni vicitrāni pañhāpaṭibhānāni sotukāmo evāhaṁ bhavantaṁ kassapaṁ paccanīkaṁ kātabbaṁ amaññissaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Nevertheless, I wanted to hear your various solutions to the problem, so I thought I’d oppose you in this way.

root-pli-ms: Abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa, abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa.
translation-en-sujato: Excellent, Master Kassapa! Excellent!

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bho kassapa, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā kassapena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
translation-en-sujato: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Kassapa has made the teaching clear in many ways.

root-pli-ms: Esāhaṁ, bho kassapa, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
translation-en-sujato: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: From this day forth, may Master Kassapa remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

root-pli-ms: Icchāmi cāhaṁ, bho kassapa, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ, anusāsatu maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo, yaṁ mamassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Master Kassapa, I wish to perform a great sacrifice. Please instruct me so it will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.

root-pli-ms: 4. Yaññakathā
translation-en-sujato: 4. On Sacrifice

root-pli-ms: “Yathārūpe kho, rājañña, yaññe gāvo vā haññanti ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṁso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
translation-en-sujato: “Chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

root-pli-ms: So tattha dukkhette dubbhūme avihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhāpeyya khaṇḍāni pūtīni vātātapahatāni asāradāni asukhasayitāni.
translation-en-sujato: And on that barren field, that barren ground, with uncleared stumps he sowed seeds that were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged, infertile, and ill kept.

root-pli-ms: Devo ca na kālena kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya.
translation-en-sujato: And the heavens don’t provide enough rain when needed.

root-pli-ms: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyyuṁ, kassako vā vipulaṁ phalaṁ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

root-pli-ms: “No hidaṁ, bho kassapa”.
translation-en-sujato: “No, Master Kassapa.”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe gāvo vā haññanti, ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṁso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or splendid or bountiful.

root-pli-ms: Yathārūpe ca kho, rājañña, yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṁso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
translation-en-sujato: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.

root-pli-ms: So tattha sukhette subhūme suvihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhapeyya akhaṇḍāni apūtīni avātātapahatāni sāradāni sukhasayitāni.
translation-en-sujato: And on that fertile field, that fertile ground, with well-cleared stumps he sowed seeds that were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well kept.

root-pli-ms: Devo ca kālena kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya.
translation-en-sujato: And the heavens provide plenty of rain when needed.

root-pli-ms: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyyuṁ, kassako vā vipulaṁ phalaṁ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho kassapa”.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, Master Kassapa.”

root-pli-ms: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṁso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and splendid and bountiful.”

root-pli-ms: 5. Uttaramāṇavavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 5. On the Brahmin Student Uttara

root-pli-ms: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño dānaṁ paṭṭhapesi samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then the chieftain Pāyāsi set up an offering for ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, travelers, and beggars.

root-pli-ms: Tasmiṁ kho pana dāne evarūpaṁ bhojanaṁ dīyati kaṇājakaṁ bilaṅgadutiyaṁ, dhorakāni ca vatthāni guḷavālakāni.
translation-en-sujato: At that offering such food as rough gruel with pickles was given, and heavy clothes with ball-tails.
comment-en-sujato: Read dhorakani, from dhura (comm thūlāni). For guḷavālakāni, cp. Kd 15 which has macchavāḷaka for a monk’s (forbidden) robe. It doesn’t make it particularly clear, but at least it’s something.
variant-pli-ms: dhorakāni → corakāni (sya-all, km); therakāni (pts1ed) | guḷavālakāni → guḷagāḷakāni (bj, mr)

root-pli-ms: Tasmiṁ kho pana dāne uttaro nāma māṇavo vāvaṭo ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: Now, it was a brahmin student named Uttara who organized that offering.

root-pli-ms: So dānaṁ datvā evaṁ anuddisati:
translation-en-sujato: When the offering was over he referred to it like this,

root-pli-ms: “imināhaṁ dānena pāyāsiṁ rājaññameva imasmiṁ loke samāgacchiṁ, mā parasmin”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Through this offering may I be together with the chieftain Pāyāsi in this world, but not in the next.”

root-pli-ms: Assosi kho pāyāsi rājañño:
translation-en-sujato: Pāyāsi heard of this,

root-pli-ms: “uttaro kira māṇavo dānaṁ datvā evaṁ anuddisati:
‘imināhaṁ dānena pāyāsiṁ rājaññameva imasmiṁ loke samāgacchiṁ, mā parasmin’”ti.
Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño uttaraṁ māṇavaṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: so he summoned Uttara and said,

root-pli-ms: “saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, tāta uttara, dānaṁ datvā evaṁ anuddisasi:
translation-en-sujato: “Is it really true, dear Uttara, that you referred to the offering in this way?”

root-pli-ms: ‘imināhaṁ dānena pāyāsiṁ rājaññameva imasmiṁ loke samāgacchiṁ, mā parasmin’”ti?
“Evaṁ, bho”.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir.”

root-pli-ms: “Kissa pana tvaṁ, tāta uttara, dānaṁ datvā evaṁ anuddisasi:
translation-en-sujato: “But why?

root-pli-ms: ‘imināhaṁ dānena pāyāsiṁ rājaññameva imasmiṁ loke samāgacchiṁ, mā parasmin’ti?
Nanu mayaṁ, tāta uttara, puññatthikā dānasseva phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhino”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Don’t we who seek merit expect some result from the offering?”

root-pli-ms: “Bhoto kho dāne evarūpaṁ bhojanaṁ dīyati kaṇājakaṁ bilaṅgadutiyaṁ, yaṁ bhavaṁ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṁ, kuto bhuñjituṁ, dhorakāni ca vatthāni guḷavālakāni, yāni bhavaṁ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṁ, kuto paridahituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “At your offering such food as rough gruel with pickles was given, which you wouldn’t even want to touch with your foot, much less eat. And also heavy clothes with ball-tails, which you also wouldn’t want to touch with your foot, much less wear.
variant-pli-ms: pādāpi → pādāsi (mr) , samphusituṁ → phusituṁ (bj); chupituṁ (pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: Bhavaṁ kho panamhākaṁ piyo manāpo, kathaṁ mayaṁ manāpaṁ amanāpena saṁyojemā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Sir, you’re dear and beloved to me. But how can I reconcile one so dear with something so disagreeable?”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta uttara, yādisāhaṁ bhojanaṁ bhuñjāmi, tādisaṁ bhojanaṁ paṭṭhapehi.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, dear Uttara, set up an offering with the same kind of food that I eat,

root-pli-ms: Yādisāni cāhaṁ vatthāni paridahāmi, tādisāni ca vatthāni paṭṭhapehī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: and the same kind of clothes that I wear.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho uttaro māṇavo pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yādisaṁ bhojanaṁ pāyāsi rājañño bhuñjati, tādisaṁ bhojanaṁ paṭṭhapesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied Uttara, and did so.

root-pli-ms: Yādisāni ca vatthāni pāyāsi rājañño paridahati, tādisāni ca vatthāni paṭṭhapesi.

Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā asahatthā dānaṁ datvā acittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā apaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajji suññaṁ serīsakaṁ vimānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So the chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Four Great Kings, in an empty palace of acacia.
variant-pli-ms: acittīkataṁ → apaviddhaṁ (bj); acittikataṁ (sya-all, km, pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo. So sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā sahatthā dānaṁ datvā cittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajji devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But the brahmin student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: 6. Pāyāsidevaputta
translation-en-sujato: 6. The God Pāyāsi

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā gavampati abhikkhaṇaṁ suññaṁ serīsakaṁ vimānaṁ divāvihāraṁ gacchati.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Venerable Gavampati would often go to that empty acacia palace for the day’s meditation.
comment-en-sujato: Contra MW’s note, divivihara is usually the day’s meditation; siesta is divaseyya

root-pli-ms: Atha kho pāyāsi devaputto yenāyasmā gavampati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ gavampatiṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhitaṁ kho pāyāsiṁ devaputtaṁ āyasmā gavampati etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the god Pāyāsi went up to him, bowed, and stood to one side. Gavampati said to him,

root-pli-ms: “kosi tvaṁ, āvuso”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Who are you, reverend?”

root-pli-ms: “Ahaṁ, bhante, pāyāsi rājañño”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I am the chieftain Pāyāsi.”

root-pli-ms: “Nanu tvaṁ, āvuso, evaṁdiṭṭhiko ahosi:
translation-en-sujato: “Didn’t you have the view that

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: there’s no afterlife, no beings are reborn spontaneously, and there’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds?”

root-pli-ms: “Saccāhaṁ, bhante, evaṁdiṭṭhiko ahosiṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “It’s true, sir, I did have such a view.

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti.
Api cāhaṁ ayyena kumārakassapena etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecito”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But Venerable Kassapa the Prince dissuaded me from that harmful misconception.”

root-pli-ms: “Yo pana te, āvuso, dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so kuhiṁ upapanno”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But the student named Uttara who organized that offering for you—where has he been reborn?”

root-pli-ms: “Yo me, bhante, dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā sahatthā dānaṁ datvā cittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapanno devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, Uttara gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Thirty-Three.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ pana, bhante, asakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā asahatthā dānaṁ datvā acittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā apaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapanno suññaṁ serīsakaṁ vimānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But I gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with my own hands, giving the dregs. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in company with the gods of the Four Great Kings, in an empty palace of acacia.

root-pli-ms: Tena hi, bhante gavampati, manussalokaṁ gantvā evamārocehi:
translation-en-sujato: So, sir, when you’ve returned to the human realm, please announce this:

root-pli-ms: ‘sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ detha, sahatthā dānaṁ detha, cittīkataṁ dānaṁ detha, anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ detha.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Give gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with your own hands, not giving the dregs.

root-pli-ms: Pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā asahatthā dānaṁ datvā acittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā apaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapanno suññaṁ serīsakaṁ vimānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Four Great Kings, in an empty palace of acacia.

root-pli-ms: Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā sahatthā dānaṁ datvā cittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapanno devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyatan’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But the brahmin student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Thirty-Three.’”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā gavampati manussalokaṁ āgantvā evamārocesi:
translation-en-sujato: So when Venerable Gavampati returned to the human realm he made that announcement.

root-pli-ms: “sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ detha, sahatthā dānaṁ detha, cittīkataṁ dānaṁ detha, anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ detha.

Pāyāsi rājañño asakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā asahatthā dānaṁ datvā acittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā apaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapanno suññaṁ serīsakaṁ vimānaṁ.

Yo pana tassa dāne vāvaṭo ahosi uttaro nāma māṇavo, so sakkaccaṁ dānaṁ datvā sahatthā dānaṁ datvā cittīkataṁ dānaṁ datvā anapaviddhaṁ dānaṁ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapanno devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyatan”ti.
Pāyāsisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dasamaṁ.
Mahāvaggo niṭṭhito.
Tassuddānaṁ
Mahāpadāna nidānaṁ,
nibbānañca sudassanaṁ;
Janavasabha govindaṁ,
samayaṁ sakkapañhakaṁ;
Mahāsatipaṭṭhānañca,
pāyāsi dasamaṁ bhave.

root-pli-ms: Mahāvaggapāḷi niṭṭhitā.
Dīgha Nikāya 24
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 24

root-pli-ms: Pāthikasutta
translation-en-sujato: About Pāṭikaputta

root-pli-ms: 1. Sunakkhattavatthu
translation-en-sujato: 1. On Sunakkhatta

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.
reference: bj9.2, cck11.1, csp1ed8.1, csp2ed8.1, dr11.1, ms8D_2, msdiv1, ndp8.3, pts-cs1.1, pts-vp-pli3.1, sc1, sya11.1, vri3.1

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu viharati anupiyaṁ nāma mallānaṁ nigamo.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Anupiya.
variant-pli-ms: anupiyaṁ nāma → anupiyā nāma (bj); anuppiyaṁ nāma (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya anupiyaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Anupiya for alms.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then it occurred to him,

root-pli-ms: “atippago kho tāva anupiyāyaṁ piṇḍāya carituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Anupiya.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ yena bhaggavagottassa paribbājakassa ārāmo, yena bhaggavagotto paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I go to the wanderer Bhaggavagotta’s monastery to visit him?”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā yena bhaggavagottassa paribbājakassa ārāmo, yena bhaggavagotto paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.
reference: bj9.4, cck11.2, csp1ed8.2, csp2ed8.2, dr11.2, ms8D_3, msdiv2, ndp8.4, pts-cs1.2, pts-vp-pli3.2, sc2, sya11.2, vri3.2

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then the wanderer Bhaggavagotta said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “etu kho, bhante, bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: “Come, Blessed One!

root-pli-ms: Svāgataṁ, bhante, bhagavato.
translation-en-sujato: Welcome, Blessed One!

root-pli-ms: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
translation-en-sujato: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

root-pli-ms: Nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā, idamāsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”

root-pli-ms: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane.
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

root-pli-ms: Bhaggavagottopi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: while Bhaggavagotta took a low seat, sat to one side,

root-pli-ms: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho bhaggavagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: and said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, a few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me and said:

root-pli-ms: ‘paccakkhāto dāni mayā, bhaggava, bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Now, Bhaggava, I have rejected the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Na dānāhaṁ bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Now I no longer live dedicated to him.’

root-pli-ms: Kaccetaṁ, bhante, tatheva, yathā sunakkhatto licchaviputto avacā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: Sir, is what Sunakkhatta said true?”

root-pli-ms: “Tatheva kho etaṁ, bhaggava, yathā sunakkhatto licchaviputto avaca.
translation-en-sujato: “Indeed it is, Bhaggava.

root-pli-ms: Purimāni, bhaggava, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, bhaggava, sunakkhatto licchaviputto maṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: A few days ago Sunakkhatta the Licchavi came to me, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:
reference: cck11.3, ms8D_4, msdiv3, pts-cs1.3, pts-vp-pli3.3, sc3, sya11.3

root-pli-ms: ‘paccakkhāmi dānāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Now I reject the Buddha!

root-pli-ms: Na dānāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Now I shall no longer live dedicated to you.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, bhaggava, sunakkhattaṁ licchaviputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When Sunakkhatta said this, I said to him,

root-pli-ms: ‘api nu tāhaṁ, sunakkhatta, evaṁ avacaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Come, live dedicated to me”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tvaṁ vā pana maṁ evaṁ avaca—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, nevāhaṁ taṁ vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: ‘So it seems that I did not ask you to

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhīti.
translation-en-sujato: live dedicated to me,

root-pli-ms: Napi kira maṁ tvaṁ vadesi—
translation-en-sujato: nor did you say you would

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmīti.
translation-en-sujato: live dedicated to me.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṁ paccācikkhasi?
translation-en-sujato: In that case, you silly man, are you really in a position to be rejecting anything?

root-pli-ms: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṁ aparaddhan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: See how far you have strayed!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘But sir, the Buddha never performs any superhuman demonstrations of psychic power for me.’
reference: bj9.6, cck11.4, csp1ed8.3, csp2ed8.3, dr11.3, ms8D_5, msdiv4, ndp8.5, pts-cs1.4, pts-vp-pli3.4, sc4, sya11.4, vri3.3

root-pli-ms: ‘Api nu tāhaṁ, sunakkhatta, evaṁ avacaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṁ te uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissāmī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for you”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tvaṁ vā pana maṁ evaṁ avaca—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissatī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for me”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, nevāhaṁ taṁ vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṁ te uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissāmīti;
napi kira maṁ tvaṁ vadesi—
ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ karissatīti.
Evaṁ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṁ paccācikkhasi?
translation-en-sujato: In that case, you silly man, are you really in a position to be rejecting anything?

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, sunakkhatta,
translation-en-sujato: What do you think, Sunakkhatta?

root-pli-ms: kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: Whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kate vā, bhante, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya bhagavatā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It does, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
translation-en-sujato: ‘So it seems that whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Tatra, sunakkhatta, kiṁ uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṁ kataṁ karissati?
translation-en-sujato: In that case, what is the point of superhuman demonstrations of psychic power?

root-pli-ms: Passa, moghapurisa, yāvañca te idaṁ aparaddhan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: See how far you have strayed, you silly man!’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi pana me, bhante, bhagavā aggaññaṁ paññapetī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But sir, the Buddha never describes the origin of the world to me.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Api nu tāhaṁ, sunakkhatta, evaṁ avacaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: ‘But Sunakkhatta, did I ever say to you:

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṁ te aggaññaṁ paññapessāmī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Come, live dedicated to me and I will describe the origin of the world to you”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Tvaṁ vā pana maṁ evaṁ avaca—
translation-en-sujato: ‘Or did you ever say to me:

root-pli-ms: ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me aggaññaṁ paññapessatī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, I shall live dedicated to the Buddha, and the Buddha will describe the origin of the world to me”?’

root-pli-ms: ‘No hetaṁ, bhante’.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sir.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, nevāhaṁ taṁ vadāmi—
translation-en-sujato: ‘So it seems that I did not ask this of you, and you did not require it of me.

root-pli-ms: ehi tvaṁ, sunakkhatta, mamaṁ uddissa viharāhi, ahaṁ te aggaññaṁ paññapessāmīti.
Napi kira maṁ tvaṁ vadesi—
ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ uddissa viharissāmi, bhagavā me aggaññaṁ paññapessatīti.
Evaṁ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo kaṁ paccācikkhasi?
translation-en-sujato: In that case, you silly man, are you really in a position to be rejecting anything?
