root-pli-ms: Iti kho, nigrodha, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ avacāsi:
translation-en-sujato: Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:

root-pli-ms: ‘ko nāma so, bhante, bhagavato dhammo, yena bhagavā sāvake vineti, yena bhagavatā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, what teaching do you use to guide your disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life?’

root-pli-ms: Iti kho taṁ, nigrodha, ṭhānaṁ uttaritarañca paṇītatarañca, yenāhaṁ sāvake vinemi, yena mayā sāvakā vinītā assāsappattā paṭijānanti ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Well, there is something better and finer than this. That’s what I use to guide my disciples, through which they claim solace in the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, those wanderers made an uproar,

root-pli-ms: “ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā, na mayaṁ ito bhiyyo uttaritaraṁ pajānāmā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “In that case, we’re lost, and so is our tradition! We don’t know anything better or finer than that!”

root-pli-ms: 4. Nigrodhassapajjhāyana
translation-en-sujato: 4. Nigrodha Feels Depressed

root-pli-ms: Yadā aññāsi sandhāno gahapati:
translation-en-sujato: Then the householder Sandhāna realized,
reference: bj9.88, cck11.57, csp1ed8.44, csp2ed8.44, dr11.57, ms8D_168, msdiv75, ndp8.42, pts-cs20, pts-vp-pli3.53, sc60, sya11.56, vri3.39

root-pli-ms: “aññadatthu kho dānime aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato bhāsitaṁ sussūsanti, sotaṁ odahanti, aññācittaṁ upaṭṭhāpentī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Obviously, now these wanderers want to listen to what the Buddha says. They’re paying attention and applying their minds to understand!”

root-pli-ms: Atha nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So he said to the wanderer Nigrodha,

root-pli-ms: “iti kho, bhante nigrodha, yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ avacāsi:
translation-en-sujato: “Nigrodha, remember you said this to me:

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, gahapati, jāneyyāsi, kena samaṇo gotamo saddhiṁ sallapati, kena sākacchaṁ samāpajjati, kena paññāveyyattiyaṁ samāpajjati,
translation-en-sujato: ‘Surely, householder, you should know better! With whom does the ascetic Gotama converse? With whom does he engage in discussion? With whom does he achieve lucidity of wisdom?

root-pli-ms: suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṁ sallāpāya, so antamantāneva sevati;
translation-en-sujato: Staying in empty huts has destroyed the ascetic Gotama’s wisdom. Not frequenting assemblies, he is unable to hold a discussion. He just lurks on the periphery.

root-pli-ms: seyyathāpi nāma gokāṇā pariyantacārinī antamantāneva sevati.
translation-en-sujato: He’s just like the nilgai antelope, circling around and lurking on the periphery.

root-pli-ms: Evameva suññāgārahatā samaṇassa gotamassa paññā, aparisāvacaro samaṇo gotamo nālaṁ sallāpāya; so antamantāneva sevati;
iṅgha, gahapati, samaṇo gotamo imaṁ parisaṁ āgaccheyya, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādeyyāma, tucchakumbhīva naṁ maññe orodheyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Please, householder, let the ascetic Gotama come to this assembly. I’ll sink him with just one question! I’ll roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot!’

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho so, bhante, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho idhānuppatto, aparisāvacaraṁ pana naṁ karotha, gokāṇaṁ pariyantacāriniṁ karotha, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādetha, tucchakumbhīva naṁ orodhethā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a nilgai antelope? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, Nigrodha sat silent, embarrassed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ maṅkubhūtaṁ pattakkhandhaṁ adhomukhaṁ pajjhāyantaṁ appaṭibhānaṁ viditvā nigrodhaṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Knowing this, the Buddha said to him,
reference: cck11.58, ms8D_169, msdiv76, pts-cs21, pts-vp-pli3.54, sc61, sya11.57

root-pli-ms: “saccaṁ kira, nigrodha, bhāsitā te esā vācā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Is it really true, Nigrodha—are those your words?”

root-pli-ms: “Saccaṁ, bhante, bhāsitā me esā vācā, yathābālena yathāmūḷhena yathāakusalenā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”

root-pli-ms: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, nigrodha.
translation-en-sujato: “What do you think, Nigrodha?

root-pli-ms: Kinti te sutaṁ paribbājakānaṁ vuḍḍhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Have you heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said that

root-pli-ms: ‘ye te ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, evaṁ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ anuyuttā viharanti.
translation-en-sujato: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they made an uproar, a dreadful racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of unworthy topics,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ …pe… itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
Seyyathāpi tvaṁ etarahi sācariyako.
translation-en-sujato: like you do in your tradition these days?

root-pli-ms: Udāhu, evaṁ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpāhaṁ etarahī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Or did they say that the Buddhas frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat, like I do these days?”

root-pli-ms: “Sutaṁ metaṁ, bhante. Paribbājakānaṁ vuḍḍhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
translation-en-sujato: “I have heard that wanderers of the past who were elderly and senior, said that

root-pli-ms: ‘ye te ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, na evaṁ su te bhagavanto saṅgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ anuyuttā viharanti.
translation-en-sujato: when the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas of the past came together, they didn’t make an uproar,
variant-pli-ms: na evaṁ su te → na evaṁsute (sya-all); nāssu te (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ …pe… itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā,
seyyathāpāhaṁ etarahi sācariyako.
translation-en-sujato: like I do in my tradition these days.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ su te bhagavanto araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni, seyyathāpi bhagavā etarahī’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: They said that the Buddhas of the past frequented remote lodgings in the wilderness, like the Buddha does these days.”

root-pli-ms: “Tassa te, nigrodha, viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: “Nigrodha, you are a sensible and mature man. Did it not occur to you:

root-pli-ms: ‘buddho so bhagavā bodhāya dhammaṁ deseti, danto so bhagavā damathāya dhammaṁ deseti, santo so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṁ deseti, tiṇṇo so bhagavā taraṇāya dhammaṁ deseti, parinibbuto so bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammaṁ desetī’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and extinguished. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, taming, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment’?”

root-pli-ms: 5. Brahmacariyapariyosānasacchikiriyā
translation-en-sujato: 5. The Culmination of the Spiritual Path

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, nigrodho paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Nigrodha said,

root-pli-ms: “accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yvāhaṁ evaṁ bhagavantaṁ avacāsiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “I have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to speak in that way.

root-pli-ms: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”

root-pli-ms: “Taggha tvaṁ, nigrodha, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yo maṁ tvaṁ evaṁ avacāsi.
translation-en-sujato: “Indeed, Nigrodha, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to speak in that way.

root-pli-ms: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, nigrodha, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
translation-en-sujato: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.

root-pli-ms: Vuddhi hesā, nigrodha, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
translation-en-sujato: For it is growth in the training of the noble one to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ kho pana, nigrodha, evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: Nigrodha, this is what I say:

root-pli-ms: ‘Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

root-pli-ms: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattavassāni.
translation-en-sujato: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven years. They will live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Tiṭṭhantu, nigrodha, satta vassāni.
translation-en-sujato: Let alone seven years.

root-pli-ms: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

root-pli-ms: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati cha vassāni.
translation-en-sujato: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in six years …

root-pli-ms: Pañca vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: five years …

root-pli-ms: cattāri vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: four years …

root-pli-ms: tīṇi vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: three years …

root-pli-ms: dve vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: two years …

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ vassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: one year …

root-pli-ms: Tiṭṭhatu, nigrodha, ekaṁ vassaṁ.
Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.

Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati satta māsāni.
translation-en-sujato: seven months …

root-pli-ms: Tiṭṭhantu, nigrodha, satta māsāni …
cha māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: six months …

root-pli-ms: pañca māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: five months …

root-pli-ms: cattāri māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: four months …

root-pli-ms: tīṇi māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: three months …

root-pli-ms: dve māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: two months …

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ māsaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: one month …

root-pli-ms: aḍḍhamāsaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: a fortnight.

root-pli-ms: Tiṭṭhatu, nigrodha, aḍḍhamāso.
translation-en-sujato: Let alone a fortnight.

root-pli-ms: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.

root-pli-ms: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati sattāhaṁ’.
translation-en-sujato: By practicing as instructed they will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life, in seven days.

root-pli-ms: 6. Paribbājakānaṁpajjhāyana
translation-en-sujato: 6. The Wanderers Feel Depressed

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Nigrodha, you might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘antevāsikamyatā no samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants pupils.’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like this.

root-pli-ms: Yo eva vo ācariyo, so eva vo ācariyo hotu.
translation-en-sujato: Let your teacher remain your teacher.

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: You might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘uddesā no cāvetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our recitation.’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like this.

root-pli-ms: Yo eva vo uddeso so eva vo uddeso hotu.
translation-en-sujato: Let your recitation remain as it is.

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: You might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ājīvā no cāvetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to give up our livelihood.’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like this.

root-pli-ms: Yo eva vo ājīvo, so eva vo ājīvo hotu.
translation-en-sujato: Let your livelihood remain as it is.

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: You might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ye no dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to start doing things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in our tradition.’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like this.

root-pli-ms: Akusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu akusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let those things that are unskillful and considered unskillful in your tradition remain as they are.
variant-pli-ms: ceva vo te dhammā → vo dhammā (bj, mr); te dhammā (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: Siyā kho pana te, nigrodha, evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: You might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ye no dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tehi vivecetukāmo samaṇo gotamo evamāhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama speaks like this because he wants us to stop doing things that are skillful and considered skillful in our tradition.’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ, nigrodha, evaṁ daṭṭhabbaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But you should not see it like this.

root-pli-ms: Kusalā ceva vo te dhammā hontu kusalasaṅkhātā ca sācariyakānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Let those things that are skillful and considered skillful in your tradition remain as they are.

root-pli-ms: Iti khvāhaṁ, nigrodha, neva antevāsikamyatā evaṁ vadāmi, napi uddesā cāvetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ājīvā cāvetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṁ, tehi vivecetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi.
translation-en-sujato: I do not speak for any of these reasons.
variant-pli-ms: napi ājīvā cāvetukāmo evaṁ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā → napi ye ca kho dhammā (bj); napi ye te dhammā (sya-all); napi ye ca vo dhammā (mr) | napi ye vo dhammā → napi ye ca kho dhammā (bj); napi ye te dhammā (sya-all); napi ye ca vo dhammā (mr)

root-pli-ms: Santi ca kho, nigrodha, akusalā dhammā appahīnā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, yesāhaṁ pahānāya dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Nigrodha, there are things that are unskillful, corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. I teach Dhamma so that those things may be given up.
variant-pli-ms: sadarā → sadarathā (sya-all, mr); saddarā (pts1ed, mr) | ponobbhavikā → ponobhavikā (bj, pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: Yathāpaṭipannānaṁ vo saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodānīyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṁ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.”

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhībhūtā maṅkubhūtā pattakkhandhā adhomukhā pajjhāyantā appaṭibhānā nisīdiṁsu yathā taṁ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacittā.
translation-en-sujato: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say, as if their minds were possessed by Māra.
reference: cck11.62, ms8D_180, msdiv79, ndp8.45, pts-cs24, sc72

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha thought,

root-pli-ms: “sabbepime moghapurisā phuṭṭhā pāpimatā.
translation-en-sujato: “All these foolish people have been touched by the Wicked One!

root-pli-ms: Yatra hi nāma ekassapi na evaṁ bhavissati:
translation-en-sujato: For not even a single one thinks,

root-pli-ms: ‘handa mayaṁ aññāṇatthampi samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ carāma, kiṁ karissati sattāho’”ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, let us lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama for the sake of enlightenment—for what do seven days matter?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā udumbarikāya paribbājakārāme sīhanādaṁ naditvā vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā gijjhakūṭe pabbate paccupaṭṭhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha, having roared his lion’s roar in the lady Udumbarikā’s monastery for wanderers, rose into the air and landed on Vulture’s Peak.

root-pli-ms: Sandhāno pana gahapati tāvadeva rājagahaṁ pāvisīti.
translation-en-sujato: Meanwhile, the householder Sandhāna just went back to Rājagaha.

root-pli-ms: Udumbarikasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dutiyaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 26
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 26

root-pli-ms: Cakkavattisutta
translation-en-sujato: The Wheel-Turning Monarch

root-pli-ms: 1. Attadīpasaraṇatā
translation-en-sujato: 1. Taking Refuge in Oneself

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.
reference: bj9.96, cck11.63, csp1ed8.48, csp2ed8.48, dr11.62, ms8D_183, msdiv80, ndp8.46, pts-cs1, pts-vp-pli3.58, sc1, sya11.62, vri3.42

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā magadhesu viharati mātulāyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at Mātulā.

root-pli-ms: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

root-pli-ms: “bhikkhavo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants!”

root-pli-ms: “Bhaddante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:

root-pli-ms: “Attadīpā, bhikkhave, viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant do this?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Vedanāsu vedanānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

root-pli-ms: citte cittānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: mind …

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how they let the teaching be their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

root-pli-ms: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
translation-en-sujato: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

root-pli-ms: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṁ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṁ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t catch you or get hold of you.

root-pli-ms: Kusalānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ samādānahetu evamidaṁ puññaṁ pavaḍḍhati.
translation-en-sujato: It is due to undertaking skillful qualities that this merit grows.
comment-en-sujato: This line feels awkward, and I suspect that both here and in its recurrence at the end it is clumsily inserted. It’s not clear what “idam” refers to. Both RD and MW translate “evamidam” as if it were eva’m’idam, but this is unlikely. Evamidam is used to indicate entailment, eg MN 73. Comm: “Evamidaṁ puññaṁ pavaḍḍhatīti evaṁ idaṁ lokiyalokuttaraṁ puññaphalaṁ vaḍḍhati, puññaphalanti ca uparūpari puññampi puññavipākopi veditabbo.”

root-pli-ms: 2. Daḷhanemicakkavattirājā
translation-en-sujato: 2. King Daḷhanemi

root-pli-ms: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi nāma ahosi cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Daḷhanemi who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
reference: bj9.98, cck11.64, dr11.63, ms8D_186, msdiv81, pts-cs2, pts-vp-pli3.59, sc4, sya11.63, vri3.43

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni ahesuṁ seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: He had the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā ahesuṁ sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He had over a thousand sons who were valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasi.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigned by principle, without rod or sword.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Daḷhanemi addressed one of his men,
reference: cck11.65, csp1ed8.49, csp2ed8.49, ms8D_187, msdiv82, ndp8.47, pts-cs3, pts-vp-pli3.60, sc5, sya11.64

root-pli-ms: ‘yadā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, passeyyāsi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, atha me āroceyyāsī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My good man, when you see that the heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place, please tell me.’
comment-en-sujato: osakkati: like a woman shrinking away from a man’s advances (DN 12), or a ram drawing back getting ready to charge (Ja 324).

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño daḷhanemissa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied that man.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so puriso bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, disvāna yena rājā daḷhanemi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ daḷhanemiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: After many thousand years had passed, that man saw that the heavenly wheel-treasure had receded back from its place. So he went to King Daḷhanemi and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ te cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Please sire, you should know that your heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: So the king summoned the crown prince and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘dibbaṁ kira me, tāta kumāra, cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Dear prince, my heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place.

root-pli-ms: Sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: I’ve heard that

root-pli-ms: yassa rañño cakkavattissa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkati ṭhānā cavati, na dāni tena raññā ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ hotīti.
translation-en-sujato: when this happens to a wheel-turning monarch, he does not have long to live.

root-pli-ms: Bhuttā kho pana me mānusakā kāmā, samayo dāni me dibbe kāme pariyesituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: I have enjoyed human pleasures. Now it is time for me to seek heavenly pleasures.

root-pli-ms: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta kumāra, imaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ paṭipajja.
translation-en-sujato: Come, dear prince, rule this land surrounded by ocean!

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ pana kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
translation-en-sujato: And so, after carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Daḷhanemi shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Sattāhapabbajite kho pana, bhikkhave, rājisimhi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso yena rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then a certain man approached the newly anointed aristocrat king and said,
reference: cck11.66, csp1ed8.50, csp2ed8.50, ms8D_189, ndp8.48, pts-cs4, sc7, vri3.44

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antarahitan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi, anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi.
translation-en-sujato: At that the king was unhappy and experienced unhappiness.

root-pli-ms: So yena rājisi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājisiṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He went to the royal sage and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antarahitan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājisi rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When he said this, the royal sage said to him,

root-pli-ms: ‘mā kho tvaṁ, tāta, dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi, mā anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi, na hi te, tāta, dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pettikaṁ dāyajjaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Don’t be unhappy at the vanishing of the wheel-treasure. My dear, the wheel-treasure is not inherited from your father.

root-pli-ms: Iṅgha tvaṁ, tāta, ariye cakkavattivatte vattāhi.
translation-en-sujato: Come now, my dear, implement the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.
comment-en-sujato: Since this is the only place where ariya qualifies cakkavatti, I assume it refers to the duties, similar to ariyavinaya. Also see the title below, Cakkavattiariyavatta

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ te ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pātubhavissati sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūran’ti.
translation-en-sujato: If you do so, it’s possible that—on a fifteenth day sabbath, having bathed your head and gone upstairs in the stilt longhouse to observe the sabbath—the heavenly wheel-treasure will appear to you, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.’

root-pli-ms: 2.1. Cakkavattiariyavatta
translation-en-sujato: 2.1. The Noble Duties of a Wheel-Turning Monarch

root-pli-ms: ‘Katamaṁ pana taṁ, deva, ariyaṁ cakkavattivattan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But sire, what are the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch?’
reference: bj9.102, cck11.67, dr11.65, ms8D_190, msdiv84, pts-cs5, pts-vp-pli3.61, sc8, sya11.65

root-pli-ms: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
comment-en-sujato: saṁvidahassu is second middle imperative
variant-pli-ms: anuyantesu → anuyuttesu (bj, pts1ed) | garuṁ karonto → garukaronto (bj, sya-all, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Mā ca te, tāta, vijite adhammakāro pavattittha.
translation-en-sujato: Do not let injustice prevail in the realm.
comment-en-sujato: pavattittha is aorist middle. Curiously, (a)dhammakāra doesn’t seem to occur elswehere in the EBTs. It does occur in Ja 513 and Ja 498, both times in the context of just rule: Adhammakāro tava māhu raṭṭhe

root-pli-ms: Ye ca te, tāta, vijite adhanā assu, tesañca dhanamanuppadeyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Pay money to the penniless in the realm.
comment-en-sujato: While anuppadeti is given in the dicts in the sense of “give, hand over”, in the nikayas it seems to be restricted to “pay” in the sense of a just reward for work, or return on a loan. While I wouldn’t want to over-interpret it, it is an interesting choice here, which suggests more “pay them a fair wage “than” support them with charity”.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca te, tāta, vijite samaṇabrāhmaṇā madappamādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṁ damenti, ekamattānaṁ samenti, ekamattānaṁ parinibbāpenti, te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā paripuccheyyāsi pariggaṇheyyāsi:
translation-en-sujato: And there are ascetics and brahmins in the realm who avoid intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves. From time to time you should go up to them and ask:
comment-en-sujato: Where this idiom occurs elsewhere, it is inevitably with paripucchati paripañhati. PTS here omits the second verb. Comm is silent. Generally the suttas are very precise about the sequence of learning: first you ask, then you listen, then you learn. Most likely this is a mistake here.

root-pli-ms: “kiṁ, bhante, kusalaṁ, kiṁ akusalaṁ, kiṁ sāvajjaṁ, kiṁ anavajjaṁ, kiṁ sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ na sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya assa, kiṁ vā pana me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya assā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?”

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ sutvā yaṁ akusalaṁ taṁ abhinivajjeyyāsi, yaṁ kusalaṁ taṁ samādāya vatteyyāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Having heard them, you should reject what is unskillful and undertake and follow what is skillful.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, tāta, taṁ ariyaṁ cakkavattivattan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.’

root-pli-ms: 2.2. Cakkaratanapātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 2.2. The Wheel-Treasure Appears

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto rājisissa paṭissutvā ariye cakkavattivatte vatti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the new king to the royal sage. And he implemented the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.
reference: bj9.104, csp1ed8.51, csp2ed8.51, dr11.66, ms8D_191, msdiv85, pts-vp-pli3.62, sc9, sya11.66, vri3.45

root-pli-ms: Tassa ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa
translation-en-sujato: While he was implementing them, on a fifteenth day sabbath, he had bathed his head and gone upstairs in the stilt longhouse to observe the sabbath.

root-pli-ms: dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pāturahosi sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And the heavenly wheel-treasure appeared to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.

root-pli-ms: Disvāna rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Seeing this, the king thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ—yassa rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṁnhātassa uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ pātubhavati sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ sanābhikaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ, so hoti rājā cakkavattīti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Assaṁ nu kho ahaṁ rājā cakkavattī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā vāmena hatthena bhiṅkāraṁ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena cakkaratanaṁ abbhukkiri:
translation-en-sujato: Then the anointed king, rising from his seat and arranging his robe over one shoulder, took a ceremonial vase in his left hand and besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘pavattatu bhavaṁ cakkaratanaṁ, abhivijinātu bhavaṁ cakkaratanan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, cakkaratanaṁ puratthimaṁ disaṁ pavatti, anvadeva rājā cakkavattī saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya. Yasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, padese cakkaratanaṁ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā cakkavattī vāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: Then the wheel-treasure rolled towards the east. And the king followed it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṁ cakkavattiṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to the wheel-turning monarch and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṁ te mahārāja, sakaṁ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

root-pli-ms: Rājā cakkavattī evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: The wheel-turning monarch said,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṁ nādātabbaṁ, kāmesumicchā na caritabbā, musā na bhāsitabbā, majjaṁ na pātabbaṁ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, puratthimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter became his vassals.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, cakkaratanaṁ puratthimaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ pavatti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolled towards the south. …
reference: bj9.106, cck11.69, csp1ed8.52, csp2ed8.52, ms8D_194, msdiv86, pts-cs7, pts-vp-pli3.63, sc12

root-pli-ms: dakkhiṇaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā pacchimaṁ disaṁ pavatti, anvadeva rājā cakkavattī saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the west. …

root-pli-ms: Yasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, padese cakkaratanaṁ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā cakkavattī vāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, pacchimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṁ cakkavattiṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṁ te, mahārāja, sakaṁ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
Rājā cakkavattī evamāha:
‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṁ nādātabbaṁ, kāmesumicchā na caritabbā, musā na bhāsitabbā, majjaṁ na pātabbaṁ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, pacchimāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, cakkaratanaṁ pacchimaṁ samuddaṁ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā uttaraṁ disaṁ pavatti, anvadeva rājā cakkavattī saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions.

root-pli-ms: Yasmiṁ kho pana, bhikkhave, padese cakkaratanaṁ patiṭṭhāsi, tattha rājā cakkavattī vāsaṁ upagacchi saddhiṁ caturaṅginiyā senāya.
translation-en-sujato: In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rājānaṁ cakkavattiṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to the wheel-turning monarch and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi kho, mahārāja, svāgataṁ te, mahārāja, sakaṁ te, mahārāja, anusāsa, mahārājā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’

root-pli-ms: Rājā cakkavattī evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: The wheel-turning monarch said,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāṇo na hantabbo, adinnaṁ nādātabbaṁ, kāmesumicchā na caritabbā, musā na bhāsitabbā, majjaṁ na pātabbaṁ, yathābhuttañca bhuñjathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, bhikkhave, uttarāya disāya paṭirājāno, te rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And so the rulers of the northern quarter became his vassals.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, cakkaratanaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ abhivijinitvā tameva rājadhāniṁ paccāgantvā rañño cakkavattissa antepuradvāre atthakaraṇapamukhe akkhāhataṁ maññe aṭṭhāsi rañño cakkavattissa antepuraṁ upasobhayamānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returned to the royal capital. There it stood still by the gate to the royal compound at the High Court as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
comment-en-sujato: https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/does-a-akara-a-mean-judgment-hall/3399

root-pli-ms: 3. Dutiyādicakkavattikathā
translation-en-sujato: 3. On Subsequent Wheel-Turning Monarchs

root-pli-ms: Dutiyopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And for a second time,
reference: cck11.70, csp1ed8.53, csp2ed8.53, dr11.69, ms8D_197, msdiv88, pts-cs8, pts-vp-pli3.64, sc15, sya11.69

root-pli-ms: tatiyopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī …
translation-en-sujato: and a third,

root-pli-ms: catutthopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī …
translation-en-sujato: a fourth,

root-pli-ms: pañcamopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī …
translation-en-sujato: a fifth,

root-pli-ms: chaṭṭhopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī …
translation-en-sujato: a sixth,

root-pli-ms: sattamopi kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: and a seventh time, a wheel-turning monarch was established in exactly the same way. And after many years the seventh wheel-turning monarch went forth, handing the realm over to the crown prince.

root-pli-ms: ‘yadā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, passeyyāsi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ, atha me āroceyyāsī’ti.
‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño cakkavattissa paccassosi.
Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so puriso bahunnaṁ vassānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasatānaṁ bahunnaṁ vassasahassānaṁ accayena dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutaṁ.
Disvāna yena rājā cakkavattī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ cakkavattiṁ etadavoca:
‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ te cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ ṭhānā cutan’ti?
Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ āmantāpetvā etadavoca:
reference: bj9.108, ms8D_198, msdiv89, ndp8.51, sc16, vri3.47

root-pli-ms: ‘dibbaṁ kira me, tāta kumāra, cakkaratanaṁ osakkitaṁ, ṭhānā cutaṁ, sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ—
yassa rañño cakkavattissa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkati, ṭhānā cavati, na dāni tena raññā ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ hotīti.
Bhuttā kho pana me mānusakā kāmā, samayo dāni me dibbe kāme pariyesituṁ, ehi tvaṁ, tāta kumāra, imaṁ samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ paṭipajja.
Ahaṁ pana kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmī’ti.
Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
Sattāhapabbajite kho pana, bhikkhave, rājisimhi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso yena rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then a certain man approached the newly anointed aristocrat king and said,
reference: dr11.70, ms8D_200, msdiv90, pts-cs9, sc18, sya11.70

root-pli-ms: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antarahitan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi. Anattamanatañca paṭisaṁvedesi;
translation-en-sujato: At that the king was unhappy and experienced unhappiness.

root-pli-ms: no ca kho rājisiṁ upasaṅkamitvā ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ pucchi.
translation-en-sujato: But he didn’t go to the royal sage and ask about the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: So samateneva sudaṁ janapadaṁ pasāsati.
translation-en-sujato: He just governed the country according to his own ideas.

root-pli-ms: Tassa samatena janapadaṁ pasāsato pubbenāparaṁ janapadā na pabbanti, yathā taṁ pubbakānaṁ rājūnaṁ ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So governed, the nations did not prosper like before, as they had when former kings implemented the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.
comment-en-sujato: I don’t know what pabbanti means, but comm sensibly has “na pabbantīti na vaḍḍhanti”. Note janapada in plural; extrapolating from the contemporary situation, it seems that the realm of the cakkavatti was comprised of several smaller nations. Both RD and MW mistranslate as “people” here.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, amaccā pārisajjā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā mantassājīvino sannipatitvā rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ muddhābhisittaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then the ministers and counselors, the treasury officials, military officers, guardsmen, and advisers gathered and said to the king,
comment-en-sujato: For anīkaṭṭhā, RD and MW both have “guards”. However comm says “Anīkaṭṭhāti hatthiācariyādayo”, which for some reason CPD thinks is worthy of an exclamation point. But surely this is reasonable: those in charge of the elephants and so on would have been important officials in the army. I think it is standing officers in the army, rather than royal guards as such. For mantassājīvino, RD and MW think it means chanters of mantras, but comm has “Mantassājīvinoti mantā vuccati paññā, taṁ nissayaṁ katvā ye jīvanti paṇḍitā mahāmattā, tesaṁ etaṁ nāmaṁ.”

root-pli-ms: ‘na kho te, deva, samatena sudaṁ janapadaṁ pasāsato pubbenāparaṁ janapadā pabbanti, yathā taṁ pubbakānaṁ rājūnaṁ ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, when governed according to your own ideas, the nations do not prosper like before, as they did when former kings implemented the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Saṁvijjanti kho te, deva, vijite amaccā pārisajjā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā mantassājīvino mayañceva aññe ca ye mayaṁ ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ dhārema.
translation-en-sujato: In your realm are found ministers and counselors, treasury officials, military officers, guardsmen, and advisers—both ourselves and others—who remember the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Iṅgha tvaṁ, deva, amhe ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puccha.
translation-en-sujato: Please, Your Majesty, ask us about the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Tassa te mayaṁ ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puṭṭhā byākarissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: We will answer you.’

root-pli-ms: 4. Āyuvaṇṇādiparihānikathā
translation-en-sujato: 4. On the Period of Decline

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto amacce pārisajje gaṇakamahāmatte anīkaṭṭhe dovārike mantassājīvino sannipātetvā ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ pucchi.
translation-en-sujato: So the anointed king asked the assembled ministers and counselors, treasury officials, military officers, guardsmen, and advisers about the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.
reference: bj9.110, cck11.72, dr11.71, ms8D_202, msdiv91, ndp8.52, pts-cs10, pts-vp-pli3.66, sc20, sya11.71, vri3.48

root-pli-ms: Tassa te ariyaṁ cakkavattivattaṁ puṭṭhā byākariṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And they answered him.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ sutvā dhammikañhi kho rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahi, no ca kho adhanānaṁ dhanamanuppadāsi.
translation-en-sujato: But after listening to them, he didn’t provide just protection and security. Nor did he pay money to the penniless in the realm.

root-pli-ms: Adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so poverty grew widespread.

root-pli-ms: Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: When poverty was widespread, a certain person stole from others, with the intention to commit theft.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They arrested him

root-pli-ms: Gahetvā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa dassesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: and presented him to the king, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others with the intention to commit theft.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The king said to that person,

root-pli-ms: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is it really true, mister, that you stole from others with the intention to commit theft?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Saccaṁ, devā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s true, sire.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁ kāraṇā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What was the reason?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi, deva, jīvāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, I can’t survive.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tassa purisassa dhanamanuppadāsi:
translation-en-sujato: So the king paid some money to that person, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘iminā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, dhanena attanā ca jīvāhi, mātāpitaro ca posehi, puttadārañca posehi, kammante ca payojehi, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhāpehi sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘With this money, mister, keep yourself alive, and provide for your mother and father, partners and children. Work for a living, and establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied that man.

root-pli-ms: Aññataropi kho, bhikkhave, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: But then another man stole something from others.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They arrested him

root-pli-ms: Gahetvā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa dassesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: and presented him to the king, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The king said to that person,

root-pli-ms: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is it really true, mister, that you stole from others?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Saccaṁ, devā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s true, sire.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁ kāraṇā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What was the reason?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi, deva, jīvāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, I can’t survive.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto tassa purisassa dhanamanuppadāsi:
translation-en-sujato: So the king paid some money to that person, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘iminā tvaṁ, ambho purisa, dhanena attanā ca jīvāhi, mātāpitaro ca posehi, puttadārañca posehi, kammante ca payojehi, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhāpehi sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘With this money, mister, keep yourself alive, and provide for your mother and father, partners and children. Work for a living, and establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied that man.

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho, bhikkhave, manussā:
translation-en-sujato: People heard about this:
reference: bj9.112, cck11.74, csp1ed8.56, csp2ed8.56, dr11.73, ms8D_204, msdiv92, pts-cs12, pts-vp-pli3.67, sc22, sya11.73, vri3.49

root-pli-ms: ‘ye kira, bho, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, tesaṁ rājā dhanamanuppadetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It seems the king is paying money to anyone who steals from others!’

root-pli-ms: Sutvāna tesaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: It occurred to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūna mayampi paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why don’t we steal from others?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: So then another man stole something from others.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They arrested him

root-pli-ms: Gahetvā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa dassesuṁ:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The king said to that person,

root-pli-ms: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is it really true, mister, that you stole from others?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Saccaṁ, devā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s true, sire.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Kiṁ kāraṇā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What was the reason?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi, deva, jīvāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sire, I can’t survive.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the king thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘sace kho ahaṁ yo yo paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyissati, tassa tassa dhanamanuppadassāmi, evamidaṁ adinnādānaṁ pavaḍḍhissati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘If I pay money to anyone who steals from others, it will only increase the stealing.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ purisaṁ sunisedhaṁ nisedheyyaṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ kareyyaṁ, sīsamassa chindeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: I’d better make an end of this person, finish him off, and chop off his head.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto purise āṇāpesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then he ordered his men,

root-pli-ms: ‘tena hi, bhaṇe, imaṁ purisaṁ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sunisedhaṁ nisedhetha, mūlaghaccaṁ karotha, sīsamassa chindathā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Well then, my men, tie this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope. Shave his head and march him from street to street and square to square to the beating of a harsh drum. Then take him out the south gate and make an end of him, finish him off, and chop off his head.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, te purisā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṁ gāḷhabandhanaṁ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṁ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṁ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṁ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhamitvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sunisedhaṁ nisedhesuṁ, mūlaghaccaṁ akaṁsu, sīsamassa chindiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ they replied, and did as he commanded.

root-pli-ms: Assosuṁ kho, bhikkhave, manussā:
translation-en-sujato: People heard about this:
reference: cck11.75, ms8D_205, msdiv93, ndp8.54, pts-cs13, pts-vp-pli3.68, sc23

root-pli-ms: ‘ye kira, bho, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, te rājā sunisedhaṁ nisedheti, mūlaghaccaṁ karoti, sīsāni tesaṁ chindatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It seems the king is chopping the head off anyone who steals from others!’

root-pli-ms: Sutvāna tesaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: It occurred to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘yannūna mayampi tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpessāma, tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā yesaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyissāma, te sunisedhaṁ nisedhessāma, mūlaghaccaṁ karissāma, sīsāni tesaṁ chindissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We’d better have sharp swords made. Then when we steal from others, we’ll make an end of them, finish them off, and chop off their heads.’

root-pli-ms: Te tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpesuṁ, tiṇhāni satthāni kārāpetvā gāmaghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, nigamaghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, nagaraghātampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ, panthaduhanampi upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They had sharp swords made. Then they started to make raids on villages, towns, and cities, and to infest the highways.

root-pli-ms: Yesaṁ te adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyanti, te sunisedhaṁ nisedhenti, mūlaghaccaṁ karonti, sīsāni tesaṁ chindanti.
translation-en-sujato: And they chopped the heads off anyone they stole from.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi, dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi, satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, mendicants, from not paying money to the penniless, poverty became widespread. When poverty was widespread, theft became widespread. When theft was widespread, swords became widespread. When swords were widespread, killing living creatures became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom killing was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
reference: dr11.74, ms8D_206, msdiv94, pts-cs14, sc24, sya11.74

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ asītivassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people lived for 80,000 years, but their children lived for 40,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Cattārīsavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 40,000 years, a certain person stole something from others.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They arrested him

root-pli-ms: Gahetvā rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa dassesuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: and presented him to the king, saying,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Your Majesty, this person stole from others.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ vutte, bhikkhave, rājā khattiyo muddhābhisitto taṁ purisaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The king said to that person,

root-pli-ms: ‘saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, ambho purisa, paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is it really true, mister, that you stole from others?’

root-pli-ms: ‘Na hi, devā’ti sampajānamusā abhāsi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘No, sire,’ he said, deliberately lying.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate musāvādo vepullamagamāsi, musāvāde vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, mendicants, from not paying money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, and killing became widespread. When killing was widespread, lying became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom lying was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
reference: csp1ed8.57, csp2ed8.57, dr11.75, ms8D_208, msdiv95, pts-cs15, pts-vp-pli3.69, sc26

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ cattārīsavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsativassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 40,000 years had children who lived for 20,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Vīsativassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu aññataro puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyi.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 20,000 years, a certain person stole something from others.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aññataro puriso rañño khattiyassa muddhābhisittassa ārocesi:
translation-en-sujato: Someone else reported this to the king,

root-pli-ms: ‘itthannāmo, deva, puriso paresaṁ adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyī’ti pesuññamakāsi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Your Majesty, such-and-such person stole from others,’ he said, going behind his back.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi, adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi, satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi, pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate musāvādo vepullamagamāsi, musāvāde vepullaṁ gate pisuṇā vācā vepullamagamāsi, pisuṇāya vācāya vepullaṁ gatāya tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, mendicants, from not paying money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, killing, and lying became widespread. When lying was widespread, backbiting became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom backbiting was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ vīsativassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ dasavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 20,000 years had children who lived for 10,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Dasavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ekidaṁ sattā vaṇṇavanto honti, ekidaṁ sattā dubbaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 10,000 years, some were more beautiful than others.

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye te sattā dubbaṇṇā, te vaṇṇavante satte abhijjhāyantā paresaṁ dāresu cārittaṁ āpajjiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And the ugly beings, coveting the beautiful ones, committed adultery with others’ wives.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi. Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate …pe… kāmesumicchācāro vepullamagamāsi, kāmesumicchācāre vepullaṁ gate tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, mendicants, from not paying money to the penniless, poverty, theft, swords, killing, lying, and backbiting became widespread. When backbiting was widespread, sexual misconduct became widespread. And for the sentient beings among whom sexual misconduct was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.
reference: csp1ed8.58, csp2ed8.58, ms8D_212, msdiv97, sc30, vri3.51

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ dasavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ pañcavassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 10,000 years had children who lived for 5,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Pañcavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu dve dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu—
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 5,000 years, two things became widespread:

root-pli-ms: pharusāvācā samphappalāpo ca.
translation-en-sujato: harsh speech and talking nonsense.

root-pli-ms: Dvīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: For the sentient beings among whom these two things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ pañcavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ appekacce aḍḍhateyyavassasahassāyukā, appekacce dvevassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 5,000 years had some children who lived for 2,500 years, while others lived for 2,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Aḍḍhateyyavassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu abhijjhābyāpādā vepullamagamaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 2,500 years, desire and ill will became widespread.

root-pli-ms: Abhijjhābyāpādesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: For the sentient beings among whom desire and ill will were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ aḍḍhateyyavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vassasahassāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 2,500 years had children who lived for 1,000 years.

root-pli-ms: Vassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu micchādiṭṭhi vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for 1,000 years, wrong view became widespread.

root-pli-ms: Micchādiṭṭhiyā vepullaṁ gatāya tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: For the sentient beings among whom wrong view was widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ vassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ pañcavassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for 1,000 years had children who lived for five hundred years.

root-pli-ms: Pañcavassasatāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tayo dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu—
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for five hundred years, three things became widespread:

root-pli-ms: adhammarāgo visamalobho micchādhammo.
translation-en-sujato: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong thoughts.

root-pli-ms: Tīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: For the sentient beings among whom these three things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ pañcavassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ appekacce aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukā, appekacce dvevassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for five hundred years had some children who lived for two hundred and fifty years, while others lived for two hundred years.

root-pli-ms: Aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ime dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who lived for two hundred and fifty years, three things became widespread:

root-pli-ms: Amatteyyatā apetteyyatā asāmaññatā abrahmaññatā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitā.
translation-en-sujato: lack of due respect for mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and failure to honor the elders in the family.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, bhikkhave, adhanānaṁ dhane ananuppadiyamāne dāliddiyaṁ vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: And so, mendicants, from not paying money to the penniless, all these things became widespread—poverty,

root-pli-ms: Dāliddiye vepullaṁ gate adinnādānaṁ vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: theft,

root-pli-ms: Adinnādāne vepullaṁ gate satthaṁ vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: swords,

root-pli-ms: Satthe vepullaṁ gate pāṇātipāto vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: killing,

root-pli-ms: Pāṇātipāte vepullaṁ gate musāvādo vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: lying,

root-pli-ms: Musāvāde vepullaṁ gate pisuṇā vācā vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: backbiting,

root-pli-ms: Pisuṇāya vācāya vepullaṁ gatāya kāmesumicchācāro vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: sexual misconduct,

root-pli-ms: Kāmesumicchācāre vepullaṁ gate dve dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, pharusā vācā samphappalāpo ca.
translation-en-sujato: harsh speech and talking nonsense,

root-pli-ms: Dvīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu abhijjhābyāpādā vepullamagamaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: desire and ill will,

root-pli-ms: Abhijjhābyāpādesu vepullaṁ gatesu micchādiṭṭhi vepullamagamāsi.
translation-en-sujato: wrong view,

root-pli-ms: Micchādiṭṭhiyā vepullaṁ gatāya tayo dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, adhammarāgo visamalobho micchādhammo.
translation-en-sujato: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong thoughts,

root-pli-ms: Tīsu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu ime dhammā vepullamagamaṁsu, amatteyyatā apetteyyatā asāmaññatā abrahmaññatā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitā.
translation-en-sujato: and lack of due respect for mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and failure to honor the elders in the family.

root-pli-ms: Imesu dhammesu vepullaṁ gatesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ āyupi parihāyi, vaṇṇopi parihāyi.
translation-en-sujato: For the sentient beings among whom these things were widespread, their lifespan and beauty declined.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi parihāyamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi parihāyamānānaṁ aḍḍhateyyavassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vassasatāyukā puttā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who lived for two hundred and fifty years had children who lived for a hundred years.

root-pli-ms: 5. Dasavassāyukasamaya
translation-en-sujato: 5. When People Live for Ten Years

root-pli-ms: Bhavissati, bhikkhave, so samayo, yaṁ imesaṁ manussānaṁ dasavassāyukā puttā bhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: There will come a time, mendicants, when these people will have children who live for ten years.
reference: dr11.78, ms8D_219, msdiv103, ndp8.57, pts-cs19, sc37, sya11.78

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu pañcavassikā kumārikā alaṁpateyyā bhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who live for ten years, girls will be marriageable at five.

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu imāni rasāni antaradhāyissanti, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: The following flavors will disappear:

root-pli-ms: sappi navanītaṁ telaṁ madhu phāṇitaṁ loṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ghee, butter, oil, honey, molasses, and salt.

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu kudrūsako aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ bhavissati.
translation-en-sujato: The best kind of food will be finger millet,
comment-en-sujato: Horner has “rye” for kudrūsaka, but rye is a European grain. Finger millet is a widespread secondary grain in India, which grows in places rice cannot. While in Sri Lanka I learned that it is grown in the South, where it is too hot and dry for rice. But with the influence of climate change, rice will soon be unviable and finger millet, or kurukkan, will become essential. When I learned of this I was immediately reminded of this passage. I have no idea whether the word kurukkan is related to kudrusaka, but some of the other Indic terms for this grain seem to be, eg. the Pahari term “kodra”, Garhwal “koda”.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, etarahi sālimaṁsodano aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: just as fine rice with meat is the best kind of food today.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu kudrūsako aggaṁ bhojanānaṁ bhavissati.
Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu dasa kusalakammapathā sabbena sabbaṁ antaradhāyissanti, dasa akusalakammapathā atibyādippissanti.
translation-en-sujato: The ten ways of doing skillful deeds will totally disappear, and the ten ways of doing unskillful deeds will explode in popularity.
comment-en-sujato: Comm has “Atibyādippissantīti ativiya dippissanti, ayameva vā pāṭho” so its mainline version must have been Atibyādippissanti or similar. But this leaves unexplained the long ā in the sandhi. At the same time, the sense of dippati is not entirely clear here. RD has “flourish”, MW has “prevail”, but neither of these is really what it means. If anything, its basic meaning of “appear, show” contrasts more directly with antaradhayati. However, note that ādippati occurs, I think, once elsewhere in the canon, in AN 7.66, which by coincidence or not, also concerns a myth of the future. There it refers to an erupting volcano. Given that this explains the long ā, and that the unusual and emphatic form suggests a powerful meaning, I suggest that the sense “explode” (in popularity, etc.) fits here.
reference: cck11.80, csp1ed8.60, csp2ed8.60, ms8D_220, pts-vp-pli3.72, sc38

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu kusalantipi na bhavissati, kuto pana kusalassa kārako.
translation-en-sujato: Those people will not even have the word ‘skillful’, still less anyone who does what is skillful.

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ye te bhavissanti amatteyyā apetteyyā asāmaññā abrahmaññā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, te pujjā ca bhavissanti pāsaṁsā ca.
translation-en-sujato: And anyone who disrespects mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, and fails to honor the elders in the family will be venerated and praised,

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, etarahi matteyyā petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino pujjā ca pāsaṁsā ca;
translation-en-sujato: just as the opposite is venerated and praised today.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu ye te bhavissanti amatteyyā apetteyyā asāmaññā abrahmaññā na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, te pujjā ca bhavissanti pāsaṁsā ca.
Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu na bhavissati mātāti vā mātucchāti vā mātulānīti vā ācariyabhariyāti vā garūnaṁ dārāti vā.
translation-en-sujato: There’ll be no recognition of the status of mother, aunts, or wives and partners of teachers and respected people.
comment-en-sujato: See AN 2.9.

root-pli-ms: Sambhedaṁ loko gamissati yathā ajeḷakā kukkuṭasūkarā soṇasiṅgālā.
translation-en-sujato: The world will become promiscuous, like goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and dogs and jackals.
comment-en-sujato: For sambheda, see AN 2.9=DN 26, AN 5.103 = AN 10.45, and DN 3. In each case the sense is not “breaking, destroying” as you might expect, but the dissolving of boundaries, resulting in promiscuity or leaking of secrets. Comm. to DN 26 has “Sambhedanti missībhāvaṁ, mariyādabhedaṁ vā.”

root-pli-ms: Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ aññamaññamhi tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They’ll be full of hostility towards each other, with acute ill will, malevolence, and thoughts of murder.

root-pli-ms: Mātupi puttamhi puttassapi mātari;
translation-en-sujato: Even a mother will feel like this for her child, and the child for its mother,

root-pli-ms: pitupi puttamhi puttassapi pitari;
translation-en-sujato: father for child, child for father,

root-pli-ms: bhātupi bhaginiyā bhaginiyāpi bhātari tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: brother for sister, and sister for brother.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, māgavikassa migaṁ disvā tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito hoti tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They’ll be just like a deer hunter when he sees a deer—full of hostility, ill will, malevolence, and thoughts of killing.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, dasavassāyukesu manussesu tesaṁ sattānaṁ aññamaññamhi tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
Mātupi puttamhi puttassapi mātari;
pitupi puttamhi puttassapi pitari;
bhātupi bhaginiyā bhaginiyāpi bhātari tibbo āghāto paccupaṭṭhito bhavissati tibbo byāpādo tibbo manopadoso tibbaṁ vadhakacittaṁ.
Dasavassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu sattāhaṁ satthantarakappo bhavissati.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who live for ten years, there will be an interregnum of swords lasting seven days.
reference: csp1ed8.61, csp2ed8.61, ms8D_223, msdiv104, pts-cs21, sc41, sya11.80

root-pli-ms: Te aññamaññamhi migasaññaṁ paṭilabhissanti.
translation-en-sujato: During that time they will see each other as beasts.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ tiṇhāni satthāni hatthesu pātubhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Sharp swords will appear in their hands,

root-pli-ms: Te tiṇhena satthena ‘esa migo esa migo’ti aññamaññaṁ jīvitā voropessanti.
translation-en-sujato: with which they’ll take each other’s life, crying, ‘It’s a beast! It’s a beast!’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ ekaccānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
translation-en-sujato: But then some of those beings will think,

root-pli-ms: ‘mā ca mayaṁ kañci, mā ca amhe koci, yannūna mayaṁ tiṇagahanaṁ vā vanagahanaṁ vā rukkhagahanaṁ vā nadīviduggaṁ vā pabbatavisamaṁ vā pavisitvā vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Let us neither be perpetrators nor victims! Why don’t we hide in thick grass, thick jungle, thick trees, inaccessible riverlands, or rugged mountains and survive on forest roots and fruits?’
variant-pli-ms: tiṇagahanaṁ → … gahaṇaṁ (bj, sya-all) | kañci → kiñci (mr) | te tiṇagahanaṁ vā vanagahanaṁ vā vā rukkhagahanaṁ vā nadīviduggaṁ vā pabbatavisamaṁ vā → te tiṇagahanaṁ vanagahanaṁ rukkhagahanaṁ nadīviduggaṁ pabbatavisamaṁ (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Te tiṇagahanaṁ vā vanagahanaṁ vā rukkhagahanaṁ vā nadīviduggaṁ vā pabbatavisamaṁ vā pavisitvā sattāhaṁ vanamūlaphalāhārā yāpessanti.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they do.

root-pli-ms: Te tassa sattāhassa accayena tiṇagahanā vanagahanā rukkhagahanā nadīviduggā pabbatavisamā nikkhamitvā aññamaññaṁ āliṅgitvā sabhāgāyissanti samassāsissanti:
translation-en-sujato: When those seven days have passed, having emerged from their hiding places and embraced each other, they will come together in one voice and cry,
comment-en-sujato: According to Cone (gāyati), sabhāgāyissanti is correct and PTS sabhā gāyissanti incorrect. Sabhāgāyissanti = sabhāga + āyissanti = will come together. samassāsissanti = sama + sāsati is absent from some manuscripts and is not commented on; I think it’s dubious.

root-pli-ms: ‘diṭṭhā, bho, sattā jīvasi, diṭṭhā, bho, sattā jīvasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘How fantastic, dear being, you live! How fantastic, dear being, you live!’
comment-en-sujato: Diṭṭhā here probably doesn’t mean “seen, but” hurrah!'The plural for satt-a is puzzling; one var in PTS edition has the second as satta = voc sing, which I take as correct. Otherwise we would expect bhonto sattā, but this disagrees with the verb.

root-pli-ms: 6. Āyuvaṇṇādivaḍḍhanakathā
translation-en-sujato: 6. The Period of Growth

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings will think,
reference: bj9.122, ms8D_225, msdiv105, pts-vp-pli3.74, sc43, vri3.54

root-pli-ms: ‘mayaṁ kho akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu evarūpaṁ āyataṁ ñātikkhayaṁ pattā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘It’s because we undertook unskillful things that we suffered such an extensive loss of our relatives.

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ kusalaṁ kareyyāma.
translation-en-sujato: We’d better do what’s skillful.

root-pli-ms: Kiṁ kusalaṁ kareyyāma?
translation-en-sujato: What skillful thing should we do?

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ pāṇātipātā virameyyāma, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vatteyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we refrain from killing living creatures? Having undertaken this skillful thing we’ll live by it.’

root-pli-ms: Te pāṇātipātā viramissanti, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vattissanti.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they do.

root-pli-ms: Te kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhissanti, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Because of undertaking this skillful thing, their lifespan and beauty will grow.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ dasavassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsativassāyukā puttā bhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Those people who live for ten years will have children who live for twenty years.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ bhavissati:
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings will think,

root-pli-ms: ‘mayaṁ kho kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhāma, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhāma.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Because of undertaking this skillful thing, our lifespan and beauty are growing.

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ bhiyyoso mattāya kusalaṁ kareyyāma.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we do even more skillful things?

root-pli-ms: Kiṁ kusalaṁ kareyyāma?
translation-en-sujato: What skillful thing should we do?

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ adinnādānā virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we refrain from stealing …

root-pli-ms: kāmesumicchācārā virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: sexual misconduct …

root-pli-ms: musāvādā virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: lying …

root-pli-ms: pisuṇāya vācāya virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: backbiting …

root-pli-ms: pharusāya vācāya virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: harsh speech …

root-pli-ms: samphappalāpā virameyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: and talking nonsense.

root-pli-ms: abhijjhaṁ pajaheyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we give up covetousness …

root-pli-ms: byāpādaṁ pajaheyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: ill will …

root-pli-ms: micchādiṭṭhiṁ pajaheyyāma …
translation-en-sujato: wrong view …

root-pli-ms: tayo dhamme pajaheyyāma—
translation-en-sujato: three things:
