root-pli-ms: adhammarāgaṁ visamalobhaṁ micchādhammaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: illicit desire, immoral greed, and wrong thoughts.

root-pli-ms: yannūna mayaṁ matteyyā assāma petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vatteyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we pay due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in our families? Having undertaken this skillful thing we’ll live by it.’

root-pli-ms: Te matteyyā bhavissanti petteyyā sāmaññā brahmaññā kule jeṭṭhāpacāyino, idaṁ kusalaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya vattissanti.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they do.

root-pli-ms: Te kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ samādānahetu āyunāpi vaḍḍhissanti, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Because of undertaking this skillful thing, their lifespan and beauty will grow.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ āyunāpi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhamānānaṁ vīsativassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsavassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: Those people who live for twenty years will have children who live for forty years.

root-pli-ms: cattārīsavassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ asītivassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: Those people who live for forty years will have children who live for eighty years,

root-pli-ms: asītivassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ saṭṭhivassasatāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: then a hundred and sixty years,

root-pli-ms: saṭṭhivassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsatitivassasatāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: three hundred and twenty years,

root-pli-ms: vīsatitivassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsachabbassasatāyukā puttā bhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: six hundred and forty years,

root-pli-ms: Cattārīsachabbassasatāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ dvevassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: 2,000 years,

root-pli-ms: dvevassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārivassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: 4,000 years,

root-pli-ms: cattārivassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ aṭṭhavassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: 8,000 years,

root-pli-ms: aṭṭhavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ vīsativassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: 20,000 years,

root-pli-ms: vīsativassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ cattārīsavassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: 40,000 years,

root-pli-ms: cattārīsavassasahassāyukānaṁ manussānaṁ asītivassasahassāyukā puttā bhavissanti …
translation-en-sujato: and finally 80,000 years.

root-pli-ms: asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu pañcavassasatikā kumārikā alaṁpateyyā bhavissanti.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who live for 80,000 years, girls will be marriageable at five hundred.

root-pli-ms: 7. Saṅkharājauppatti
translation-en-sujato: 7. The Time of King Saṅkha

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu tayo ābādhā bhavissanti, icchā, anasanaṁ, jarā.
translation-en-sujato: Among the people who live for 80,000 years, there will be just three afflictions: greed, starvation, and old age.

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ jambudīpo iddho ceva bhavissati phīto ca, kukkuṭasampātikā gāmanigamarājadhāniyo.
translation-en-sujato: India will be successful and prosperous. The villages, towns, and capital cities will be no more than a chicken’s flight apart.

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ jambudīpo avīci maññe phuṭo bhavissati manussehi, seyyathāpi naḷavanaṁ vā saravanaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: And the land will be as crowded as hell, just full of people, like a thicket of rushes or reeds.

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ayaṁ bārāṇasī ketumatī nāma rājadhānī bhavissati iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
translation-en-sujato: The royal capital will be our Benares, but renamed Ketumati. And it will be successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu imasmiṁ jambudīpe caturāsītinagarasahassāni bhavissanti ketumatīrājadhānīpamukhāni.
translation-en-sujato: There will be 84,000 cities in India, with the royal capital of Ketumati foremost.

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu ketumatiyā rājadhāniyā saṅkho nāma rājā uppajjissati cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: And in the royal capital of Ketumati a king named Saṅkha will arise, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion will extend to all four sides, he will achieve stability in the country, and possess the seven treasures.

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavissanti, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: He will have the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavissanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He will have over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasissati.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea, he will reign by principle, without rod or sword.

root-pli-ms: 8. Metteyyabuddhuppāda
translation-en-sujato: 8. The Arising of the Buddha Metteyya

root-pli-ms: Asītivassasahassāyukesu, bhikkhave, manussesu metteyyo nāma bhagavā loke uppajjissati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: And the Blessed One named Metteyya will arise in the world—perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed—
reference: cck11.85, ms8D_229, msdiv107, pts-cs25, pts-vp-pli3.76, sc47, sya11.84, vri3.56

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpāhametarahi loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: just as I have arisen today.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedessati, seyyathāpāhametarahi imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedemi.
translation-en-sujato: He will realize with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and make it known to others, just as I do today.

root-pli-ms: So dhammaṁ desessati ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāsessati;
translation-en-sujato: He will teach the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he will reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure,

root-pli-ms: seyyathāpāhametarahi dhammaṁ desemi ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāsemi.
translation-en-sujato: just as I do today.

root-pli-ms: So anekasahassaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pariharissati, seyyathāpāhametarahi anekasataṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pariharāmi.
translation-en-sujato: He will look after a Saṅgha of many thousand mendicants, just as I look after a Saṅgha of many hundreds today.
comment-en-sujato: Interesting choice of verb here: pariharati is not lead or command, but nurture, like a mother the child in her womb.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, bhikkhave, saṅkho nāma rājā yo so yūpo raññā mahāpanādena kārāpito.
translation-en-sujato: Then King Saṅkha will have the sacrificial post that had been built by King Mahāpanāda raised up.
comment-en-sujato: This oddity is found in Bhaddaji’s verses at Thag 2.22 and the full story at Ja 264. While the Comm. stories, followed by RD and MW, say this is a palace, the verses there clearly depict a sacrificial post, yūpa. Probably the original meaning of this reference was lost early on, and the story filled in.
reference: bj9.132, cck11.86, csp1ed8.64, csp2ed8.64, dr11.84, ms8D_230, msdiv108, ndp8.61, pts-cs26, pts-vp-pli3.77, sc48

root-pli-ms: Taṁ yūpaṁ ussāpetvā ajjhāvasitvā taṁ datvā vissajjitvā samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṁ dānaṁ datvā metteyyassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati.
translation-en-sujato: After staying there, he will give it away to ascetics and brahmins, paupers, vagrants, travelers, and beggars. Then, having shaved off his hair and beard and dressed in ocher robes, he will go forth from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha Metteyya’s presence.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati.
translation-en-sujato: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, he will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He will live having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: Attadīpā, bhikkhave, viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Mendicants, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant do this?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Vedanāsu vedanānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

root-pli-ms: citte cittānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: mind …

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how they let the teaching be their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

root-pli-ms: 9. Bhikkhunoāyuvaṇṇādivaḍḍhanakathā
translation-en-sujato: 9. On Long Life and Beauty for Mendicants

root-pli-ms: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
translation-en-sujato: Mendicants, you should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

root-pli-ms: Gocare, bhikkhave, carantā sake pettike visaye āyunāpi vaḍḍhissatha, vaṇṇenapi vaḍḍhissatha, sukhenapi vaḍḍhissatha, bhogenapi vaḍḍhissatha, balenapi vaḍḍhissatha.
translation-en-sujato: Doing so, you will grow in life span, beauty, happiness, wealth, and power.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno āyusmiṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is long life for a mendicant?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti,
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: vīriyasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti,
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: cittasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti,
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: vīmaṁsāsamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṁ iddhipādaṁ bhāveti.
translation-en-sujato: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

root-pli-ms: So imesaṁ catunnaṁ iddhipādānaṁ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā ākaṅkhamāno kappaṁ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: Having developed and cultivated these four bases of psychic power they may, if they wish, live on for the eon or what’s left of the eon.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno āyusmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is long life for a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno vaṇṇasmiṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is beauty for a mendicant?
reference: bj9.134, csp1ed8.65, csp2ed8.65, ms8D_234, ndp8.62, pts-vp-pli3.78, sc52

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno vaṇṇasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is beauty for a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sukhasmiṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is happiness for a mendicant?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …

root-pli-ms: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: third absorption …

root-pli-ms: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: fourth absorption.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno, sukhasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is happiness for a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhogasmiṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is wealth for a mendicant?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a monk meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

root-pli-ms: muditāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: rejoicing …

root-pli-ms: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṁ. Tathā tatiyaṁ. Tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
translation-en-sujato: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhogasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is wealth for a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno balasmiṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is power for a mendicant?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno balasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is power for a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Nāhaṁ, bhikkhave, aññaṁ ekabalampi samanupassāmi yaṁ evaṁ duppasahaṁ, yathayidaṁ, bhikkhave, mārabalaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Mendicants, I do not see a single power so hard to defeat as the power of Māra.

root-pli-ms: Kusalānaṁ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṁ samādānahetu evamidaṁ puññaṁ pavaḍḍhatī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: It is due to undertaking skillful qualities that this merit grows.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Cakkavattisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ tatiyaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 27
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 27

root-pli-ms: Aggaññasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Origin of the World

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.
reference: bj9.136, cck11.89, csp1ed8.66, csp2ed8.66, dr11.87, ms8D_241, msdiv111, ndp8.63, pts-cs1, pts-vp-pli3.80, sc1, sya11.87, vri3.59

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā bhikkhūsu parivasanti bhikkhubhāvaṁ ākaṅkhamānā.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were living on probation among the mendicants in hopes of being ordained.
comment-en-sujato: Note that paravasati is the normal term for those of other sects who spend probation before ordaining. This is a rare case featuring men who are actually undergoing such probation. Note that RD gets this right, MW does not.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito pāsādā orohitvā pāsādapacchāyāyaṁ abbhokāse caṅkamati.
translation-en-sujato: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came downstairs from the longhouse and was walking mindfully in the open air, beneath the shade of the longhouse.

root-pli-ms: Addasā kho vāseṭṭho bhagavantaṁ sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaṁ pāsādā orohitvā pāsādapacchāyāyaṁ abbhokāse caṅkamantaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Vāseṭṭha saw him

root-pli-ms: Disvāna bhāradvājaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: and said to Bhāradvāja,

root-pli-ms: “ayaṁ, āvuso bhāradvāja, bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito pāsādā orohitvā pāsādapacchāyāyaṁ abbhokāse caṅkamati.
translation-en-sujato: “Reverend Bhāradvāja, the Buddha is walking mindfully in the open air, beneath the shade of the longhouse.

root-pli-ms: Āyāmāvuso bhāradvāja, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma;
translation-en-sujato: Come, reverend, let’s go to the Buddha.

root-pli-ms: appeva nāma labheyyāma bhagavato santikā dhammiṁ kathaṁ savanāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: Hopefully we’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from him.”

root-pli-ms: “Evamāvuso”ti kho bhāradvājo vāseṭṭhassa paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, reverend,” replied Bhāradvāja.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā bhagavantaṁ caṅkamantaṁ anucaṅkamiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: So they went to the Buddha, bowed, and walked beside him.
reference: bj9.138, cck11.90, csp1ed8.67, csp2ed8.67, dr11.88, ms8D_243, msdiv113, ndp8.64, pts-vp-pli3.81, sc3, sya11.88, vri3.60

root-pli-ms: Atha kho bhagavā vāseṭṭhaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then the Buddha said to Vāseṭṭha,

root-pli-ms: “tumhe khvattha, vāseṭṭha, brāhmaṇajaccā brāhmaṇakulīnā brāhmaṇakulā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, kacci vo, vāseṭṭha, brāhmaṇā na akkosanti na paribhāsantī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Vāseṭṭha, you are both brahmins by birth and clan, and have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness from a brahmin family. I hope you don’t have to suffer abuse and insults from the brahmins.”

root-pli-ms: “Taggha no, bhante, brāhmaṇā akkosanti paribhāsanti attarūpāya paribhāsāya paripuṇṇāya, no aparipuṇṇāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Actually, sir, the brahmins do insult and abuse us with their typical insults to the fullest extent.”

root-pli-ms: “Yathā kathaṁ pana vo, vāseṭṭha, brāhmaṇā akkosanti paribhāsanti attarūpāya paribhāsāya paripuṇṇāya, no aparipuṇṇāyā”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But how do the brahmins insult you?”

root-pli-ms: “Brāhmaṇā, bhante, evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: “Sir, the brahmins say:

root-pli-ms: ‘brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo, hīnā aññe vaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior.

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇova sukko vaṇṇo, kaṇhā aññe vaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark.

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇāva sujjhanti, no abrāhmaṇā.
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are purified, not others.

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇāva brahmuno puttā orasā mukhato jātā brahmajā brahmanimmitā brahmadāyādā.
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.

root-pli-ms: Te tumhe seṭṭhaṁ vaṇṇaṁ hitvā hīnamattha vaṇṇaṁ ajjhupagatā, yadidaṁ muṇḍake samaṇake ibbhe kaṇhe bandhupādāpacce.
translation-en-sujato: You’ve both abandoned the best caste to join an inferior caste, namely these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman.

root-pli-ms: Tayidaṁ na sādhu, tayidaṁ nappatirūpaṁ, yaṁ tumhe seṭṭhaṁ vaṇṇaṁ hitvā hīnamattha vaṇṇaṁ ajjhupagatā yadidaṁ muṇḍake samaṇake ibbhe kaṇhe bandhupādāpacce’ti.
translation-en-sujato: This is not right, it’s not proper!’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho no, bhante, brāhmaṇā akkosanti paribhāsanti attarūpāya paribhāsāya paripuṇṇāya, no aparipuṇṇāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how the brahmins insult us.”

root-pli-ms: “Taggha vo, vāseṭṭha, brāhmaṇā porāṇaṁ assarantā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: “Actually, Vāseṭṭha, the brahmins are forgetting their tradition when they say this to you.
reference: cck11.91, dr11.89, ms8D_244, msdiv114, pts-cs4, pts-vp-pli3.82, sc4, sya11.89

root-pli-ms: ‘brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo, hīnā aññe vaṇṇā;
brāhmaṇova sukko vaṇṇo, kaṇhā aññe vaṇṇā;
brāhmaṇāva sujjhanti, no abrāhmaṇā;
brāhmaṇāva brahmuno puttā orasā mukhato jātā brahmajā brahmanimmitā brahmadāyādā’ti.
Dissanti kho pana, vāseṭṭha, brāhmaṇānaṁ brāhmaṇiyo utuniyopi gabbhiniyopi vijāyamānāpi pāyamānāpi.
translation-en-sujato: For brahmin women are seen menstruating, being pregnant, giving birth, and breast-feeding.

root-pli-ms: Te ca brāhmaṇā yonijāva samānā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Yet even though they’re born from a brahmin womb they say:

root-pli-ms: ‘brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo, hīnā aññe vaṇṇā;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇova sukko vaṇṇo, kaṇhā aññe vaṇṇā;
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇāva sujjhanti, no abrāhmaṇā;
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are purified, not others.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇāva brahmuno puttā orasā mukhato jātā brahmajā brahmanimmitā brahmadāyādā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.’

root-pli-ms: Te brahmānañceva abbhācikkhanti, musā ca bhāsanti, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavanti.
translation-en-sujato: They misrepresent the brahmins, speak falsely, and make much bad karma.

root-pli-ms: 1. Catuvaṇṇasuddhi
translation-en-sujato: 1. Purification in the Four Castes

root-pli-ms: Cattārome, vāseṭṭha, vaṇṇā—
translation-en-sujato: Vāseṭṭha, there are these four castes:
reference: csp1ed8.68, csp2ed8.68, ms8D_245, msdiv115, pts-cs5, sc5

root-pli-ms: khattiyā, brāhmaṇā, vessā, suddā.
translation-en-sujato: aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers.

root-pli-ms: Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, idhekacco pāṇātipātī hoti adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavāco pharusavāco samphappalāpī abhijjhālu byāpannacitto micchādiṭṭhī.
translation-en-sujato: Some aristocrats kill living creatures, steal, and commit sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, yeme dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā naalamariyā naalamariyasaṅkhātā kaṇhā kaṇhavipākā viññugarahitā, khattiyepi te idhekacce sandissanti.
translation-en-sujato: These things are unskillful, blameworthy, not to be cultivated, unworthy of the noble ones—and are reckoned as such. They are dark deeds with dark results, criticized by sensible people. Such things are seen in some aristocrats.

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And they are also seen among some brahmins,

root-pli-ms: vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
translation-en-sujato: merchants,

root-pli-ms: suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha, idhekacco pāṇātipātī hoti adinnādāyī kāmesumicchācārī musāvādī pisuṇavāco pharusavāco samphappalāpī abhijjhālu byāpannacitto micchādiṭṭhī.
translation-en-sujato: and workers.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, yeme dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā …pe…
kaṇhā kaṇhavipākā viññugarahitā;
suddepi te idhekacce sandissanti.

Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, idhekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato, musāvādā paṭivirato, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato, samphappalāpā paṭivirato, anabhijjhālu abyāpannacitto, sammādiṭṭhī.
translation-en-sujato: But some aristocrats refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct. They refrain from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. And they’re content, kind-hearted, with right view.
reference: bj9.140, cck11.92, dr11.90, ms8D_246, ndp8.65, pts-cs6, pts-vp-pli3.83, sc6, sya11.90, vri3.61

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, yeme dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā sukkā sukkavipākā viññuppasatthā, khattiyepi te idhekacce sandissanti.
translation-en-sujato: These things are skillful, blameless, to be cultivated, worthy of the noble ones—and are reckoned as such. They are bright deeds with bright results, praised by sensible people. Such things are seen in some aristocrats.

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And they are also seen among some brahmins,

root-pli-ms: vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
translation-en-sujato: merchants,

root-pli-ms: suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha, idhekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: and workers.

root-pli-ms: anabhijjhālu, abyāpannacitto, sammādiṭṭhī.
Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, yeme dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā sukkā sukkavipākā viññuppasatthā;
suddepi te idhekacce sandissanti.
Imesu kho, vāseṭṭha, catūsu vaṇṇesu evaṁ ubhayavokiṇṇesu vattamānesu kaṇhasukkesu dhammesu viññugarahitesu ceva viññuppasatthesu ca yadettha brāhmaṇā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Both these things occur like this, mixed up in these four castes—the dark and the bright, that which is praised and that which is criticized by sensible people. Yet of this the brahmins say:
reference: cck11.93, ms8D_247, msdiv116, pts-cs7, sc7, sya11.91

root-pli-ms: ‘brāhmaṇova seṭṭho vaṇṇo, hīnā aññe vaṇṇā;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Only brahmins are the highest caste; other castes are inferior.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇova sukko vaṇṇo, kaṇhā aññe vaṇṇā;
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are the light caste; other castes are dark.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇāva sujjhanti, no abrāhmaṇā;
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are purified, not others.

root-pli-ms: brāhmaṇāva brahmuno puttā orasā mukhato jātā brahmajā brahmanimmitā brahmadāyādā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Only brahmins are Brahmā’s rightful sons, born of his mouth, born of Brahmā, created by Brahmā, heirs of Brahmā.’

root-pli-ms: Taṁ tesaṁ viññū nānujānanti.
translation-en-sujato: Sensible people don’t acknowledge this.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: Imesañhi, vāseṭṭha, catunnaṁ vaṇṇānaṁ yo hoti bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, so nesaṁ aggamakkhāyati dhammeneva, no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: Because any mendicant from these four castes who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—is said to be the best by virtue of principle, not without principle.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ, diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: Tadamināpetaṁ, vāseṭṭha, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā dhammova seṭṭho janetasmiṁ, diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: And here’s a way to understand how this is so.

root-pli-ms: Jānāti kho, vāseṭṭha, rājā pasenadi kosalo:
translation-en-sujato: King Pasenadi of Kosala knows that
reference: cck11.94, csp1ed8.69, csp2ed8.69, dr11.91, ms8D_249, ndp8.66, pts-cs8, pts-vp-pli3.84, sc9, vri3.62

root-pli-ms: ‘samaṇo gotamo anantarā sakyakulā pabbajito’ti.
translation-en-sujato: the ascetic Gotama has gone forth from the neighboring clan of the Sakyans.

root-pli-ms: Sakyā kho pana, vāseṭṭha, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa anuyuttā bhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: And the Sakyans are his vassals.
variant-pli-ms: kosalassa anuyuttā → anantarā anuyuttā (bj, mr); anantarā anuyantā (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: Karonti kho, vāseṭṭha, sakyā raññe pasenadimhi kosale nipaccakāraṁ abhivādanaṁ paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikammaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The Sakyans show deference to King Pasenadi by bowing down, rising up, greeting him with joined palms, and observing proper etiquette for him.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, yaṁ karonti sakyā raññe pasenadimhi kosale nipaccakāraṁ abhivādanaṁ paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikammaṁ, karoti taṁ rājā pasenadi kosalo tathāgate nipaccakāraṁ abhivādanaṁ paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikammaṁ, na naṁ ‘sujāto samaṇo gotamo, dujjātohamasmi.
translation-en-sujato: Now, King Pasenadi shows the same kind of deference to the Realized One. But he doesn’t think: ‘The ascetic Gotama is well-born, I am ill-born.
comment-en-sujato: MS na naṁ yields a better sense than PTS nanu, followed by RD and MW.

root-pli-ms: Balavā samaṇo gotamo, dubbalohamasmi.
translation-en-sujato: He is powerful, I am weak.

root-pli-ms: Pāsādiko samaṇo gotamo, dubbaṇṇohamasmi.
translation-en-sujato: He is handsome, I am ugly.

root-pli-ms: Mahesakkho samaṇo gotamo, appesakkhohamasmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: He is influential, I am insignificant.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho naṁ dhammaṁyeva sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno evaṁ rājā pasenadi kosalo tathāgate nipaccakāraṁ karoti, abhivādanaṁ paccuṭṭhānaṁ añjalikammaṁ sāmīcikammaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Rather, in showing such deference to the Realized One he is only honoring, respecting, and venerating principle.

root-pli-ms: Imināpi kho etaṁ, vāseṭṭha, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ, yathā dhammova seṭṭho janetasmiṁ, diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: And here’s another way to understand how principle is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: Tumhe khvattha, vāseṭṭha, nānājaccā nānānāmā nānāgottā nānākulā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā.
translation-en-sujato: Vāseṭṭha, you have different births, names, and clans, and have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness from different families.
reference: dr11.92, ms8D_250, msdiv118, pts-cs9, sc10, sya11.92

root-pli-ms: ‘Ke tumhe’ti—puṭṭhā samānā ‘samaṇā sakyaputtiyāmhā’ti—paṭijānātha.
translation-en-sujato: When they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics, followers of the Sakyan.

root-pli-ms: Yassa kho panassa, vāseṭṭha, tathāgate saddhā niviṭṭhā mūlajātā patiṭṭhitā daḷhā asaṁhāriyā samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ, tassetaṁ kallaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: But only when someone has faith in the Realized One—settled, rooted, and planted deep, strong, not to be shifted by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world—is it appropriate for them to say:

root-pli-ms: ‘bhagavatomhi putto oraso mukhato jāto dhammajo dhammanimmito dhammadāyādo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I am the Buddha’s true-born child, born from his mouth, born of principle, created by principle, heir to principle.’

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: Tathāgatassa hetaṁ, vāseṭṭha, adhivacanaṁ ‘dhammakāyo’ itipi, ‘brahmakāyo’ itipi, ‘dhammabhūto’ itipi, ‘brahmabhūto’ itipi.
translation-en-sujato: For these are terms for the Realized One: ‘the embodiment of truth’, and ‘the embodiment of holiness’, and ‘the one who has become the truth’, and ‘the one who has become holy’.

root-pli-ms: Hoti kho so, vāseṭṭha, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko saṁvaṭṭati.
translation-en-sujato: There comes a time when, Vāseṭṭha, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
reference: bj9.144, csp1ed8.70, csp2ed8.70, ms8D_251, msdiv119, pts-cs10, sc11

root-pli-ms: Saṁvaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarasaṁvattanikā honti.
translation-en-sujato: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.

root-pli-ms: Te tattha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
translation-en-sujato: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: Hoti kho so, vāseṭṭha, samayo yaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena ayaṁ loko vivaṭṭati.
translation-en-sujato: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.

root-pli-ms: Vivaṭṭamāne loke yebhuyyena sattā ābhassarakāyā cavitvā itthattaṁ āgacchanti.
translation-en-sujato: As the cosmos expands, sentient beings mostly pass away from that host of radiant deities and come back to this realm.

root-pli-ms: Tedha honti manomayā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti.
translation-en-sujato: Here they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: 2. Rasapathavipātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 2. Solid Nectar Appears

root-pli-ms: Ekodakībhūtaṁ kho pana, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena hoti andhakāro andhakāratimisā.
translation-en-sujato: But the single mass of water at that time was utterly dark.
reference: dr11.93, ms8D_253, msdiv120, ndp8.67, pts-cs11, sc13, sya11.93, vri3.63

root-pli-ms: Na candimasūriyā paññāyanti, na nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni paññāyanti, na rattindivā paññāyanti, na māsaḍḍhamāsā paññāyanti, na utusaṁvaccharā paññāyanti, na itthipumā paññāyanti, sattā sattātveva saṅkhyaṁ gacchanti.
translation-en-sujato: The moon and sun were not found, nor were stars and constellations, day and night, months and fortnights, years and seasons, or male and female. Beings were simply known as ‘beings’.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena rasapathavī udakasmiṁ samatani;
translation-en-sujato: After a very long period had passed, solid nectar curdled in the water.
comment-en-sujato: The reading and sense of samatani is obscure. RD and MW evidently derive it from samanta, in line with comm: “Samatanīti patiṭṭhahi samantato patthari”. This seems to assume an otherwise unattested verb form of samanta. However, I think it is more likely connected with santānaka in the next line, in the sense of “networks” or tendrils appearing in the water, a clear enough description of curdling. This is supported by the Sanskrit at SF 277, which has “saṁmūrcchitaḥ saṁtanoti tadyathā pakvasya kṣīrasya śaraḥ saṁmūrcchitaḥ saṁtanoty” Sammucchati, which is absent from the Pali, I think clarifies the meaning. It is also found at Mu-Kd 17. Rasapathavi is also obscure, and nowhere, i think, explained in comms. At SN 5.9 we have pathavirasa in the sense “nutriments in soil”. SF 277 and Mu-Kd 17 also have pṛthivīrasa, so we probably should take the exact form too literally. RD and MW translate “savoury earth” which is not satisfactory. The substance is clearly described, and it is not earth. And rasa more likely means “juice, nectar, essence”. Given the divine context, and the description, I believe this is related to the nectar of the gods, which I think was originally honey.

root-pli-ms: seyyathāpi nāma payaso tattassa nibbāyamānassa upari santānakaṁ hoti;
translation-en-sujato: It appeared just like the curd on top of hot milk as it cools.

root-pli-ms: evameva pāturahosi.
Sā ahosi vaṇṇasampannā gandhasampannā rasasampannā, seyyathāpi nāma sampannaṁ vā sappi sampannaṁ vā navanītaṁ evaṁvaṇṇā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: It was beautiful, fragrant, and delicious, like ghee or butter.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma khuddamadhuṁ aneḷakaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: And it was as sweet as pure manuka honey.
comment-en-sujato: Obviously this is not literally manuka, but it conveys a similar sense of a very flavorful and exotic honey.
variant-pli-ms: khuddamadhuṁ → khuddamadhu (bj, pts1ed); khuddaṁ madhuṁ (mr) | aneḷakaṁ → anelakaṁ (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: evamassādā ahosi.
Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññataro satto lolajātiko:
translation-en-sujato: Now, one of those beings was reckless.

root-pli-ms: ‘ambho, kimevidaṁ bhavissatī’ti rasapathaviṁ aṅguliyā sāyi.
translation-en-sujato: Thinking, ‘Oh my, what might this be?’ they tasted the solid nectar with their finger.

root-pli-ms: Tassa rasapathaviṁ aṅguliyā sāyato acchādesi, taṇhā cassa okkami.
translation-en-sujato: They enjoyed it, and craving was born in them.
comment-en-sujato: Read assādesi for acchadesi. RD has “became suffused”, following comm “Acchādesīti jivhagge ṭhapitamattā satta rasaharaṇīsahassāni pharitvā manāpā hutvā tiṭṭhati”. However Mu Kd 17 has āsvādayati, as does SF 277 albeit in reconstructed phrases only. This yields a more satisfactory sense, and I propose that an old misreading preceded the commentary.

root-pli-ms: Aññepi kho, vāseṭṭha, sattā tassa sattassa diṭṭhānugatiṁ āpajjamānā rasapathaviṁ aṅguliyā sāyiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And other beings, following that being’s example, tasted solid nectar with their fingers.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ rasapathaviṁ aṅguliyā sāyataṁ acchādesi, taṇhā ca tesaṁ okkami.
translation-en-sujato: They too enjoyed it, and craving was born in them.

root-pli-ms: 3. Candimasūriyādipātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 3. The Moon and Sun Appear

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā rasapathaviṁ hatthehi āluppakārakaṁ upakkamiṁsu paribhuñjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings started to eat the solid nectar, breaking it into lumps.
reference: bj9.146, cck11.96, csp1ed8.71, csp2ed8.71, dr11.94, ms8D_254, msdiv121, pts-cs12, pts-vp-pli3.86, sc14, sya11.94

root-pli-ms: Yato kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā rasapathaviṁ hatthehi āluppakārakaṁ upakkamiṁsu paribhuñjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But when they did this
variant-pli-ms: Yato kho te → yato kho (si, sya-all, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Atha tesaṁ sattānaṁ sayaṁpabhā antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: their luminosity vanished.

root-pli-ms: Sayaṁpabhāya antarahitāya candimasūriyā pāturahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And with the vanishing of their luminosity the moon and sun appeared,

root-pli-ms: Candimasūriyesu pātubhūtesu nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni pāturahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: stars and constellations appeared,

root-pli-ms: Nakkhattesu tārakarūpesu pātubhūtesu rattindivā paññāyiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: days and nights were distinguished,

root-pli-ms: Rattindivesu paññāyamānesu māsaḍḍhamāsā paññāyiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: and so were months and fortnights,

root-pli-ms: Māsaḍḍhamāsesu paññāyamānesu utusaṁvaccharā paññāyiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: and years and seasons.

root-pli-ms: Ettāvatā kho, vāseṭṭha, ayaṁ loko puna vivaṭṭo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: To this extent the world had evolved once more.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā rasapathaviṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings eating the solid nectar, with that as their food and nourishment, remained for a very long time.
reference: cck11.97, ms8D_255, msdiv122, ndp8.68, pts-cs13, sc15, vri3.64

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā rasapathaviṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu tathā tathā tesaṁ sattānaṁ rasapathaviṁ paribhuñjantānaṁ kharattañceva kāyasmiṁ okkami, vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā ca paññāyittha.
translation-en-sujato: But so long as they ate that solid nectar, their bodies became more solid and they diverged in appearance;
variant-pli-ms: rasapathaviṁ paribhuñjantānaṁ → etthantare pāṭho sya-all, pts1ed potthakesu natthi | vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā → vaṇṇavevajjatā (ṭīkā)

root-pli-ms: Ekidaṁ sattā vaṇṇavanto honti, ekidaṁ sattā dubbaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: some beautiful, some ugly.

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye te sattā vaṇṇavanto, te dubbaṇṇe satte atimaññanti:
translation-en-sujato: And the beautiful beings looked down on the ugly ones:

root-pli-ms: ‘mayametehi vaṇṇavantatarā, amhehete dubbaṇṇatarā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We’re more beautiful, they’re the ugly ones!’

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ vaṇṇātimānapaccayā mānātimānajātikānaṁ rasapathavī antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And the vanity of the beautiful ones made the solid nectar vanish.

root-pli-ms: Rasāya pathaviyā antarahitāya sannipatiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: They gathered together and bemoaned,

root-pli-ms: Sannipatitvā anutthuniṁsu:
‘aho rasaṁ, aho rasan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, what a taste! Oh, what a taste!’

root-pli-ms: Tadetarahipi manussā kañcideva surasaṁ labhitvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And even today when people get something tasty they say:

root-pli-ms: ‘aho rasaṁ, aho rasan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, what a taste! Oh, what a taste!’

root-pli-ms: Tadeva porāṇaṁ aggaññaṁ akkharaṁ anusaranti, na tvevassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re just remembering an ancient traditional saying, but they don’t understand what it means.

root-pli-ms: 4. Bhūmipappaṭakapātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 4. Ground-Sprouts

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ rasāya pathaviyā antarahitāya bhūmipappaṭako pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: When the solid nectar had vanished, ground-sprouts appeared to those beings.
comment-en-sujato: I am not sure why there is such uncertainty about pappaṭaka. Surely it must = papaṭikā = Skt prapāṭikā = shoots, sprouts.
reference: bj9.148, dr11.95, ms8D_256, msdiv123, pts-cs14, pts-vp-pli3.87, sc16, sya11.95

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma ahicchattako; evameva pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: They appeared just like mushrooms.

root-pli-ms: So ahosi vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno, seyyathāpi nāma sampannaṁ vā sappi sampannaṁ vā navanītaṁ evaṁvaṇṇo ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: They were beautiful, fragrant, and delicious, like ghee or butter.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma khuddamadhuṁ aneḷakaṁ; evamassādo ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And they were as sweet as pure manuka honey.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā bhūmipappaṭakaṁ upakkamiṁsu paribhuñjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings started to eat the ground-sprouts.

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: With that as their food and nourishment, they remained for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā bhūmipappaṭakaṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu tathā tathā tesaṁ sattānaṁ bhiyyoso mattāya kharattañceva kāyasmiṁ okkami, vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā ca paññāyittha.
translation-en-sujato: But so long as they ate those ground-sprouts, their bodies became more solid and they diverged in appearance;

root-pli-ms: Ekidaṁ sattā vaṇṇavanto honti, ekidaṁ sattā dubbaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: some beautiful, some ugly.

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye te sattā vaṇṇavanto, te dubbaṇṇe satte atimaññanti:
translation-en-sujato: And the beautiful beings looked down on the ugly ones:

root-pli-ms: ‘mayametehi vaṇṇavantatarā, amhehete dubbaṇṇatarā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We’re more beautiful, they’re the ugly ones!’

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ vaṇṇātimānapaccayā mānātimānajātikānaṁ bhūmipappaṭako antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And the vanity of the beautiful ones made the ground-sprouts vanish.

root-pli-ms: 5. Padālatāpātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 5. Bursting Pods

root-pli-ms: Bhūmipappaṭake antarahite padālatā pāturahosi, seyyathāpi nāma kalambukā; evameva pāturahosi.
translation-en-sujato: When the ground-sprouts had vanished, bursting pods appeared, like the fruit of the kadam tree.
comment-en-sujato: Readings and meaning of padālatā are uncertain. It has usually been understood that the second element = latā creeper. But this leaves the first part unexplained, and comm’s bhaddālatā is unconvincing. It also leaves unexplained the connection with kalambukā, unconvincingly translated by RD and MW as “bamboo”. I think padālatā is related to padālana in the sense of “bursting”. Kalambukā is probably the fruit of the kadam tree, described thus: “small, fleshy capsules packed closely together to form a fleshy yellow-orange infructescence containing approximately 8000 seeds. On maturing, the fruit splits apart”. Thus padālatā would be a kind of bud or seed pod that splits open, somewhat like a fig or pomegranate.

root-pli-ms: Sā ahosi vaṇṇasampannā gandhasampannā rasasampannā, seyyathāpi nāma sampannaṁ vā sappi sampannaṁ vā navanītaṁ evaṁvaṇṇā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: They were beautiful, fragrant, and delicious, like ghee or butter.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma khuddamadhuṁ aneḷakaṁ; evamassādā ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: And they were as sweet as pure manuka honey.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā padālataṁ upakkamiṁsu paribhuñjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings started to eat the bursting pods.
reference: ms8D_259, ndp8.69, pts-cs15, pts-vp-pli3.88, sc19, sya11.96, vri3.65

root-pli-ms: Te taṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: With that as their food and nourishment, they remained for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā padālataṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu tathā tathā tesaṁ sattānaṁ bhiyyoso mattāya kharattañceva kāyasmiṁ okkami, vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā ca paññāyittha.
translation-en-sujato: But so long as they ate those bursting pods, their bodies became more solid and they diverged in appearance;

root-pli-ms: Ekidaṁ sattā vaṇṇavanto honti, ekidaṁ sattā dubbaṇṇā.
translation-en-sujato: some beautiful, some ugly.

root-pli-ms: Tattha ye te sattā vaṇṇavanto, te dubbaṇṇe satte atimaññanti:
translation-en-sujato: And the beautiful beings looked down on the ugly ones:

root-pli-ms: ‘mayametehi vaṇṇavantatarā, amhehete dubbaṇṇatarā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘We’re more beautiful, they’re the ugly ones!’

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ vaṇṇātimānapaccayā mānātimānajātikānaṁ padālatā antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: And the vanity of the beautiful ones made the bursting pods vanish.

root-pli-ms: Padālatāya antarahitāya sannipatiṁsu. Sannipatitvā anutthuniṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: They gathered together and bemoaned,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahu vata no, ahāyi vata no padālatā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, what we’ve lost! Oh, what we’ve lost—those bursting pods!’

root-pli-ms: Tadetarahipi manussā kenaci dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: And even today when people experience suffering they say:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahu vata no, ahāyi vata no’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, what we’ve lost! Oh, what we’ve lost!’

root-pli-ms: Tadeva porāṇaṁ aggaññaṁ akkharaṁ anusaranti, na tvevassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re just remembering an ancient traditional saying, but they don’t understand what it means.

root-pli-ms: 6. Akaṭṭhapākasālipātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 6. Ripe Untilled Rice

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ padālatāya antarahitāya akaṭṭhapāko sāli pāturahosi akaṇo athuso suddho sugandho taṇḍulapphalo.
translation-en-sujato: When the bursting pods had vanished, ripe untilled rice appeared to those beings. It had no powder or husk, pure and fragrant, with only the rice-grain.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ taṁ sāyaṁ sāyamāsāya āharanti, pāto taṁ hoti pakkaṁ paṭivirūḷhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: What they took for supper in the evening, by the morning had grown back and ripened.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ taṁ pāto pātarāsāya āharanti, sāyaṁ taṁ hoti pakkaṁ paṭivirūḷhaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: And what they took for breakfast in the morning had grown back and ripened by the evening,

root-pli-ms: nāpadānaṁ paññāyati.
translation-en-sujato: so the cutting didn’t show.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā akaṭṭhapākaṁ sāliṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings eating the ripe untilled rice, with that as their food and nourishment, remained for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: 7. Itthipurisaliṅgapātubhāva
translation-en-sujato: 7. Gender Appears

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā akaṭṭhapākaṁ sāliṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu tathā tathā tesaṁ sattānaṁ bhiyyoso mattāya kharattañceva kāyasmiṁ okkami, vaṇṇavevaṇṇatā ca paññāyittha, itthiyā ca itthiliṅgaṁ pāturahosi purisassa ca purisaliṅgaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But so long as they ate that ripe untilled rice, their bodies became more solid and they diverged in appearance. And female characteristics appeared on women, while male characteristics appeared on men.
comment-en-sujato: Comm here offers nothing on what litthi/purisa-linga actually means, but at Pj 1 it says massudāṭhikādi “beard and whiskers, etc.” So it seems this is not restricted to genitals.

root-pli-ms: Itthī ca purisaṁ ativelaṁ upanijjhāyati puriso ca itthiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Women spent too much time gazing at men, and men at women.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ ativelaṁ aññamaññaṁ upanijjhāyataṁ sārāgo udapādi, pariḷāho kāyasmiṁ okkami.
translation-en-sujato: They became lustful, and their bodies burned with fever.

root-pli-ms: Te pariḷāhapaccayā methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭiseviṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Due to this fever they had sex with each other.

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana te, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena sattā passanti methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevante, aññe paṁsuṁ khipanti, aññe seṭṭhiṁ khipanti, aññe gomayaṁ khipanti:
translation-en-sujato: Those who saw them having sex pelted them with dirt, ashes, or cow-dung, saying,
comment-en-sujato: Unless seṭṭhiṁ khipanti means “they threw millionares” I am stumped by this. Comm says “Seṭṭhinti chārikaṁ” which is equally plausible and unsupported. Mu Kd 17 has “pāṁśum api kṣipanti, loṣṭam api śarkarā api kapālāny api”, all of which are earthy: dust, mud lumps, potsherds, etc. Nevertheless, in the absence of anything better I follow comm.
reference: dr11.98, ms8D_263, ndp8.70, pts-vp-pli3.89, sc23, vri3.66

root-pli-ms: ‘nassa asuci, nassa asucī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Get lost, filth! Get lost, filth!
comment-en-sujato: Nassa could mean “die! “or” get lost”, but I take the softer.
variant-pli-ms: asuci → vasalī (bj, mr); vasali (sya-all) | asucī → vasalī (bj, mr); vasali (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: ‘Kathañhi nāma satto sattassa evarūpaṁ karissatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: How on earth can one being do that to another?’

root-pli-ms: Tadetarahipi manussā ekaccesu janapadesu vadhuyā nibbuyhamānāya aññe paṁsuṁ khipanti, aññe seṭṭhiṁ khipanti, aññe gomayaṁ khipanti.
translation-en-sujato: And even today people in some countries, when a bride is carried off, pelt her with dirt, ashes, or cow-dung.
comment-en-sujato: nibbuyhamānā is unusual, and I think has a stronger meaning than “led”. It is used of being swept away by a river. I think the bride was carried out by the guests. Note that Skt here has cūrṇam api kṣipanti gandham api mālyam api vastrajālāny api kṣipanti, which sounds much more pleasant!

root-pli-ms: Tadeva porāṇaṁ aggaññaṁ akkharaṁ anusaranti, na tvevassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re just remembering an ancient traditional saying, but they don’t understand what it means.

root-pli-ms: 8. Methunadhammasamācāra
translation-en-sujato: 8. Sexual Intercourse

root-pli-ms: Adhammasammataṁ kho pana, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena hoti, tadetarahi dhammasammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: What was reckoned as immoral at that time, these days is reckoned as moral.
comment-en-sujato: Comm, echoed by MW, say it is the throwing of dirt that is “adhamma “, hence MW’s cute translation as” bad form”. However, this seems unlikely. Note that the Skt, where only auspicious things are thrown, and where the bride is given only good wishes (sukhinī bhava vadhūke sukhinī bhava vadhūke) is also followed by a similar clause (iti hi gautamā yat pūrvam adharmasaṁmataṁ tad etarhi dharmasaṁmataṁ; yat pūrvam avinayasaṁmataṁ tad etarhi vinayasaṁmataṁ; yat pūrvaṁ garhyasaṁmataṁ tad etarhi praśasyasaṁmatam). Here it must obviously be the act of sex that is referred to.
reference: bj9.152, cck11.100, csp1ed8.74, csp2ed8.74, ms8D_264, msdiv127, pts-cs17, sc24, sya11.98

root-pli-ms: Ye kho pana, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena sattā methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevanti, te māsampi dvemāsampi na labhanti gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā pavisituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The beings who had sex together weren’t allowed to enter a village or town for one or two months.

root-pli-ms: Yato kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā tasmiṁ asaddhamme ativelaṁ pātabyataṁ āpajjiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: Ever since they excessively threw themselves into immorality,

root-pli-ms: Atha agārāni upakkamiṁsu kātuṁ tasseva asaddhammassa paṭicchādanatthaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they started to make buildings to hide their immoral deeds.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññatarassa sattassa alasajātikassa etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then one of those beings of idle disposition thought,

root-pli-ms: ‘ambho, kimevāhaṁ vihaññāmi sāliṁ āharanto sāyaṁ sāyamāsāya pāto pātarāsāya.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Hey now, why should I be bothered to gather rice in the evening for supper, and in the morning for breakfast?

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ sāliṁ āhareyyaṁ sakideva sāyapātarāsāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I gather rice for supper and breakfast all at once?’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so, vāseṭṭha, satto sāliṁ āhāsi sakideva sāyapātarāsāya.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what he did.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññataro satto yena so satto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ sattaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then one of the other beings approached that being and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi, bho satta, sālāhāraṁ gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, good being, we shall go to gather rice.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Alaṁ, bho satta, āhato me sāli sakideva sāyapātarāsāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no need, good being! I gathered rice for supper and breakfast all at once.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so, vāseṭṭha, satto tassa sattassa diṭṭhānugatiṁ āpajjamāno sāliṁ āhāsi sakideva dvīhāya. ‘Evampi kira, bho, sādhū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: So that being, following their example, gathered rice for two days all at once, thinking: ‘This seems fine.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññataro satto yena so satto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ sattaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then one of the other beings approached that being and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi, bho satta, sālāhāraṁ gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, good being, we shall go to gather rice.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Alaṁ, bho satta, āhato me sāli sakideva dvīhāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no need, good being! I gathered rice for two days all at once.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so, vāseṭṭha, satto tassa sattassa diṭṭhānugatiṁ āpajjamāno sāliṁ āhāsi sakideva catūhāya, ‘evampi kira, bho, sādhū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: So that being, following their example, gathered rice for four days all at once, thinking: ‘This seems fine.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññataro satto yena so satto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ sattaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: Then one of the other beings approached that being and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi, bho satta, sālāhāraṁ gamissāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, good being, we shall go to gather rice.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Alaṁ, bho satta, āhato me sāli sakideva catūhāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no need, good being! I gathered rice for four days all at once.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho so, vāseṭṭha, satto tassa sattassa diṭṭhānugatiṁ āpajjamāno sāliṁ āhāsi sakideva aṭṭhāhāya, ‘evampi kira, bho, sādhū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: So that being, following their example, gathered rice for eight days all at once, thinking: ‘This seems fine.’

root-pli-ms: Yato kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā sannidhikārakaṁ sāliṁ upakkamiṁsu paribhuñjituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But when they started to store up rice to eat,

root-pli-ms: Atha kaṇopi taṇḍulaṁ pariyonandhi, thusopi taṇḍulaṁ pariyonandhi;
translation-en-sujato: the rice grains became wrapped in powder and husk,

root-pli-ms: lūnampi nappaṭivirūḷhaṁ, apadānaṁ paññāyittha, saṇḍasaṇḍā sālayo aṭṭhaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: it didn’t grow back after reaping, the cutting showed, and the rice stood in clumps.

root-pli-ms: 9. Sālivibhāga
translation-en-sujato: 9. Dividing the Fields

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā sannipatiṁsu, sannipatitvā anutthuniṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings gathered together and bemoaned,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāpakā vata, bho, dhammā sattesu pātubhūtā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, how wicked things have appeared among beings!

root-pli-ms: Mayañhi pubbe manomayā ahumhā pītibhakkhā sayaṁpabhā antalikkhacarā subhaṭṭhāyino, ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhamhā.
translation-en-sujato: For we used to be mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, moving through the sky, steadily glorious, and we remained like that for a very long time.

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁ no amhākaṁ kadāci karahaci dīghassa addhuno accayena rasapathavī udakasmiṁ samatani.
translation-en-sujato: After a very long period had passed, solid nectar curdled in the water.

root-pli-ms: Sā ahosi vaṇṇasampannā gandhasampannā rasasampannā.
Te mayaṁ rasapathaviṁ hatthehi āluppakārakaṁ upakkamimha paribhuñjituṁ, tesaṁ no rasapathaviṁ hatthehi āluppakārakaṁ upakkamataṁ paribhuñjituṁ sayaṁpabhā antaradhāyi.

Sayaṁpabhāya antarahitāya candimasūriyā pāturahesuṁ, candimasūriyesu pātubhūtesu nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni pāturahesuṁ, nakkhattesu tārakarūpesu pātubhūtesu rattindivā paññāyiṁsu, rattindivesu paññāyamānesu māsaḍḍhamāsā paññāyiṁsu.
variant-pli-ms: candimasūriyā → … suriyā (bj, sya-all, pts1ed) | Sayaṁpabhāya → tāya (bj)

root-pli-ms: Māsaḍḍhamāsesu paññāyamānesu utusaṁvaccharā paññāyiṁsu.
Te mayaṁ rasapathaviṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhamhā.
Tesaṁ no pāpakānaṁyeva akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pātubhāvā rasapathavī antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: But due to bad, unskillful things among us, the savory nectar vanished,

root-pli-ms: Rasapathaviyā antarahitāya bhūmipappaṭako pāturahosi.
So ahosi vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
Te mayaṁ bhūmipappaṭakaṁ upakkamimha paribhuñjituṁ.
Te mayaṁ taṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhamhā.
Tesaṁ no pāpakānaṁyeva akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pātubhāvā bhūmipappaṭako antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: the ground-sprouts vanished,

root-pli-ms: Bhūmipappaṭake antarahite padālatā pāturahosi.
Sā ahosi vaṇṇasampannā gandhasampannā rasasampannā.
Te mayaṁ padālataṁ upakkamimha paribhuñjituṁ.
Te mayaṁ taṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhamhā.
Tesaṁ no pāpakānaṁyeva akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pātubhāvā padālatā antaradhāyi.
translation-en-sujato: the bursting pods vanished,

root-pli-ms: Padālatāya antarahitāya akaṭṭhapāko sāli pāturahosi akaṇo athuso suddho sugandho taṇḍulapphalo.
Yaṁ taṁ sāyaṁ sāyamāsāya āharāma, pāto taṁ hoti pakkaṁ paṭivirūḷhaṁ.
Yaṁ taṁ pāto pātarāsāya āharāma, sāyaṁ taṁ hoti pakkaṁ paṭivirūḷhaṁ.
Nāpadānaṁ paññāyittha.
Te mayaṁ akaṭṭhapākaṁ sāliṁ paribhuñjantā tambhakkhā tadāhārā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ aṭṭhamhā.
Tesaṁ no pāpakānaṁyeva akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pātubhāvā kaṇopi taṇḍulaṁ pariyonandhi, thusopi taṇḍulaṁ pariyonandhi, lūnampi nappaṭivirūḷhaṁ, apadānaṁ paññāyittha, saṇḍasaṇḍā sālayo ṭhitā.
translation-en-sujato: and now the rice grains have become wrapped in powder and husk, it doesn’t grow back after reaping, the cutting shows, and the rice stands in clumps.

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ sāliṁ vibhajeyyāma, mariyādaṁ ṭhapeyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: We’d better divide up the rice and set boundaries.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā sāliṁ vibhajiṁsu, mariyādaṁ ṭhapesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they did.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho, vāseṭṭha, aññataro satto lolajātiko sakaṁ bhāgaṁ parirakkhanto aññataraṁ bhāgaṁ adinnaṁ ādiyitvā paribhuñji.
translation-en-sujato: Now, one of those beings was reckless. While guarding their own share they took another’s share without it being given, and ate it.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ, gahetvā etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: They grabbed the one who had done this and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘pāpakaṁ vata, bho satta, karosi, yatra hi nāma sakaṁ bhāgaṁ parirakkhanto aññataraṁ bhāgaṁ adinnaṁ ādiyitvā paribhuñjasi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘You have done a bad thing, good being, in that while guarding your own share you took another’s share without it being given, and ate it.

root-pli-ms: Māssu, bho satta, punapi evarūpamakāsī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Do not do such a thing again.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho, vāseṭṭha, so satto tesaṁ sattānaṁ paccassosi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, sirs,’ replied that being.

root-pli-ms: Dutiyampi kho, vāseṭṭha, so satto …pe…
translation-en-sujato: But for a second time,

root-pli-ms: tatiyampi kho, vāseṭṭha, so satto sakaṁ bhāgaṁ parirakkhanto aññataraṁ bhāgaṁ adinnaṁ ādiyitvā paribhuñji.
translation-en-sujato: and a third time they did the same thing, and were told not to continue.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ aggahesuṁ, gahetvā etadavocuṁ:
‘pāpakaṁ vata, bho satta, karosi, yatra hi nāma sakaṁ bhāgaṁ parirakkhanto aññataraṁ bhāgaṁ adinnaṁ ādiyitvā paribhuñjasi.
Māssu, bho satta, punapi evarūpamakāsī’ti.
Aññe pāṇinā pahariṁsu, aññe leḍḍunā pahariṁsu, aññe daṇḍena pahariṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: And then they struck that being, some with fists, others with stones, and still others with rods.

root-pli-ms: Tadagge kho, vāseṭṭha, adinnādānaṁ paññāyati, garahā paññāyati, musāvādo paññāyati, daṇḍādānaṁ paññāyati.
translation-en-sujato: From that day on stealing was found, and blaming and lying and the taking up of rods.

root-pli-ms: 10. Mahāsammatarājā
translation-en-sujato: 10. The Elected King

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā sannipatiṁsu, sannipatitvā anutthuniṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings gathered together and bemoaned,
reference: cck11.104, csp1ed8.77, csp2ed8.77, ms8D_271, msdiv130, pts-cs20, sc31

root-pli-ms: ‘pāpakā vata bho dhammā sattesu pātubhūtā, yatra hi nāma adinnādānaṁ paññāyissati, garahā paññāyissati, musāvādo paññāyissati, daṇḍādānaṁ paññāyissati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, how wicked things have appeared among beings, in that stealing is found, and blaming and lying and the taking up of rods!

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ ekaṁ sattaṁ sammanneyyāma, yo no sammā khīyitabbaṁ khīyeyya, sammā garahitabbaṁ garaheyya, sammā pabbājetabbaṁ pabbājeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we elect one being who would rightly accuse those who deserve it, blame those who deserve it, and expel those who deserve it?
comment-en-sujato: khiyati = object to accuse, hardly “show anger” as per RD and MW.

root-pli-ms: Mayaṁ panassa sālīnaṁ bhāgaṁ anuppadassāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: We shall pay them with a share of rice.’

root-pli-ms: Atha kho te, vāseṭṭha, sattā yo nesaṁ satto abhirūpataro ca dassanīyataro ca pāsādikataro ca mahesakkhataro ca taṁ sattaṁ upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: Then those beings approached the being among them who was most attractive, good-looking, lovely, and illustrious, and said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ehi, bho satta, sammā khīyitabbaṁ khīya, sammā garahitabbaṁ garaha, sammā pabbājetabbaṁ pabbājehi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Come, good being, rightly accuse those who deserve it, blame those who deserve it, and banish those who deserve it.
comment-en-sujato: Note that the ehi formula is the same as original ordination.

root-pli-ms: Mayaṁ pana te sālīnaṁ bhāgaṁ anuppadassāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: We shall pay you with a share of rice.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho, vāseṭṭha, so satto tesaṁ sattānaṁ paṭissuṇitvā sammā khīyitabbaṁ khīyi, sammā garahitabbaṁ garahi, sammā pabbājetabbaṁ pabbājesi.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Yes, sirs,’ replied that being. They acted accordingly,

root-pli-ms: Te panassa sālīnaṁ bhāgaṁ anuppadaṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: and were paid with a share of rice.

root-pli-ms: Mahājanasammatoti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘mahāsammato, mahāsammato’ tveva paṭhamaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Elected by the people’, Vāseṭṭha, is the meaning of ‘elected one’, the first term to be specifically invented for them.
comment-en-sujato: Upanibbatta is unknown elsewhere, and given that it is consistently used in different way than abhinibbatti, I would think there is some nuance of meaning distinguishing them. Clearly it doesn’t mean “first word” as they have been using language before. Mu Kd 17 here has saṁjñodapādi, “arisen by agreement”. I take the distinction to be that these terms were consciously invented and applied in this context, “closely” (upa-) or specifically for them. Comm has na kevalaṁ akkharameva, which may lend some support this idea.
reference: bj9.158, ms8D_273, msdiv131, pts-cs21, sc33, vri3.69

root-pli-ms: Khettānaṁ adhipatīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘khattiyo, khattiyo’ tveva dutiyaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Lord of the fields’ is the meaning of ‘aristocrat’, the second term to be specifically invented.

root-pli-ms: Dhammena pare rañjetīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘rājā, rājā’ tveva tatiyaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘They please others with principle’ is the meaning of ‘king’, the third term to be specifically invented.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, evametassa khattiyamaṇḍalassa porāṇena aggaññena akkharena abhinibbatti ahosi tesaṁyeva sattānaṁ, anaññesaṁ. Sadisānaṁyeva, no asadisānaṁ. Dhammeneva, no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: And that, Vāseṭṭha, is how the ancient traditional terms for the circle of aristocrats were created; for those very beings, not others; for those like them, not unlike; legitimately, not illegitimately.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: 11. Brāhmaṇamaṇḍala
translation-en-sujato: 11. The Circle of Brahmins

root-pli-ms: Atha kho tesaṁ, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁyeva ekaccānaṁ etadahosi:
translation-en-sujato: Then some of those same beings thought,
variant-pli-ms: sattānaṁyeva → te sattānaṁyeva (cck, sya1ed); tesaṁ sattānaṁyeva (sya2ed); tesaṁ yeva kho vāseṭṭha sattānaṁ (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: ‘pāpakā vata, bho, dhammā sattesu pātubhūtā, yatra hi nāma adinnādānaṁ paññāyissati, garahā paññāyissati, musāvādo paññāyissati, daṇḍādānaṁ paññāyissati, pabbājanaṁ paññāyissati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, how wicked things have appeared among beings, in that stealing is found, and blaming and lying and the taking up of rods and banishment!

root-pli-ms: Yannūna mayaṁ pāpake akusale dhamme vāheyyāmā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t we set aside bad, unskillful things?’
comment-en-sujato: Read bāheti.

root-pli-ms: Te pāpake akusale dhamme vāhesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So that’s what they did.

root-pli-ms: Pāpake akusale dhamme vāhentīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘brāhmaṇā, brāhmaṇā’ tveva paṭhamaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘They set aside bad, unskillful things’ is the meaning of ‘brahmin’, the first term to be specifically invented for them.

root-pli-ms: Te araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyo karitvā paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyanti vītaṅgārā vītadhūmā pannamusalā sāyaṁ sāyamāsāya pāto pātarāsāya gāmanigamarājadhāniyo osaranti ghāsamesamānā.
translation-en-sujato: They built leaf huts in a wilderness region where they meditated pure and bright, without lighting cooking fires or digging the soil. They came down in the morning for breakfast and in the evening for supper to the village, town, or royal capital seeking a meal.
comment-en-sujato: Comm has “Vītaṅgārāvītadhūmāti pacitvā khāditabbābhāvato vigatadhūmaṅgārā” See https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/an-extremely-dense-four-words/6049

root-pli-ms: Te ghāsaṁ paṭilabhitvā punadeva araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyanti.
translation-en-sujato: When they had obtained food they continued to meditate in the leaf huts.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ manussā disvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: When people noticed this they said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime kho, bho, sattā araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyo karitvā paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyanti, vītaṅgārā vītadhūmā pannamusalā sāyaṁ sāyamāsāya pāto pātarāsāya gāmanigamarājadhāniyo osaranti ghāsamesamānā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘These beings build leaf huts in a wilderness region where they meditate pure and bright, without lighting cooking fires or digging the soil. They come down in the morning for breakfast and in the evening for supper to the village, town, or royal capital seeking a meal.

root-pli-ms: Te ghāsaṁ paṭilabhitvā punadeva araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyantī’ti,
translation-en-sujato: When they have obtained food they continue to meditate in the leaf huts.’
variant-pli-ms: paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyantī’ti → paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyanti (bj, pts1ed); paṇṇakuṭīsu (sya-all); paṇṇakuṭīsu jhāyantīti kho (mr)

root-pli-ms: jhāyantīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘jhāyakā, jhāyakā’ tveva dutiyaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘They meditate’ is the meaning of ‘meditator’, the second term to be specifically invented for them.
variant-pli-ms: jhāyantīti kho → jhāyantīti kho pana (bj, pts1ed); jhāyanti te kho (sya-all)

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁyeva kho, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ ekacce sattā araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu taṁ jhānaṁ anabhisambhuṇamānā gāmasāmantaṁ nigamasāmantaṁ osaritvā ganthe karontā acchanti.
translation-en-sujato: But some of those beings were unable to keep up with their meditation in the leaf huts in the wilderness. They came down to the neighborhood of a village or town where they dwelt compiling texts.
comment-en-sujato: Cp. DN 3

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ manussā disvā evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: When people noticed this they said,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime kho, bho, sattā araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu taṁ jhānaṁ anabhisambhuṇamānā gāmasāmantaṁ nigamasāmantaṁ osaritvā ganthe karontā acchanti, na dānime jhāyantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘These beings were unable to keep up with their meditation in the leaf huts in the wilderness. They came down to the neighborhood of a village or town where they dwelt compiling texts. Now they don’t meditate.’

root-pli-ms: Na dānime jhāyantīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘ajjhāyakā, ajjhāyakā’ tveva tatiyaṁ akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Now they don’t meditate’ is the meaning of ‘reciter’, the third term to be specifically invented for them.
variant-pli-ms: Na dānime → na dānime jhāyanti na dānime (bj, pts1ed, mr)

root-pli-ms: Hīnasammataṁ kho pana, vāseṭṭha, tena samayena hoti, tadetarahi seṭṭhasammataṁ.
translation-en-sujato: What was reckoned as lesser at that time, these days is reckoned as better.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, evametassa brāhmaṇamaṇḍalassa porāṇena aggaññena akkharena abhinibbatti ahosi tesaṁyeva sattānaṁ, anaññesaṁ sadisānaṁyeva no asadisānaṁ dhammeneva, no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: And that, Vāseṭṭha, is how the ancient traditional terms for the circle of brahmins were created; for those very beings, not others; for those like them, not unlike; legitimately, not illegitimately.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: 12. Vessamaṇḍala
translation-en-sujato: 12. The Circle of Merchants

root-pli-ms: Tesaṁyeva kho, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ ekacce sattā methunaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya visukammante payojesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Some of those same beings, taking up an active sex life, applied themselves to various jobs.
reference: csp1ed8.79, csp2ed8.79, ms8D_275, msdiv133, pts-cs24, sc35, sya11.104
variant-pli-ms: visukammante → vissutaṁ kammante (bj, pts1ed); vissukammante (si); visuṁ kammante (sya-all, mr)

root-pli-ms: Methunaṁ dhammaṁ samādāya visukammante payojentīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘vessā, vessā’ tveva akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Having taken up an active sex life, they apply themselves to various jobs’ is the meaning of ‘merchant’, the term specifically invented for them.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, evametassa vessamaṇḍalassa porāṇena aggaññena akkharena abhinibbatti ahosi tesaññeva sattānaṁ anaññesaṁ sadisānaṁyeva, no asadisānaṁ, dhammeneva no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: And that, Vāseṭṭha, is how the ancient traditional term for the circle of merchants was created; for those very beings, not others; for those like them, not unlike; legitimately, not illegitimately.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: 13. Suddamaṇḍala
translation-en-sujato: 13. The Circle of Workers

root-pli-ms: Tesaññeva kho, vāseṭṭha, sattānaṁ ye te sattā avasesā te luddācārā khuddācārā ahesuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The remaining beings lived by hunting and menial tasks.

root-pli-ms: Luddācārā khuddācārāti kho, vāseṭṭha, ‘suddā, suddā’ tveva akkharaṁ upanibbattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘They live by hunting and menial tasks’ is the meaning of ‘worker’, the term specifically invented for them.

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, vāseṭṭha, evametassa suddamaṇḍalassa porāṇena aggaññena akkharena abhinibbatti ahosi tesaṁyeva sattānaṁ anaññesaṁ, sadisānaṁyeva no asadisānaṁ, dhammeneva, no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: And that, Vāseṭṭha, is how the ancient traditional term for the circle of workers was created; for those very beings, not others; for those like them, not unlike; legitimately, not illegitimately.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: Ahu kho so, vāseṭṭha, samayo, yaṁ khattiyopi sakaṁ dhammaṁ garahamāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati:
translation-en-sujato: There came a time when an aristocrat, brahmin, merchant, or worker, deprecating their own vocation, went forth from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
comment-en-sujato: A rare use of dhamma in this sense.
reference: cck11.107, ms8D_277, msdiv135, ndp8.75, pts-cs26, pts-vp-pli3.96, sc37

root-pli-ms: ‘samaṇo bhavissāmī’ti.
Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha, sakaṁ dhammaṁ garahamāno agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati:
‘samaṇo bhavissāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I will be an ascetic.’

root-pli-ms: Imehi kho, vāseṭṭha, catūhi maṇḍalehi samaṇamaṇḍalassa abhinibbatti ahosi, tesaṁyeva sattānaṁ anaññesaṁ, sadisānaṁyeva no asadisānaṁ, dhammeneva no adhammena.
translation-en-sujato: And that, Vāseṭṭha, is how these four circles were created; for those very beings, not others; for those like them, not unlike; legitimately, not illegitimately.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo hi, vāseṭṭha, seṭṭho janetasmiṁ diṭṭhe ceva dhamme abhisamparāyañca.
translation-en-sujato: For principle, Vāseṭṭha, is the best thing about people in both this life and the next.

root-pli-ms: 14. Duccaritādikathā
translation-en-sujato: 14. On Bad Conduct

root-pli-ms: Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā micchādiṭṭhiko micchādiṭṭhikammasamādāno micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
translation-en-sujato: An aristocrat, brahmin, merchant, worker, or ascetic may do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They have wrong view, and they act out of that wrong view. And because of that, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
reference: bj9.162, ms8D_278, msdiv136, pts-cs27, sc38, sya11.105, vri3.71

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …
suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha …

samaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā micchādiṭṭhiko micchādiṭṭhikammasamādāno micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.

Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena sucaritaṁ caritvā vācāya sucaritaṁ caritvā manasā sucaritaṁ caritvā sammādiṭṭhiko sammādiṭṭhikammasamādāno sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …
suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha …

samaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena sucaritaṁ caritvā vācāya sucaritaṁ caritvā manasā sucaritaṁ caritvā sammādiṭṭhiko sammādiṭṭhikammasamādāno sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
translation-en-sujato: An aristocrat, brahmin, merchant, worker, or ascetic may do good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They have right view, and they act out of that right view. And because of that, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

root-pli-ms: Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena dvayakārī, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī, vimissadiṭṭhiko vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādāno vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī hoti.
reference: cck11.109, dr11.108, ms8D_280, msdiv137, ndp8.76, pts-cs29, pts-vp-pli3.97, sc40, sya11.106

root-pli-ms: Brāhmaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha …pe…
vessopi kho, vāseṭṭha …
suddopi kho, vāseṭṭha …
