translation-en-sujato: For your teacher is awakened, and their teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.
variant-pli-ms: satthā ca te → satthā ca te arahaṁ (sya-all, pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: Tvañca tasmiṁ dhamme dhammānudhammappaṭipanno viharasi sāmīcippaṭipanno anudhammacārī, samādāya taṁ dhammaṁ vattasī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And you practice in line with that teaching, you practice following that procedure, you live in line with the teaching. You proceed having undertaken that teaching.’

root-pli-ms: Iti kho, cunda, satthāpi tattha pāsaṁso, dhammopi tattha pāsaṁso, sāvakopi tattha evaṁ pāsaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: In such a case the teacher, the teaching, and the disciple all deserve praise.

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, cunda, evarūpaṁ sāvakaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Suppose someone was to say to such a disciple,

root-pli-ms: ‘addhāyasmā ñāyappaṭipanno ñāyamārādhessatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Clearly the venerable is practicing methodically and will succeed in completing that method.’

root-pli-ms: Yo ca pasaṁsati, yañca pasaṁsati, yo ca pasaṁsito bhiyyoso mattāya vīriyaṁ ārabhati. Sabbe te bahuṁ puññaṁ pasavanti.
translation-en-sujato: The one who praises, the one who they praise, and the one who, being praised, rouses up even more energy all make much merit.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: Evañhetaṁ, cunda, hoti svākkhāte dhammavinaye suppavedite niyyānike upasamasaṁvattanike sammāsambuddhappavedite.
translation-en-sujato: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.

root-pli-ms: 3. Sāvakānutappasatthu
translation-en-sujato: 3. When Disciples Have Regrets

root-pli-ms: Idha pana, cunda, satthā ca loke udapādi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito,
translation-en-sujato: Take the case where a teacher arises in the world who is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.
comment-en-sujato: Comm: aviññāpitatthāti abodhitatthā. I think this is a mistake. it is to be understood in line with the Buddha inviting the monks to question him on his deathbed. viññāpita is used in the sense “asked about or for”.
reference: csp1ed8.101, csp2ed8.101, dr11.136, ms8D_343, msdiv170, pts-cs8, pts-vp-pli3.122, sc10

root-pli-ms: aviññāpitatthā cassa honti sāvakā saddhamme, na ca tesaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ hoti uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But the disciples haven’t inquired about the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has not been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Atha nesaṁ satthuno antaradhānaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: And then their teacher passes away.

root-pli-ms: Evarūpo kho, cunda, satthā sāvakānaṁ kālaṅkato anutappo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are tormented by regrets.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: ‘Satthā ca no loke udapādi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito, aviññāpitatthā camha saddhamme, na ca no kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ hoti uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They think: ‘Our teacher was perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. His teaching was well explained, but we didn’t inquire about the meaning, and the spiritual practice was not fully disclosed to us.

root-pli-ms: Atha no satthuno antaradhānaṁ hotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And then our teacher passed away.’

root-pli-ms: Evarūpo kho, cunda, satthā sāvakānaṁ kālaṅkato anutappo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are tormented by regrets.

root-pli-ms: 4. Sāvakānanutappasatthu
translation-en-sujato: 4. When Disciples Have No Regrets

root-pli-ms: Idha pana, cunda, satthā ca loke udapādi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho. Dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
translation-en-sujato: Take the case where a teacher arises in the world who is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.

root-pli-ms: Viññāpitatthā cassa honti sāvakā saddhamme, kevalañca tesaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ hoti uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The disciples have inquired about the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Atha nesaṁ satthuno antaradhānaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: And then their teacher passes away.

root-pli-ms: Evarūpo kho, cunda, satthā sāvakānaṁ kālaṅkato ananutappo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are free of regrets.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: ‘Satthā ca no loke udapādi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho.
translation-en-sujato: They think: ‘Our teacher was perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
translation-en-sujato: His teaching was well explained,

root-pli-ms: Viññāpitatthā camha saddhamme, kevalañca no paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ hoti uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: we inquired about the meaning, and the spiritual practice was fully disclosed to us.

root-pli-ms: Atha no satthuno antaradhānaṁ hotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And then our teacher passed away.’

root-pli-ms: Evarūpo kho, cunda, satthā sāvakānaṁ kālaṅkato ananutappo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: When such a teacher has passed away the disciples are free of regrets.

root-pli-ms: 5. Brahmacariyaaparipūrādikathā
translation-en-sujato: 5. On the Incomplete Spiritual Path, Etc.

root-pli-ms: Etehi cepi, cunda, aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, no ca kho satthā hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: Now suppose, Cunda, that a spiritual path possesses those factors. But the teacher is not senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and reached the final stage of life.
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW seem to take this as referring to a monk. But it refers to the Buddha, as is made clear in the recapitulation.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ aparipūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Yato ca kho, cunda, etehi ceva aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior,

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ paripūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Etehi cepi, cunda, aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto, no ca khvassa therā bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.
translation-en-sujato: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior. But there are no senior monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, have attained sanctuary,

root-pli-ms: Alaṁ samakkhātuṁ saddhammassa, alaṁ uppannaṁ parappavādaṁ sahadhammehi suniggahitaṁ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: who can rightly explain the true teaching, and who can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ aparipūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Yato ca kho, cunda, etehi ceva aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto, therā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.
translation-en-sujato: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,

root-pli-ms: Alaṁ samakkhātuṁ saddhammassa, alaṁ uppannaṁ parappavādaṁ sahadhammehi suniggahitaṁ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ paripūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Etehi cepi, cunda, aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto, therā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.
translation-en-sujato: Now suppose that a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks.

root-pli-ms: Alaṁ samakkhātuṁ saddhammassa, alaṁ uppannaṁ parappavādaṁ sahadhammehi suniggahitaṁ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
No ca khvassa majjhimā bhikkhū sāvakā honti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: But there are no competent middle monks,

root-pli-ms: majjhimā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti, no ca khvassa navā bhikkhū sāvakā honti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: junior monks,

root-pli-ms: navā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti, no ca khvassa therā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: senior nuns,

root-pli-ms: therā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti, no ca khvassa majjhimā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: middle nuns,

root-pli-ms: majjhimā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti, no ca khvassa navā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: junior nuns,

root-pli-ms: navā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti, no ca khvassa upāsakā sāvakā honti gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino …pe…
translation-en-sujato: celibate white-clothed laymen,

root-pli-ms: upāsakā cassa sāvakā honti gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino, no ca khvassa upāsakā sāvakā honti gihī odātavasanā kāmabhogino …pe…
translation-en-sujato: white-clothed laymen enjoying sensual pleasures,

root-pli-ms: upāsakā cassa sāvakā honti gihī odātavasanā kāmabhogino, no ca khvassa upāsikā sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā brahmacāriniyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: celibate white-clothed laywomen,

root-pli-ms: upāsikā cassa sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā brahmacāriniyo, no ca khvassa upāsikā sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā kāmabhoginiyo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: white-clothed laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures. …

root-pli-ms: upāsikā cassa sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā kāmabhoginiyo, no ca khvassa brahmacariyaṁ hoti iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṁ bāhujaññaṁ puthubhūtaṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: There are white-clothed laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures, but the spiritual path is not successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans …

root-pli-ms: brahmacariyañcassa hoti iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṁ bāhujaññaṁ puthubhūtaṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ, no ca kho lābhaggayasaggappattaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, but it has not reached the peak of material possessions and fame.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ aparipūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: Then that spiritual path is incomplete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Yato ca kho, cunda, etehi ceva aṅgehi samannāgataṁ brahmacariyaṁ hoti, satthā ca hoti thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto, therā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.
translation-en-sujato: But when a spiritual path possesses those factors and the teacher is senior and there are competent senior monks,

root-pli-ms: Alaṁ samakkhātuṁ saddhammassa, alaṁ uppannaṁ parappavādaṁ sahadhammehi suniggahitaṁ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
Majjhimā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti …
translation-en-sujato: middle monks,

root-pli-ms: navā cassa bhikkhū sāvakā honti …
translation-en-sujato: junior monks,

root-pli-ms: therā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …
translation-en-sujato: senior nuns,

root-pli-ms: majjhimā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …
translation-en-sujato: middle nuns,

root-pli-ms: navā cassa bhikkhuniyo sāvikā honti …
translation-en-sujato: junior nuns,

root-pli-ms: upāsakā cassa sāvakā honti … gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino.
translation-en-sujato: celibate laymen,

translation-en-sujato: laymen enjoying sensual pleasures,

root-pli-ms: upāsikā cassa sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā brahmacāriniyo …
translation-en-sujato: celibate laywomen,

root-pli-ms: upāsikā cassa sāvikā honti gihiniyo odātavasanā kāmabhoginiyo …
translation-en-sujato: laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures,

root-pli-ms: brahmacariyañcassa hoti iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṁ bāhujaññaṁ puthubhūtaṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ, lābhaggappattañca yasaggappattañca.
translation-en-sujato: and the spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans, and it has reached the peak of material possessions and fame,

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ taṁ brahmacariyaṁ paripūraṁ hoti tenaṅgena.
translation-en-sujato: then that spiritual path is complete in that respect.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ kho pana, cunda, etarahi satthā loke uppanno arahaṁ sammāsambuddho.
translation-en-sujato: I, Cunda, am a teacher who has arisen in the world today, perfected and fully awakened.

root-pli-ms: Dhammo ca svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṁvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
translation-en-sujato: The teaching is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is fully awakened.

root-pli-ms: Viññāpitatthā ca me sāvakā saddhamme, kevalañca tesaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ āvikataṁ uttānīkataṁ sabbasaṅgāhapadakataṁ sappāṭihīrakataṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: My disciples have inquired about the meaning of that good teaching. And the spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure has been disclosed and revealed to them with all its collected sayings, with its demonstrable basis, well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Ahaṁ kho pana, cunda, etarahi satthā thero rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
translation-en-sujato: I am a teacher today who is senior, long standing, long gone forth, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life.

root-pli-ms: Santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi therā bhikkhū sāvakā honti viyattā vinītā visāradā pattayogakkhemā.
translation-en-sujato: I have today disciples who are competent senior monks,

root-pli-ms: Alaṁ samakkhātuṁ saddhammassa, alaṁ uppannaṁ parappavādaṁ sahadhammehi suniggahitaṁ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
Santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi majjhimā bhikkhū sāvakā …
translation-en-sujato: middle monks,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi navā bhikkhū sāvakā …
translation-en-sujato: junior monks,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi therā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā …
translation-en-sujato: senior nuns,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi majjhimā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā …
translation-en-sujato: middle nuns,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi navā bhikkhuniyo sāvikā …
translation-en-sujato: junior nuns,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi upāsakā sāvakā gihī odātavasanā brahmacārino …
translation-en-sujato: celibate laymen,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi upāsakā sāvakā gihī odātavasanā kāmabhogino …

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi upāsikā sāvikā gihiniyo odātavasanā brahmacāriniyo …
translation-en-sujato: celibate laywomen,

root-pli-ms: santi kho pana me, cunda, etarahi upāsikā sāvikā gihiniyo odātavasanā kāmabhoginiyo …
translation-en-sujato: and laywomen enjoying sensual pleasures.

root-pli-ms: etarahi kho pana me, cunda, brahmacariyaṁ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṁ bāhujaññaṁ puthubhūtaṁ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Today my spiritual life is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

root-pli-ms: Yāvatā kho, cunda, etarahi satthāro loke uppannā, nāhaṁ, cunda, aññaṁ ekasatthārampi samanupassāmi evaṁlābhaggayasaggappattaṁ yatharivāhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Of all the teachers in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the peak of material possessions and fame like me.

root-pli-ms: Yāvatā kho pana, cunda, etarahi saṅgho vā gaṇo vā loke uppanno;
translation-en-sujato: Of all the spiritual communities and groups in the world today, Cunda, I don’t see even a single one who has reached the pinnacle of material possessions and fame like the mendicant Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: nāhaṁ, cunda, aññaṁ ekasaṅghampi samanupassāmi evaṁlābhaggayasaggappattaṁ yatharivāyaṁ, cunda, bhikkhusaṅgho.
Yaṁ kho taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: And if there’s any spiritual path of which it may be rightly said that

root-pli-ms: ‘sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: it’s endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded,

root-pli-ms: Idameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: it’s of this spiritual path that this should be said.

root-pli-ms: ‘sabbākārasampannaṁ …pe… suppakāsitan’ti.
Udako sudaṁ, cunda, rāmaputto evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsati:
translation-en-sujato: Uddaka, son of Rāma, used to say:

root-pli-ms: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Seeing, one does not see.’

root-pli-ms: Kiñca passaṁ na passatīti?
translation-en-sujato: But seeing what does one not see?

root-pli-ms: Khurassa sādhunisitassa talamassa passati, dhārañca khvassa na passati.
translation-en-sujato: You can see the blade of a well-sharpened razor, but not the edge.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ vuccati:
translation-en-sujato: Thus it is said:

root-pli-ms: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Seeing, one does not see.’

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, udakena rāmaputtena bhāsitaṁ hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ khurameva sandhāya.
translation-en-sujato: But that saying of Uddaka’s is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless, as it’s only concerning a razor.

root-pli-ms: Yañca taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: If there’s anything of which it may be rightly said:

root-pli-ms: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti, idameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Seeing, one does not see,’ it’s of this that it should be said.

root-pli-ms: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti.
Kiñca passaṁ na passatīti?
translation-en-sujato: Seeing what does one not see?

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitanti, iti hetaṁ passati.
translation-en-sujato: One sees this: a spiritual path endowed with all good qualities, complete in all good qualities, neither too little nor too much, well explained, whole, full, and well propounded.
variant-pli-ms: paripūraṁ → parisuddhataraṁ (bj, sya-all, mr); paripūrataraṁ (?) | hetaṁ passati → na passatīti (sya-all, mr)

root-pli-ms: Idamettha apakaḍḍheyya, evaṁ taṁ parisuddhataraṁ assāti, iti hetaṁ na passati.
translation-en-sujato: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be removed, would make it purer.

root-pli-ms: Idamettha upakaḍḍheyya, evaṁ taṁ paripūraṁ assāti, iti hetaṁ na passati.
translation-en-sujato: One does not see this: anything that, were it to be added, would make it more complete.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ vuccati, cunda:
translation-en-sujato: Thus it is rightly said:

root-pli-ms: ‘passaṁ na passatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Seeing, one does not see.’

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho taṁ, cunda, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
‘sabbākārasampannaṁ …pe…
brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitan’ti.
Idameva taṁ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
‘sabbākārasampannaṁ sabbākāraparipūraṁ anūnamanadhikaṁ svākkhātaṁ kevalaṁ paripūraṁ brahmacariyaṁ suppakāsitan’ti.
6. Saṅgāyitabbadhamma
translation-en-sujato: 6. Teachings Should be Recited in Concert

root-pli-ms: Tasmātiha, cunda, ye vo mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, tattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: So, Cunda, you should all come together and recite in concert, without disputing, those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, comparing meaning with meaning and phrasing with phrasing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
reference: cck11.142, dr11.143, ms8D_355, msdiv177, ndp8.99, pts-cs17, pts-vp-pli3.128, sc22, sya11.140

root-pli-ms: Katame ca te, cunda, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā, yattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what are those things I have taught from my direct knowledge?

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅgā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
translation-en-sujato: They are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho te, cunda, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā.
translation-en-sujato: These are the things I have taught from my own direct knowledge.

root-pli-ms: Yattha sabbeheva saṅgamma samāgamma atthena atthaṁ byañjanena byañjanaṁ saṅgāyitabbaṁ na vivaditabbaṁ, yathayidaṁ brahmacariyaṁ addhaniyaṁ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṁ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
7. Saññāpetabbavidhi
translation-en-sujato: 7. Reaching Agreement

root-pli-ms: Tesañca vo, cunda, samaggānaṁ sammodamānānaṁ avivadamānānaṁ sikkhataṁ aññataro sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose one of those spiritual companions who is training in harmony and mutual appreciation, without fighting, were to recite the teaching in the Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: Tatra ce tumhākaṁ evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Now, you might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañceva micchā gaṇhāti, byañjanāni ca micchā ropetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This venerable misconstrues the meaning and mistakes the phrasing.’

root-pli-ms: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
translation-en-sujato: You should neither approve nor dismiss them, but say,

root-pli-ms: ‘imassa nu kho, āvuso, atthassa imāni vā byañjanāni etāni vā byañjanāni katamāni opāyikatarāni, imesañca byañjanānaṁ ayaṁ vā attho eso vā attho katamo opāyikataro’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverend, if this is the meaning, the phrasing may either be this or that: which is more fitting? And if this is the phrasing, the meaning may be either this or that: which is more fitting?’

root-pli-ms: So ce evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Suppose they reply,

root-pli-ms: ‘imassa kho, āvuso, atthassa imāneva byañjanāni opāyikatarāni, yā ceva etāni; imesañca byañjanānaṁ ayameva attho opāyikataro, yā ceva eso’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This phrasing fits the meaning better than that. And this meaning fits the phrasing better than that.’

root-pli-ms: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo, anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tassa ca atthassa tesañca byañjanānaṁ nisantiyā.
translation-en-sujato: Without flattering or rebuking them, you should carefully convince them by examining that meaning and that phrasing.

root-pli-ms: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose another spiritual companion were to recite the teaching in the Saṅgha.
reference: dr11.144, ms8D_357, msdiv179, ndp8.100, pts-cs19, pts-vp-pli3.129, sc24

root-pli-ms: Tatra ce tumhākaṁ evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Now, you might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañhi kho micchā gaṇhāti byañjanāni sammā ropetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This venerable misconstrues the meaning but gets the phrasing right.’

root-pli-ms: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ, anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
translation-en-sujato: You should neither approve nor dismiss them, but say,

root-pli-ms: ‘imesaṁ nu kho, āvuso, byañjanānaṁ ayaṁ vā attho eso vā attho katamo opāyikataro’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverend, if this is the phrasing, the meaning may be either this or that: which is more fitting?’

root-pli-ms: So ce evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Suppose they reply,

root-pli-ms: ‘imesaṁ kho, āvuso, byañjanānaṁ ayameva attho opāyikataro, yā ceva eso’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This meaning fits the phrasing better than that.’

root-pli-ms: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo, anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tasseva atthassa nisantiyā.
translation-en-sujato: Without flattering or rebuking, you should carefully convince them by examining that meaning.

root-pli-ms: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose another spiritual companion were to recite the teaching in the Saṅgha.
reference: cck11.144, ms8D_358, msdiv180, pts-cs20, sc25, sya11.142, vri3.96

root-pli-ms: Tatra ce tumhākaṁ evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Now, you might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañhi kho sammā gaṇhāti byañjanāni micchā ropetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This venerable construes the meaning correctly but mistakes the phrasing.’

root-pli-ms: Tassa neva abhinanditabbaṁ na paṭikkositabbaṁ; anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
translation-en-sujato: You should neither approve nor dismiss them, but say,

root-pli-ms: ‘imassa nu kho, āvuso, atthassa imāni vā byañjanāni etāni vā byañjanāni katamāni opāyikatarānī’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverend, if this is the meaning, the phrasing may be either this or that: which is more fitting?’

root-pli-ms: So ce evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Suppose they reply,

root-pli-ms: ‘imassa kho, āvuso, atthassa imāneva byañjanāni opayikatarāni, yā ceva etānī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This phrasing fits the meaning better than that.’

root-pli-ms: So neva ussādetabbo na apasādetabbo; anussādetvā anapasādetvā sveva sādhukaṁ saññāpetabbo tesaññeva byañjanānaṁ nisantiyā.
translation-en-sujato: Without flattering or rebuking, you should carefully convince them by examining that phrasing.

root-pli-ms: Aparopi ce, cunda, sabrahmacārī saṅghe dhammaṁ bhāseyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose another spiritual companion were to recite the teaching in the Saṅgha.
reference: csp1ed8.107, csp2ed8.107, dr11.145, ms8D_359, msdiv181, pts-cs21, sc26

root-pli-ms: Tatra ce tumhākaṁ evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Now, you might think,

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho āyasmā atthañceva sammā gaṇhāti byañjanāni ca sammā ropetī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This venerable construes the meaning correctly and gets the phrasing right.’

root-pli-ms: Tassa ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṁ abhinanditabbaṁ anumoditabbaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: Saying ‘Good!’ you should applaud and cheer that mendicant’s statement,

root-pli-ms: tassa ‘sādhū’ti bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā so evamassa vacanīyo:
translation-en-sujato: and then say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘lābhā no, āvuso, suladdhaṁ no, āvuso,
translation-en-sujato: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate

root-pli-ms: ye mayaṁ āyasmantaṁ tādisaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ passāma evaṁ atthupetaṁ byañjanupetan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: to see a venerable such as yourself, so well-versed in the meaning and the phrasing, as one of our spiritual companions!’

root-pli-ms: 8. Paccayānuññātakāraṇa
translation-en-sujato: 8. The Reasons for Allowing Requisites

root-pli-ms: Na vo ahaṁ, cunda, diṭṭhadhammikānaṁyeva āsavānaṁ saṁvarāya dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Cunda, I do not teach you solely for restraining defilements that affect the present life.
reference: bj9.216, cck11.145, ms8D_360, msdiv182, ndp8.101, pts-cs22, pts-vp-pli3.130, sc27, sya11.143

root-pli-ms: Na panāhaṁ, cunda, samparāyikānaṁyeva āsavānaṁ paṭighātāya dhammaṁ desemi.
translation-en-sujato: Nor do I teach solely for protecting against defilements that affect lives to come.

root-pli-ms: Diṭṭhadhammikānaṁ cevāhaṁ, cunda, āsavānaṁ saṁvarāya dhammaṁ desemi;
translation-en-sujato: I teach both for restraining defilements that affect the present life and

root-pli-ms: samparāyikānañca āsavānaṁ paṭighātāya.
translation-en-sujato: protecting against defilements that affect lives to come.

root-pli-ms: Tasmātiha, cunda, yaṁ vo mayā cīvaraṁ anuññātaṁ, alaṁ vo taṁ
translation-en-sujato: And that’s why I have allowed robes for you that suffice
comment-en-sujato: Both MW and RD have optative mod here, but it is not justified.

root-pli-ms: yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and for covering up the private parts.

root-pli-ms: Yo vo mayā piṇḍapāto anuññāto, alaṁ vo so
translation-en-sujato: I have allowed alms-food for you that suffices

root-pli-ms: yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro ca.
translation-en-sujato: only to continue and sustain this body, avoid harm, and support spiritual practice; so that you will put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and will keep on living blamelessly and at ease.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ vo mayā senāsanaṁ anuññātaṁ, alaṁ vo taṁ
translation-en-sujato: I have allowed lodgings for you that suffice

root-pli-ms: yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya, uṇhassa paṭighātāya, ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ paṭighātāya, yāvadeva utuparissayavinodanapaṭisallānārāmatthaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; to shelter from harsh weather and to enjoy retreat.

root-pli-ms: Yo vo mayā gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāro anuññāto, alaṁ vo so
translation-en-sujato: I have allowed medicines and supplies for the sick for you that suffice

root-pli-ms: yāvadeva uppannānaṁ veyyābādhikānaṁ vedanānaṁ paṭighātāya abyāpajjaparamatāya.
translation-en-sujato: only for the sake of warding off the pains of illness and to promote good health.

root-pli-ms: 9. Sukhallikānuyoga
translation-en-sujato: 9. Indulgence in Pleasure

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,
reference: csp1ed8.108, csp2ed8.108, dr11.146, ms8D_361, msdiv183, pts-cs23, sc28, vri3.97

root-pli-ms: ‘sukhallikānuyogamanuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure.’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘katamo so, āvuso, sukhallikānuyogo?
translation-en-sujato: ‘What is that indulgence in pleasure?

root-pli-ms: Sukhallikānuyogā hi bahū anekavihitā nānappakārakā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: For there are many different kinds of indulgence in pleasure.’

root-pli-ms: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
translation-en-sujato: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, Cunda, are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, cunda, ekacco bālo pāṇe vadhitvā vadhitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when some fool makes themselves happy and pleased by killing living creatures.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco adinnaṁ ādiyitvā ādiyitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by theft.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco musā bhaṇitvā bhaṇitvā attānaṁ sukheti pīṇeti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, someone makes themselves happy and pleased by lying.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, idhekacco pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, someone amuses themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure that are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’
comment-en-sujato: RD and MW phrase this as a question, which is unjustified.

root-pli-ms: Te vo ‘mā hevaṁ’ tissu vacanīyā.
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so!’

root-pli-ms: Na te vo sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṁ, abbhācikkheyyuṁ asatā abhūtena.
translation-en-sujato: It isn’t right to say that about you; it misrepresents you with an untruth.

root-pli-ms: Cattārome, cunda, sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
translation-en-sujato: These four kinds of indulgence in pleasure, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, cunda, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. It has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho sukhallikānuyogo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth kind of indulgence in pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, cunda, cattāro sukhallikānuyogā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four kinds of indulgence in pleasure which, when developed and cultivated, lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’

root-pli-ms: Te vo ‘evaṁ’ tissu vacanīyā.
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Exactly so!’

root-pli-ms: Sammā te vo vadamānā vadeyyuṁ, na te vo abbhācikkheyyuṁ asatā abhūtena.
translation-en-sujato: It’s right to say that about you; it doesn’t misrepresent you with an untruth.

root-pli-ms: 10. Sukhallikānuyogānisaṁsa
translation-en-sujato: 10. The Benefits of Indulgence in Pleasure

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime panāvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ kati phalāni katānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘How many fruits and benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ cattāri phalāni cattāro ānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, with the ending of three fetters a mendicant becomes a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ paṭhamaṁ phalaṁ, paṭhamo ānisaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first fruit and benefit.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—becomes a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ dutiyaṁ phalaṁ, dutiyo ānisaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: This is the second fruit and benefit.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcannaṁ orambhāgiyānaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, with the ending of the five lower fetters, a mendicant is reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ tatiyaṁ phalaṁ, tatiyo ānisaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: This is the third fruit and benefit.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and lives having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ catutthaṁ phalaṁ catuttho ānisaṁso.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth fruit and benefit.

root-pli-ms: Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro sukhallikānuyoge anuyuttānaṁ viharataṁ imāni cattāri phalāni, cattāro ānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: These four benefits may be expected by those who live indulging in pleasure in these four ways.’

root-pli-ms: 11. Khīṇāsavaabhabbaṭhāna
translation-en-sujato: 11. Things Impossible for the Perfected

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘aṭṭhitadhammā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā viharantī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetics who follow the Sakyan are inconsistent.’
comment-en-sujato: Both RD and MW take dhamma in (at)thitadhamma here as “doctrine”, but it is at AN 8.19 in the same context, but of the ocean, where it just means “stable”. Both places are glossed as ṭhitasabhāvā. Incidentally, the context here shows that PTS dict’s “eternal” for AN 8.19 is wrong.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṁ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṁ anatikkamanīyā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverends, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, indakhīlo vā ayokhīlo vā gambhīranemo sunikhāto acalo asampavedhī;
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a boundary pillar or an iron pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sāvakānaṁ dhammā desitā paññattā yāvajīvaṁ anatikkamanīyā.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, these things have been taught and pointed out for his disciples by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, not to be transgressed so long as life lasts.

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in nine respects.

root-pli-ms: Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādiyituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṁ kāme paribhuñjituṁ, seyyathāpi pubbe āgārikabhūto; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu chandāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu dosāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu mohāgatiṁ gantuṁ; abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu bhayāgatiṁ gantuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a lay person. And they can’t make decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, or cowardice.

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so imāni nava ṭhānāni ajjhācaritun’ti.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these nine respects.’

root-pli-ms: 12. Pañhābyākaraṇa
translation-en-sujato: 12. Questions and Answers

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘atītaṁ kho addhānaṁ ārabbha samaṇo gotamo atīrakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapeti, no ca kho anāgataṁ addhānaṁ ārabbha atīrakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapeti, tayidaṁ kiṁsu tayidaṁ kathaṁsū’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘The ascetic Gotama demonstrates boundless knowledge and vision of the past, but not of the future. What’s up with that?’

root-pli-ms: Te ca aññatitthiyā paribbājakā aññavihitakena ñāṇadassanena aññavihitakaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paññapetabbaṁ maññanti yathariva bālā abyattā.
translation-en-sujato: Those wanderers, like incompetent fools, seem to imagine that one kind of knowledge and vision can be demonstrated by means of another kind of knowledge and vision.

root-pli-ms: Atītaṁ kho, cunda, addhānaṁ ārabbha tathāgatassa satānusāriñāṇaṁ hoti;
translation-en-sujato: Regarding the past, the Realized One has knowledge stemming from memory.

root-pli-ms: so yāvatakaṁ ākaṅkhati tāvatakaṁ anussarati.
translation-en-sujato: He recollects as far as he wants.

root-pli-ms: Anāgatañca kho addhānaṁ ārabbha tathāgatassa bodhijaṁ ñāṇaṁ uppajjati:
translation-en-sujato: Regarding the future, the Realized One has the knowledge born of awakening:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is my last rebirth. Now there are no more future lives.’

root-pli-ms: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṁ atacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na taṁ tathāgato byākaroti.
translation-en-sujato: If a question about the past is untrue, false, and pointless, the Realized One does not reply.

root-pli-ms: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, tampi tathāgato na byākaroti.
translation-en-sujato: If a question about the past is true and substantive, but pointless, he does not reply.

root-pli-ms: Atītañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ, tatra kālaññū tathāgato hoti tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
translation-en-sujato: If a question about the past is true, substantive, and beneficial, he knows the right time to reply.

root-pli-ms: Anāgatañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṁ atacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na taṁ tathāgato byākaroti …pe… tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
translation-en-sujato: And the Realized One replies to questions about the future or the present in the same way.

root-pli-ms: Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti abhūtaṁ atacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na taṁ tathāgato byākaroti.
Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, tampi tathāgato na byākaroti.
Paccuppannañcepi, cunda, hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ, tatra kālaññū tathāgato hoti tassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
Iti kho, cunda, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu dhammesu tathāgato kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
translation-en-sujato: And so the Realized One has speech that’s well-timed, true, meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

root-pli-ms: Yañca kho, cunda, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṁ sutaṁ mutaṁ viññātaṁ pattaṁ pariyesitaṁ anuvicaritaṁ manasā, sabbaṁ tathāgatena abhisambuddhaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind, all that has been understood by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

root-pli-ms: Yañca, cunda, rattiṁ tathāgato anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṁ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, yaṁ etasmiṁ antare bhāsati lapati niddisati. Sabbaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti no aññathā,
translation-en-sujato: From the night when the Realized One understands the supreme perfect awakening until the night he becomes fully extinguished—through the natural principle of extinguishment, without anything left over—everything he speaks, says, and expresses is real, not otherwise.

root-pli-ms: tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

root-pli-ms: Yathāvādī, cunda, tathāgato tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
translation-en-sujato: The Realized One does as he says, and says as he does.

root-pli-ms: Iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Since this is so, that’s why he’s called the ‘Realized One’.

root-pli-ms: Sadevake loke, cunda, samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccati.
translation-en-sujato: In this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—the Realized One is the undefeated, the champion, the universal seer, the wielder of power.

root-pli-ms: 13. Abyākataṭṭhāna
translation-en-sujato: 13. The Undeclared Points

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,
reference: bj9.226, csp1ed8.112, csp2ed8.112, ms8D_380, msdiv189, pts-cs30, pts-vp-pli3.136, sc47, vri3.101

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Is this your view: “A Realized One exists after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly”?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘abyākataṁ kho etaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverend, this has not been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: “hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan”’ti.
Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The wanderers might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ panāvuso, na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly”?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘etampi kho, āvuso, bhagavatā abyākataṁ:
translation-en-sujato: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: “na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan”’ti.
Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The wanderers might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ panāvuso, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly”?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘abyākataṁ kho etaṁ, āvuso, bhagavatā:
translation-en-sujato: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan”’ti.
Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The wanderers might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ panāvuso, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Then is this your view: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly”?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘etampi kho, āvuso, bhagavatā abyākataṁ:
translation-en-sujato: ‘This too has not been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan”’ti.
Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The wanderers might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kasmā panetaṁ, āvuso, samaṇena gotamena abyākatan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But why has this not been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘na hetaṁ, āvuso, atthasaṁhitaṁ na dhammasaṁhitaṁ na ādibrahmacariyakaṁ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati, tasmā taṁ bhagavatā abyākatan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That’s why it hasn’t been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: 14. Byākataṭṭhāna
translation-en-sujato: 14. The Declared Points

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kiṁ panāvuso, samaṇena gotamena byākatan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But what has been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘idaṁ dukkhanti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākatan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘What has been declared by the Buddha is this: “This is suffering”—“This is the origin of suffering”—“This is the cessation of suffering”—“This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.”’

root-pli-ms: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: The wanderers might say,

root-pli-ms: ‘kasmā panetaṁ, āvuso, samaṇena gotamena byākatan’ti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘But why has this been declared by the ascetic Gotama?’

root-pli-ms: Evaṁvādino, cunda, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evamassu vacanīyā:
translation-en-sujato: You should say to them,

root-pli-ms: ‘etañhi, āvuso, atthasaṁhitaṁ, etaṁ dhammasaṁhitaṁ, etaṁ ādibrahmacariyakaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati. Tasmā taṁ bhagavatā byākatan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That’s why it has been declared by the Buddha.’

root-pli-ms: 15. Pubbantasahagatadiṭṭhinissaya
translation-en-sujato: 15. Views of the Past

root-pli-ms: Yepi te, cunda, pubbantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, tepi vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Cunda, I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the past.

root-pli-ms: Yathā ca te na byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te tathā byākarissāmi?
translation-en-sujato: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?
variant-pli-ms: tathā → tattha (bj, sya-all, mr) | byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te → kiṁ te ahante aññatitthiye (sya1ed, sya2ed); kiṁ no ahaṁ (pts1ed) | Yathā ca te na byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te tathā byākarissāmi → etthantare pāṭho si potthake natthi

root-pli-ms: Yepi te, cunda, aparantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, tepi vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: I have explained to you as they should be explained the views that some rely on regarding the future.

root-pli-ms: Yathā ca te na byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te tathā byākarissāmi?
translation-en-sujato: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?

root-pli-ms: Katame ca te, cunda, pubbantasahagatā diṭṭhinissayā, ye vo mayā byākatā, yathā te byākātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: What are the views that some rely on regarding the past?

root-pli-ms: Yathā ca te na byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te tathā byākarissāmi?
Santi kho, cunda, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
translation-en-sujato: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

root-pli-ms: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’

root-pli-ms: Santi pana, cunda, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
translation-en-sujato: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

root-pli-ms: ‘asassato attā ca loko ca …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘The self and the cosmos are not eternal,

root-pli-ms: sassato ca asassato ca attā ca loko ca …
translation-en-sujato: or both eternal and not eternal,

root-pli-ms: neva sassato nāsassato attā ca loko ca …
translation-en-sujato: or neither eternal nor not eternal.

root-pli-ms: sayaṅkato attā ca loko ca …
translation-en-sujato: The self and the cosmos are made by oneself,

root-pli-ms: paraṅkato attā ca loko ca …
translation-en-sujato: or made by another,

root-pli-ms: sayaṅkato ca paraṅkato ca attā ca loko ca …
translation-en-sujato: or made by both oneself and another,

root-pli-ms: asayaṅkāro aparaṅkāro adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: or they have arisen by chance, not made by oneself or another.

root-pli-ms: ‘Sassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: Pleasure and pain are eternal,

root-pli-ms: asassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: or not eternal,

root-pli-ms: sassatañca asassatañca sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: or both eternal and not eternal,

root-pli-ms: nevasassataṁ nāsassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: or neither eternal nor not eternal.

root-pli-ms: sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: Pleasure and pain are made by oneself,

root-pli-ms: paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: or made by another,

root-pli-ms: sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: or made by both oneself and another,

root-pli-ms: asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: or they have arisen by chance, not made by oneself or another. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’

root-pli-ms: Tatra, cunda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
translation-en-sujato: Regarding this, I go up to the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

root-pli-ms: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: the self and the cosmos are eternal,

root-pli-ms: Tyāhaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: and say,

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi nu kho idaṁ, āvuso, vuccati:
translation-en-sujato: ‘Reverends, is this what you say,

root-pli-ms: “sassato attā ca loko cā”’ti?
translation-en-sujato: “The self and the cosmos are eternal”?’

root-pli-ms: Yañca kho te evamāhaṁsu:
translation-en-sujato: But when they say, ‘Yes!

root-pli-ms: ‘idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: This is the only truth, other ideas are silly,’

root-pli-ms: Taṁ tesaṁ nānujānāmi.
translation-en-sujato: I don’t acknowledge that.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kissa hetu?
translation-en-sujato: Why is that?

root-pli-ms: Aññathāsaññinopi hettha, cunda, santeke sattā.
translation-en-sujato: Because there are beings who have different opinions on this topic.

root-pli-ms: Imāyapi kho ahaṁ, cunda, paññattiyā neva attanā samasamaṁ samanupassāmi kuto bhiyyo.
translation-en-sujato: I don’t see any such expositions that are equal to my own, still less superior.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo yadidaṁ adhipaññatti.
translation-en-sujato: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher exposition.

root-pli-ms: Tatra, cunda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
translation-en-sujato: Regarding this, I go up to the ascetics and brahmins who assert all the other views as described above.

translation-en-sujato: These are the views that some rely on regarding the future, which I have explained to you as they should be explained.

root-pli-ms: Yathā ca te na byākātabbā, kiṁ vo ahaṁ te tathā byākarissāmi?
translation-en-sujato: Shall I explain them to you in the wrong way?

root-pli-ms: Imesañca, cunda, pubbantasahagatānaṁ diṭṭhinissayānaṁ imesañca aparantasahagatānaṁ diṭṭhinissayānaṁ pahānāya samatikkamāya evaṁ mayā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā desitā paññattā.
translation-en-sujato: I have taught and pointed out the four kinds of mindfulness meditation for giving up and going beyond all these views of the past and the future.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, cunda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Vedanāsu vedanānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

root-pli-ms: citte cittānupassī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: mind …

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Imesañca, cunda, pubbantasahagatānaṁ diṭṭhinissayānaṁ imesañca aparantasahagatānaṁ diṭṭhinissayānaṁ pahānāya samatikkamāya. Evaṁ mayā ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā desitā paññattā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation that I have taught for giving up and going beyond all these views of the past and the future.”

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṁ bījayamāno.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time Venerable Upavāṇa was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: He said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!

root-pli-ms: Pāsādiko vatāyaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo;
translation-en-sujato: This exposition of the teaching is impressive, sir,

root-pli-ms: supāsādiko vatāyaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo, ko nāmāyaṁ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo”ti?
translation-en-sujato: it is very impressive. Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”

root-pli-ms: “Tasmātiha tvaṁ, upavāṇa, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ ‘pāsādiko’ tveva naṁ dhārehī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well, Upavāṇa, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Impressive Discourse’.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamano āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, Venerable Upavāṇa was happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Pāsādikasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 30
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 30

root-pli-ms: Lakkhaṇasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Marks of a Great Man

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

root-pli-ms: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

root-pli-ms: “bhikkhavo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants!”

root-pli-ms: “Bhaddante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:

root-pli-ms: “Dvattiṁsimāni, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā.
translation-en-sujato: “There are thirty-two marks of a great man. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

root-pli-ms: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti;
translation-en-sujato: He has the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

root-pli-ms: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
translation-en-sujato: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.

root-pli-ms: Katamāni ca tāni, bhikkhave, dvattiṁsa mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā?
translation-en-sujato: And what are the thirty-two marks?

root-pli-ms: Sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
Idha, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: He has well-planted feet.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni. Yampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa heṭṭhāpādatalesu cakkāni jātāni honti sahassārāni sanemikāni sanābhikāni sabbākāraparipūrāni, idampi, bhikkhave, mahāpurisassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ bhavati.
translation-en-sujato: On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, mahāpuriso āyatapaṇhi hoti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: He has projecting heels.

root-pli-ms: dīghaṅguli hoti …
translation-en-sujato: He has long fingers.

root-pli-ms: mudutalunahatthapādo hoti …
translation-en-sujato: His hands and feet are tender.

root-pli-ms: jālahatthapādo hoti …
translation-en-sujato: His hands and feet cling gracefully.

root-pli-ms: ussaṅkhapādo hoti …
translation-en-sujato: His feet are arched.

root-pli-ms: eṇijaṅgho hoti …
translation-en-sujato: His calves are like those of an antelope.

root-pli-ms: ṭhitakova anonamanto ubhohi pāṇitalehi jaṇṇukāni parimasati parimajjati …
translation-en-sujato: When standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.

root-pli-ms: kosohitavatthaguyho hoti …
translation-en-sujato: His private parts are retracted.

root-pli-ms: suvaṇṇavaṇṇo hoti kañcanasannibhattaco …
translation-en-sujato: He is gold colored; his skin has a golden sheen.

root-pli-ms: sukhumacchavi hoti, sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṁ kāye na upalimpati …
translation-en-sujato: He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.

root-pli-ms: Yampi, bhikkhave, tathāgato purimaṁ jātiṁ purimaṁ bhavaṁ purimaṁ niketaṁ pubbe manussabhūto samāno daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu, avatthitasamādāno kāyasucarite vacīsucarite manosucarite dānasaṁvibhāge sīlasamādāne uposathupavāse matteyyatāya petteyyatāya sāmaññatāya brahmaññatāya kule jeṭṭhāpacāyitāya aññataraññataresu ca adhikusalesu dhammesu.
translation-en-sujato: In some past lives, past existences, past abodes the Realized One was reborn as a human being. He firmly undertook and persisted in skillful behaviors such as good conduct by way of body, speech, giving and sharing, taking precepts, observing the sabbath, paying due respect to mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in the family, and various other things pertaining to skillful behaviors.
reference: cck11.161, dr11.163, ms8D_407, msdiv201, pts-cs1.4, pts-vp-pli3.146, sc10, sya11.160

root-pli-ms: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
translation-en-sujato: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

root-pli-ms: So tattha aññe deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhiggaṇhāti dibbena āyunā dibbena vaṇṇena dibbena sukhena dibbena yasena dibbena ādhipateyyena dibbehi rūpehi dibbehi saddehi dibbehi gandhehi dibbehi rasehi dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
translation-en-sujato: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: divine life span, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

root-pli-ms: So tato cuto itthattaṁ āgato samāno imaṁ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ paṭilabhati.
translation-en-sujato: When he passed away from there and came back to this state of existence he obtained this mark of a great man:

root-pli-ms: Suppatiṭṭhitapādo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: he has well-planted feet.

root-pli-ms: Samaṁ pādaṁ bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipati, samaṁ uddharati, samaṁ sabbāvantehi pādatalehi bhūmiṁ phusati.
translation-en-sujato: He places his foot on the ground evenly, raises it evenly, and touches the ground evenly with the whole sole of his foot.

root-pli-ms: So tena lakkhaṇena samannāgato sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: Possessing this mark, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti;
translation-en-sujato: He has the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṁ iddhaṁ phītaṁ khemaṁ sivaṁ nirabbudaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and untroubled—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.

root-pli-ms: Rājā samāno kiṁ labhati?
translation-en-sujato: And what does he obtain as king?

root-pli-ms: Akkhambhiyo hoti kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena paccāmittena.

root-pli-ms: Rājā samāno idaṁ labhati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s what he obtains as king.

root-pli-ms: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
translation-en-sujato: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.

root-pli-ms: Buddho samāno kiṁ labhati?
translation-en-sujato: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

root-pli-ms: Akkhambhiyo hoti abbhantarehi vā bāhirehi vā paccatthikehi paccāmittehi rāgena vā dosena vā mohena vā samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: He can’t be stopped by any foe or enemy whether internal or external; nor by greed, hate, or delusion; nor by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.

root-pli-ms: Buddho samāno idaṁ labhati”.

root-pli-ms: So tena kammena divaṁ samakkami,

translation-en-sujato: Due to performing those deeds he was reborn in a heavenly realm.

root-pli-ms: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.

root-pli-ms: rājā samāno kiṁ labhati?
translation-en-sujato: And what does he obtain as king?

translation-en-sujato: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in wealth and grain, fields and land, birds and beasts, children and partners; in bondservants, workers, and staff; in family, friends, and kin. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.

root-pli-ms: Rājā samāno idaṁ labhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: That’s what he obtains as king.

root-pli-ms: buddho samāno kiṁ labhati?
translation-en-sujato: And what does he obtain as Buddha?

root-pli-ms: Aparihānadhammo hoti, na parihāyati saddhāya sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya, na parihāyati sabbasampattiyā.
translation-en-sujato: He’s not liable to decline. He doesn’t decline in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. He doesn’t decline in any of his accomplishments.
comment-en-sujato: Note dhamma is absent here, but present both above and below in verse.

root-pli-ms: Buddho samāno idaṁ labhati”.

root-pli-ms: Puttehi dārehi catuppadehi ca.

root-pli-ms: Ñātīhi mittehi ca bandhavehi ca,
translation-en-sujato: in children, partners, and livestock,

root-pli-ms: Balena vaṇṇena sukhena cūbhayaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: in family, friends, and kin,

root-pli-ms: Kathaṁ na hāyeyyuṁ pareti icchati,

root-pli-ms: micchājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṁ kappesi, tulākūṭakaṁsakūṭamānakūṭaukkoṭanavañcananikatisāciyogachedanavadhabandhanaviparāmosaālopasahasākārā paṭivirato ahosi.
translation-en-sujato: He gave up wrong livelihood and earned a living by right livelihood. He refrained from falsifying weights, metals, or measures; bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity; mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

root-pli-ms: So tassa kammassa kaṭattā upacitattā ussannattā vipulattā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
translation-en-sujato: Due to performing, accumulating, heaping up, and amassing those deeds, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

root-pli-ms: So tattha aññe deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti dibbena āyunā dibbena vaṇṇena dibbena sukhena dibbena yasena dibbena ādhipateyyena dibbehi rūpehi dibbehi saddehi dibbehi gandhehi dibbehi rasehi dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
translation-en-sujato: There he surpassed the other gods in ten respects: divine life span, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

root-pli-ms: So tato cuto itthattaṁ āgato samāno imāni dve mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni paṭilabhati, samadanto ca hoti susukkadāṭho ca.
translation-en-sujato: When he came back to this state of existence he obtained these two marks: his teeth are even and perfectly white.

root-pli-ms: So tehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato sace agāraṁ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
translation-en-sujato: Possessing these marks, if he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.

root-pli-ms: Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: He has the following seven treasures:

root-pli-ms: cakkaratanaṁ hatthiratanaṁ assaratanaṁ maṇiratanaṁ itthiratanaṁ gahapatiratanaṁ pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.

root-pli-ms: Parosahassaṁ kho panassa puttā bhavanti sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
translation-en-sujato: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ pathaviṁ sāgarapariyantaṁ akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakaṁ iddhaṁ phītaṁ khemaṁ sivaṁ nirabbudaṁ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati.
translation-en-sujato: After conquering this land girt by sea—free of harassment by bandits, successful and prosperous, safe, blessed, and untroubled—he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
comment-en-sujato: Comm: Akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakanti niccoraṁ. Corā hi kharasamphassaṭṭhena khilā, upaddavapaccayaṭṭhena nimittā, vijjhanaṭṭhena kaṇṭakāti vuccanti. It’s possible that, as per RD, and partly MW, this refers to physical characteristics of the land, but in this instance I think comm is more plausible. We don’t expect a king to eliminate all rough terrain, but we do expect him to quell banditry.

root-pli-ms: Rājā samāno kiṁ labhati?
translation-en-sujato: And what does he obtain as king?

root-pli-ms: Suciparivāro hoti sucissa honti parivārā brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamajānapadā gaṇakamahāmattā anīkaṭṭhā dovārikā amaccā pārisajjā rājāno bhogiyā kumārā.
translation-en-sujato: His retinue is pure. This includes brahmins and householders, people of town and country, treasury officials, military officers, guardsmen, ministers, counselors, rulers, tax beneficiaries, and princes.

root-pli-ms: Rājā samāno idaṁ labhati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s what he obtains as king.

root-pli-ms: Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati, arahaṁ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado.
translation-en-sujato: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.
