translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Kāyagatāsati sātasahagatā.
translation-en-sujato: Mindfulness of the body that is full of pleasure.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo bhāvetabbo. (2)
Katamo eko dhammo pariññeyyo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Phasso sāsavo upādāniyo.
translation-en-sujato: Contact, which is accompanied by defilements and is prone to being grasped.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo pariññeyyo. (3)
Katamo eko dhammo pahātabbo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Asmimāno.
translation-en-sujato: The conceit ‘I am’.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo pahātabbo. (4)
Katamo eko dhammo hānabhāgiyo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing makes things worse?

root-pli-ms: Ayoniso manasikāro.
translation-en-sujato: Improper attention.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo hānabhāgiyo. (5)
Katamo eko dhammo visesabhāgiyo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing leads to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Yoniso manasikāro.
translation-en-sujato: Proper attention.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo visesabhāgiyo. (6)
Katamo eko dhammo duppaṭivijjho?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing is hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Ānantariko cetosamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: The heart’s immersion of immediate result.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo duppaṭivijjho. (7)
Katamo eko dhammo uppādetabbo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Akuppaṁ ñāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Unshakable knowledge.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo uppādetabbo. (8)
Katamo eko dhammo abhiññeyyo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā.
translation-en-sujato: All sentient beings are sustained by food.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo abhiññeyyo. (9)
Katamo eko dhammo sacchikātabbo?
translation-en-sujato: What one thing should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Akuppā cetovimutti.
translation-en-sujato: The unshakable heart’s release.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ eko dhammo sacchikātabbo. (10)
Iti ime dasa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these ten things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 2. Dve dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 2. Groups of Two

root-pli-ms: Dve dhammā bahukārā, dve dhammā bhāvetabbā, dve dhammā pariññeyyā, dve dhammā pahātabbā, dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā, dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā, dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā, dve dhammā uppādetabbā, dve dhammā abhiññeyyā, dve dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Two things are helpful, two things should be developed, two things should be completely understood, two things should be given up, two things make things worse, two things lead to distinction, two things are hard to comprehend, two things should be produced, two things should be directly known, two things should be realized.
reference: ms8D_1148, msdiv352, pts-cs1.3, sc15, sya11.290, vri3.219

root-pli-ms: Katame dve dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Sati ca sampajaññañca.
translation-en-sujato: Mindfulness and situational awareness.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame dve dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Samatho ca vipassanā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Serenity and discernment.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame dve dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Nāmañca rūpañca.
translation-en-sujato: Name and form.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame dve dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Avijjā ca bhavataṇhā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Dovacassatā ca pāpamittatā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Being hard to admonish and having bad friends.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Sovacassatā ca kalyāṇamittatā ca.
translation-en-sujato: Being easy to admonish and having good friends.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṁ saṅkilesāya, yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā.
translation-en-sujato: What are the causes and conditions for the corruption of sentient beings, and what are the causes and conditions for the purification of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7)
Katame dve dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Dve ñāṇāni—
translation-en-sujato: Two knowledges:

root-pli-ms: khaye ñāṇaṁ, anuppāde ñāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: knowledge of ending, and knowledge of non-arising.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame dve dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Dve dhātuyo—
translation-en-sujato: Two elements:

root-pli-ms: saṅkhatā ca dhātu asaṅkhatā ca dhātu.
translation-en-sujato: the conditioned element and the unconditioned element.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame dve dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What two things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Vijjā ca vimutti ca.
translation-en-sujato: Knowledge and freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime dve dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime vīsati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these twenty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 3. Tayo dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 3. Groups of Three

root-pli-ms: Tayo dhammā bahukārā, tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… tayo dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Three things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame tayo dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Sappurisasaṁsevo, saddhammassavanaṁ, dhammānudhammappaṭipatti.
translation-en-sujato: Associating with good people, listening to the true teaching, and practicing in line with the teaching.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Tayo samādhī—
translation-en-sujato: Three kinds of immersion.

root-pli-ms: savitakko savicāro samādhi, avitakko vicāramatto samādhi, avitakko avicāro samādhi.
translation-en-sujato: Immersion with placing the mind and keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind, but just keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind or keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame tayo dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Tisso vedanā—
translation-en-sujato: Three feelings:

root-pli-ms: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
translation-en-sujato: pleasant, painful, and neutral.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame tayo dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Tisso taṇhā—
translation-en-sujato: Three cravings:

root-pli-ms: kāmataṇhā, bhavataṇhā, vibhavataṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame tayo dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Tīṇi akusalamūlāni—
translation-en-sujato: Three unskillful roots:

root-pli-ms: lobho akusalamūlaṁ, doso akusalamūlaṁ, moho akusalamūlaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: greed, hate, and delusion.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame tayo dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Tīṇi kusalamūlāni—
translation-en-sujato: Three skillful roots:

root-pli-ms: alobho kusalamūlaṁ, adoso kusalamūlaṁ, amoho kusalamūlaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame tayo dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Tisso nissaraṇiyā dhātuyo—
translation-en-sujato: Three elements of escape.

root-pli-ms: kāmānametaṁ nissaraṇaṁ yadidaṁ nekkhammaṁ, rūpānametaṁ nissaraṇaṁ yadidaṁ arūpaṁ, yaṁ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ, nirodho tassa nissaraṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Renunciation is the escape from sensual pleasures. The formless is the escape from form. Cessation is the escape from whatever is created, conditioned, and dependently originated.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7)
Katame tayo dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Tīṇi ñāṇāni—
translation-en-sujato: Three knowledges:

root-pli-ms: atītaṁse ñāṇaṁ, anāgataṁse ñāṇaṁ, paccuppannaṁse ñāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: regarding the past, future, and present.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame tayo dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Tisso dhātuyo—
translation-en-sujato: Three elements:

root-pli-ms: kāmadhātu, rūpadhātu, arūpadhātu.
translation-en-sujato: sensuality, form, and formlessness.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame tayo dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What three things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Tisso vijjā—
translation-en-sujato: Three knowledges:

root-pli-ms: pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṁ vijjā, sattānaṁ cutūpapāte ñāṇaṁ vijjā, āsavānaṁ khaye ñāṇaṁ vijjā.
translation-en-sujato: recollection of past lives, knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, and knowledge of the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: Ime tayo dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime tiṁsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these thirty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 4. Cattāro dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 4. Groups of Four

root-pli-ms: Cattāro dhammā bahukārā, cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Four things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Cattāri cakkāni—
translation-en-sujato: Four situations:

root-pli-ms: patirūpadesavāso, sappurisūpanissayo, attasammāpaṇidhi, pubbe ca katapuññatā.
translation-en-sujato: living in a suitable region, relying on good people, being rightly resolved in oneself, and past merit.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā—
translation-en-sujato: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Vedanāsu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

root-pli-ms: citte …
translation-en-sujato: mind …

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame cattāro dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro āhārā—
translation-en-sujato: Four foods:

root-pli-ms: kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṁ catutthaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: solid food, whether coarse or fine; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame cattāro dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro oghā—
translation-en-sujato: Four floods:

root-pli-ms: kāmogho, bhavogho, diṭṭhogho, avijjogho.
translation-en-sujato: sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame cattāro dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro yogā—
translation-en-sujato: Four bonds:

root-pli-ms: kāmayogo, bhavayogo, diṭṭhiyogo, avijjāyogo.
translation-en-sujato: sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame cattāro dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro visaṁyogā—
translation-en-sujato: Four kinds of detachment:

root-pli-ms: kāmayogavisaṁyogo, bhavayogavisaṁyogo, diṭṭhiyogavisaṁyogo, avijjāyogavisaṁyogo.
translation-en-sujato: detachment from the bonds of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame cattāro dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Cattāro samādhī—
translation-en-sujato: Four kinds of immersion:

root-pli-ms: hānabhāgiyo samādhi, ṭhitibhāgiyo samādhi, visesabhāgiyo samādhi, nibbedhabhāgiyo samādhi.
translation-en-sujato: immersion liable to decline, stable immersion, immersion that leads to distinction, and immersion that leads to penetration.
comment-en-sujato: In my view, this is almost certainly a mistake. Four sannas are more plausibly described in this way at AN 4.179. The sanskrit text at SF 107 has the four noble truths, which makes much more sense.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7)
Katame cattāro dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Cattāri ñāṇāni—
translation-en-sujato: Four knowledges:

root-pli-ms: dhamme ñāṇaṁ, anvaye ñāṇaṁ, pariye ñāṇaṁ, sammutiyā ñāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: knowledge of the present phenomena, inferential knowledge, knowledge of others’ minds, and conventional knowledge.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame cattāro dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Cattāri ariyasaccāni—
translation-en-sujato: The four noble truths:

root-pli-ms: dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What four things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Cattāri sāmaññaphalāni—
translation-en-sujato: Four fruits of the ascetic life:

root-pli-ms: sotāpattiphalaṁ, sakadāgāmiphalaṁ, anāgāmiphalaṁ, arahattaphalaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

root-pli-ms: Ime cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime cattārīsadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these forty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 5. Pañca dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 5. Groups of Five

root-pli-ms: Pañca dhammā bahukārā …pe… pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Five things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame pañca dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Pañca padhāniyaṅgāni—
translation-en-sujato: Five factors that support meditation.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṁ:
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

root-pli-ms: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

root-pli-ms: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
translation-en-sujato: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

root-pli-ms: Asaṭho hoti amāyāvī yathābhūtamattānaṁ āvīkattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
translation-en-sujato: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

root-pli-ms: Āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
translation-en-sujato: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

root-pli-ms: Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
translation-en-sujato: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Pañcaṅgiko sammāsamādhi—
translation-en-sujato: Right immersion with five factors:

root-pli-ms: pītipharaṇatā, sukhapharaṇatā, cetopharaṇatā, ālokapharaṇatā, paccavekkhaṇanimittaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: pervaded with rapture, pervaded with pleasure, pervaded with mind, pervaded with light, and the foundation for reviewing.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame pañca dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Pañcupādānakkhandhā—
translation-en-sujato: Five grasping aggregates:

root-pli-ms: rūpupādānakkhandho, vedanupādānakkhandho, saññupādānakkhandho, saṅkhārupādānakkhandho viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
translation-en-sujato: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame pañca dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Pañca nīvaraṇāni—
translation-en-sujato: Five hindrances:

root-pli-ms: kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṁ, byāpādanīvaraṇaṁ, thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṁ, uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇaṁ, vicikicchānīvaraṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame pañca dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Pañca cetokhilā—
translation-en-sujato: Five kinds of emotional barrenness.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
translation-en-sujato: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

root-pli-ms: Yassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
Ayaṁ paṭhamo cetokhilo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

root-pli-ms: saṅghe kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: the Saṅgha …

root-pli-ms: sikkhāya kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: the training …

root-pli-ms: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

root-pli-ms: Yassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
translation-en-sujato: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamo cetokhilo.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame pañca dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Pañcindriyāni—
translation-en-sujato: Five faculties:

root-pli-ms: saddhindriyaṁ, vīriyindriyaṁ, satindriyaṁ, samādhindriyaṁ, paññindriyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame pañca dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Pañca nissaraṇiyā dhātuyo—
translation-en-sujato: Five elements of escape.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāme manasikaroto kāmesu cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant focuses on sensual pleasures, but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided about them.

root-pli-ms: Nekkhammaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: But when they focus on renunciation, their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided about it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ kāmehi.
translation-en-sujato: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from sensual pleasures.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca kāmapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of sensual pleasures, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

root-pli-ms: Idamakkhātaṁ kāmānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ. (7.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is how the escape from sensual pleasures is explained.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno byāpādaṁ manasikaroto byāpāde cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on ill will, but their mind isn’t eager …

root-pli-ms: Abyāpādaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto abyāpāde cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: But when they focus on good will, their mind is eager …

root-pli-ms: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ byāpādena.
translation-en-sujato: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from ill will.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca byāpādapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of ill will, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

root-pli-ms: Idamakkhātaṁ byāpādassa nissaraṇaṁ. (7.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is how the escape from ill will is explained.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno vihesaṁ manasikaroto vihesāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on harming, but their mind isn’t eager …

root-pli-ms: Avihesaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto avihesāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: But when they focus on compassion, their mind is eager …

root-pli-ms: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ vihesāya.
translation-en-sujato: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from harming.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca vihesāpaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of harming, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

root-pli-ms: Idamakkhātaṁ vihesāya nissaraṇaṁ. (7.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is how the escape from harming is explained.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno rūpe manasikaroto rūpesu cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on form, but their mind isn’t eager …

root-pli-ms: Arūpaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto arūpe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: But when they focus on the formless, their mind is eager …

root-pli-ms: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ rūpehi.
translation-en-sujato: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from forms.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca rūpapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of form, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

root-pli-ms: Idamakkhātaṁ rūpānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ. (7.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is how the escape from forms is explained.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno sakkāyaṁ manasikaroto sakkāye cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on identity, but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided about it.

root-pli-ms: Sakkāyanirodhaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: But when they focus on the ending of identity, their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided about it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ sakkāyena.
translation-en-sujato: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from identity.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca sakkāyapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of identity, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

root-pli-ms: Idamakkhātaṁ sakkāyassa nissaraṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is how the escape from identity is explained.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7.5)
Katame pañca dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Pañca ñāṇiko sammāsamādhi:
translation-en-sujato: Right immersion with five knowledges.

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ samādhi paccuppannasukho ceva āyatiñca sukhavipāko’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: The following knowledges arise for you personally: ‘This immersion is blissful now, and results in bliss in the future.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ samādhi ariyo nirāmiso’ti paccattaññeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This immersion is noble and spiritual.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ samādhi akāpurisasevito’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This immersion is not cultivated by sinners.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Ayaṁ samādhi santo paṇīto paṭippassaddhaladdho ekodibhāvādhigato, na sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This immersion is peaceful and sublime and tranquil and unified, not held in place by forceful suppression.’

root-pli-ms: ‘So kho panāhaṁ imaṁ samādhiṁ satova samāpajjāmi sato vuṭṭhahāmī’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I mindfully enter into and emerge from this immersion.’

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame pañca dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Pañca vimuttāyatanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Five opportunities for freedom.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṁ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī.
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
translation-en-sujato: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ paṭhamaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ. (9.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first opportunity for freedom.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, api ca kho yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
translation-en-sujato: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they teach it in detail to others as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ dutiyaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ. (9.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second opportunity for freedom.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti. Api ca kho yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma. But the mendicant recites the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
translation-en-sujato: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they recite it in detail as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ tatiyaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ. (9.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third opportunity for freedom.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant recite the teaching.

root-pli-ms: Api ca kho yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati.
translation-en-sujato: But the mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
translation-en-sujato: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how they think about and consider it in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.

root-pli-ms: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ catutthaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ. (9.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth opportunity for freedom.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati;
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor … the mendicant teaches Dhamma … nor does the mendicant recite the teaching … or think about it.

root-pli-ms: api ca khvassa aññataraṁ samādhinimittaṁ suggahitaṁ hoti sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritaṁ suppaṭividdhaṁ paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: But a meditation subject as a foundation of immersion is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno aññataraṁ samādhinimittaṁ suggahitaṁ hoti sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritaṁ suppaṭividdhaṁ paññāya tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammappaṭisaṁvedī ca.
translation-en-sujato: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how a meditation subject as a foundation of immersion is properly grasped, attended, borne in mind, and comprehended with wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammappaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ pañcamaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth opportunity for freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9.5)
Katame pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What five things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Pañca dhammakkhandhā—
translation-en-sujato: Five spectrums of the teaching:

root-pli-ms: sīlakkhandho, samādhikkhandho, paññākkhandho, vimuttikkhandho, vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandho.
translation-en-sujato: ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime paññāsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these fifty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 6. Cha dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 6. Groups of Six

root-pli-ms: Cha dhammā bahukārā …pe… cha dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Six things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame cha dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things are helpful?
reference: csp1ed8.237, csp2ed8.237, ms8D_1209, ndp8.219, pts-vp-pli3.280, sc72

root-pli-ms: Cha sāraṇīyā dhammā.
translation-en-sujato: Six warm-hearted qualities.

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca,
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.

root-pli-ms: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati. (1.1)
translation-en-sujato: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati. (1.2)
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ manokammaṁ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati. (1.3)
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi, tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati. (1.4)
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu, yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati. (1.5)
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca,
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

root-pli-ms: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo, saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
translation-en-sujato: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā bahukārā. (1.6)
Katame cha dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Cha anussatiṭṭhānāni—
translation-en-sujato: Six recollections:

root-pli-ms: buddhānussati, dhammānussati, saṅghānussati, sīlānussati, cāgānussati, devatānussati.
translation-en-sujato: the recollection of the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, ethics, generosity, and the deities.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame cha dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Six interior sense fields:

root-pli-ms: cakkhāyatanaṁ, sotāyatanaṁ, ghānāyatanaṁ, jivhāyatanaṁ, kāyāyatanaṁ, manāyatanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame cha dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Cha taṇhākāyā—
translation-en-sujato: Six classes of craving:

root-pli-ms: rūpataṇhā, saddataṇhā, gandhataṇhā, rasataṇhā, phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, dhammataṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame cha dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Cha agāravā—
translation-en-sujato: Six kinds of disrespect.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre agāravo viharati appatisso.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame cha dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Cha gāravā—
translation-en-sujato: Six kinds of respect.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari sagāravo viharati sappatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre sagāravo viharati sappatisso.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant has respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame cha dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Cha nissaraṇiyā dhātuyo—
translation-en-sujato: Six elements of escape.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take a mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘mettā hi kho me, cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by love. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana me byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow ill will still occupies my mind.’

root-pli-ms: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhānametaṁ āvuso anavakāso yaṁ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya.
translation-en-sujato: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the heart’s release by love has been developed and properly implemented,

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
translation-en-sujato: yet somehow ill will still occupies the mind.

root-pli-ms: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṁ mettācetovimuttī’ti. (7.1)
translation-en-sujato: For it is the heart’s release by love that is the escape from ill will.’

root-pli-ms: Idha panāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take another mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by compassion. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

root-pli-ms: Atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow the thought of harming still occupies my mind.’

root-pli-ms: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo, ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

root-pli-ms: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vihesāya, yadidaṁ karuṇācetovimuttī’ti. (7.2)
translation-en-sujato: For it is the heart’s release by compassion that is the escape from thoughts of harming.’

root-pli-ms: Idha panāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take another mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘muditā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by rejoicing. …

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana me arati cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow negativity still occupies my mind.’

root-pli-ms: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

root-pli-ms: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, aratiyā, yadidaṁ muditācetovimuttī’ti. (7.3)
translation-en-sujato: For it is the heart’s release by rejoicing that is the escape from negativity.’

root-pli-ms: Idha panāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take another mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘upekkhā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by equanimity. …

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow desire still occupies my mind.’

root-pli-ms: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

root-pli-ms: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, rāgassa yadidaṁ upekkhācetovimuttī’ti. (7.4)
translation-en-sujato: For it is the heart’s release by equanimity that is the escape from desire.’

root-pli-ms: Idha panāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take another mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘animittā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve developed the signless heart’s release. …

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ hotī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow my consciousness still follows after signs.’

root-pli-ms: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

root-pli-ms: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṁ yadidaṁ animittā cetovimuttī’ti. (7.5)
translation-en-sujato: For it is the signless release of the heart that is the escape from all signs.’

root-pli-ms: Idha panāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:
translation-en-sujato: Take another mendicant who says:

root-pli-ms: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṁ, ayamahamasmīti na samanupassāmi,
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’m rid of the conceit “I am”. And I don’t regard anything as “I am this”.

root-pli-ms: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies my mind.’

root-pli-ms: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
translation-en-sujato: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti asamanupassato.
translation-en-sujato: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the conceit “I am” has been done away with, and nothing is regarded as “I am this”,

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
translation-en-sujato: yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupy the mind.

root-pli-ms: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa, yadidaṁ asmimānasamugghāto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: For it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am” that is the escape from the dart of doubt and indecision.’

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7.6)
Katame cha dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Cha satatavihārā.
translation-en-sujato: Six consistent responses.

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

root-pli-ms: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Hearing a sound with their ears …

root-pli-ms: ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Smelling an odor with their nose …

root-pli-ms: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …

root-pli-ms: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Feeling a touch with their body …

root-pli-ms: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
translation-en-sujato: Knowing a thought with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame cha dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Cha anuttariyāni—
translation-en-sujato: Six unsurpassable things:

root-pli-ms: dassanānuttariyaṁ, savanānuttariyaṁ, lābhānuttariyaṁ, sikkhānuttariyaṁ, pāricariyānuttariyaṁ, anussatānuttariyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the unsurpassable seeing, listening, acquisition, training, service, and recollection.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame cha dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What six things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Cha abhiññā—
translation-en-sujato: Six direct knowledges.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti. (10.1)
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca. (10.2)
translation-en-sujato: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.

root-pli-ms: Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti, sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti …pe… avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti. (10.3)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.

root-pli-ms: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. (10.4)
translation-en-sujato: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

root-pli-ms: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe… (10.5)
translation-en-sujato: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

root-pli-ms: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: Ime cha dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10.6)
Iti ime saṭṭhi dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these sixty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 7. Satta dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 7. Groups of Seven

root-pli-ms: Satta dhammā bahukārā …pe… satta dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Seven things are helpful, etc.
reference: dr11.329, ms8D_1236, msdiv357, pts-cs1.8, pts-vp-pli3.282, sc98

root-pli-ms: Katame satta dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Satta ariyadhanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Seven kinds of wealth of noble ones:

root-pli-ms: saddhādhanaṁ, sīladhanaṁ, hiridhanaṁ, ottappadhanaṁ, sutadhanaṁ, cāgadhanaṁ, paññādhanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: the wealth of faith, ethical conduct, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame satta dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Satta sambojjhaṅgā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven awakening factors:

root-pli-ms: satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
translation-en-sujato: mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame satta dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo—
translation-en-sujato: Seven planes of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in Brahmā’s Host through the first absorption.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyā viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods replete with glory.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catutthī viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā …pe… ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamī viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ chaṭṭhī viññāṇaṭṭhiti. (3.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ sattamī viññāṇaṭṭhiti.
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh plane of consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā pariññeyyā. (3.7)
Katame satta dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Sattānusayā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven underlying tendencies:

root-pli-ms: kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo.
translation-en-sujato: sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame satta dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Satta asaddhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven bad qualities:

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
translation-en-sujato: a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, uneducated, lazy, unmindful, and witless.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame satta dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Satta saddhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven good qualities:

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame satta dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Satta sappurisadhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven aspects of the teachings of the good persons:

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaññū ca.
translation-en-sujato: a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, knows themselves, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows people.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7)
Katame satta dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Satta saññā—
translation-en-sujato: Seven perceptions:

root-pli-ms: aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
translation-en-sujato: the perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame satta dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Satta niddasavatthūni—
translation-en-sujato: Seven qualifications for graduation.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training …

root-pli-ms: Dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: to examine the teachings …

root-pli-ms: Icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: to get rid of desires …

root-pli-ms: Paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: for retreat …

root-pli-ms: Vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: to rouse up energy …

root-pli-ms: Satinepakke tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: for mindfulness and alertness …

root-pli-ms: Diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
translation-en-sujato: to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame satta dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What seven things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Satta khīṇāsavabalāni—
translation-en-sujato: Seven powers of one who has ended the defilements.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom all conditions as truly impermanent.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayaṁ paṭijānāti: ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim: ‘My defilements have ended.’

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has clearly seen with right wisdom that sensual pleasures are truly like a pit of glowing coals. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso …pe… ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.2)
Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṁ cittaṁ hoti vivekapoṇaṁ vivekapabbhāraṁ vivekaṭṭhaṁ nekkhammābhirataṁ byantībhūtaṁ sabbaso āsavaṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, the mind of a mendicant with defilements ended slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion. They’re withdrawn, loving renunciation, and they’ve totally done with defiling influences. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso …pe… ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.3)
Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso …pe… ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.4)
Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitāni.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the five faculties. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso …pe… ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.5)
Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the seven awakening factors. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso …pe… ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti. (10.6)
Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant with defilements ended has well developed the noble eightfold path. …

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvito hoti subhāvito, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma khīṇāsavo bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayaṁ paṭijānāti:
translation-en-sujato: This is a power that a mendicant who has ended the defilements relies on to claim:

root-pli-ms: ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘My defilements have ended.’

root-pli-ms: Ime satta dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10.7)
Itime sattati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these seventy things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro niṭṭhito.
translation-en-sujato: The first recitation section is finished.

root-pli-ms: 8. Aṭṭha dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 8. Groups of Eight

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha dhammā bahukārā …pe… aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Eight things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame aṭṭha dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things are helpful?
reference: csp1ed8.244, csp2ed8.244, ms8D_1263, pts-vp-pli3.285, sc123, vri3.235

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha hetū aṭṭha paccayā ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattanti.
translation-en-sujato: There are eight causes and reasons that lead to acquiring the wisdom fundamental to the spiritual life, and to its increase, growth, development, and fulfillment once it has been acquired.

root-pli-ms: Katame aṭṭha?
translation-en-sujato: What eight?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ, yatthassa tibbaṁ hirottappaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti pemañca gāravo ca.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role. And they set up a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo hetu paṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first cause.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana satthāraṁ upanissāya viharati aññataraṁ vā garuṭṭhāniyaṁ sabrahmacāriṁ, yatthassa tibbaṁ hirottappaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti pemañca gāravo ca. Te kālena kālaṁ upasaṅkamitvā paripucchati paripañhati:
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant lives relying on the Teacher or a spiritual companion in a teacher’s role—with a keen sense of conscience and prudence for them, with warmth and respect—from time to time they go and ask them questions:

root-pli-ms: ‘idaṁ, bhante, kathaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: ‘Why, sir, does it say this?

root-pli-ms: Imassa ko attho’ti?
translation-en-sujato: What does that mean?’

root-pli-ms: Tassa te āyasmanto avivaṭañceva vivaranti, anuttānīkatañca uttānīkaronti, anekavihitesu ca kaṅkhāṭṭhāniyesu dhammesu kaṅkhaṁ paṭivinodenti.
translation-en-sujato: Those venerables clarify what is unclear, reveal what is obscure, and dispel doubt regarding the many doubtful matters.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo hetu dutiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya, vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second cause.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ kho pana dhammaṁ sutvā dvayena vūpakāsena sampādeti—kāyavūpakāsena ca cittavūpakāsena ca.
translation-en-sujato: After hearing that teaching they perfect withdrawal of both body and mind.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo hetu tatiyo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third cause.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho hetu catuttho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth cause.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamo hetu pañcamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth cause.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ chaṭṭho hetu chaṭṭho paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth cause.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato. Cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ sattamo hetu sattamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati. (1.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh cause.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu, udayabbayānupassī viharati:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

root-pli-ms: ‘iti rūpaṁ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

root-pli-ms: iti vedanā iti vedanāya samudayo iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

root-pli-ms: iti saññā iti saññāya samudayo iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

root-pli-ms: iti saṅkhārā iti saṅkhārānaṁ samudayo iti saṅkhārānaṁ atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.

root-pli-ms: iti viññāṇaṁ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo hetu aṭṭhamo paccayo ādibrahmacariyikāya paññāya appaṭiladdhāya paṭilābhāya, paṭiladdhāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṁvattati.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth cause.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā bahukārā. (1.8)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: The noble eightfold path, that is:

root-pli-ms: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha lokadhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Eight worldly conditions:

root-pli-ms: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
translation-en-sujato: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha micchattā—
translation-en-sujato: Eight wrong ways:

root-pli-ms: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha kusītavatthūni.
translation-en-sujato: Eight grounds for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kātabbaṁ hoti,
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do.

root-pli-ms: tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘kammaṁ kho me kātabbaṁ bhavissati, kammaṁ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I have some work to do. But while doing it my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ paṭhamaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kataṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho kammaṁ akāsiṁ, kammaṁ kho pana me karontassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve done some work. But while working my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṁ ārabhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ dutiyaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilamissati, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I have to go on a journey. But while walking my body will get tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṁ ārabhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ tatiyaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho maggaṁ agamāsiṁ, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantassa kāyo kilanto, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. But while walking my body got tired. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati, na vīriyaṁ ārabhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ catutthaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo kilanto akammañño, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is tired and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ pañcamaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo garuko akammañño, māsācitaṁ maññe, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is heavy, unfit for work, like I’ve just eaten a load of beans. I’d better have a lie down.’...

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho, tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick. They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṁ appamattako ābādho atthi kappo nipajjituṁ, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I feel a little sick. Lying down would be good for me. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: So nipajjati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ sattamaṁ kusītavatthu. (5.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānāvuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gilānāvuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. My body is weak and unfit for work. I’d better have a lie down.’

root-pli-ms: Tassa me kāyo dubbalo akammañño, handāhaṁ nipajjāmī’ti.
So nipajjati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They lie down, and don’t rouse energy...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ aṭṭhamaṁ kusītavatthu.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth ground for laziness.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5.8)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha ārambhavatthūni.
translation-en-sujato: Eight grounds for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kātabbaṁ hoti, tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a mendicant has some work to do. They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘kammaṁ kho me kātabbaṁ bhavissati, kammaṁ kho pana me karontena na sukaraṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
