translation-en-sujato: ‘I have some work to do. While working it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

root-pli-ms: So vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
translation-en-sujato: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ paṭhamaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā kammaṁ kataṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has done some work.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho kammaṁ akāsiṁ, kammaṁ kho panāhaṁ karonto nāsakkhiṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve done some work. While I was working I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ dutiyaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gantabbo hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has to go on a journey.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘maggo kho me gantabbo bhavissati, maggaṁ kho pana me gacchantena na sukaraṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I have to go on a journey. While walking it’s not easy to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ tatiyaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhunā maggo gato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has gone on a journey.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho maggaṁ agamāsiṁ, maggaṁ kho panāhaṁ gacchanto nāsakkhiṁ buddhānaṁ sāsanaṁ manasikātuṁ, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve gone on a journey. While I was walking I wasn’t able to focus on the instructions of the Buddhas. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ catutthaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto na labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, but they didn’t get to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto nālatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ, tassa me kāyo lahuko kammañño, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, but I didn’t get to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is light and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ pañcamaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto labhati lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has wandered for alms, and they got to fill up on as much food as they like, coarse or fine.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya caranto alatthaṁ lūkhassa vā paṇītassa vā bhojanassa yāvadatthaṁ pāripūriṁ.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve wandered for alms, and I got to fill up on as much food as I like, coarse or fine. My body is strong and fit for work. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: Tassa me kāyo balavā kammañño, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
idaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno uppanno hoti appamattako ābādho.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant feels a little sick.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘uppanno kho me ayaṁ appamattako ābādho ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ me ābādho pavaḍḍheyya, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘I feel a little sick. It’s possible this illness will worsen. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy.’...

root-pli-ms: idaṁ sattamaṁ ārambhavatthu. (6.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu gilānā vuṭṭhito hoti aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has recently recovered from illness.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
translation-en-sujato: They think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ me ābādho paccudāvatteyya, handāhaṁ vīriyaṁ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘I’ve recently recovered from illness. It’s possible the illness will come back. I’d better preemptively rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

root-pli-ms: So vīriyaṁ ārabhati appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
translation-en-sujato: They rouse energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ aṭṭhamaṁ ārambhavatthu.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth ground for arousing energy.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6.8)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha akkhaṇā asamayā brahmacariyavāsāya.
translation-en-sujato: Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
translation-en-sujato: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.

root-pli-ms: Ayañca puggalo nirayaṁ upapanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: But a person has been reborn in hell.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṁ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: Ayañca puggalo tiracchānayoniṁ upapanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: But a person has been reborn in the animal realm.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: pettivisayaṁ upapanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: But a person has been reborn in the ghost realm.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: aññataraṁ dīghāyukaṁ devanikāyaṁ upapanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: But person has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: paccantimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti milakkhesu aviññātāresu, yattha natthi gati bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But a person has been reborn in the borderlands, among barbarian tribes, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti micchādiṭṭhiko viparītadassano:
translation-en-sujato: And a person is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:

root-pli-ms: ‘natthi dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There are no duties to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ chaṭṭho akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti duppañño jaḷo eḷamūgo, nappaṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And a person is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, stupid, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ sattamo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya. (7.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

root-pli-ms: ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti paññavā ajaḷo aneḷamūgo, paṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But he doesn’t teach the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as announced by the Holy One. And a person is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.
comment-en-sujato: That this is the correct sense is inferred from DN 33 and AN 8.29.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo akkhaṇo asamayo brahmacariyavāsāya.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7.8)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakkā—
translation-en-sujato: Eight thoughts of a great man.

root-pli-ms: appicchassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo mahicchassa.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.

root-pli-ms: Santuṭṭhassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo asantuṭṭhassa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for the contented, not those who lack contentment.

root-pli-ms: Pavivittassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo saṅgaṇikārāmassa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for the secluded, not those who enjoy company.

root-pli-ms: Āraddhavīriyassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo kusītassa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for the energetic, not the lazy.

root-pli-ms: Upaṭṭhitasatissāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo muṭṭhassatissa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for the mindful, not the unmindful.

root-pli-ms: Samāhitassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo asamāhitassa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for those with immersion, not those without immersion.

root-pli-ms: Paññavato ayaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo duppaññassa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s for the wise, not the witless.

root-pli-ms: Nippapañcassāyaṁ dhammo, nāyaṁ dhammo papañcārāmassāti ime aṭṭha dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
translation-en-sujato: This teaching is for those who don’t enjoy proliferating, not for those who enjoy proliferating.’
comment-en-sujato: Following BJT reading.

root-pli-ms: Katame aṭṭha dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha abhibhāyatanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Eight dimensions of mastery.

root-pli-ms: ajjhattaṁ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
translation-en-sujato: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: evaṁsaññī hoti.
Idaṁ paṭhamaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
translation-en-sujato: Perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: evaṁsaññī hoti.
Idaṁ dutiyaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: evaṁsaññī hoti.
Idaṁ tatiyaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: evaṁsaññī hoti.
Idaṁ catutthaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma umāpupphaṁ nīlaṁ nīlavaṇṇaṁ nīlanidassanaṁ nīlanibhāsaṁ, seyyathā vā pana taṁ vatthaṁ bārāṇaseyyakaṁ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṁ nīlaṁ nīlavaṇṇaṁ nīlanidassanaṁ nīlanibhāsaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color, blue hue, and blue tint.

root-pli-ms: evameva ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṁsaññī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ pañcamaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma kaṇikārapupphaṁ pītaṁ pītavaṇṇaṁ pītanidassanaṁ pītanibhāsaṁ, seyyathā vā pana taṁ vatthaṁ bārāṇaseyyakaṁ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṁ pītaṁ pītavaṇṇaṁ pītanidassanaṁ pītanibhāsaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.

root-pli-ms: evameva ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṁsaññī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma bandhujīvakapupphaṁ lohitakaṁ lohitakavaṇṇaṁ lohitakanidassanaṁ lohitakanibhāsaṁ, seyyathā vā pana taṁ vatthaṁ bārāṇaseyyakaṁ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṁ lohitakaṁ lohitakavaṇṇaṁ lohitakanidassanaṁ lohitakanibhāsaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color, red hue, and red tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.

root-pli-ms: evameva ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṁsaññī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ sattamaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ. (9.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi nāma osadhitārakā odātā odātavaṇṇā odātanidassanā odātanibhāsā, seyyathā vā pana taṁ vatthaṁ bārāṇaseyyakaṁ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṁ odātaṁ odātavaṇṇaṁ odātanidassanaṁ odātanibhāsaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color, white hue, and white tint. Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.

root-pli-ms: evameva ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṁsaññī hoti.
Idaṁ aṭṭhamaṁ abhibhāyatanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9.8)
Katame aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What eight things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭha vimokkhā—
translation-en-sujato: Eight liberations.

root-pli-ms: rūpī rūpāni passati.
translation-en-sujato: Having physical form, they see visions.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo vimokkho. (10.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first liberation.

root-pli-ms: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati.
translation-en-sujato: Not perceiving physical form internally, someone see visions externally.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo vimokkho. (10.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second liberation.

root-pli-ms: Subhanteva adhimutto hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They’re focused only on beauty.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo vimokkho. (10.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third liberation.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho vimokkho. (10.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth liberation.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamo vimokkho. (10.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth liberation.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ chaṭṭho vimokkho. (10.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth liberation.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ sattamo vimokkho. (10.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh liberation.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo vimokkho.
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth liberation.

root-pli-ms: Ime aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10.8)
Iti ime asīti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these eighty things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 9. Nava dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 9. Groups of Nine

root-pli-ms: Nava dhammā bahukārā …pe… nava dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Nine things are helpful, etc.

root-pli-ms: Katame nava dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Nava yonisomanasikāramūlakā dhammā, yonisomanasikaroto pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati, samāhite citte yathābhūtaṁ jānāti passati, yathābhūtaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ nibbindati, nibbindaṁ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati.
translation-en-sujato: Nine things rooted in proper attention. When you attend properly, joy springs up. When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed. When your mind is immersed, you truly know and see. When you truly know and see, you grow disillusioned. Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away you’re freed.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā bahukārā. (1)
Katame nava dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Nava pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgāni—
translation-en-sujato: Nine factors of trying to be pure.

root-pli-ms: sīlavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, cittavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, diṭṭhivisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, ñāṇadassanavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, paññāvisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, vimuttivisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: The factors of trying to be pure in ethics, mind, view, overcoming doubt, knowledge and vision of the variety of paths, knowledge and vision of the practice, knowledge and vision, wisdom, and freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame nava dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Nava sattāvāsā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine abodes of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ paṭhamo sattāvāso. (3.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is the first abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in Brahmā’s Host through the first absorption.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ dutiyo sattāvāso. (3.2)
translation-en-sujato: This is the second abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ tatiyo sattāvāso. (3.3)
translation-en-sujato: This is the third abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods replete with glory.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ catuttho sattāvāso. (3.4)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā asaññino appaṭisaṁvedino, seyyathāpi devā asaññasattā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ pañcamo sattāvāso. (3.5)
translation-en-sujato: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ chaṭṭho sattāvāso. (3.6)
translation-en-sujato: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ sattamo sattāvāso. (3.7)
translation-en-sujato: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo sattāvāso. (3.8)
translation-en-sujato: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagā.
translation-en-sujato: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ navamo sattāvāso.
translation-en-sujato: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: (3.9) Ime nava dhammā pariññeyyā.
Katame nava dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Nava taṇhāmūlakā dhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine things rooted in craving.

root-pli-ms: taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo, vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ daṇḍādānasatthādānakalahaviggahavivādatuvaṁtuvaṁpesuññamusāvādā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti.
translation-en-sujato: Craving is a cause for seeking. Seeking is a cause for gaining material possessions. Gaining material possessions is a cause for assessing. Assessing is a cause for desire and lust. Desire and lust is a cause for attachment. Attachment is a cause for possessiveness. Possessiveness is a cause for stinginess. Stinginess is a cause for safeguarding. Owing to safeguarding, many bad, unskillful things come to be: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, fights, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame nava dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Nava āghātavatthūni:
translation-en-sujato: Nine grounds for resentment.

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me acarī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati,
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me,’ you harbor resentment.

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me caratī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati,
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me carissatī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati;
translation-en-sujato: ‘They will do wrong to me’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘piyassa me manāpassa anatthaṁ acarī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They did wrong by someone I love’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ caratī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ carissatī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati;
translation-en-sujato: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘appiyassa me amanāpassa atthaṁ acarī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They helped someone I dislike’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘atthaṁ caratī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They are helping someone I dislike’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘atthaṁ carissatī’ti āghātaṁ bandhati.
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike,’ you harbor resentment.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame nava dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Nava āghātapaṭivinayā:
translation-en-sujato: Nine methods to get rid of resentment.

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me acari, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me carati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me …’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘anatthaṁ me carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
translation-en-sujato: ‘They will do wrong to me …’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘piyassa me manāpassa anatthaṁ acari …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They did wrong by someone I love …’ …

root-pli-ms: anatthaṁ carati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love …’ …

root-pli-ms: anatthaṁ carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
translation-en-sujato: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love …’ …

root-pli-ms: ‘appiyassa me amanāpassa atthaṁ acari …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They helped someone I dislike …’ …

root-pli-ms: atthaṁ carati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘They are helping someone I dislike …’ …

root-pli-ms: atthaṁ carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti.
translation-en-sujato: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame nava dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Nava nānattā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine kinds of diversity.

root-pli-ms: dhātunānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṁ, phassanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṁ, vedanānānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṁ, saññānānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṁ, saṅkappanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṁ, chandanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṁ, pariḷāhanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṁ, pariyesanānānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati lābhanānattaṁ (…).
translation-en-sujato: Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings. Diversity of feelings gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of intentions. Diversity of intentions gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches. Diversity of searches gives rise to diversity of gains.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7)
Katame nava dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Nava saññā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine perceptions:

root-pli-ms: asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhārepaṭikūlasaññā, sabbalokeanabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā.
translation-en-sujato: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame nava dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Nava anupubbavihārā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine progressive meditations.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …

root-pli-ms: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: second absorption …

root-pli-ms: Pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: third absorption …

root-pli-ms: Sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: fourth absorption.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

root-pli-ms: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame nava dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What nine things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Nava anupubbanirodhā—
translation-en-sujato: Nine progressive cessations.

root-pli-ms: paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa kāmasaññā niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.

root-pli-ms: dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā niruddhā honti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.

root-pli-ms: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.

root-pli-ms: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa assāsapassāssā niruddhā honti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.

root-pli-ms: ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samāpannassa rūpasaññā niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.

root-pli-ms: viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samāpannassa ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.

root-pli-ms: ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samāpannassa viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.

root-pli-ms: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samāpannassa ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.

root-pli-ms: saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
translation-en-sujato: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.

root-pli-ms: Ime nava dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime navuti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
translation-en-sujato: So these ninety things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.

root-pli-ms: 10. Dasa dhammā
translation-en-sujato: 10. Groups of Ten

root-pli-ms: Dasa dhammā bahukārā …pe… dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā.
translation-en-sujato: Ten things are helpful, ten things should be developed, ten things should be completely understood, ten things should be given up, ten things make things worse, ten things lead to distinction, ten things are hard to comprehend, ten things should be produced, ten things should be directly known, ten things should be realized.

root-pli-ms: Katame dasa dhammā bahukārā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things are helpful?

root-pli-ms: Dasa nāthakaraṇā dhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten qualities that serve as protector.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
translation-en-sujato: First, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.1)
translation-en-sujato: This is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is learned.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto …pe…
ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.2)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe… kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.3)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe… anusāsaniṁ.
Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.4)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṁ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṁsāya samannāgato, alaṁ kātuṁ, alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe… alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ.
Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.5)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe… uḷārapāmojjo.
Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.6)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarehi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe…
ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.7)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati …pe… kusalesu dhammesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is energetic.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe…
ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.8)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti, paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe…
ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo. (1.9)
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato, ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe…
ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.
translation-en-sujato: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā bahukārā. (1.10)
Katame dasa dhammā bhāvetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be developed?

root-pli-ms: Dasa kasiṇāyatanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Ten universal dimensions of meditation.

root-pli-ms: pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṁ adho tiriyaṁ advayaṁ appamāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.

root-pli-ms: Āpokasiṇameko sañjānāti …pe…
translation-en-sujato: They perceive the meditation on universal water …

root-pli-ms: tejokasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal fire …

root-pli-ms: vāyokasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal air …

root-pli-ms: nīlakasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal blue …

root-pli-ms: pītakasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal yellow …

root-pli-ms: lohitakasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal red …

root-pli-ms: odātakasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal white …

root-pli-ms: ākāsakasiṇameko sañjānāti …
translation-en-sujato: the meditation on universal space …

root-pli-ms: viññāṇakasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṁ adho tiriyaṁ advayaṁ appamāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, non-dual and limitless.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā bhāvetabbā. (2)
Katame dasa dhammā pariññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be completely understood?

root-pli-ms: Dasāyatanāni—
translation-en-sujato: Ten sense fields:

root-pli-ms: cakkhāyatanaṁ, rūpāyatanaṁ, sotāyatanaṁ, saddāyatanaṁ, ghānāyatanaṁ, gandhāyatanaṁ, jivhāyatanaṁ, rasāyatanaṁ, kāyāyatanaṁ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: eye and sights, ear and sounds, nose and smells, tongue and tastes, body and touches.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā pariññeyyā. (3)
Katame dasa dhammā pahātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be given up?

root-pli-ms: Dasa micchattā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten wrong ways:

root-pli-ms: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi, micchāñāṇaṁ, micchāvimutti.
translation-en-sujato: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā pahātabbā. (4)
Katame dasa dhammā hānabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things make things worse?

root-pli-ms: Dasa akusalakammapathā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten ways of doing unskillful deeds:

root-pli-ms: pāṇātipāto, adinnādānaṁ, kāmesumicchācāro, musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo, abhijjhā, byāpādo, micchādiṭṭhi.
translation-en-sujato: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā hānabhāgiyā. (5)
Katame dasa dhammā visesabhāgiyā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things lead to distinction?

root-pli-ms: Dasa kusalakammapathā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten ways of doing skillful deeds:

root-pli-ms: pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī, musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī, anabhijjhā, abyāpādo, sammādiṭṭhi.
translation-en-sujato: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā visesabhāgiyā. (6)
Katame dasa dhammā duppaṭivijjhā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things are hard to comprehend?

root-pli-ms: Dasa ariyavāsā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten noble abodes.

root-pli-ms: idhāvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti, chaḷaṅgasamannāgato, ekārakkho, caturāpasseno, paṇunnapaccekasacco, samavayasaṭṭhesano, anāvilasaṅkappo, passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro, suvimuttacitto, suvimuttapañño.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṁ pahīnaṁ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahīnaṁ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti. (7.1)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

root-pli-ms: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: Hearing a sound with their ears …

root-pli-ms: ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Smelling an odor with their nose …

root-pli-ms: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Tasting a flavor with their tongue …

root-pli-ms: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
translation-en-sujato: Feeling a touch with their body …

root-pli-ms: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
translation-en-sujato: Knowing a thought with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti. (7.2)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satārakkhena cetasā samannāgato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti. (7.3)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant have four supports?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṁ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṁ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṁ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṁ vinodeti.
translation-en-sujato: After reflection, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti. (7.4)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu paṇunnapaccekasacco hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how has a mendicant eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ puthupaccekasaccāni, sabbāni tāni nunnāni honti paṇunnāni cattāni vantāni muttāni pahīnāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni.
translation-en-sujato: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has dispelled, eliminated, thrown out, rejected, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu paṇunnapaccekasacco hoti. (7.5)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has eliminated idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmesanā pahīnā hoti, bhavesanā pahīnā hoti, brahmacariyesanā paṭippassaddhā.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti. (7.6)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu anāvilasaṅkappā hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, byāpādasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, vihiṁsāsaṅkappo pahīno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu anāvilasaṅkappo hoti. (7.7)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti. (7.8)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttacitto hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ hoti, dosā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ hoti, mohā cittaṁ vimuttaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttacitto hoti. (7.9)
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.

root-pli-ms: Kathañcāvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttapañño hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?

root-pli-ms: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ‘rāgo me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Doso me pahīno …pe…
āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
‘Moho me pahīno …pe…
āyatiṁ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttapañño hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā duppaṭivijjhā. (7.10)
Katame dasa dhammā uppādetabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be produced?

root-pli-ms: Dasa saññā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten perceptions:

root-pli-ms: asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhārepaṭikūlasaññā, sabbalokeanabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
translation-en-sujato: the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā uppādetabbā. (8)
Katame dasa dhammā abhiññeyyā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be directly known?

root-pli-ms: Dasa nijjaravatthūni—
translation-en-sujato: Ten grounds for wearing away.

root-pli-ms: sammādiṭṭhissa micchādiṭṭhi nijjiṇṇā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: For one of right view, wrong view is worn away.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
translation-en-sujato: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong view are worn away.

root-pli-ms: Sammāsaṅkappassa micchāsaṅkappo …pe…
translation-en-sujato: For one of right intention, wrong intention is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāvācassa micchāvācā …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right speech, wrong speech is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammākammantassa micchākammanto …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right action, wrong action is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāājīvassa micchāājīvo …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right livelihood, wrong livelihood is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāvāyāmassa micchāvāyāmo …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right effort, wrong effort is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāsatissa micchāsati …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāsamādhissa micchāsamādhi …
translation-en-sujato: For one of right immersion, wrong immersion is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: sammāñāṇassa micchāñāṇaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: For one of right knowledge, wrong knowledge is worn away. …

root-pli-ms: Sammāvimuttissa micchāvimutti nijjiṇṇā hoti.
translation-en-sujato: For one of right freedom, wrong freedom is worn away.

root-pli-ms: Ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
translation-en-sujato: And the many bad, unskillful qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are worn away.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā abhiññeyyā. (9)
Katame dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā?
translation-en-sujato: What ten things should be realized?

root-pli-ms: Dasa asekkhā dhammā—
translation-en-sujato: Ten qualities of an adept:

root-pli-ms: asekkhā sammādiṭṭhi, asekkho sammāsaṅkappo, asekkhā sammāvācā, asekkho sammākammanto, asekkho sammāājīvo, asekkho sammāvāyāmo, asekkhā sammāsati, asekkho sammāsamādhi, asekkhaṁ sammāñāṇaṁ, asekkhā sammāvimutti.
translation-en-sujato: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

root-pli-ms: Ime dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā. (10)
Iti ime satadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: So these hundred things that are true, real, and accurate, not unreal, not otherwise were rightly awakened to by the Realized One.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavocāyasmā sāriputto.
translation-en-sujato: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

root-pli-ms: Dasuttarasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ ekādasamaṁ.
Pāthikavaggo niṭṭhito.
Tassuddānaṁ
Pāthiko ca udumbaraṁ,
variant-pli-ms: Pāthiko ca udumbaraṁ → pāṭikañca udumbaraṁ (sya-all, km); pāṭikodumbarīceva (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: cakkavatti aggaññakaṁ;
Sampasādanapāsādaṁ,
mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṁ.
Siṅgālāṭānāṭiyakaṁ,
saṅgīti ca dasuttaraṁ;
Ekādasahi suttehi,
pāthikavaggoti vuccati.
Pāthikavaggapāḷi niṭṭhitā.
Tīhi vaggehi paṭimaṇḍito sakalo
dīghanikāyo samatto.
translation-en-sujato: The Long Discourses are completed.

root-pli-ms: Dīgha Nikāya 7
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 7

root-pli-ms: Jāliyasutta
translation-en-sujato: With Jāliya

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena dve pabbajitā—
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time two renunciates—

root-pli-ms: muṇḍiyo ca paribbājako jāliyo ca dārupattikantevāsī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu.
translation-en-sujato: the wanderer Muṇḍiya and Jāliya the pupil of Dārupattika—came to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhaṁsu. Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho te dve pabbajitā bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they stood to one side and said to the Buddha,

root-pli-ms: “kiṁ nu kho, āvuso gotama, taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīraṁ, udāhu aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “Reverend Gotama, are the soul and the body the same thing, or they are different things?”

root-pli-ms: “Tena hāvuso, suṇātha sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

root-pli-ms: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te dve pabbajitā bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, reverend,” they replied.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:

root-pli-ms: “idhāvuso, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ, sammāsambuddho …pe…
translation-en-sujato: “Take the case when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …

root-pli-ms: …pe…
Paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They enter and remain in the first absorption …

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, kallaṁ nu kho tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’?”

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, kallaṁ tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: “It would, reverend.”

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
Ahaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, evaṁ jānāmi evaṁ passāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “But reverends, I know and see like this.

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panāhaṁ na vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: Nevertheless, I do not say:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’. …

root-pli-ms: dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: They enter and remain in the second absorption …

root-pli-ms: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: third absorption …

root-pli-ms: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: fourth absorption.

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, kallaṁ nu kho tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’?”

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati kallaṁ, tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: “It would, reverend.”

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
Ahaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, evaṁ jānāmi evaṁ passāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “But reverends, I know and see like this.

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panāhaṁ na vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: Nevertheless, I do not say:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’. …

root-pli-ms: ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti …
translation-en-sujato: They extend and project the mind toward knowledge and vision …

root-pli-ms: yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, kallaṁ nu kho tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’?”

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati kallaṁ tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: “It would, reverend.”

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
Ahaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, evaṁ jānāmi evaṁ passāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “But reverends, I know and see like this.

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panāhaṁ na vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: Nevertheless, I do not say:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā …pe….
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’. …

root-pli-ms: …pe… Nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, kallaṁ nu kho tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti?
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’?”

root-pli-ms: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ jānāti evaṁ passati, na kallaṁ tassetaṁ vacanāya:
translation-en-sujato: “It would not, reverend.”

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vāti.
Ahaṁ kho panetaṁ, āvuso, evaṁ jānāmi evaṁ passāmi.
translation-en-sujato: “But reverends, I know and see like this.

root-pli-ms: Atha ca panāhaṁ na vadāmi:
translation-en-sujato: Nevertheless, I do not say:

root-pli-ms: ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing’ or ‘The soul and the body are different things’.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te dve pabbajitā bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the two renunciates were happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Jāliyasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ sattamaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 10
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 10

root-pli-ms: Subhasutta
translation-en-sujato: With Subha

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme aciraparinibbute bhagavati.
translation-en-sujato: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. It was not long after the Buddha had become fully extinguished.

root-pli-ms: Tena kho pana samayena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto sāvatthiyaṁ paṭivasati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
translation-en-sujato: Now at that time the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī on some business.

root-pli-ms: Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto aññataraṁ māṇavakaṁ āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: Then he addressed a certain student,

root-pli-ms: “ehi tvaṁ, māṇavaka, yena samaṇo ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ puccha:
translation-en-sujato: “Here, student, go to the ascetic Ānanda and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

root-pli-ms: ‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchatī’ti.
Evañca vadehi:
translation-en-sujato: And then say:

root-pli-ms: ‘sādhu kira bhavaṁ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Sir, please visit the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, at his home out of compassion.’”
reference: cck9.252, dr9.270, km15.161, ms6D_771, msdiv446, pts-cs1.3, pts-vp-pli1.205, sc3, sya9.251

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so māṇavako subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the student, and did as he was asked.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so māṇavako āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
“subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchati;
evañca vadeti:
‘sādhu kira bhavaṁ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā’”ti.
Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to him,
reference: km15.162, ms6D_772, msdiv447, pts-cs1.4, sc4, vri1.181

root-pli-ms: “akālo kho, māṇavaka.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s not the right time, student.

root-pli-ms: Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā.
translation-en-sujato: I’ve drunk sufficient refreshments for today.

root-pli-ms: Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But hopefully tomorrow I’ll get a chance to visit him.”

root-pli-ms: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho so māṇavako āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā subhaṁ māṇavaṁ todeyyaputtaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: “Yes, sir,” replied the student. He went back to Subha, and told him what had happened, adding,

root-pli-ms: “avocumhā kho mayaṁ bhoto vacanena taṁ bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ:
‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṁ ānandaṁ appābādhaṁ appātaṅkaṁ lahuṭṭhānaṁ balaṁ phāsuvihāraṁ pucchati, evañca vadeti:
“sādhu kira bhavaṁ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā”’ti.
Evaṁ vutte, bho, samaṇo ānando maṁ etadavoca:
‘akālo kho, māṇavaka.
Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā.
Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā’ti.
Ettāvatāpi kho, bho, katameva etaṁ, yato kho so bhavaṁ ānando okāsamakāsi svātanāyapi upasaṅkamanāyā”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “This much, sir, I managed to do. At least Master Ānanda will take the opportunity to visit tomorrow.”

root-pli-ms: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya cetakena bhikkhunā pacchāsamaṇena yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
translation-en-sujato: Then when the night had passed, Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Cetaka as his second monk to Subha’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out. Then Subha went up to Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

root-pli-ms: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

root-pli-ms: “bhavañhi ānando tassa bhoto gotamassa dīgharattaṁ upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro samīpacārī.
translation-en-sujato: “Master Ānanda, you were Master Gotama’s attendant. You were close to him, living in his presence.

root-pli-ms: Bhavametaṁ ānando jāneyya, yesaṁ so bhavaṁ gotamo dhammānaṁ vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: You ought to know what things Master Gotama praised, and in which he encouraged, settled, and grounded all these people.

root-pli-ms: Katamesānaṁ kho, bho ānanda, dhammānaṁ so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi; kattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: What were those things?”

root-pli-ms: “Tiṇṇaṁ kho, māṇava, khandhānaṁ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: “Student, the Buddha praised three sets of things, and that’s what he encouraged, settled, and grounded all these people in.

root-pli-ms: Katamesaṁ tiṇṇaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: What three?

root-pli-ms: Ariyassa sīlakkhandhassa, ariyassa samādhikkhandhassa, ariyassa paññākkhandhassa.
translation-en-sujato: The entire spectrum of noble ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Imesaṁ kho, māṇava, tiṇṇaṁ khandhānaṁ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti.
translation-en-sujato: These are the three sets of things that the Buddha praised.”

root-pli-ms: 1. Sīlakkhandha
translation-en-sujato: 1. The Entire Spectrum of Ethics

root-pli-ms: “Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho, yassa so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: “But what was that noble spectrum of ethics that the Buddha praised?”
reference: csp1ed6.190, csp2ed6.190, mc9.199, ms6D_777, msdiv450, sc9, vri1.182

root-pli-ms: “Idha, māṇava, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: “Student, it’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.

root-pli-ms: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
translation-en-sujato: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

root-pli-ms: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
translation-en-sujato: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

root-pli-ms: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
translation-en-sujato: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.

root-pli-ms: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
translation-en-sujato: They gain faith in the Realized One,

root-pli-ms: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
translation-en-sujato: and reflect:

root-pli-ms: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā,
translation-en-sujato: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.

root-pli-ms: nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
translation-en-sujato: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

root-pli-ms: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
translation-en-sujato: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno, anumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo, sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
translation-en-sujato: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?

root-pli-ms: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. …

root-pli-ms: Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati;
idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.
variant-pli-ms: sīlasmiṁ → athā sāmaññaphalasutte 194 yāva 210 anucchedesu evaṁ

root-pli-ms: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṁ kappenti,
translation-en-sujato: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood.

root-pli-ms: seyyathidaṁ—santikammaṁ paṇidhikammaṁ bhūtakammaṁ bhūrikammaṁ vassakammaṁ vossakammaṁ vatthukammaṁ vatthuparikammaṁ ācamanaṁ nhāpanaṁ juhanaṁ vamanaṁ virecanaṁ uddhaṁvirecanaṁ adhovirecanaṁ sīsavirecanaṁ kaṇṇatelaṁ nettatappanaṁ natthukammaṁ añjanaṁ paccañjanaṁ sālākiyaṁ sallakattiyaṁ dārakatikicchā mūlabhesajjānaṁ anuppadānaṁ osadhīnaṁ paṭimokkho
translation-en-sujato: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs.

root-pli-ms: iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They refrain from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood. …

root-pli-ms: Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṁ kappenti,
seyyathidaṁ—santikammaṁ paṇidhikammaṁ …pe… osadhīnaṁ paṭimokkho
iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti.
Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their ethics.

root-pli-ms: Sa kho so, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ sīlasaṁvarato.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
variant-pli-ms: Sa kho so → ayaṁ kho so (mr)

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nihatapaccāmitto na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ paccatthikato;
translation-en-sujato: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṁ samanupassati, yadidaṁ sīlasaṁvarato.
translation-en-sujato: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.

root-pli-ms: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo sīlakkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: This is that noble spectrum of ethics that the Buddha praised.

root-pli-ms: Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But there is still more to be done.”

root-pli-ms: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, Master Ānanda, it’s amazing,

root-pli-ms: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
translation-en-sujato: This noble spectrum of ethics is complete, not lacking anything!

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ sīlakkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Such a complete spectrum of ethics cannot be seen among the other ascetics and brahmins.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ sīlakkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṁ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu:
