translation-en-sujato: Were other ascetics and brahmins to see such a complete spectrum of noble ethics in themselves, they’d be delighted with just that much:

root-pli-ms: ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘At this point it’s enough; at this point our work is done. We’ve reached the goal of our ascetic life. There is nothing more to be done.’

root-pli-ms: Atha ca pana bhavaṁ ānando evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: And yet you say:

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan’”ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘But there is still more to be done.’

root-pli-ms: 2. Samādhikkhandha
translation-en-sujato: 2. The Spectrum of Immersion

root-pli-ms: “Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho, yassa so bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: But what, Master Ānanda, was that noble spectrum of immersion that the Buddha praised?”
reference: km15.170, ms6D_784, msdiv454, pts-cs2.1, sc16, vri1.184

root-pli-ms: “Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
translation-en-sujato: “And how, student, does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

root-pli-ms: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
translation-en-sujato: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

root-pli-ms: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ; tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
translation-en-sujato: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

root-pli-ms: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: When they hear a sound with their ears …

root-pli-ms: ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: When they smell an odor with their nose …

root-pli-ms: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
translation-en-sujato: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

root-pli-ms: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a touch with their body …

root-pli-ms: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī;
translation-en-sujato: When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

root-pli-ms: yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ; tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
translation-en-sujato: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

root-pli-ms: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
translation-en-sujato: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant have mindfulness and situational awareness?
reference: bj7.458, csp1ed6.193, csp2ed6.193, ms6D_786, msdiv455, ndp6.173, pts-cs2.3, sc18

root-pli-ms: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant has mindfulness and situational awareness.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti?
translation-en-sujato: And how is a mendicant content?

root-pli-ms: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
translation-en-sujato: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant is content.

root-pli-ms: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato
translation-en-sujato: When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, and this noble contentment,

root-pli-ms: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

root-pli-ms: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
translation-en-sujato: After the meal, they return from alms-round, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.

root-pli-ms: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.

root-pli-ms: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.

root-pli-ms: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.

root-pli-ms: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.

root-pli-ms: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,

root-pli-ms: Tassa te kammantā samijjheyyuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: and his efforts proved successful.

root-pli-ms: So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṁ kareyya, siyā cassa uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāya.
translation-en-sujato: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Thinking about this,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojesiṁ.
Tassa me te kammantā samijjhiṁsu.
Sohaṁ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṁ akāsiṁ, atthi ca me uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāyā’ti.
So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a person who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak.

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya, bhattañcassa chādeyya, siyā cassa kāye balamattā.
translation-en-sujato: But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Thinking about this,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā.
Somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti.
So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso bandhanāgāre baddho assa.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail.
reference: cck9.260, ms6D_792, msdiv461, pts-cs2.9, sc24, vri1.186

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena tamhā bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena, na cassa kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo.
translation-en-sujato: But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Thinking about this,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṁ.
Somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto sotthinā abbhayena, natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo’ti.
So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso dāso assa anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a person was a bondservant. They belonged to someone else and were unable to go where they wish.

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyā mucceyya, attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo.
translation-en-sujato: But after some time they’d be freed from servitude and become their own master, an emancipated individual able to go where they wish.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Thinking about this,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe dāso ahosiṁ anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo.
Somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā mutto attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo’ti.
So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjeyya dubbhikkhaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road, which was perilous, with nothing to eat.
reference: csp1ed6.195, csp2ed6.195, dr9.278, ms6D_794, msdiv463, pts-cs2.11, sc26

root-pli-ms: So aparena samayena taṁ kantāraṁ nitthareyya, sotthinā gāmantaṁ anupāpuṇeyya khemaṁ appaṭibhayaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But after some time they crossed over the desert safely, reaching the neighborhood of a village, a sanctuary free of peril.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: Thinking about this,

root-pli-ms: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjiṁ dubbhikkhaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ.
Somhi etarahi taṁ kantāraṁ nitthiṇṇo, sotthinā gāmantaṁ anuppatto khemaṁ appaṭibhayan’ti.
So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, evaṁ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, yathā āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and sanctuary.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
Tassime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

root-pli-ms: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṁsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṁ paripphosakaṁ sanneyya. Sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena, na ca paggharaṇī.
translation-en-sujato: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

root-pli-ms: Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
Idampissa hoti samādhismiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their immersion.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, māṇava, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako. Tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, devo ca na kālena kālaṁ sammā dhāraṁ anupaveccheyya. Atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṁ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
So imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
Idampissa hoti samādhismiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their immersion.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, māṇava, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, uppaliniyaṁ vā paduminiyaṁ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṁ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṁ uppalānaṁ vā padumānaṁ vā puṇḍarīkānaṁ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
So imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
Idampissa hoti samādhismiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their immersion.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti;
translation-en-sujato: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind.

root-pli-ms: nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṁ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṁ assa.
translation-en-sujato: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, a mendicant sits spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There's no part of their body that's not spread with pure bright mind.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
Idampissa hoti samādhismiṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their immersion.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo samādhikkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: This is that noble spectrum of immersion that the Buddha praised.

root-pli-ms: Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: But there is still more to be done.”

root-pli-ms: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, Master Ānanda, it’s amazing!

root-pli-ms: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
translation-en-sujato: This noble spectrum of immersion is complete, not lacking anything!

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ samādhikkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Such a complete spectrum of immersion cannot be seen among the other ascetics and brahmins.

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ samādhikkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṁ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu:
translation-en-sujato: Were other ascetics and brahmins to see such a complete spectrum of noble immersion in themselves, they’d be delighted with just that much:

root-pli-ms: ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘At this point it’s enough; at this point our work is done. We’ve reached the goal of our ascetic life. There is nothing more to be done.’

root-pli-ms: Atha ca pana bhavaṁ ānando evamāha:
translation-en-sujato: And yet you say:

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘But there is still more to be done.’

root-pli-ms: 3. Paññākkhandha
translation-en-sujato: 3. The Spectrum of Wisdom

root-pli-ms: Katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho, yassa bho bhavaṁ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī”ti?
translation-en-sujato: But what, Master Ānanda, was that noble spectrum of wisdom that the Buddha praised?”
reference: csp1ed6.198, csp2ed6.198, km15.184, ms6D_808, msdiv472, pts-cs2.20, sc40

root-pli-ms: “So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: “When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge and vision.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pajānāti:
translation-en-sujato: They understand:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo; idañca pana me viññāṇaṁ ettha sitaṁ ettha paṭibaddhan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This body of mine is physical. It’s made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction. And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities. And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.

root-pli-ms: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ayaṁ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatridaṁ suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: And someone with good eyesight were to take it in their hand and examine it: ‘This beryl gem is naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities. And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge and vision.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ pajānāti:
‘ayaṁ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo. Idañca pana me viññāṇaṁ ettha sitaṁ ettha paṭibaddhan’ti.
Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe…
āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
So evaṁ pajānāti …pe…
ettha paṭibaddhanti.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṁ kāyaṁ abhinimmānāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward the creation of a mind-made body.

root-pli-ms: So imamhā kāyā aññaṁ kāyaṁ abhinimmināti rūpiṁ manomayaṁ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṁ ahīnindriyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: From this body they create another body, physical, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso muñjamhā īsikaṁ pavāheyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: They’d think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ muñjo ayaṁ īsikā; añño muñjo aññā īsikā; muñjamhā tveva īsikā pavāḷhā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, puriso asiṁ kosiyā pavāheyya.
translation-en-sujato: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: They’d think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ asi, ayaṁ kosi; añño asi, aññā kosi; kosiyā tveva asi pavāḷho’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, puriso ahiṁ karaṇḍā uddhareyya.
translation-en-sujato: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evamassa:
translation-en-sujato: They’d think:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayaṁ ahi, ayaṁ karaṇḍo; añño ahi, añño karaṇḍo; karaṇḍā tveva ahi ubbhato’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward the creation of a mind-made body.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṁ kāyaṁ abhinimmānāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti …pe….
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward psychic power.

root-pli-ms: So anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti seyyathāpi udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁ mahiddhike evaṁ mahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
translation-en-sujato: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; going unimpeded through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, dakkho kumbhakāro vā kumbhakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatāya mattikāya yaññadeva bhājanavikatiṁ ākaṅkheyya, taṁ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose an expert potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, dakkho dantakāro vā dantakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṁ dantasmiṁ yaññadeva dantavikatiṁ ākaṅkheyya, taṁ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Or suppose an expert ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṁ suvaṇṇasmiṁ yaññadeva suvaṇṇavikatiṁ ākaṅkheyya, taṁ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya.
translation-en-sujato: Or suppose an expert goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe… yampi māṇava bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward psychic power.

root-pli-ms: So anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward clairaudience.

root-pli-ms: So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca.
translation-en-sujato: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno. So suṇeyya bherisaddampi mudiṅgasaddampi saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddampi. Tassa evamassa—bherisaddo itipi mudiṅgasaddo itipi saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddo itipi.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a person traveling along the road. They’d hear the sound of drums, clay drums, horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms. They’d think: ‘That’s the sound of drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of clay-drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward clairaudience.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward comprehending the minds of others.

root-pli-ms: So parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti, sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, samohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītamohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘saṅkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vikkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘mahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘amahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sauttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘anuttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘asamāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti, avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘avimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’, and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’. They understand mind with hate … mind without hate … mind with delusion … mind without delusion … constricted mind … scattered mind … expansive mind … unexpansive mind … mind that is not supreme … mind that is supreme … immersed mind … unimmersed mind … freed mind … They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udakapatte sakaṁ mukhanimittaṁ paccavekkhamāno sakaṇikaṁ vā sakaṇikanti jāneyya, akaṇikaṁ vā akaṇikanti jāneyya.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot,’ and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward comprehending the minds of others.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite …pe… āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
So parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti, sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti …pe… avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward recollection of past lives.

root-pli-ms: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
translation-en-sujato: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere, and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ gaccheyya; tamhāpi gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ gaccheyya; so tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgaccheyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ahaṁ kho sakamhā gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ agacchiṁ, tatra evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ evaṁ nisīdiṁ evaṁ abhāsiṁ evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ. So tamhāpi gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ gacchiṁ, tatrāpi evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ evaṁ nisīdiṁ evaṁ abhāsiṁ evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ. Somhi tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgato’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward recollection of past lives.

root-pli-ms: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, majjhesiṅghāṭake pāsādo, tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya manusse gehaṁ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikāyapi vīthiṁ sañcarante majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnepi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ete manussā gehaṁ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikāya vīthiṁ sañcaranti, ete majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse at the central square. A person with good eyesight standing there might see people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square. They’d think: ‘These are people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend and project it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
translation-en-sujato: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
translation-en-sujato: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

root-pli-ms: ime āsavāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

root-pli-ms: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,
translation-en-sujato: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

root-pli-ms: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
translation-en-sujato: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

root-pli-ms: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tattha cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiṭṭhantampi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ayaṁ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tatrime sippisambukāpi sakkharakathalāpi macchagumbāpi carantipi tiṭṭhantipī’ti.
translation-en-sujato: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. They’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu …pe…
translation-en-sujato: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

root-pli-ms: yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte …pe… āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe…
āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.

Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
Idampissa hoti paññāya.
translation-en-sujato: This pertains to their wisdom.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ kho so, māṇava, ariyo paññākkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṁ janataṁ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi.
translation-en-sujato: This is that noble spectrum of wisdom that the Buddha praised.

root-pli-ms: Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: And there is nothing more to be done.”

root-pli-ms: “Acchariyaṁ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṁ, bho ānanda.
translation-en-sujato: “It’s incredible, Master Ānanda, it’s amazing!

root-pli-ms: So cāyaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo.
translation-en-sujato: This noble spectrum of wisdom is complete, not lacking anything!

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ paripuṇṇañcāhaṁ, bho ānanda, ariyaṁ paññākkhandhaṁ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi.
translation-en-sujato: Such a complete spectrum of wisdom cannot be seen among the other ascetics and brahmins.

root-pli-ms: Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: And there is nothing more to be done.
variant-pli-ms: Natthi cevettha → natthi cettha (bj); natthi no kiñci (sya-all, mr)

root-pli-ms: Abhikkantaṁ, bho ānanda, abhikkantaṁ, bho ānanda.
translation-en-sujato: Excellent, Master Ānanda! Excellent!

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bho ānanda, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā ānandena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
translation-en-sujato: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Ānanda has made the teaching clear in many ways.

root-pli-ms: Esāhaṁ, bho ānanda, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
translation-en-sujato: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

root-pli-ms: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ ānando dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: From this day forth, may Master Ānanda remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

root-pli-ms: Subhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ dasamaṁ.
Dīgha Nikāya 22
translation-en-sujato: Long Discourses 22

root-pli-ms: Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutta
translation-en-sujato: The Longer Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation

root-pli-ms: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: So I have heard.

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṁ nāma kurūnaṁ nigamo.
translation-en-sujato: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.

root-pli-ms: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
translation-en-sujato: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

root-pli-ms: “bhikkhavo”ti.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants!”

root-pli-ms: “Bhaddante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
translation-en-sujato: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

root-pli-ms: Bhagavā etadavoca:
translation-en-sujato: The Buddha said this:

root-pli-ms: “Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
translation-en-sujato: “Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.

root-pli-ms: Katame cattāro?
translation-en-sujato: What four?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Uddeso niṭṭhito.
1. Kāyānupassanā
translation-en-sujato: 1. Observing the Body

root-pli-ms: 1.1. Kāyānupassanāānāpānapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.1. Mindfulness of Breathing

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the body?
reference: bj8.438, cck10.341, dr10.322, ms7D_945, msdiv374, pts-cs2, pts-vp-pli2.291, sc4, vri2.215

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, with their body straight, and focuses their mindfulness right there.

root-pli-ms: So satova assasati, satova passasati.
translation-en-sujato: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

root-pli-ms: Dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

root-pli-ms: Rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

root-pli-ms: ‘Sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
translation-en-sujato: They practice breathing in experiencing the whole body. They practice breathing out experiencing the whole body.

root-pli-ms: ‘Passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
translation-en-sujato: They practice breathing in stilling the body’s motion. They practice breathing out stilling the body’s motion.

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho bhamakāro vā bhamakārantevāsī vā dīghaṁ vā añchanto ‘dīghaṁ añchāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā añchanto ‘rassaṁ añchāmī’ti pajānāti;
translation-en-sujato: It’s like a deft carpenter or carpenter’s apprentice. When making a deep cut they know: ‘I’m making a deep cut,’ and when making a shallow cut they know: ‘I’m making a shallow cut.’

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.

‘Sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Ānāpānapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
1.2. Kāyānupassanāiriyāpathapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.2. The Postures

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti,
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know: ‘I am walking.’ When standing they know: ‘I am standing.’ When sitting they know: ‘I am sitting.’ And when lying down they know: ‘I am lying down.’
reference: mc10.250, ms7D_953, msdiv375, pts-cs3, sc11, vri2.216

root-pli-ms: yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṁ pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Iriyāpathapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
1.3. Kāyānupassanāsampajānapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.3. Situational Awareness

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl, and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Sampajānapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
1.4. Kāyānupassanāpaṭikūlamanasikārapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.4. Focusing on the Repulsive

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
reference: cck10.344, csp1ed7.234, csp2ed7.234, mc10.251, ms7D_959, msdiv377, pts-cs5, sc15, vri2.217

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ, hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ, antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ, pittaṁ semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṁ—sālīnaṁ vīhīnaṁ muggānaṁ māsānaṁ tilānaṁ taṇḍulānaṁ. Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso muñcitvā paccavekkheyya: ‘ime sālī, ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice. And someone with good eyesight were to open it and examine the contents: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’

root-pli-ms: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā …pe… muttan’ti.
Iti ajjhattaṁ vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Paṭikūlamanasikārapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
1.5. Kāyānupassanādhātumanasikārapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.5. Focusing on the Elements

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

root-pli-ms: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṁ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa;
translation-en-sujato: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into portions.

root-pli-ms: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Dhātumanasikārapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
1.6. Kāyānupassanānavasivathikapabba
translation-en-sujato: 1.6. The Charnel Ground Contemplations

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ ekāhamataṁ vā dvīhamataṁ vā tīhamataṁ vā uddhumātakaṁ vinīlakaṁ vipubbakajātaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
reference: bj8.450, cck10.346, csp1ed7.235, csp2ed7.235, ms7D_967, msdiv379, pts-cs7, sc21

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
translation-en-sujato: They’d compare it with their own body:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati. (1)
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ kākehi vā khajjamānaṁ kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṁ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṁ vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
reference: dr10.327, ms7D_968, pts-cs8, pts-vp-pli2.296, sc22, sya10.331, vri2.219
variant-pli-ms: kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṁ sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṁ → suvānehi vā khajjamānaṁ sigālehi vā khajjamānaṁ (si, sya-all, km), supāṇehi vā khajjamānaṁ sigālehi vā khajjamānaṁ (pts1ed)

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
translation-en-sujato: They’d compare it with their own body:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā …pe…
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally …

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati. (2)
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ samaṁsalohitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe… (3)
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ nimaṁsalohitamakkhitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe… (4)
translation-en-sujato: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṁ apagatamaṁsalohitaṁ nhārusambandhaṁ …pe… (5)
translation-en-sujato: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhāni disā vidisā vikkhittāni, aññena hatthaṭṭhikaṁ aññena pādaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gopphakaṭṭhikaṁ aññena jaṅghaṭṭhikaṁ aññena ūruṭṭhikaṁ aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṁ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṁ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena dantaṭṭhikaṁ aññena sīsakaṭāhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Bones without sinews, scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a rib-bone, here a back-bone, there an arm-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skull …
variant-pli-ms: aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṁ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṁ aññena hanukaṭṭhikaṁ → aññena kaṭaṭṭhikaṁ aññena piṭṭhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena kaṇḍakaṭṭhikaṁ aññena phāsukaṭṭhikaṁ aññena uraṭṭhikaṁ aññena aṁsaṭṭhikaṁ aññena bāhuṭṭhikaṁ (sya-all, km) | aññena kaṭiṭṭhikaṁ → aññena piṭṭhiṭṭhikaṁ aññena kaṭaṭṭhikaṁ aññena khandhaṭṭhikaṁ aññena gīvaṭṭhikaṁ (si)

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
Iti ajjhattaṁ vā …pe…
viharati. (6)
Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgāni …pe… (7)
translation-en-sujato: White bones, the color of shells …

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikāni puñjakitāni terovassikāni …pe… (8)
translation-en-sujato: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …

root-pli-ms: Aṭṭhikāni pūtīni cuṇṇakajātāni.
translation-en-sujato: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.

root-pli-ms: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
translation-en-sujato: They’d compare it with their own body:

root-pli-ms: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṁ viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the body as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi kāyo’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that the body exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati. (9)
translation-en-sujato: That too is how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body.

root-pli-ms: Navasivathikapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
Cuddasa kāyānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
2. Vedanānupassanā
translation-en-sujato: 2. Observing the Feelings

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of feelings?
reference: dr10.329, ms7D_977, msdiv380, pts-cs11, sc30, sya10.333

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (1)
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant who feels a pleasant feeling knows: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Dukkhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (2)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Adukkhamasukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (3)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Sāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (4)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a material pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material pleasant feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Nirāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (5)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a spiritual pleasant feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual pleasant feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Sāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (6)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a material painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material painful feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Nirāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (7)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a spiritual painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual painful feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Sāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (8)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a material neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material neutral feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Nirāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. (9)
translation-en-sujato: When they feel a spiritual neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a spiritual neutral feeling.’

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of feelings internally, externally, and both internally and externally.
reference: csp1ed7.237, csp2ed7.237, ms7D_986, ndp7.222, pts-vp-pli2.299, sc39, vri2.221

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing feelings as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi vedanā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that feelings exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings.

root-pli-ms: Vedanānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
3. Cittānupassanā
translation-en-sujato: 3. Observing the Mind

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of the mind?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (1) Vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (2) Sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (3) Vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (4) Samohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (5) Vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītamohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (6) Saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘saṅkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (7) Vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vikkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (8) Mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘mahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (9) Amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘amahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (10) Sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sauttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (11) Anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘anuttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (12) Samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (13) Asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘asamāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (14) Vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (15) Avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘avimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti. (16)
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant knows mind with greed as ‘mind with greed,’ and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed.’ They know mind with hate as ‘mind with hate,’ and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate.’ They know mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion,’ and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion.’ They know constricted mind as ‘constricted mind,’ and scattered mind as ‘scattered mind.’ They know expansive mind as ‘expansive mind,’ and unexpansive mind as ‘unexpansive mind.’ They know mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme,’ and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme.’ They know mind immersed in meditation as ‘mind immersed in meditation,’ and mind not immersed in meditation as ‘mind not immersed in meditation.’ They know freed mind as ‘freed mind,’ and unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind.’

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā citte cittānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā citte cittānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā cittasmiṁ viharati,
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the mind as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘atthi cittan’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that the mind exists, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu citte cittānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the mind.

root-pli-ms: Cittānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
4. Dhammānupassanā
translation-en-sujato: 4. Observing Principles

root-pli-ms: 4.1. Dhammānupassanānīvaraṇapabba
translation-en-sujato: 4.1. The Hindrances

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles?
reference: csp1ed7.238, csp2ed7.238, dr10.331, ms7D_1006, msdiv382, pts-cs13, sc57, vri2.222

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ kāmacchandaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ kāmacchandaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ kāmacchando’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa kāmacchandassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa kāmacchandassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa kāmacchandassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (1)
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant who has sensual desire in them understands: ‘I have sensual desire in me.’ When they don’t have sensual desire in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have sensual desire in me.’ They understand how sensual desire arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ byāpādaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ byāpādo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ byāpādaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ byāpādo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa byāpādassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa byāpādassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa byāpādassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (2)
translation-en-sujato: When they have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I have ill will in me.’ When they don’t have ill will in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have ill will in me.’ They understand how ill will arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ thinamiddhan’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa thinamiddhassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa thinamiddhassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa thinamiddhassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (3)
translation-en-sujato: When they have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ When they don’t have dullness and drowsiness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have dullness and drowsiness in me.’ They understand how dullness and drowsiness arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ uddhaccakukkuccan’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa uddhaccakukkuccassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (4)
