translation-en-sujato: When they have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I have restlessness and remorse in me.’ When they don’t have restlessness and remorse in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have restlessness and remorse in me.’ They understand how restlessness and remorse arise; how, when they’ve already arisen, they’re given up; and how, once they’re given up, they don’t arise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ vicikicchaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ vicikicchaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ vicikicchā’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannāya vicikicchāya uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannāya vicikicchāya pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnāya vicikicchāya āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (5)
translation-en-sujato: When they have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I have doubt in me.’ When they don’t have doubt in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have doubt in me.’ They understand how doubt arises; how, when it’s already arisen, it’s given up; and how, once it’s given up, it doesn’t arise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five hindrances.

root-pli-ms: Nīvaraṇapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
4.2. Dhammānupassanākhandhapabba
translation-en-sujato: 4.2. The Aggregates

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu:
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant contemplates:

root-pli-ms: ‘iti rūpaṁ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

root-pli-ms: iti vedanā, iti vedanāya samudayo, iti vedanāya atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.

root-pli-ms: iti saññā, iti saññāya samudayo, iti saññāya atthaṅgamo;
translation-en-sujato: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.

root-pli-ms: iti saṅkhārā, iti saṅkhārānaṁ samudayo, iti saṅkhārānaṁ atthaṅgamo,
translation-en-sujato: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.

root-pli-ms: iti viññāṇaṁ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti,
translation-en-sujato: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

root-pli-ms: iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the five grasping aggregates.

root-pli-ms: Khandhapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
4.3. Dhammānupassanāāyatanapabba
translation-en-sujato: 4.3. The Sense Fields

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields.
reference: csp1ed7.240, csp2ed7.240, mc10.258, ms7D_1016, msdiv384, pts-cs15, sc65, sya10.338

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six interior and exterior sense fields?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhuñca pajānāti, rūpe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (1)
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant understands the eye, sights, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.

root-pli-ms: Sotañca pajānāti, sadde ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (2)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the ear, sounds, and the fetter …

root-pli-ms: Ghānañca pajānāti, gandhe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (3)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the nose, smells, and the fetter …

root-pli-ms: Jivhañca pajānāti, rase ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (4)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the tongue, tastes, and the fetter …

root-pli-ms: Kāyañca pajānāti, phoṭṭhabbe ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (5)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the body, touches, and the fetter …

root-pli-ms: Manañca pajānāti, dhamme ca pajānāti, yañca tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saṁyojanaṁ tañca pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa saṁyojanassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa saṁyojanassa pahānaṁ hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca pahīnassa saṁyojanassa āyatiṁ anuppādo hoti tañca pajānāti. (6)
translation-en-sujato: They understand the mind, thoughts, and the fetter that arises dependent on both of these. They understand how the fetter that has not arisen comes to arise; how the arisen fetter comes to be abandoned; and how the abandoned fetter comes to not rise again in the future.
reference: cck10.355, csp1ed7.241, csp2ed7.241, ms7D_1022, pts-vp-pli2.303, sc71

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the six internal and external sense fields.

root-pli-ms: Āyatanapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
4.4. Dhammānupassanābojjhaṅgapabba
translation-en-sujato: 4.4. The Awakening Factors

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ satisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ satisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ satisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ satisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa satisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa satisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (1)
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant who has the awakening factor of mindfulness in them understands: ‘I have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of mindfulness in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of mindfulness that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (2)
translation-en-sujato: When they have the awakening factor of investigation of principles …

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ vīriyasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ vīriyasambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ vīriyasambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (3)
translation-en-sujato: energy …

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ pītisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ pītisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ pītisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ pītisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa pītisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa pītisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (4)
translation-en-sujato: rapture …

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ passaddhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ passaddhisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ passaddhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (5)
translation-en-sujato: tranquility …

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ samādhisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ samādhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ samādhisambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ samādhisambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa samādhisambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa samādhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (6)
translation-en-sujato: immersion …

root-pli-ms: Santaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṁ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, asantaṁ vā ajjhattaṁ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṁ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṁ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo’ti pajānāti, yathā ca anuppannassa upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa uppādo hoti tañca pajānāti, yathā ca uppannassa upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya pāripūrī hoti tañca pajānāti. (7)
translation-en-sujato: equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ When they don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in them, they understand: ‘I don’t have the awakening factor of equanimity in me.’ They understand how the awakening factor of equanimity that has not arisen comes to arise; and how the awakening factor of equanimity that has arisen becomes fulfilled by development.

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya, anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati sattasu bojjhaṅgesu.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the seven awakening factors.

root-pli-ms: Bojjhaṅgapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
4.5. Dhammānupassanāsaccapabba
translation-en-sujato: 4.5. The Truths

root-pli-ms: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu.
translation-en-sujato: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.

root-pli-ms: Kathañca pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu?
translation-en-sujato: And how does a mendicant meditate observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

root-pli-ms: Paṭhamabhāṇavāro niṭṭhito.
translation-en-sujato: The first recitation section is finished.

root-pli-ms: 4.5.1. Dukkhasaccaniddesa
translation-en-sujato: 4.5.1. The Truth of Suffering

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
reference: ms7D_1036, msdiv387, pts-cs18, pts-vp-pli2.305, sc82, sya10.341, vri2.228

root-pli-ms: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogopi dukkho, piyehi vippayogopi dukkho, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
translation-en-sujato: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
variant-pli-ms: dukkho → appiyehi …pe… vippayogo dukkhotipāṭho ceva taṁniddeso ca katthaci na dissati, aṭṭhakathāyampi taṁsaṁvaṇṇanā

root-pli-ms: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, jāti?
translation-en-sujato: And what is rebirth?

root-pli-ms: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānaṁ pātubhāvo āyatanānaṁ paṭilābho,
translation-en-sujato: The rebirth, inception, conception, reincarnation, manifestation of the sets of phenomena, and acquisition of the sense fields of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, jāti. (1)
translation-en-sujato: This is called rebirth.

root-pli-ms: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, jarā?
translation-en-sujato: And what is old age?

root-pli-ms: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṁ pāliccaṁ valittacatā āyuno saṁhāni indriyānaṁ paripāko,
translation-en-sujato: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, jarā. (2)
translation-en-sujato: This is called old age.

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, maraṇaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is death?

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṁ maccu maraṇaṁ kālakiriyā khandhānaṁ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo,
translation-en-sujato: The passing away, perishing, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, laying to rest of the corpse, and cutting off of the life faculty of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

root-pli-ms: idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, maraṇaṁ. (3)
translation-en-sujato: This is called death.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, soko?
translation-en-sujato: And what is sorrow?

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṁ antosoko antoparisoko,
translation-en-sujato: The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, soko. (4)
translation-en-sujato: This is called sorrow.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, paridevo?
translation-en-sujato: And what is lamentation?

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṁ paridevitattaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, paridevo. (5)
translation-en-sujato: This is called lamentation.

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is pain?

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ kāyikaṁ asātaṁ kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Physical pain, physical displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact.

root-pli-ms: idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ. (6)
translation-en-sujato: This is called pain.

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, domanassaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is sadness?

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mental contact.

root-pli-ms: idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, domanassaṁ. (7)
translation-en-sujato: This is called sadness.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, upāyāso?
translation-en-sujato: And what is distress?

root-pli-ms: Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṁ upāyāsitattaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering.

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, upāyāso. (8)
translation-en-sujato: This is called distress.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho?
translation-en-sujato: And what is meant by ‘association with the disliked is suffering’?

root-pli-ms: Idha yassa te honti aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā dhammā, ye vā panassa te honti anatthakāmā ahitakāmā aphāsukakāmā ayogakkhemakāmā, yā tehi saddhiṁ saṅgati samāgamo samodhānaṁ missībhāvo,
translation-en-sujato: There are sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts that are unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable. And there are those who want to harm, injure, disturb, and threaten you. The coming together with these, the joining, inclusion, mixing with them:

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho. (9)
translation-en-sujato: this is what is meant by ‘association with the disliked is suffering’.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho?
translation-en-sujato: And what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’?

root-pli-ms: Idha yassa te honti iṭṭhā kantā manāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā dhammā, ye vā panassa te honti atthakāmā hitakāmā phāsukakāmā yogakkhemakāmā mātā vā pitā vā bhātā vā bhaginī vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātisālohitā vā, yā tehi saddhiṁ asaṅgati asamāgamo asamodhānaṁ amissībhāvo,
translation-en-sujato: There are sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts that are likable, desirable, and agreeable. And there are those who want to benefit, help, comfort, and protect you. The division from these, the disconnection, segregation, and parting from them:

root-pli-ms: ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho. (10)
translation-en-sujato: this is what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’.

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’?

root-pli-ms: Jātidhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati:
translation-en-sujato: In sentient beings who are liable to be reborn, such a wish arises:

root-pli-ms: ‘aho vata mayaṁ na jātidhammā assāma, na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to be reborn! If only rebirth would not come to us!’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: But you can’t get that by wishing.

root-pli-ms: idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

root-pli-ms: Jarādhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati:
translation-en-sujato: In sentient beings who are liable to grow old …

root-pli-ms: ‘aho vata mayaṁ na jarādhammā assāma, na ca vata no jarā āgaccheyyā’ti.
Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.
Byādhidhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṁ na byādhidhammā assāma, na ca vata no byādhi āgaccheyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: fall ill …

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.
Maraṇadhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṁ na maraṇadhammā assāma, na ca vata no maraṇaṁ āgaccheyyā’ti.
translation-en-sujato: die …

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.

Sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṁ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma, na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsaā āgaccheyyun’ti.
translation-en-sujato: experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’

root-pli-ms: Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ,
translation-en-sujato: But you can’t get that by wishing.

root-pli-ms: idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. (11)
translation-en-sujato: This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’

root-pli-ms: Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā?
translation-en-sujato: And what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’?

root-pli-ms: Seyyathidaṁ—rūpupādānakkhandho, vedanupādānakkhandho, saññupādānakkhandho, saṅkhārupādānakkhandho, viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
translation-en-sujato: They are the grasping aggregates that consist of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

root-pli-ms: Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
translation-en-sujato: This is what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

root-pli-ms: 4.5.2. Samudayasaccaniddesa
translation-en-sujato: 4.5.2. The Origin of Suffering

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?
reference: cck10.360, ms7D_1049, msdiv400, pts-cs19, pts-vp-pli2.308, sc95

root-pli-ms: Yāyaṁ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms. That is,

root-pli-ms: kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhā.
translation-en-sujato: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.

root-pli-ms: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, taṇhā kattha uppajjamānā uppajjati, kattha nivisamānā nivisati?
translation-en-sujato: But where does that craving arise and where does it settle?

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
translation-en-sujato: Whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant, it is there that craving arises and settles.

root-pli-ms: 4.5.3. Nirodhasaccaniddesa
translation-en-sujato: 4.5.3. The Cessation of Suffering

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

root-pli-ms: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo.
translation-en-sujato: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.

root-pli-ms: Sā kho panesā, bhikkhave, taṇhā kattha pahīyamānā pahīyati, kattha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati?
Yaṁ loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
translation-en-sujato: Whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant, it is there that craving is given up and ceases.

root-pli-ms: Kiñca loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what in the world seems nice and pleasant?

translation-en-sujato: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving is given up and ceases. …

root-pli-ms: 4.5.4. Maggasaccaniddesa
translation-en-sujato: 4.5.4. The Path

root-pli-ms: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ?
translation-en-sujato: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

root-pli-ms: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo seyyathidaṁ—
translation-en-sujato: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

root-pli-ms: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

root-pli-ms: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right view?

root-pli-ms: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammādiṭṭhi. (1)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right view.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right thought?

root-pli-ms: Nekkhammasaṅkappo abyāpādasaṅkappo avihiṁsāsaṅkappo.
translation-en-sujato: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāsaṅkappo. (2)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right thought.

root-pli-ms: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammāvācā?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right speech?

root-pli-ms: Musāvādā veramaṇī pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī samphappalāpā veramaṇī.
translation-en-sujato: The refraining from lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and talking nonsense.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāvācā. (3)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right speech.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammākammanto?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right action?

root-pli-ms: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī adinnādānā veramaṇī kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī.
translation-en-sujato: Refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammākammanto. (4)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right action.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right livelihood?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvitaṁ kappeti.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a noble disciple gives up wrong livelihood and earns a living by right livelihood.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāājīvo. (5)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right livelihood.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāvāyāmo?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right effort?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

root-pli-ms: uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
translation-en-sujato: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

root-pli-ms: anuppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ uppādāya chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati;
translation-en-sujato: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

root-pli-ms: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati.
translation-en-sujato: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāvāyāmo. (6)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right effort.

root-pli-ms: Katamā ca, bhikkhave, sammāsati?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right mindfulness?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ;
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāsati. (7)
translation-en-sujato: This is called right mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, sammāsamādhi?
translation-en-sujato: And what is right immersion?

root-pli-ms: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

root-pli-ms: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

root-pli-ms: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
translation-en-sujato: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

root-pli-ms: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, sammāsamādhi.
translation-en-sujato: This is called right immersion.

root-pli-ms: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ. (8)
translation-en-sujato: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

root-pli-ms: Iti ajjhattaṁ vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, bahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, ajjhattabahiddhā vā dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati.
translation-en-sujato: And so they meditate observing an aspect of principles internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

root-pli-ms: Samudayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, vayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati, samudayavayadhammānupassī vā dhammesu viharati.
translation-en-sujato: They meditate observing the principles as liable to originate, as liable to vanish, and as liable to both originate and vanish.

root-pli-ms: ‘Atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati, na ca kiñci loke upādiyati.
translation-en-sujato: Or mindfulness is established that principles exist, to the extent necessary for knowledge and mindfulness. They meditate independent, not grasping at anything in the world.

root-pli-ms: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati catūsu ariyasaccesu.
translation-en-sujato: That’s how a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of principles with respect to the four noble truths.

root-pli-ms: Saccapabbaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ.
Dhammānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṁ bhāveyya sattavassāni, tassa dvinnaṁ phalānaṁ aññataraṁ phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ
translation-en-sujato: Anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven years can expect one of two results:
reference: bj8.498, ms7D_1084, msdiv404, ndp7.235, pts-cs22, sc129

root-pli-ms: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
translation-en-sujato: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

root-pli-ms: Tiṭṭhantu, bhikkhave, sattavassāni.
translation-en-sujato: Let alone seven years,

root-pli-ms: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṁ bhāveyya cha vassāni …pe…
translation-en-sujato: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for six years …

root-pli-ms: pañca vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: five years …

root-pli-ms: cattāri vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: four years …

root-pli-ms: tīṇi vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: three years …

root-pli-ms: dve vassāni …
translation-en-sujato: two years …

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ vassaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: one year …

root-pli-ms: tiṭṭhatu, bhikkhave, ekaṁ vassaṁ.
Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṁ bhāveyya sattamāsāni, tassa dvinnaṁ phalānaṁ aññataraṁ phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ
translation-en-sujato: seven months …

root-pli-ms: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
Tiṭṭhantu, bhikkhave, satta māsāni.
Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṁ bhāveyya cha māsāni …pe…
translation-en-sujato: six months …

root-pli-ms: pañca māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: five months …

root-pli-ms: cattāri māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: four months …

root-pli-ms: tīṇi māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: three months …

root-pli-ms: dve māsāni …
translation-en-sujato: two months …

root-pli-ms: ekaṁ māsaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: one month …

root-pli-ms: aḍḍhamāsaṁ …
translation-en-sujato: a fortnight …

root-pli-ms: tiṭṭhatu, bhikkhave, aḍḍhamāso.
translation-en-sujato: Let alone a fortnight,

root-pli-ms: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro satipaṭṭhāne evaṁ bhāveyya sattāhaṁ, tassa dvinnaṁ phalānaṁ aññataraṁ phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ
translation-en-sujato: anyone who develops these four kinds of mindfulness meditation in this way for seven days can expect one of two results:

root-pli-ms: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā; sati vā upādisese anāgāmitāti.
translation-en-sujato: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

root-pli-ms: Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti.
translation-en-sujato: ‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.’

root-pli-ms: Iti yaṁ taṁ vuttaṁ, idametaṁ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
translation-en-sujato: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

root-pli-ms: Idamavoca bhagavā.
translation-en-sujato: That is what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
translation-en-sujato: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

root-pli-ms: Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ navamaṁ.
